HEADLINE: Growth Plus Grace on the Audubon Site

 BODY:
The old movie house and ballroom in Washington Heights where Malcolm X was murdered 25 years ago is shabby and empty. Yet it still whispers of memories and grandeur.
To many New Yorkers, the Audubon Theater and Ballroom is of great historic and emotional significance. To many preservationists, it is of great architectural significance. To Columbia University and to New York City and State, it is of great economic significance. Not surprisingly, those three perspectives have sparked a controversy. 
Columbia and public agencies have been working for years on a $25 million plan to lease the city-owned site and build a big biomedical facility, the first phase of a four-block research park. Now, with deadlines for city approval approaching, opposition threatens the project. Its loss would cost the neighborhood and city a much-needed economic boost. But losing the 78-year-old building would hurt, too. Fortunately, the Dinkins administration has come up with a compromise. It calls for saving part of the old building and turning it into a museum dedicated to Malcolm X. Columbia would then proceed with its proposal, which includes a $500,000 scholarship for black medical students, a job training program for lab technicians and land for a community center. The university had also planned to affix some of the Audubon's terra cotta facade to the new building and provide space for a memorial to Malcolm X. Columbia says conscientiously that it is willing to work with the city but rightly resists paying for a public museum. That's the city's responsibility. So far the city has not determined costs or who should pay them. Those are such big gaps that it's hard to know whether the proposal will work. But a just compromise is surely worth pursuing. It would insure this vital boost to the city's economy and development while recognizing a distinctive building and an important figure.

HEADLINE: Only Washington Can Break Mideast Stalemate

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As long as the Middle East diplomatic stalemate continues, it is child's play to generate new cycles of violence - whether the provocation is murder by a deranged Israeli or landings on Israel's beaches by a deviant Palestine Liberation Organization group (front page, May 31).
What is the United States waiting for? It is not likely that Yasir Arafat's relatively moderate posture at the head of the P.L.O. can survive another year with nothing to show for willingness to renounce terrorism and recognize Israel's right to exist. Nor can President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt continue to play the moderate Arab broker in the face of the Iraqi challenge. And if projected migration figures for Soviet Jews materialize, the specter of a solution that forces West Bank Palestinians into Jordan or the Sinai no longer sounds far-fetched. 
The United States should take some of the pressure off by reclassifying migrating Soviet Jews as political refugees. Then, we should make it clear that, while we do not intend to impose any particular solution on the Mideast conflict, we insist that the parties talk, that Israel implement its own peace plan. Without that, we should state that we feel no obligation to support an illusory peace process with our increasingly scarce aid dollars and diplomatic attention.
Nothing will happen unless we act. What presumably keeps us from doing so is some perceived lack of Congressional support and Main Street support, plus the notion that overt pressure would be counterproductive. I suggest the facts are otherwise.
Rank-and-file support for Israel's policies - on Capitol Hill and in the American Jewish community - has been waning rapidly. The Likud Government would balk at overt pressure, but a truly independent foreign policy for Israel is unrealistic. We could expect considerable short-term discomfort, but a genuine concern for Israel's future does not translate into continuing unconditional support for deeply flawed and self-destructive policies.
 
GUSTAV RANIS
New Haven, May 31, 1990
 The writer is Frank Altschul Professor of International Economics at Yale University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Why the Flag-Waving?

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Do you wonder why the ordinarily reasonable George Bush is wrapping himself in a ''flag amendment'' to lead an assault on the Bill of Rights?
Are you puzzled by the President's arts flip-flop, as he now backs away from the public funding of obscene or sacrilegious art?
These questions have a common answer: The 1990 midterm election campaign is under way.
The Republican goal is to make inroads into the moderate middle with centrist domestic policies and nice-guy treatment of collapsing Communists, while holding the growling right by punching its supposed hot buttons of superpatriotism and antipornism. 
The Democratic goal is simply to re-elect incumbents to Congress. To this uninspiring end, the party will raid the Treasury to fund mass franked mailings to constituents; its philosophy is to summitize on the budget deficit until after the election and hope for the invigorating boost of a major recession.
These are unworthy goals and demeaning strategies. Should we throw up our hands and say ''I never vote, it only encourages them''?
No; now is the time for Democrats to get mad at their leaders for hiding in the Hill bunker (doesn't anybody here want to start to run for President?) and for G.O.P. voters to refuse to be manipulated by the White House politics of cultural resentment.
I'll do my bit from the right, beginning with a brief diatribe against the abandonment of conservative principle in the unprecedented, unconscionable and wholly unnecessary attack on the Bill of Rights.
The central tenet of conservatism is that ''unless it is necessary to change, it is necessary not to change.'' The country is not under intolerable siege or danger of overthrow; absolutely no need exists to amend our First Amendment guaranteeing freedom of speech, assembly and religion.
Flag-burners, by infuriating most of us, seek repression; but by fooling with the Bill of Rights, we would play into their hands. The way to frustrate those who test the strength of our Constitution is to ignore them, to tune them out, not to make prime-time political martyrs out of them.
Equally important, conservatives aware of the Founders' prohibition of the establishment of an official religion reject the application of the word ''desecration'' to our nation's symbol.
Although we may express religious belief in political settings - from an opening prayer in Congress to ''In God We Trust'' on our coins - in this democracy, nothing political can be consecrated, ''made sacred.''
Should we respect the flag? Always. Should we worship the flag? Never. We salute the flag but we reserve worship for God.
Any attempt to make the nation's flag sacred - to endow this secular symbol with the holiness required for ''desecration'' - not only undermines our political freedom but belittles our worship of the Creator.
If Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois thinks a flag issue will help her unseat Senator Paul Simon, she may discover many principled conservatives turning to the Democrat for his support of the Bill of Rights.
The campaign-year inclination to treat the American eagle as the Golden Calf is closely related to the controversy over the use of public money to support sacrilegious or borderline-obscene works of art.
At first, the President reacted to the outrage of conservatives at the taxpayer support of the Mapplethorpe and Serrano works by disapproving ''censorship.'' That allied Mr. Bush with the cultural-political left.
Censorship is not the issue; funding is. Artists are free to express themselves in outrageous ways, but the Government is not obligated to buy their works. Freedom of expression is a right, but payment for it is not an entitlement.
Mr. Bush's political advisers warned him this was a cultural resentment button on a par with flagburning. With an eye to the 1990 campaigns, the President swung around; we'll see new accountability in the way taxpayer money goes to the arts.
I happen to believe the arts and the Feds should never be bedfellows, but that's my libertarian self-indulgence. Today's focus is on why Mr. Bush veered from his middle-road instincts: in this case, he is moving only to palliate the antipornists.
He should cut out all this flag-waving, antiporn posturing; that's not why most righties vote Republican. And his macho-bluenose pose will never fool the hard right; they know he's no first-term Reagan.
O.K., now what about you Democrats? As the 1990 campaign begins, are you satisfied with the abuse of franking and the absence of frankness on the left?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: AIDS Travels New York-Puerto Rico 'Air Bridge'

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
For half a century, millions of Puerto Ricans have crossed back and forth over the ''air bridge'' linking New York and San Juan. These days, the air bridge also joins New York and its southernmost ''suburb'' in the devastating epidemic of AIDS.
AIDS is inflicting a heavy toll throughout America, but nowhere is it heavier than among Puerto Ricans. It continues to grow fastest among intravenous drug users; it is these addicts, their sex partners and their children who make up the vast majority of Puerto Ricans with AIDS.
Today, the island has the nation's highest per capita rate of new cases, more than three times the national average. On the mainland, research shows that AIDS is striking Puerto Ricans harder than other Hispanic people, blacks or non-Hispanic whites. 
 
Tracing the Epidemic
''We need help,'' said Fernando R., one of five members of a Puerto Rican family infected with the disease. ''AIDS is killing a lot of people.''
Some Puerto Ricans believe AIDS was imported by those returning from the mainland - those they call ''New Yoricans,'' and gay tourists. Epidemiologists say it is impossible to trace. But whatever its origin, the Puerto Rican AIDS epidemic is overwhelmingly caused by intravenous drug use and is now being exchanged back and forth across the air bridge in a growing cycle of disease.
Air travel ''made it one epidemic,'' said Dr. Nicholas A. Rango, director of the New York State Health Department's AIDS Institute.
Today, the air bridge carries the medical and societal casualties of AIDS. Patients come to the states desperate for medical treatment they cannot get on the island. Those in terminal stages return home to die. Grieving relatives arrive for funerals. Orphaned children are dispatched to grandmothers across the water.
''That's the pattern. They get infected in New York and come back home to die with their families, or they get infected here and go there for treatment,'' said Dr. Gaspar Encarnacion, a doctor in San Juan who saw his first AIDS case in 1981 and now sees an average of 35 patients a day. There are deathbed reunions. ''The mothers always come,'' said Dr. Gerald H. Friedland of the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. One woman flew in to comfort her son at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center. Two days later, he slipped into a coma, and she maintained a bedside vigil for months.
This movement is rooted in Puerto Rico's poverty and in its curious status as a stepchild of the United States - a status that has hindered the development of AIDS services in Puerto Rico but allows the island's residents to travel to New York for what they cannot get back home.
AIDS services are not ideal on the mainland, but health experts say conditions on the island are worse. Many obstacles - political, cultural, economic and religious - have thwarted efforts to improve AIDS treatment in Puerto Rico, the experts say.
Most Puerto Ricans with AIDS are poor and must rely on limited public health care. But Medicaid, the Federal insurance program for the indigent, is virtually unavailable unless one leaves the island; while the Federal Government reimburses half of Medicaid bills in the states, it allocates $79 million for all health care in Puerto Rico.
Some Puerto Ricans move to the mainland; others claim residency while visiting friends or relatives.
 
'Not Entitled to Medicaid'
''As a Puerto Rican you're an American citizen, but you're not entitled to Medicaid here,'' said Dr. Jaime Rivera Dueno, director of the AIDS Institute in San Juan. ''But you can get on a plane to the states and qualify there.''
Advocates for AIDS patients in Puerto Rico say that sometimes there is not even any aspirin in hospital pharmacies or clean sheets for beds. Many patients languish for days, even weeks, in emergency rooms, if they get that far. Some die in the streets.
The most disturbing gap, the experts say, is that potentially life-prolonging drugs like AZT and pentamidine, though widely used on the mainland, remain largely unavailable in Puerto Rico. They are simply far too expensive; local officials estimate AZT alone would cost $60 million of the $79 million in Federal aid for health care.
''Most of our clients aren't informed, so they don't ask about AZT,'' said Jose Toro Alfonso, director of the AIDS Foundation, a nonprofit agency in San Juan. ''And we don't tell them, since we cannot get it for them,''
 
A Scourge
Five Siblings Ravaged by Disease
One who has traveled the air bridge is 32-year-old Fernando R., who belongs to one of the most AIDS-ravaged families in America.
Fernando R., soft spoken and a neat dresser, works in a restaurant in a quiet valley town nestled below Puerto Rico's dark mountain rain forests. He recently returned there after 14 years in New York City and agreed to be interviewed on the condition that his last name be withheld, to protect his job and relatives.
Fernando R. is one of seven children. Their father was a police officer, their mother a school worker. They were born on the island, but he and several others moved to the mainland, and the family exchanged visits. #2 Die, 3 Suffer All grew up to use illegal drugs. The two eldest brothers were killed in drug-related violence a few years ago. The remaining five children, because they sometimes shared needles among one another, became trapped in the AIDS epidemic. Two brothers died of AIDS last year. Another brother now lies in an AIDS hospice no longer able to speak.
And the survivors, Fernando R. and a sister, are both infected.
As a reformed addict, Fernando R. testified at a hearing in the Bronx last December on a Federal bill for AIDS disaster relief. Now that bill is making headway in Congress, and could bring $24 million to Puerto Rico. But Fernando R. has an immediate personal need. The supply of AZT he obtained in the Bronx is running out in Puerto Rico. Despite monthly visits to the island's leading AIDS clinic, he has been unable to get the prescription refilled.
''My mother and father are always going to the hospital'' to visit their sick children, Fernando R. said. He does not want to be next.
 
The Crossing
From Mainland To Island and Back
At a San Juan methadone clinic, a questionnaire for infected addicts has a line for ''country last visited.'' The most popular destination listed: the Bronx.
As American citizens, Puerto Ricans travel to the mainland free of immigration barriers. Flights take about three hours, at off-season fares as low as $100. Almost as many Puerto Ricans live in the states, about 2.5 million, as on the island, whose population is 3.5 million. Those on the mainland are concentrated in the Northeast, with 1.5 million in the New York region. About 30 percent on each side visit the other at least once a year, studies indicate.
Several blocks from the centuries-old Spanish fortifications and pricey tourist boutiques of Old San Juan sits an abandoned building of scaling concrete. A pet horse is tethered outside. Inside, addicts inject speedballs, a heroin-cocaine mixture. Scrawled on the wall is notice of the $1 entry fee for ''chutin'' - phonetic Spanish for the New York street slang of ''shooting'' drugs. The entire scene, says Hector Colon, an addiction researcher in San Juan, ''seems intimately related to the migration experience.''
''The Bronx and Puerto Rico are really extensions of each other,'' said Dr. Friedland of Montefiore. ''It's a state of mind.''
On the island, the AIDS epidemic continues to grow, just as it does among Puerto Ricans in New York. So far, health officials in Puerto Rico have recorded 4,200 full-fledged cases. Some AIDS experts estimate the true number is as much as double that, since doctors sometimes decline to report cases because of the stigma, and still others are never diagnosed at all.
The island's official numbers are bad enough. With 2,603 known AIDS deaths, the disease has become one of the leading causes of death among those aged 20 to 45. In New York City, AIDS is the No. 1 killer of Hispanic people aged 1 to 4 and 25 to 44.
For the year ending March 31, Puerto Rico had 47 new cases per 100,000 population. According to Federal records, the next highest was New York State at 39. The national average was 15. Among metropolitan regions, San Juan's rate of 87 was second only to San Francisco's 115; New York City was third, at 69.
 
A Singular Problem
New research shows that the umbrella Hispanic label has camouflaged stark contrasts between Puerto Ricans and other Hispanic people.
In New York City, Puerto Ricans are the most severely affected racial or ethnic group, Dr. Barbara S. Menendez of Lehman College reports in this month's Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. She found male AIDS mortality highest among Puerto Rican migrants, at 362 per 100,000 population, compared to 217 for other Hispanics, 267 for blacks and 182 for non-Hispanic whites. Her study covered men only.
A study last year by Dr. Richard M. Selik and Dr. Kenneth G. Castro found that native Mexican in the United States had an AIDS rate identical to Whites. But the AIDS of native Puerto Ricans on the mainland was seven times higher.
Also dramatically different were the causes of AIDS. Among other Hispanic people, homosexuals were the leading group. But for Puerto Ricans, it was drug abusers. On the island, three of four AIDS cases originate with drug abuse. Puerto Ricans inject more often than than other drug abusers, research shows, and are more likely to use ''shooting galleries,'' where needles are often rented or shared. Adding to the risk, studies indicate few Puerto Ricans use condoms, and a significant number engage in heterosexual anal intercourse, which spreads the virus.
More ominous than the numbers to date are the estimates of how many more are infected. Puerto Rico's official AIDS commission says upwards of 40,000 people carry the virus. Some health experts estimate several times that. Preliminary samples of pregnant poor women in San Juan show 1 in 10 infected - identical to the rate at a South Bronx hospital.
 
The Barriers
Homosexuality And Other Taboos
Frank Chaulon is one of Puerto Rico's most vocal advocates for people with AIDS.
''People are dying without asking for help,'' said Mr. Chaulon, who ran a San Juan program that taught addicts to clean their needles. ''In our culture if you speak out, you're impolite. Our national emblem should be a lamb. Gays are a big minority here, some of the most talented people, but they're are dying in silence. The drug users -sometimes I have have 17 dying in one weekend. The general population is saying, 'Oh, they are dying, oh, good.' ''
While a majority of AIDS victims are drug users or their sex partners, many are gay people. Homosexuality is repressed as a taboo, and gay or not, having AIDS carries with it an unmistakeable stigma and frequent discrimination. Physicians in New York tell of Puerto Rican patients driven to the mainland by their families' rejection. Some homosexuals with AIDS even falsely admit to drug abuse.
''There are no homosexuals in Puerto Rico - we're all macho males,'' laughed Toro Alfonso of the AIDS Foundation. Donald E. Babb, the foundation's chairman and an editor at The San Juan Star, said: ''In places like New York, you already had a gay movement. In Puerto Rico, you never had that.''
 
Political Infighting
The Roman Catholic Church has been at the forefront in providing care, but its opposition to condoms has hampered prevention. One prelate proclaimed it better to die of AIDS than to use condoms, and the island's health minister opposed advertising them ''as a medical man and as a Christian.''
At the same time, the fight against AIDS has been fragmented by infighting among Puerto Rico's political parties and feuding between health officials from San Juan and the commonwealth government.
''AIDS appears to have been co-opted by the party politicans, and its controversies turned into themes which can be bickered about,'' Dr. Ineke Cunningham, a University of Puerto Rico sociologist, wrote in a British journal.
Tourism is Puerto Rico's prime industry, and some have worried about AIDS blighting the image of an idyllic paradise. The official response to one television report on AIDS came not from health experts but the tourism agency.
''The biggest problem is denial that the problem exists,'' said Mr. Babb of the AIDS Foundation.
Increasingly, however, AIDS is impossible to ignore.
'As we enter the 1990's,'' said Mr. Babb, a native Puerto Rican whose brother died of AIDS in the States, ''AIDS is winning the battle for people's lives in Puerto Rico.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Producer prices rose by 0.3 percent in May as a sharp upturn in the cost of food was largely offset by another hefty decline in the cost of energy, the Government reported. [Page D1.] Business inventories inched upward by 0.1 percent in April, while sales fell 1.1 percent, the Commerce Department said. [D5.] 
 
In a sign that the savings bailout is becoming a partisan issue, House Democrats disputed the Administration's contention that the slumping real estate market was responsible for the escalating costs of the rescue. [D1.] Felix Rohatyn proposed a 5 percent income tax surcharge to pay for the bailout. [D17.]
 
A study of the cable television industry showed that rates for the lowest-priced basic cable service last year rose more than twice as fast as the Consumer Price Index. [D15.]
 
A prosecutor tried to discredit John Mulheren by implying that he had misled the jury about his ties to Ivan Boesky. [D5.]
 
For all the talk of rising American protectionism, the caseload of the International Trade Commission seems to show that the storm surge has passed. [A14.]
 
COMPANIES
 
ABC said it would use NBC's plan to verify its audience size to advertisers. ABC had proposed its own viewer measurement system. CBS did not commit itself. [D1.]
 
In the talks between Donald Trump and his bankers, the roles of two New Jersey banks have become pivotal as uncertainty grew that a deal would be reached, bankers said. [D1.]
 
S.&P. downgraded its credit ranking for Ford and Chrysler, signaling sagging faith in the auto industry's finances. Moody's said it would decide soon whether it would change Chrysler's rating. [D1.]
 
The Supreme Court ruled that Texaco violated Federal antitrust law during the 1970's in its gasoline sales. [D4.] The Court also ruled that hospitals and nursing homes can sue states for higher Medicaid rates. [A1.]
 
Reebok International said its largest stockholder, Pentland Group, would sell its 31.5 percent holding. [D4.]
 
Southland sweetened a deal to pay off its bondholders. The proposal slashes the control the founding family will have. [D4.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Ratification of a U.S.-Mexico free-trade agreement could be held up by concerns in Congress that the wages of American workers might suffer, lawmakers warned the Administration. [D2.]
 
Four former executives of a Japanese company were arrested on charges of insider trading. [D2.]
 
MARKETS
 
John Phelan officially disclosed a five-phase plan to create a 24-hour trading market on the Big Board by 2000. [D7.]
 
Stock prices edged down in light volume as investors turned cautious. The Dow fell 1.48, to 2,928.22. [D6.]
 
Bond prices rose in active, volatile trading, as market participants shifted out of short-term securities and into bonds. [D13.]
 
Precious metals prices continued to plunge, with gold prices dropping to four-year lows. [D14.] The dollar finished mostly higher in domestic trading. [D14.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
Gorbachev continues to struggle on the economic front with the democratic forces his political reforms have unleashed. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
In the big-money game being played by RJR Nabisco and its bondholders, Henry Kravis put an important card on the table by raising $1.7 billion from his partners. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Growth in ad spending in the U.S. will continue at a sluggish pace through 1990, a leading industry forecaster said. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up 0.3% in May

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in May as a sharp upturn in the cost of food was largely offset by another hefty decline in the cost of energy, the Government reported today.
Although the increase followed three straight declines in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, analysts said they were generally encouraged about the May result. They said it confirmed the view that the inflation rate had stabilized at a moderate level after a large early-winter burst.
Excluding the erratic food and energy components, the finished-goods index edged up a modest two-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month. 
 
Drop for Companion Indexes
Inflation at the both the intermediate and crude stages of production, as measured by companion indexes, eased slightly, the first time they both declined in the same month since August.
''These latest figures are positive,'' said Ron Schreibman, a vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group whose members pay the prices compiled by the three indexes. ''They point toward a continuing reversal of the inflationary trend we experienced last fall and into the winter.''
Gordon Richards, an economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, concurred. He found in today's data a return by the producer price index to its ''underlying rate, now that food and energy prices no longer are creating a somewhat artificial decline.'' #1 Percent Energy Decline Energy fell 1 percent last month, a substantial decline although considerably smaller than the 3 percent average drop for February through April. World oil prices have been soft in recent months.
The stock market shrugged off the report as in line with expectations. Bond prices rose in active trading as credit market participants shifted out of short-term securities and into bonds. [Pages D6 and D13.] In a rare back-to-back sequence, today's report on inflation at the producer level will be followed Friday by publication of the Consumer Price Index, which, unlike the index for producer prices, includes services and imported goods.
If that report is similarly reassuring, many analysts expect the Federal Reserve to move closer to a decision to ease monetary policy, probably sometime this summer. The economy, as reflected in such indicators as employment, housing and retail sales, is thought to be growing at a very slow pace and may need the stimulus of easier credit in the near future.
Over the last year, according to today's report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the producer price index has risen 3.1 percent - exactly half the 12-month advance up to May 1989 - and various analysts believe it could continue to decelerate.
One of them is Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist for ASB Capital Management, a Washington money manager. He predicted the index would rise at a rate of 2 1/2 to 3 percent for the second half of this year and would move still lower in 1991. The Federal Reserve's policy of keeping short-term interest rates relatively high, Mr. Carpenter contended, has been forcing American manufacturers to cut their cost structures and this pressure is now spreading to other parts of the economy.
Consumer foods climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in May, today's report showed, reversing a decline of that amount in April. Price increases accelerated for fish, dairy products, pasta and processed turkeys, and turned up after a decline the preceding month for shortening, cooking oils and processed chicken.
 
Pork Rises, Eggs Decline
Pork prices rose by 5 percent for the second straight month, but egg prices plunged 22 percent and fresh fruits fell 8 percent.
Heating oil, meanwhile, fell 6 percent and gasoline by 2 percent.
Consumer goods other than food and energy, however, rose five-tenths of 1 percent, more than in April or March, as prices accelerated for tobacco products, newspapers, furniture, footwear and household glassware. Capital equipment was unchanged in price last month after edging up two-tenths of 1 percent in April.
Among goods at the intermediate stage of production, such as a bag of flour or bolt of cloth, the overall decline in prices was one-tenth of 1 percent, with energy causing much of the decline. The increases were paced by foods and an upturn in materials for nondurable manufacturing.
Prices for crude goods, such as wheat or raw cotton, also edged down one-tenth of 1 percent, but in this stage energy materials turned up in price while foodstuffs dropped more than in April.
Yet another index, one for the net output of total manufacturing industries, climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in May, the same amount as in April. Unlike the other data, this index is not adjusted to compensate for seasonal fluctuations.

HEADLINE: Savings Debate Gets Partisan Tone

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
In a new sign that the 10-month-old savings and loan bailout could finally be turning into a partisan issue, House Democrats today disputed the Bush Administration's contention that the slumping real estate market was responsible for the escalating costs of the rescue effort and charged that mismanagement by the Administration was at the root instead.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the House Banking Committee today that his latest estimates of the cost of the bailout - as high as $130 billion - could go even higher if the slumping real estate market did not turn around.
The $130 billion estimate does not include interest payments on the money borrowed to finance the program. With those costs included, the General Accounting Office has said the total could be $325 billion to $500 billion. 
''If the real estate market continues to go down, then I'll be here six months from now telling you that the cost will go up,'' Mr. Brady said.
 
Aggravating the Crisis
Administration officials have said that the real estate slump aggravates the savings crisis in two ways. It hurts the savings industry, threatening to bring down more institutions that have large numbers of real estate loans, and it makes it harder for the Government to sell its growing stockpile of property from seized institutions.
Mr. Brady said the Administration was in the midst of calculating how much money the Resolution Trust Corporation would need. The agency supervising the bailout will probably run out of money by the end of the year or early next year, he said, adding that most of the additional money would have to come from the Treasury and not through additional borrowing by the Resolution Funding Corporation, which is the financing arm of Resolution Trust.
''We are dealing with a moving target, made greatly more expensive by a weakening real estate market and constantly changing economic conditions,'' Mr. Brady said. ''It is not susceptible to easy answers or simple solutions.''
Mr. Brady's explanation of the rising costs did little to satisfy the Democrats, who said the expenses were rising because Resolution Trust had been slow in selling its huge portfolio of properties taken from seized savings and loan associations.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, called the bailout effort the second savings and loan crisis, saying there had been delay and confusion since the President signed the law last year establishing the rescue program.
''The minute the bill was signed, there was an abdication of responsibility,'' Mr. Schumer said. ''Unlike the first crisis, in this one there is not plenty of blame to go around. It has not been given the attention, the magnitude, the force.''
Representative Bruce F. Vento, Democrat of Minnesota, who is chairman of a study group on the bailout, told Mr. Brady: ''There is an appearance to many of us that the R.T.C. is floundering and the oversight board isn't doing what it can. It's simply not moving the assets.''
 
More Prosecutions Urged
The Democrats repeatedly asked why the Justice Department had prosecuted only a small fraction of the 17,000 or so referrals from bank regulators of possible crimes committed by industry executives.
Mr. Brady said the Administration was committed to prosecuting the cases, but their complex nature made quick resolution difficult. ''A white-collar crime is a lot harder to prosecute than someone who walks into a bank and has his picture taken by six cameras,'' he said.
Democratic leaders have been reluctant to make an issue of the savings and loan crisis, largely because the reputations of a number of prominent Democrats have been clouded by accusations of influence-peddling and misconduct.
Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the former Speaker of the House, and Representative Tony Coelho of California, a leader of House Democrats, were forced from office last year in part because of questions about their dealings with savings and loan officials. Fernand J. St Germain, the Rhode Island Democrat who had been chairman of the House Banking Committee, was defeated in the 1988 elections, largely because of questions about gifts from savings industry lobbyists.
In addition, there are four Democrats in the ''Keating Five,'' the Senators who are being investigated by an ethics panel over accusations that they put pressure on bank regulators who were examining a campaign contributor's failing savings and loan.
The hearing was the first opportunity that House Democrats have had to confront Mr. Brady since he substantially raised estimates of the bailout's cost.
Several members of the committee said that the latest estimates of the number of collapsing savings institutions suggested that the industry should be consolidated with commercial banks.
Earlier this week, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that as many as 1,700 of the nation's 2,500 savings institutions might ultimately collapse. The Treasury Department had earlier estimated that 1,000 insitutions might need to be bailed out.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, right, told the House Banking Committee yesterday that the cost of bailing out the savings and loan industry could increase. Before testifying, Secretary Brady was joined at the witness table by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. (Jose Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Congress Voices Concern Over Trade Pact With Mexico

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Members of Congress today warned the Bush Administration that ratification of a free trade agreement between the United States and Mexico could be held up by concerns that the wages of American workers might suffer. Lawmakers also said that curbing the flow of illegal drugs should be part of the negotiations.
The Congressional reaction came in response to the plan announced on Monday for the two nations to move toward a free trade pact.
During hearings of the House Ways and Means Committee's trade subcommittee, most members spoke in favorable terms about the concept of freer trade with Mexico, but their questions and comments quickly showed how specific constituent interests would bear on eventual votes. 
Representative Donald J. Pease, an Ohio Democrat, expressed concern that blue-collar workers in Mansfield, Ashland, Lorain and other industrial towns he represents could see their wages fall.
 
Wages Under $1 an Hour
''It seems to me inevitable that wages in Mexico will level up and wages in the U.S. will level down and that the relatively well-paid industrial worker in my district is bound to suffer,'' the Ohio lawmaker complained.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said in a recent policy statement that 400,000 Mexican workers are now employed at wages under $1 an hour, producing goods entirely for the American market.
Overall manufacturing wages in Mexico average $1.90 an hour compared with $14.50 an hour in the United States, according to figures from both governments.
Representative Frank J. Guarini, a New Jersey Democrat, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Democrat from New York City, insisted that any trade agreement take up drug issues as well.
Mr. Rangel said that 50 percent of the cocaine that enters the United States comes from Mexico. He reported that shipments have more than doubled from 15 metric tons to more than 38 tons since 1988.
The United States Trade Representative, Carla A. Hills, told the panel that while the Bush Administration does not yet have a position on the inclusion of drugs as one of the negotiating issues, ''we'll consider that.''
Still she emphasized that the economic gains of freer trade should help ease the drug problem.
''I think that two areas where we will benefit from the free trade agreement in the drugs area are the creation of jobs and opportunities,'' she said.
Should drugs become part of the negotiations, Mexico is likely to insist that labor mobility be discussed as well.
 
An Engine for Growth
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico has said that his country wants the free trade agreement as an engine for growth so that the economy can export goods not jobs.
He told an American business group in Washington on Monday that the agreement should produce ''a lesser and more orderly flow of workers'' to the United States.
On the question of the wage differences between the two countries, the President's trade chief said ''it was not necessarily the fact'' that lower Mexican wages would depress American wages.
Later, before the same panel, Rudiger Dornbusch, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, commented on the likely impact. He said that ''drawing low-wage Mexican labor into our operations helps reduce costs and creates room to pay high U.S. wages for the remaining tasks.''
Mrs. Hills said she intended to consult closely with Congress, labor, business and other interest groups before giving the final green light to a process that could eventually create a North American free trade zone embracing 350 million people. Formal negotiations between the two governments could start around the middle of next year. Both governments hope to conclude the pact within two years.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Is Kravis Playing A Waiting Game?

BYLINE: By Anise C. Wallace

 BODY:
IN the big-money game being played by RJR Nabisco Inc. and its bondholders, Henry Kravis put an important card on the table this week when it was learned that he had raised $1.7 billion from his partners to invest in RJR Nabisco.
Mr. Kravis, whose buyout firm, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, took RJR private in 1989 for $25 billion, the largest leveraged buyout in history, had told his partners that they could earn 25 to 30 percent by restructuring the debt of the company.
Now, holders of the company's ''junk bonds'' are speculating that he will spend some or all of that money with them. As a result, some RJR bonds surged more than $70 for every $1,000 in face value Wednesday, and trading was brisk again yesterday, although prices closed mostly unchanged from the day before. 
But a handful of market participants say Mr. Kravis may not invest the $1.7 billion at all and instead sit back and hope that speculators, cheered by reports of the cash at hand, drive the prices of the company's bonds higher.
''You can't come out and say they're manipulating the market, but if they balance it right, they'll have to do nothing,'' said Dirk Van Doren, a junk bond analyst who follows RJR Nabisco for McCarthy Crisanti Maffei in Montpelier, Vt. ''They have shown their hand to say this is what we can do.''
Some other investors agree, pointing out that as long as the bond prices rise, Mr. Kravis has no need to buy back the debt or propose an exchange offer. ''Why fuel the fire when the fire is burning brightly,'' said Barbara L. Kenworthy, a mutual fund manager at the Dreyfus Corporation in New York.
But sooner or later, under the rules of the financing of the RJR deal, Mr. Kravis must play a card. In April 1991, the interest rate on $6 billion in junk bonds that were issued in the buyout must be reset so that, in the opinion of the company's two investment bankers, they will trade at their par value, that is, at 100 cents to the dollar, excluding the interest that has accrued. (These bonds pay interest not in cash but in more securities.) Since the RJR bonds have been trading at less than their face value in the distressed market for junk bonds, this is likely to mean that the interest rate will have to be set higher, something that would cost Mr. Kravis and his investors more money.
One issue, for instance, the senior converting debentures due in 2009, was quoted at $90.75 for every $100 of face value yesterday. With accrued interest, their value is $120.50. If their interest rate were to be reset to yield a price of $100 plus accrued interest, they would trade at about $135.50, said Derek A. Jones, a vice president at J.P. Morgan Securities Inc. ''They've got a way to go,'' he said.
Many investors are now speculating that Mr. Kravis will take some steps to shore up the prices of the bonds in the meantime. Among his options are to buy back the bonds directly in the open market, to make an exchange offer to the holders for new securities or equity in the company, to inject more equity into RJR, or to do a combination of things.
Without taking some action on the reset problem, say analysts, RJR will be unable to borrow more cash either in the junk bond market or from commercial banks, which already hold more than $6 billion in RJR debt used for the buyout. Neither group now is likely to refinance a $1.2 billion bank loan that comes due next February, Mr. Jones said. ''They can't do that as long as the reset is hanging over them,'' he said. ''The banks really control this.''
Because Mr. Kravis and his companies may have to use junk bonds for cash in the future, some fund managers in the junk bond market hope that he is willing to help the bondholders. ''He likes this well,'' said Rebecca H. Garner, vice president of Associated Capital Investors in Little Rock, Ark.
Earlier this year, at a conference in Arizona, Mr. Kravis angered many junk bond investors when he suggested that they were selling RJR bonds in panic. Solving the reset problem, Ms. Garner said, could buy Mr. Kravis some ''cheap good will.''

HEADLINE: No Sanctions On India Trade

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today, as expected, that it would not impose economic sanctions on India for trade barriers the United States deems offensive.
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, termed India's barriers to investment by Americans and other foreigners and its exclusion of American insurance companies an unreasonable burden on United States commerce. 
But she said retaliation was inappropriate at this time because of global free-trade talks that are continuing. Mrs. Hills said the Administration would try to resolve its dispute with India during the discussions.
The talks, being held under the auspices of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are scheduled to end later this year. India is considered a critical participant in the discussions, known as the Uruguay Round, because of its influence over other developing countries.
The White House had to decide by Saturday to decide whether to increase tariffs on Indian imports or impose other retaliatory trade sanctions because of India's refusal to negotiate the dispute.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Higher in Active Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Bond prices rose in active, volatile trading yesterday, as market participants shifted out of short-term securities and into bonds after figures on producer prices were released.
The numbers, which showed that prices at the wholesale level rose by three-tenths of a percent in May, were basically in line with projections by analysts. As a result, hopes that the Federal Reserve Board might move to ease monetary policy soon were all but snuffed out.
''After the weakness in the retail sales figures, there were some people who thought the Fed might ease early,'' a government bond trader said. 
 
No Surprising Weakness
''But the producer price number didn't show any surprising weakness, and as a consequence the market's perception has shifted,'' the trader added. ''Unless the consumer price numbers on Friday are way down, the market seems to be of the conviction that the Fed won't move between now and the end of the quarter.''
Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc., said the producer price figures ''were just what the market expected, but were not what the market was hoping for.''
Nevertheless, on a year-over-year basis, the price of finished goods through May have only risen by 3.1 percent, Mr. Liro said.
''That is a very reassuring performance,'' he said. ''Unfortunately, most of the problems we have with inflation are on the service side of the economy, a side we will see in the consumer price figures.''
Most analysts are projecting that consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths to three-tenths of a percent last month. The figures are expected to be released today.
Although the producer price figures were a disappointment, a big drop in gold prices and a steep decline in the commodities included in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of futures prices helped to increase market psychology yesterday.
 
Market Vulnerability Seen
Still, some of the traders said the recent run-up in prices, which had occurred without a sign from the Fed that it was about to ease monetary policy, might have gone too far.
''The market is vulnerable to bad news at these levels,'' another trader said. ''If we get a bad consumer price number, we could have a pronounced selloff.''
Testifying before Congress yesterday, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, gave no indication of the course of monetary policy, but he did say that interest rates could fall ''significantly'' should a credible Federal budget package be passed.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks had little noticeable effect on prices in the credit markets.
With the Fed apparently still on hold, most of yesterday's price gains were recorded among longer maturities.
A decision by the central bank to ease monetary policy by lowering its target for the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market would have more of an impact on short-term interest rates that tend to fluctuate relative to the funds rate than on long-term interest rates. 2020 Bonds Fall to 8.34% By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 104 15/32, up by 13/ 32, to yield 8.34 percent, down from a yield of 8.37 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 25/32, up by 5/32, to yield 8.29 percent. And 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/2, up by 1/32, to yield 8.21 percent. Treasury bill rates dipped slightly. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.65 percent in late trading, down by a basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late-offered rate of 7.55 percent.
 
Dow Unit's Debentures
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Dow Capital B.V., an offshore financing subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Corporation, offered $200 million in 20-year debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
The 9.20 percent debentures, which mature on June 1, 2010, were priced at 100, 85 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent debentures at pricing.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
New York State Offering
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, New York State's Metropolitan Transportation Authority priced a $299 million issue of Transit and Commuter Facilities Service bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
The issue consists of serial bonds from 1992 to 2002, and three term bonds that mature in 2008, 2016 and 2019.
Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6.40 percent in 1992 to 7.50 percent in 2002.
The 7 3/8 percent term bonds of 2008 were priced to yield 7.524 percent; the 7 1/2 percent term bonds of 2016 were priced to yield 7.724 percent, and the 6 percent bonds of 2019 were priced to yield 7.571 percent.
Investment bankers familiar with the transaction said that demand for the issue was strong from retail and institutional accounts, and that the issue was oversubscribed.
The bonds are rated A by Moody's and BBB-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve said yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week that ended on June 4.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Cable TV Rate Found Rising Twice as Fast as Price Index

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
A Government study of the cable television industry released yesterday showed that rates for the lowest-priced basic cable service last year rose more than twice as fast as the Consumer Price Index. The report is expected to add to the momentum for cable re-regulation under way in the House and the Senate.
''This report should remove any lingering doubt for the need to move forward with legislation, and I intend to do so,'' said Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the House panel that commissioned the report. ''America's cable consumers want action.'' 
The lowest-priced service refers to the broadcast networks and any other services that the cable operators may choose to include.
 
Response From Industry
The National Cable Television Association, an industry organization, said in a statement yesterday that the average revenues for each cable subscriber had risen by about 5 percent last year, or by about the same rate as inflation. It added that the rate of cable increases for the basic services had leveled off in 1989, from a total increase of about 29 percent for the two previous years.
A subscriber's monthly bill often includes pay services like Home Box Office, as well the broadcast signals and advertiser-supported services like ESPN and Cable News Network.
Since the industry was deregulated in 1984, cable operators have generally raised the prices of those basic services faster than the price of the pay services. Thus an average subscriber bill that included pay services would rise less rapidly than the prices for basic cable services.
But the cable reregulation bill in the Senate and the draft legislation in the House focus on some form of controlling the price of the most basic cable services rather than the pay services.
 
Seeking More Data
The initial report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, covered 1987 and 1988. The new data also look at 1984 to 1989 and show that the rates for the lowest-priced basic cable service rose by 68 percent, while the Consumer Price Index rose by a total of 23.7 percent in the period.
After the first G.A.O. report, ''The industry contended that price increases were only a result of a pent-up need for additional revenues,'' Mr. Markey said. ''In order to get a better profile, we went back to 1984,'' he added. ''We found a consistent pattern that showed that consumers were being charged double what they pay for all other consumer goods.''
The study showed that during 1989 the monthly rates for the least expensive basic cable service rose to $15.95 per subscriber, from $14.50.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Slow Growth Projected for Spending

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
A LEADING advertising industry forecaster predicted yesterday that growth in advertising spending in the United States would continue at a sluggish pace through 1990, dragged down primarily by a recession in local ad spending.
But the analyst, Robert J. Coen of McCann-Erickson, pointed to signs of underlying strength and projected a healthy rebound next year.
Advertisers will spend $130.44 billion in the United States this year, an increase of only 5.3 percent over the $123.9 billion they spent in 1989, said Mr. Coen, a senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann.
The growth rate represents a slight improvement over last year, when advertising spending rose only 5 percent over 1988. But Mr. Coen's projection was almost a full percentage point lower than the forecast he had made in December. 
By contrast, ad spending rose an average of 10 percent a year from 1983 to 1988.
Mr. Coen's gaze into advertising's crystal ball has become a semiannual fixture in the ad industry. Yesterday, the rumpled 66-year-old executive addressed a hall full of securities analysts and journalists at the University Club in New York, a far cry from the ''no more than 10 people'' who he said had attended his first effort at public prognostication 17 years ago.
Mr. Coen saw little but gloom for media dependent on local advertising. Newspapers showed an increase of only 2.7 percent in retail advertising revenue in the first quarter of 1990, almost two percentage points below the growth rate in the period last year. And local television advertising showed serious declines in several important categories, with automobile dealers reducing their spending by 21 percent and department stores by 13 percent from the first quarter of last year.
''It's just a desperate retail market in many parts of the United States,'' Mr. Coen said. He said he expected total local advertising spending to increase only 4.7 percent this year, to $57.54 billion - far less than the 6.2 percent increase he projected for the year only six months ago.
For national advertising, Mr. Coen painted a brighter picture, predicting that it would increase by 5.7 percent over last year, to $72.89 billion.
Ad spending on network television, he noted, has been healthy, up 14 percent in the first three months of 1990.
Mr. Coen attributed the growth partly to a leveling off in the use of 15-second commercials, which accounted for 31 percent of all network commercials during a sample week in April, down from 35 percent of the total in a sample week in April 1989. Thirty-second commercials, which accounted for 61 percent of the total last year, made up 66 percent of the mix in this year's sampling.
The increase in 30-second commercials means fewer total spots are available for national advertisers to reach a mass audience, thus allowing the networks to charge more for the smaller supply.
Cable television and national syndicated television advertising continued their strong growth, up 18 percent and 32 percent, respectively, in the first quarter of this year, Mr. Coen said.
The national advertising outlook was not rosy for all media. Magazine ad pages were down 4 percent in January, February and March, and revenues rose only 1 percent. But Mr. Coen pointed out that two large categories - cigarette companies, which lowered their spending by 26 percent, and automobile makers, which cut magazine budgets by 7 percent - accounted for most of the problem.
Other product categories are maintaining strong ad spending, the McCann executive said, lending support to a generally optimistic forecast for the ad industry. He noted, for example, that food advertisers had increased their network television spending by 18 percent and their magazine spending by 11 percent in the first quarter of 1990 compared with the 1989 quarter.
''If you look at these numbers, you'd never think we're in an advertising recession,'' Mr. Coen said, taking issue with recent articles about the ad industry's slump.
For these reasons, Mr. Coen said he expected domestic ad spending to increase 7.5 percent in 1991, to $140 billion. Overseas, advertising spending will grow 5.1 percent this year, to $133.8 billion, he predicted. But that spending, too, should rise 7.5 percent next year, to $144 billion, he said.
The McCann executive's promising projections were supported by at least one analyst present. ''Ad spending in leading media is very healthy,'' said Alan J. Gottesman of Paine Webber. ''I'm more optimistic than Bob.''

HEADLINE: Rohatyn Proposes a Bailout Tax

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the Wall Street investment banker, yesterday proposed a 5 percent surcharge on Federal income taxes to pay for the bailout of the savings and loan industry.
The surcharge would raise $25 billion to $35 billion a year for three or four years, roughly covering the estimated $100 billion to $130 billion cost of the bailout, he said in a speech at the National Press Club in Washington. If the cost of the bailout turns out to be much greater, the surcharge should be extended, he said. 
Mr. Rohatyn, who played a major role in restoring New York City's financial health in the 1970's, said the surcharge was a better solution than the Administration's current approach of borrowing the billions of dollars needed to reimburse depositors of failed savings and loan associations.
''Borrowing the money will turn a $130 billion problem into a $500 billion drain - or much more -over the next 20 to 30 years, leaving it to our children to pay off our own stupidity,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. The difference in the figures reflects the interest the Government will have to pay on the borrowed money.
Mr. Rohatyn, who is still chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York as well as a partner at the Lazard Freres & Company investment firm, agreed with many economists that the bailout was essentially a transfer payment from the bank accounts of lenders and taxpayers to the bank accounts of depositors.
Such transfers do not shrink the pool of money available to borrowers. They are ''not neutral, however, from a regional point of view,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. Since most of the failed savings and loans are in the Southwest and West, there will be an ''economic drain from the Northern and central parts of the country,'' he argued.

HEADLINE: Chamorro to Cut Army by a Third, With Sandinista General's Assent

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, June 15

 BODY:
President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua announced today that she had ordered a one-third reduction in the size of the Nicaraguan Army, the biggest force in Central America and the most powerful political weapon in the arsenal of the opposition Sandinista Front.
She said the reduction, from 61,000 soldiers to 41,000, was to be completed by Aug. 3, a hundred days after her inauguration on April 25.
Mrs. Chamorro also said she had ordered the creation of an all-volunteer army, and that all draftees were to be discharged by Dec. 7.
 
Army Chief Backs Reductions
''I want a sacred Nicaragua, which instead of burying its sons in a war between brothers will forever bury its arms so that the cannons will never roar again,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in a speech. ''I will never rest until this dream is a reality.'' 
Her audience included the army Chief of Staff, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, who was Defense Minister in the Sandinista Government that governed Nicaragua for a decade. In response to questions after the President's announcement, General Ortega endorsed her proposals.
General Ortega, who will remain in his post, said the army had already been cut by about a third since the year began, when it numbered almost 97,000 soldiers. He said more cuts would help the budget and lead to a more professional armed forces. General Ortega is the brother of Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the former President and Sandinista leader.
''The quality of the E.P.S., its efficiency, its professionalism won't be lost,'' he said, using the initials for Ejercito Popular Sandinista, or Sandinista People's Army, the force's formal name. ''On the contrary, they're going to be improved.''
Mrs. Chamorro announced the plan before flying here for the opening of a regional summit meeting in Antigua, Guatemala, near Guatemala City. The Presidents of Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and Costa Rica are also to take part in the three-day meeting, and the Panamanian President will attend as an observer.
Sandinista resistance to Mrs. Chamorro had already manifested itself in a strike last month by Sandinista-dominated civil servants' unions, who forced the Government to make sizable concessions on wages. Many people speculated that the reversal would lead Mrs. Chamorro to move slowly on her previously announced plan to cut the military for fear of provoking another confrontation.
President Chamorro's plan is a vital step in resolving a paradox that has often seemed to overwhelm her seven-week administration: how to promote national reconciliation in Nicaragua while erasing the vestiges of Sandinista power.
The Nicaraguan contra rebels had refused to lay down their American-supplied weapons until the Nicaraguan Army was demobilized. But the Sandinistas, who were defeated by Mrs. Chamorro's opposition coalition in elections in February, insisted that the rebels be disarmed before they agreed to any reduction in the army.
 
Deal to Disarm Contras
The stalemate, which threatened to lead to renewed warfare, was broken late last month when Mrs. Chamorro concluded days of bargaining by agreeing to give the rebels an isolated, Massachusetts-sized tract in the sparsely settled southeastern corner of the country in exchange for their demobilization. She said today that more than 14,000 rebels had demobilized.
About 2,000 are still to hand in their guns. But rebel leaders have promised to bring a definitive end to a decade of civil war, which claimed more than 30,000 lives, by surrendering all their remaining heavy weapons before the end of the month.
The rebels' demobilization paved the way for Mrs. Chamorro to order cuts in the army, which has a large pro-Sandinista majority in the ranks and officer corps.
Despite the cuts, Nicaragua will retain a much larger army than either of its two neighbors. While Costa Rica makes do with a police force, Honduras's poorly trained armed forces number less than 25,000 and are considered no match for even a slimmed-down Nicaraguan force. El Salvador maintains a 57,000-member military, but it is engaged in a bitter civil war with leftist rebels and has vowed to reduce the army to about 15,000 when a peace treaty is signed.
 
Hint of Future Military Cuts
Mrs. Chamorro's plan appears similar to one drawn up by General Ortega, the architect of the Sandinista military. But aides to the President indicated that she had advanced the schedule for the reductions.
In her announcement, the President hinted that she would order further cuts, possibly even the elimination of the army, sometime in the future.
''A Central America in peace, in democracy, where all conflicts are resolved by the way of dialogue, doesn't need armies,'' she said.
Discussion at the regional summit meeting is expected to focus on demilitarization and establishing a common market to invigorate the economies of the area.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to arrive from Washington on Sunday for the final day of the meeting.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Growth in California Makes State a Testing Ground

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 15

 BODY:
The vibrant prosperity of California has drawn and rewarded many waves of migrants, both American and foreign, but some see a gloomy alternative prospect if more is not done to absorb the state's fast-growing Hispanic work force.
Over the next 30 years, one vision goes, the Hispanic population will swell while the white baby boom generation retires. Failed by the schools and stuck in low-paying jobs, Hispanic youths will become frustrated and angry. Unable to find skilled labor, industry will flee and California's economy will crumble.
By the turn of the century most Latinos will live in squalid towns without paved roads or electricity and stagger under heavy taxes to support Social Security and other old-age benefits for retired whites, who will retreat into walled villages. 
While this outcome may be unlikely, it is not beyond the realm of possibility, says Prof. David Hayes-Bautista, a sociologist at the University of California at Los Angeles who fleshed out this pessimistic vision.
The increasingly insistent question is whether government, business, the schools and the Hispanic people themselves take the steps needed to educate Hispanic young people and integrate them into the American economy.
 
Mainly of Mexican Origin
Professor Hayes-Bautista says the Hispanic population here, mainly of Mexican origin, has many strengths, including strong family ties and a strong work ethic, that could help it rise from the underclass.
And Hispanic political aspirations got a powerful lift on June 4 when a Federal district judge ruled that the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors had to redraw their district lines to give Hispanic voters a larger voice.
But Professor Hayes-Bautista and others agree that much needs to be done. California, especially Southern California, is emerging as an early proving ground for the American multiracial future, the place where the theory that the Hispanic population will bear the burden of supporting an aging white population will get its first test.
''It is urgent that the state take an immediate and active role, morally and economically,'' said John Vasconcellos, chairman of the State Assembly's Ways and Means Committee, who oversees budget legislation and represents the San Jose area, now about one-third Hispanic. ''If not, we will end up without the capacity to sustain our economy.''
Similar trends are evolving in other states with large Hispanic populations, including Texas, Illinois and New York, where about 9 percent of the population is of Hispanic descent, mainly Puerto Rican. An exception is Florida, where Hispanic residents also make up about 9 percent of that state's population. But most of them are well-educated and affluent Cubans and South Americans.
Depending on immigration trends, the Hispanic population is variously projected to make up 35 to 45 percent of the population of California by the year 2030, up from 21 percent in 1985.
If this happens, Professor Hayes-Bautista estimates that Hispanic children will account for half of all the children in the state, while whites will make up nearly 60 percent of the elderly population. Thus, the number of dependent young and old people would rise from 499 for every 1,000 workers in 1985 to 602 for every 1,000 workers by the year 2030. And, if current trends persist, those workers will be increasingly confined to low-income jobs.
High Dropout Rate And White Flight This demographic transition is already well under way here. Cheap immigrant labor and services have temporarily buoyed the local economy. But nearly two of every five Hispanic youths drop out of high school in the Los Angeles Unified School District, where Hispanic students make up 62 percent of the enrollment.
The heavily Hispanic suburbs of Los Angeles, including Cudahy, Bell Gardens, Huntington Park, Lynwood, Southgate, Maywood and South El Monte, have absorbed a wave of newcomers from Mexico and Central America and are among the poorest in the country.
At the same time, the number of whites who have left Los Angeles County in the last decade, amid considerable resentment against the immigrants, is estimated at nearly half a million. Today only 15 percent of the public school students here are white.
While previous waves of immigrants from Europe and Asia have generally assimilated quickly, this American passage has been more problematic for the Hispanic newcomers. Their sheer numbers and their promixity to their homeland set Hispanic immigrants apart from other immigrant groups. Hispanic leaders like Sergio Munoz, editor of La Opinion in Los Angeles, the nation's largest Spanish language daily newspaper, say this contributes to the difficulty in assimilation.
The barrio here has spread far beyond its core on the East Side of Los Angeles. Once staid working-class neighborhoods that had been inhabited mostly by whites are now alive with the sights, sounds and smells of Latin America. There is still a J. C. Penney and a F. W. Woolworth store on Pacific Avenue in Huntington Park, but across the street is the Pescado Mojado (wet fish) Restaurant and Azteca Joyeria (jewelry), and La Casa del Video is nearby.
Families Struggle To Share the Dream In the modest bungalows behind the main streets, Mexican and Central American families struggle for a place in the American dream. Parents work long hours as gardeners or maids, or at sewing machines in sweat shops, and often watch their children join gangs and drop out of school. They are unsure if their troubles are rooted in their own failings or those of the system.
Rodolfo and Elvia Mendieta of Huntington Park, who came from Mexico City 14 years ago, are determined that their sons, Rudy, who is 10 years old, and Michael, 9, will receive good educations. But Mr. Mendieta, a supermarket worker who serves as president of the parents council at their children's school, deplores what he calls the Hispanic families' tradition of resignation to larger forces; few parents show up at parent meetings.
Juan Garcia, a 17-year-old from El Salvador who dropped out of 11th grade five months ago, called school ''a waste of time.'' And Andy Mendoza, 16, a native-born son of Mexican immigrants who wants to be an electrical engineer, said getting ahead is tough because whites ''think of us as low people.''
In Professor Hayes-Bautista's recent book, ''The Burden of Support: Young Latinos in an Aging Society'' (Stanford University Press, 1988), which he wrote with Werner O. Schink and Jorge Chapa, he says, ''Anglos must realize that their future economic well-being hinges on the productivity of a largely non-Anglo work force.''
Some see a broader danger. Juan F. Lara, director of the Latino Teacher Project at the Tomas Rivera Center, a research organization affiliated with the Claremont Graduate School, said the problem threatens not only ''a group of people who are not supporting the economy,'' but also ''the esthetic soul of a state.''
''What is threatened here is intellectual life, the arts, museums, symphonies,'' he said. ''How can you talk about preserving open space and establishing museums with a large undereducated underclass?''
There are few signs that California, driven in recent years by resistance to taxes and government spending, has begun to address these issues.
Once among the nation's leaders in public education, California has dropped to 48th among the 50 states and the District of Columbia in per capita spending on public schools. Los Angeles, for example, spends $3,500 a year for each student, less than half the amount spent in New York City. Even as Hispanic enrollments have grown, the number of certified bilingual teachers in Los Angeles has dropped - to 1,522 last year from 1,895 in 1985.
For the Children, A Critical Question Still, the prospects of Hispanic youths seem far brighter than those for blacks. Only minutes from the black precincts of South Central Los Angeles, the barrios - for all their poverty -hum with small businesses. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 66 percent of Mexican-American youths 20 to 24 years of age hold jobs, as against 54 percent of black youths. They earn 21 percent more than blacks, and there is a vibrant underground economy.
While the immigrant generation, which comes mainly from rural areas and speaks little English, is stuck in menial jobs, the critical question is whether their children and grandchildren have good prospects for joining the middle class.
Some have high ambitions. Zoila Gomez, a 17-year-old senior at Huntington Park High School, emigrated three years ago from El Salvador. She lives with her mother, who speaks no English and works in a clothing factory. Miss Gomez works after school at a Burger King to save money for college. But she says many of her classmates lack ambition. ''They just like to have fun and don't study or work hard to be someone,'' she said.
Many Hispanic youths here drop out in despair at their bleak job prospects. ''My friend graduated and he can't do nothing - so what's the point?'' said Juan Garcia, a Salvadoran who has worked part time at a McDonald's restaurant in Inglewood since dropping out of high school. ''White kids have opportunity because they've got parents who can pay for college.''
Many Mexican-American leaders, like Leticia Quezada, say the schools have failed to adapt. ''The system is designed to educate middle-class families of the 40's and 50's when mom stayed home and where it was assumed they were high school graduates who could help their children with school work, bake cookies and get involved with the P.T.A.,'' said Ms. Quezada, a Mexican-born woman who was elected in 1987 as the first Hispanic board member of the Los Angeles Unified School District.
Making Education A State Priority The troubles of Martha Casian, who migrated here from Mexico in 1968 and had three sons, illustrate the problem. One of her sons, Antonio, died last year at the age of 15 in what the police called a gang- and drug-related incident. Another son, Raul, 17, is in a juvenile detention camp for violating parole on possession of cocaine. Both sons dropped out of school. Her youngest, Oscar, 14, is still in school.
''Not the teachers, not the principal, not the police, no one ever told me my sons were not going to school,'' said Mrs. Casian, who has been hired as a community representative working with parents to keep their children in school.
Guadalupe Simpson, principal of Nimitz Junior High School in Huntington Park, says the frustrations are enormous. ''The parents are not aware of how to deal with the system,'' she said. ''They don't understand middle-class values. Education is not a priority. But it's also the low expectations of teachers, starting in elementary shcool. And we don't really get the support we need. California and the nation don't have education as a priority.''
Others say the picture is not as bleak as it seems.
Kevin F. McCarthy of the Rand Corporation, citing 1980 census data, contends that Hispanic school enrollment for second-generation students approaches that of the California norm and that the alarming dropout figures are largely a function of new immigration. ''I do not agree with the notion of a permanent underclass,'' he said. ''That is much too pessimistic.''
But few Hispanic leaders share that view, and their arguments are beginning to impress the business establishment. Already having difficulty finding qualified employees, business leaders have made education a top legislative priority.
For his part, Professor Hayes-Bautista has another, more optimistic vision. A recent survey he took suggests that Californians are becoming more sensitive to Hispanic needs. He hopes substantial investments are made over the next 15 to 20 years as Hispanic and white leaders join to pass a health insurance program that provides both for maternal and child health and geriatric care.
By the year 2030, his optimistic vision goes, American economic policy will have brought economic stability to Latin America, and California will have emerged as the paradigm of the ''happy fusion'' of diverse cultural elements.

HEADLINE: BUSH AIDE OPPOSES SANCTIONS ON IRAQ

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
While strongly criticizing the Iraqi Government for its human rights record and foreign policy, a senior Bush Administration official urged Congress today to resist growing sentiment among legislators to apply economic sanctions against the Government of President Saddam Hussein.
The official, John H. Kelly, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said sanctions would worsen the American trade deficit without furthering United States interests in the Middle East.
''It would be the American farmer and the American exporter who would, in effect, be punished,'' he told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ''The Iraqis would be able to purchase the same kinds of goods and products elsewhere on the world market.'' 
But Mr. Kelly faced sharp skepticism from Republican and Democratic members, who suggested that sanctions were necessary to demonstrate Washington's displeasure with Iraq's use of poison gas and torture against its citizens and with its threats to attack Israel with chemical weapons.
 
'To Send a Message'
''I think some type of sanctions are necessary to send a message,'' said Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas. ''It would hurt wheat sales in Kansas, that's true. But sometimes we have to stand up and be counted.''
She said ''it just makes me weep to think we are not doing more'' to protest Iraqi human rights violations.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who also testified before the committee, said, ''America should not subsidize a terrorist nation.'' Mr. D'Amato has introduced a bill, which appears to be gaining support in the Senate, that would impose trade sanctions on Iraq and end all grants, loans, credits, guarantees and insurance to it.
Iraq, which has the second-largest oil reserves in the world after Saudi Arabia, is an important American trading partner. The United States buys an average of 447,000 barrels of Iraqi oil a day, amounting to about $2 billion a year. Last year, the United States exported $1 billion in agricultural products, including rice, wheat and meat to Iraq. Iraq recently requested a $500 million payment guarantee from the Commodity Credit Corporation, an Agriculture Department agency that guarantees loan payments, enabling foreign purchasers of American products to obtain bank financing.
