HEADLINE: Iranian Accord With Amoco Lifts a Barrier to U.S. Trade

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, June 15

 BODY:
Iran removed one of the biggest obstacles to a renewal of trade with the United States today by agreeing to pay an American oil company $600 million for installations seized in the Islamic revolution in 1979.
Two claims totaling $600 million were awarded to the oil conglomerate, Amoco, said an official of the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal. It was the biggest settlement in the arbitration body's nine years of activity. 
 
Total of $1.8 Billion in Claims
The Iranian Government recently suggested that a settlement of financial disputes with the United States might lead to the release of six American hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiite militants in Lebanon.
Last month, the settlement of a much smaller claims package was announced shortly after the release of two American hostages, Robert Polhill and Frank H. Reed.
The Amoco settlement was among more than $1.8 billion in oil company claims stemming from the Islamic revolution in Iran led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
United States-Iranian ties were severed over the capture and detention of employees at the United States Embassy in Teheran for 444 days by Iranian militants.
At issue in the settlement today were two claims filed by Amoco subsidiaries against the National Iranian Oil Co., said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity in line with tribunal policy.
The Amoco Iran Oil Co. is receiving $540 million in compensation for the seizure of four Persian Gulf drilling fields and an oil terminal on Kharg Island, the site of Iran's most important oil shipping facility.
The Amoco International Finance Corporation is to receive $60 million for the expropriation of a petrochemical processing plant on Kharg Island, the official said.
 
Iran Seeks to Improve Ties
Iran derives 90 percent of its foreign currency earnings from oil exports, and President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been making efforts recently to improve and expand trade with the West.
But he has faced strong opposition from Islamic militants who want nothing to do with the United States.
Until today, a $116 million award made in 1986 to Sedco, an oil-platform builder, had been the biggest single settlement by the tribunal since it was created in 1981, officials said.
The tribunal was set up as part of the 1980 Algiers agreement that helped win the freedom of the American hostages.
The panel has three American judges, three Iranians and three third-nation members. So far it has settled $3.2 billion in government-to-government and private claims.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe: Moscow Journal From Black (or Red) Market to White

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 15

 BODY:
While all about the Kremlin Mikhail S. Gorbachev's planners and worriers puzzle about the fallen Soviet economy as if it were Humpty Dumpty, Gennadi M. Poleshuk has quietly sold this city government on creating an oasis of capitalism called the white market.
He has convinced the city of Moscow to put its blessing on his plan to create a commodities exchange, and he is enlisting all manner of barterers and twilight entrepreneurs to come in out of the black market to this aboveboard counterpart.
''This happened all over the world several thousand years ago,'' he said of the idea of a commodities exchange, a convenient trading place to speed and organize supply and demand. ''We have to do it here all over again.'' 
While Mr. Gorbachev and the alarmed Congress hesitate daily in groping for some grand plan to re-energize the economy, uncounted individuals like Mr. Poleshuk, a joint-venture entrepreneur in the wily world of Moscow construction, are moving forward on their own and trying to bypass the Kremlin's gridlocked central-planning process with touches of de facto capitalism.
In this case, the new insurgent Mayor of Moscow, Gavriil K. Popov, is avidly encouraging their efforts, promising real estate and technical help to the commodities market since he has long been one of the nation's leading free-market economists.
 
Visited New York Exchange
After four months of study, a mouth-watering visit to the New York Stock Exchange and promises of help from the new insurgent city government, Mr. Poleshuk has begun enlisting the hundreds of colleagues he knows from the ''dark alley'' reality of the Soviet economy.
This is exemplified by his friend with a truckload of timber who must now grope informally among his business acquaintances until he finds the man with the truckload of cement or wiring that he urgently needs for some enterprise. Commodity swaps like this, and variations that lately include some deal-sweetening hard currency or reliable promises of needed future commodities, are increasingly the case among the hardier Soviet entrepreneurs.
It is all uncontrolled and unofficial, but it is the real way of life being used as a way around both the plummeting ruble and the drifting Government in these hard times.
''Most Soviet people think the exchange is a place where the sharks of the Stock Exchange gather to make plans to buy politicians and dictate to them to rob the working people,'' said Mr. Poleshuk, who obviously enjoys playing the party heretic. Will He Make It? Those watching throughout the world with the great cliche on their lips - Will Gorbachev make it? -might just as well ask whether no-less-driven individuals like Mr. Poleshuk will make it. He is part of Mr. Gorbachev's unsought cadre of entrepreneurial dreamers and schemers who can no longer wait for the giant rusty mechanism of central planning to catch up with the outside world.
A commodities market is one of the most ambitious plans to be broached. There is no predicting how well it might operate in the current vacuum of worn-out socialism. But Mr. Poleshuk said that at a minimum it would be fairer and more thorough than the current black market of trading and would begin introducing common values and a reliable rate of exchange between dollar and ruble to help prod the Kremlin toward the convertible ruble and a full place in the world market.
Mr. Poleshuk said various business-minded circles around the country were already far enough ahead of the Kremlin economists to be talking of creating an association of commodity exchanges in a dozen cities within the next 18 months. In contrast, Kremlin planners, facing the new problem of angry public opposition, talk of setting up a centrally regulated but somehow more open market within five years.
''We will have an island of the free market,'' Mr. Poleshuk said of his project, noting that the last commodity exchanges in this nation were abandoned in 1925 along with Lenin's experimental plan for retaining limited free-market conveniences. ''Those were state-regulated, but we are forming our own exchange as a share-holding association,'' he said, describing his plan for organization and regulations by the traders themselves.
 
Training With Western Help
He hopes to have a fledgling exchange operating by this fall, expecting, he says, three billion rubles worth of exchanges in the first year, about $200 million at the present black-market rate of the ruble.
He is recruiting a staff of 30 to 40 workers who are to be trained with the benefit of Western help. But he is still searching for a critical key -fast, reliable communications equipment to collect trading orders and replace the present primitive broker method of surreptitious, serendipitous gossip.
''Now the exchanges take place in dark alleys,'' said Mr. Poleshuk, who hopes for involvement by both Western and Eastern foreign businesses, and so has hired an American management consultant, Danielle S. Downing, who is fluent in Russian and Chinese.
''I am a pragmatist,'' Mr. Poleshuk said in explaining how he has evolved from being a young believing member of the Communist Party to a rampant capitalist. ''We are not reinventing the wheel. We are finally trying to get it spinning fast as possible.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Danielle S. Downing, an American business consultant, talking with Gennadi M. Poleshuk, a Moscow businessman who plans to create the first commodities exchange in his country since Lenin's time. (Nikolai Y. Khalip/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Detroit Basketball Celebration Turns Violent

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 15

 BODY:
Basketball fans' spontaneous celebrations of the Detroit Pistons' league championship degenerated early today into violence, vandalism, looting and eight deaths.
In the wake of the Pistons' title-clinching victory in Portland, Ore., on Thursday night, scores were injured by gunfire, stabbings and fighting; 35 were arrested; numerous instances of looting were reported; cars were overturned, and police and emergency vehicles were damaged.
The authorities were not sure how many of the casualties could be directly attributed to the celebrations. But the night was clearly an extraordinarily violent one for an already violent city. 
 
Four Killed by Car
In the most lethal incident, which the police described as a hit-and-run, a man from Warren, Mich., drove his car into a group of people who had gathered to celebrate on an East Side street. Four people were killed, three of them children, and one was injured.
Elsewhere, two other pedestrians, one of them a 4-year-old boy, were killed by cars during street celebrations; a 21-year-old reveler died in a fall from the roof of an apartment building, and a 19-year-old man was killed when someone fired into a parking lot jammed with celebrators.
The outbreaks of violence began soon after the nationally televised game ended about midnight, Detroit time, when throngs of pedestrians and motorists took to the city's streets, shouting ''Pistons!'' and ''We're No. 1!''
What followed was reminiscent of the riot that broke out here after the 1984 World Series, won by the Detroit Tigers, when bottles were thrown, the police were attacked and stores were destroyed. Unlike this morning's mayhem, however, that violence was not accompanied by any deaths.
 
Pride in Detroit's Teams
Partly because Detroit's image has been shaped for more than a decade by economic ruin, its sport teams have been regarded by residents as a special source of pride and self-respect. Joy in this pride mixed early today with the violence that is part of the daily fabric of urban life here: for the last few years, more than 600 people have been murdered annually in Detroit and thousands more injured in shootings, one of the highest rates of violent crime in the nation.
So to some extent there was a banality in what happened this morning, and it was apparent today. By dawn, there was little evidence of the mayhem except for some broken glass and brisk activity at the county morgue. Under an intense sun and powder-blue skies, the city was filling up with spectators for the Detroit Grand Prix automobile race, which is to be run on downtown streets during the weekend.
Few people walking city streets seemed to be aware that there had been any disturbance at all. In fact, a party atmosphere was building again, as concessionaires blew up balloons and sold hot dogs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eight deaths, vandalism, assault and looting in Detroit followed the Pistons' second straight National Basketball Association championship. Police officers took a man into custody early yesterday. (Associated Press)

LENGTH: 465 words

HEADLINE: A Boost for Both Countries

 BODY:
Remove trade barriers between the U.S. and Mexico: it's a good idea that the United States has long favored. Now President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico accepts the idea. By agreeing, Congress can bring more jobs and cheaper consumer goods to both countries. 
Yet opposition groups are already lobbying Congress. Organized labor and manufacturers of textiles and steel will oppose an agreement. So will politicians who regard all bilateral trade pacts as violations of Washington's commitment to nondiscriminatory trade rules.
Some of the criticism is valid, but none is overwhelming. The benefits of free trade far outweigh the costs. Mexico and the U.S. are on the right track.
Free trade would help Mexico by attracting U.S. capital, thereby creating desperately needed jobs. And Mexican consumers would enjoy a broader array of high-quality imports. These benefits would do little to discourage the flow of illegal immigrants to the North, as President Salinas contends. But everyday life would be less harsh.
The U.S. will also gain from freer trade. Employment would rise in high-tech export industries, and low-cost Mexican textile, steel and oil products would pour into U.S. markets.
There would also be losers in both countries. In Mexico, inefficient manufacturers will learn to compete or wither. In the U.S., textile and steel workers will be forced to scramble for new jobs at lower wages. But the job loss prospect is exaggerated. U.S. tariffs and quotas would eventually be eliminated as part of ongoing negotiations among the U.S. and its major trading partners. And this country can afford to provide its jobless with generous assistance.
Also exaggerated is organized labor's cry that freer trade would induce U.S. employers to abandon this country in order to exploit cheap Mexican wages and unsafe working conditions. The only U.S. wages that will suffer are those earned by workers in protected industries. These wage premiums are borne by American consumers. Otherwise, high U.S. wages reflect high productivity and are unthreatened by investment in Mexico.
Organized labor has a stronger case when it calls for stricter labor standards in Mexico. With the two economies increasingly interwined, it is appropriate to insist that Mexican employers provide safe, humane conditions.
Bilateral trade pacts can victimize innocent trading partners. If the U.S. grants tariff reductions only to Mexico, Brazil won't have an equal chance to sell its textiles. That's why universal trade rules are preferable. Still, Mexico is special. The common border justifies a bilateral relationship like the one negotiated last year with Canada.
Special interests are already hammering Congress to reject free trade with Mexico. Caving in would hurt both countries.

HEADLINE: Praising Mandela, Dinkins Shakes Fragile Coalition

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
For David N. Dinkins, political tempests over the approaching visit of Nelson Mandela have proved again just how hard it is to hold together the tiles of the city that the Mayor never tires of calling a gorgeous mosaic.
By yesterday, before it had even begun, an occasion that the Mayor has promoted as a celebration of freedom had brought to his doorstep bitter debate on topics from the security of Israel to Puerto Rican nationalism to the tactics of the Irish Republican Army.
To Mr. Dinkins and millions of others, Mr. Mandela is a commanding figure of decency and dignity, who spent almost three decades imprisoned by the white Government of South Africa and who, since his release this year, has held talks with his former jailers aimed at finding a peaceful end to apartheid.
But for all his gray hair and lawyer's training, Mr. Mandela is also a revolutionary who refused upon his release to renounce armed struggle by the African National Congress, and who has expressed solidarity with other causes and figures, including Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. 
Welcoming that revolutionary is ''probably the greatest thing that will happen to me'' as New York's first black mayor, Mr. Dinkins has said. But in communicating that joy to his own delicate coalition, Mr. Dinkins - whose political rise was distinctly evolutionary - has angered some of those with whom his relations have been touchy.
Yesterday, in an exasperated outburst, Mr. Dinkins half apologized and half defended himself as reporters peppered him with questions about why he had called three Puerto Rican nationalists who shot five Congressmen in 1954 ''assassins.'' He had made the comment on the fly in a City Hall corridor on Thursday, when a reporter asked him about a report that the nationalists, now pardoned and living in Puerto Rico, were to be among those celebrating with Mr. Mandela at a rally in Harlem next week. ''I don't want to confuse in people's minds the wonder which is Nelson Mandela with any other involvement,'' he said then.
Yesterday, he issued a statement repeating that he did not condone the nationalists' attack on the House of Representatives chamber but could ''identify with and appreciate their yearning for economic justice and political freedom.''
But later, when he elaborated at a news conference, questions from Hispanic reporters came so fast and with so little ceremony that he finally said: ''I don't care if tomorrow's headlines say 'Dinkins walked out of press conference.' I don't care. But I am not going to have you interrupt while one of your colleagues is putting a question. If you don't respect me, at least respect the dignity of this office.''
The Mayor said he saw no parallel between the fight against apartheid, which he called slavery, and an attack on the Congress of the United States. He said American blacks, with their legacy of slavery, had not used such tactics.
This colloquy came just minutes after Mr. Dinkins signed a City Council bill naming a street corner outside the Federal jail in lower Manhattan for Joseph Doherty, an Irish Republican Army member who was convicted in the death of a British soldier in Northern Ireland. He has been held since escaping and entering this country illegally in 1983, although a Federal judge ruled that he was a political offender.
But Mr. Dinkins rejected comparisons with the Puerto Rican case, saying Mr. Doherty was ''acting as a soldier, killing another soldier in a war situation.''
 
'Sad and Unfortunate'
The Mayor's day began on a more conciliatory note, as Councilman Noach Dear and Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn, who had threatened to protest Mr. Mandela's visit becuase he had likened the Palestinian cause to the anti-apartheid movement, said they would ''bend over'' in the name of unity and welcome him despite some differences.
Last week, after the protest threats, Mr. Dinkins broke his characteristic reserve, warning that demonstrations would be ''sad and unfortunate and tactically very, very unwise, because this man is an international symbol of freedom and especially so seen by persons of color.''
Mr. Dear seized on that and said Mr. Dinkins was seeking to stifle dissent, comparing it to calls for Jews to remain silent during World War II. But after Mr. Mandela assured American Jewish leaders at a meeting in Switzerland last weekend that he supported Israel's right to exist, and after Mr. Dear apologized to the Mayor for his Holocaust reference, Mr. Dinkins met with him and Mr. Hikind at Gracie Mansion.
The two later said they would protest only if P.L.O. representatives were invited to join in the celebration. But Rabbi Avraham Weiss of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale said he planned to hold a prayer vigil outside the Mayor's house on Tuesday, the evening before Mr. Mandela is to arrive.
 
'Fighters for Freedom
By day's end, things seemed a bit calmer.
Ruben Franco, president of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense Fund, said the Mayor's comments lacked sensitivity and a sense of history. Early in Mr. Dinkins's term, he faced criticism for not having appointed enough Hispanic commissioners.
''He doesn't recognize that to many people in Puerto Rico, these are fighters for freedom and justice, for liberation, just as is Nelson Mandela, who himself advocated bearing arms.''
But Mr. Franco said Mr. Dinkins's remarks should not overshadow his other efforts to help the Hispanic community.
Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi of Queens, who helped arrange the meeting between the Mayor and Mr. Hikind and Mr. Dear, said that ''since the Mayor has defined his own role in terms of bringing together the various national and ethnic and racial groups in a city that has the greatest diversity of people in the world, he has to be judged by how he succeeds.''
''So he is held to a higher standard,'' Mr. Hevesi said. ''That may be unfair. On the other hand, to this point, in my opinion, he has exceeded whatever standards people judging him might apply.''

HEADLINE: Florio Battling For Fiscal Plan In Radio Appeal

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 15

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio began an unusual radio campaign today to win the hearts and minds of middle-class voters in New Jersey as political pressures mounted for a crucial vote in the Legislature next week on his plans to raise taxes and drastically change the way state spends money on schoolchildren.
With some Democrats wavering, the state's largest teachers' union staged protests today against the Governor's school aid plan at 20 sites around the state, hoping to deal the new Democratic Governor his first legislative defeat after a string of victories.
The Governor's aides, however, cut a deal with an important Bergen County legislator Tuesday night; it would grant his and other Bergen districts millions of dollars in more aid. Later, administration officials said that that may have secured the victory. 
''Now I can support this thing,'' said Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio, a Democrat from Lyndhurst, who said that at a dinner with Mr. Florio's two senior aides, Douglas C. Berman and Steven P. Perskie, he was satisfied with the Governor's plan. ''I can recommend it. It deals with my district in a fair and equitable way.''
 
Cigarettes Would Rise 23 Cents
The Legislature is considering two sets of proposals. The first, a $12 billion budget for the 1991 fiscal year, would require $1.3 billion in new sales taxes, including increased taxes on alcohol, paper products, soaps and janitorial services, and a new tax on cigarettes that would drive up the price of a pack by 23 cents. Under the state constitution, those bills have to be passed into law by midnight June 30.
The second package includes a new formula for school aid and a $1.2 billion rise in the income tax. The income tax increases, aimed mainly at upper-income New Jerseyans, would provide property tax rebates for middle-income and poor homeowners and renters. They would also finance a new system of school aid, which would shift state funds from more affluent to less affluent districts over five years.
Mr. Florio has said that his new fiscal policies are designed to aid ''the middle class,'' but politicians say it is probably unclear to most voters who, if anybody, is to benefit.
To explain Mr. Florio's policies as a boon to people of moderate incomes, Jon Shure, the Governor's director of communications, announced that the Democratic State Committee had spent $89,000 to broadcast a week of commercials on local radio stations.
''For too long, middle-class taxpayers have paid the freight,'' Mr. Florio says in one message. ''The Democrats and I are fighting to change that.''
Although radio commercials are a mainstay of electoral campaigns in New Jersey, they are rarely used for budget battles. The Republicans, however, took out advertisements in 7 newspapers last month denouncing Mr. Florio for raising taxes and announced plans for a $5,000 radio campaign.
Mr. Florio's opposition also comes from the usually pro-Democratic New Jersey Education Association, a union that staged demonstrations today at courthouses, legislators' offices and other public sites around the state.
Under the Florio school plan the state would shift more than $800 million in teachers' pension costs to local school districts, a move the union says would force many districts to raise property taxes or curtail programs. Mr. Florio says the change will help narrow the gap between what poor and rich districts spend on education.
In Hackensack, about 250 teachers, bearing placards with messages like ''Don't Punish Good Schools'' and ''Florio: Empty Promises,'' rallied outside the Bergen County Courthouse today.
Perhaps the most troubling resistance for Florio this week came from seven disaffected Democratic legislators from Bergen County, which would be hard hit by a combination of new taxes and cuts in school aid.
In a deal worked out with Senator Ambrosio on Tuesday, 12 school districts in Mr. Ambrosio's district, including Lyndhurst, North Arlington, Rutherford and Ridgefield, would receive a total of $6 million in additional school aid. Also, the administration agreed to provide an additional $20 million in municipal aid to densely populated communities with high costs of living.
An afternoon and evening of negotiations with Mr. Ambrosio was completed at Lorenzo's Cafe, a restaurant and bar where politicians are known to gather, and which one top Florio described, shortly after Mr. Ambrosio's departure, as the birthplace of many important public policy initiatives in New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Show Modest Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose by two-tenths of 1 percent in May, the second straight month of modest inflation after a first-quarter surge that is now clearly seen to have been an aberration.
The moderation has been most evident in food, energy, shelter and clothing, the items that jumped most sharply early in the year largely as a result of very cold weather.
The latest inflation report, which followed by just one day another moderate report from the Labor Department on prices that American producers received for their goods last month, was also in line with expectations and was similarly reassuring.
Economists said it seemed increasingly likely that the Federal Reserve would be able by midsummer to spur the economy by easing credit, a luxury it has not enjoyed since just before Christmas. 'Two-Thirds of the Way' 
''We're probably two-thirds of the way to where we need to be to prove to the Fed that inflation is really calming down'' enough, said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the Pittsburgh National Bank.
At the same time, however, the dominant belief among economists and other analysts was that the improvement had about ended and that price increases had stabilized at a rate of perhaps just under 5 percent a year.
''We've probably bottomed out so far as the the low point in the Consumer Price Index is concerned,'' said Patrick C. Jackman, a Labor Department official. He pointed to firming prices for such items as meat, gasoline and tobacco products as likely to nudge the consumer inflation rate higher in coming months, with perhaps only clothing prices moving significantly lower.
The cost of health care continued to rise, climbing eight-tenths of 1 percent for the fourth straight month, resulting in a spurt of 9 percent over the last year. Over all, inflation in services has risen at an unsettling 5.6 percent annual rate over the last six months, up from 4.8 percent for the six months through November.
The Fed, which has a stated goal of reducing inflation from current levels, not just containing it, is considered in no hurry to cut interest rates so long as the economy continues to move ahead, however slowly. The latest official report on the nation's economic growth showed the gross national product rising at a sluggish 1.3 percent rate in the first quarter, and many economists believe that the second quarter could be still lower.
Both the stock and bond markets took the price report in stride, although bond prices did slump after the Fed reported that industrial production rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in May.
The consumer price report today showed that, excluding food and energy, which are subject to wide price swings, the index rose three-tenths of 1 percent, slightly higher than in April but well under a jump of seven-tenths in March. Restaurant Meals Rise Food prices at grocery stores moved down in May by two-tenths of 1 percent as declines for fresh fruits and vegetables and for dairy products were not entirely offset by increases for cereal, meat and poultry. But restaurant meals and alcoholic beverages moved up smartly and pushed the overall food and beverage component up by one-tenth of 1 percent.
Housing, the most heavily weighted item, rose two-tenths of 1 percent as fuels declined by less than in April and charges rose for cable television, trash collection, home furnishings and maintenance.
Transportation costs fell two-tenths of 1 percent as gasoline prices rose by less than normal for May, resulting in a 1.6 percent decline after seasonal adjustment, and finance charges also subsided. However, airline fares and public transportation continued to rise, and the price of used cars increased for the first time since November.
Clothing prices moved down by five-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting larger than usual cuts on women's and girls' wear, but the broader apparel and maintenance category moved down somewhat less than this after soaring in February and March and being about unchanged in April.
Entertainment rose by two-tenths of 1 percent and ''other'' goods and services jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent, the latter reflecting big increases for legal and financial services and for tuitions at business and technical schools.
Before rounding, the price index covering all urban consumers rose 0.1549187 percent, a rate that if maintained and compounded for 12 months would mean inflation of 1.9 percent a year. This was the second straight month in which the index came close to being reported as one-tenth of 1 percent instead of two-tenths.
 
Drop for New York Area
Among the five metropolitan areas for which price data are reported monthly, New York posted a drop of one-tenth of 1 percent. Consumer prices in Chicago were unchanged, while San Francisco, Philadelphia and Los Angeles had increases of one-tenth, two-tenths and three-tenths, respectively.
The price index now stands at 129.2, which means that a group of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-84 base period now costs $12.92.
A companion index, covering all urban wage earners and clerical workers, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in May. This index, often used as the standard for contractual price escalators, now stands 4.1 percent higher than a year ago.

HEADLINE: Import Fall Narrows Trade Gap

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
As a softer economy cut demand for imports, the trade deficit fell 17 percent in April, to $6.94 billion, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the second-lowest level in more than six years.
Declines of about $1 billion each in purchases of foreign cars and oil contributed to a 6.2 percent drop in total imports, to $39.25 billion.
Exports, which had posted a new monthly record in March, fell back by a lesser 3.5 percent in April, to $32.31 billion, chiefly reflecting weaker sales of telecommunications equipment, computers and aircraft engines. But exports are still at their second-highest monthly level. 
 
Viewed as Good News
Substantially lower than many economists had projected, the April imbalance continues a pattern of improvement in place since 1987 and was generally viewed as good news for the economy.
''We're almost in the position that Japan was in five years ago,'' said Kenneth T. Mayland, chief economist of the Society National Bank of Cleveland. ''Our exports are really roaring.''
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said, ''I cannot be more pleased with the latest report.'' While cautioning against the volatility of monthly trade numbers, he added that he was ''as confident as I can be'' that this year's deficit will fall to the low 90 billions, compared with $109 billion in 1989 and $118.5 billion in 1988.
 
Declines in Sales Cited
But much of the improvement in the trade report reflected the weaker economy, which has curbed the appetite for foreign as well as domestic products. ''Auto sales are down sharply and retail sales have fallen for three months running,'' said Kathleen B. Cooper, chief economist for the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles.
Earlier this year, the consensus had been that the trade deficit might not improve this year and could even worsen.
Many economists now agree with Mr. Mosbacher that the deficit will again decline. The sluggish consumer spending - shrinking demand for foreign cars, television sets and other products - along with better-than-expected exports of manufactured goods, responding to productivity growth and changes in exchange rates, account for the revised view.
It was thanks almost exclusively to export expansion that the overall output of goods and services managed a small annual rate of gain of 1.3 percent in the first quarter's gross national product.
The persistent strength of exports into the second quarter, said James Annable, chief economist of the First National Bank of Chicago, suggested that the economy would continue to grow in the range of 1 to 2 percent.
The trade figures were welcome news for the Administration, which has been worried that the economy would slip into a recession this election year. In recent months, from President Bush on down, officials have been letting the Federal Reserve Board know they want easier money.
 
'Credit Crunch' Seen
Mr. Mosbacher stepped up the pressure on Thursday when he told a Senate Banking Committee hearing that the economy was experiencing a ''credit crunch.''
''We get business people in every day in Commerce and particularly those middle and smaller business people who say there is a terrible problem getting any kind of loans and credits,'' he said.
The Federal Reserve and most bankers say there is no ''credit crunch.'' The Banking Committee intends to hold a hearing next week to address the issue.
The April trade gap compared with $8.37 billion in March and was the smallest since the $6.10 billion deficit of last February, itself the smallest since the $5.7 billion shortfall in December 1983. 20 Percent Decline in Oil Much of the improvement in April came from a 20 percent drop in oil imports, to $3.75 billion, reflecting both a fall in the volume of shipments and the price. The 226 million barrels imported in April were 35 million barrels less than in March. The average price in April was $16.57, against $18.18 in March.
Oil could skew the trade numbers in the future. ''We're unlikely to get anywhere near that kind of improvement in coming months,'' said Richard E. Rippe, senior vice president and chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds.
But economists also took heart from the fact that the non-petroleum trade deficit was falling faster than the overall deficit, which was seen as another sign of the strength in exports of manufactured goods.
Over the first four months of this year, the trade deficit, on an annualized basis excluding petroleum, dropped to $39.6 billion from $62.1 billion in the comparable 1989 period and $89.7 billion in 1988, according to Commerce Department calculations.
 
Gap With Japan Wider
More than half the total trade deficit in April was with Japan. The imbalance widened by 10 percent, to nearly $4 billion, mainly because of falling exports. Both Tokyo and Washington continue to argue over measures that Japan has promised to take to open its markets.
With the European Community, the United States in recent months has actually been running a surplus. This widened in April by more than 30 percent, to $1.4 billion, chiefly reflecting a drop in imports.
The trade accounts with the nation's largest trading partner, Canada, were nearly in balance. A March deficit of $30 million was pared to $8.3 million.
With China, the deficit widened from $581 million to $614 million. China recently won an extension by the Bush Administration of most-favored-nation trade status, giving it the lowest available tariffs.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
'Junk Bond' Funds Seem to Glimmer

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
''Junk Bond'' funds, after a bruising first quarter, seem to be on the mend. And with high-yield, high-risk funds making money in the last couple of months, instead of losing it, more investors are buying fund shares than redeeming them.
Is this a good idea? Has the junk market as a whole hit bottom, so that investors can now buy low and share in its recovery, or will there be more situations similar to that involving Donald Trump's casinos, with junk bonds plunging after a missed interest payment? Market professionals can make a persuasive case that there are indeed opportunities in junk, and yields are attractive -13 to 15 percent, even in the better funds. Still, independent financial advisers are cautious. 
Kenneth T. Urbaszewski, senior vice president of Kemper Financial Services and co-manager of the Kemper High Yield Fund, which was ranked No. 1 of 94 fixed-income funds by Lipper Analytical Services for all of the 1980's, said, ''The prices are low, the yields high - this market should appeal to everyone.''
He would put up to a quarter of a portfolio into high-yield funds, depending on risk tolerance. ''The market is very attractive versus stocks,'' he said. He said the Dow Jones industrial average would have to reach 3,400 to match the return on junk funds.
In March 1989, Mr. Urbaszewski, whose fund has a 4.5 percent ''load,'' or up-front fee, had a third of his funds in cash, which helped over the next year, he said. ''Now we think the opposite - we think the market is attractive, and we are trying to minimize cash.''
''The worst scenario I can imagine is the return would be the same as on a Treasury,'' he said, which would happen if 10 percent of the bonds in a junk portfolio defaulted. Last year defaults in the overall market were 4 percent, but a portfolio manager's goal is to avoid the issues likely to default.
Mr. Urbaszewski, who forecasts a 15 percent total return - income plus capital appreciation -over the next 12 years, said: ''We don't buy the highest-yielding bonds. We look at the expected total return.'' He holds 160 bonds of 101 issuers, and relies on a staff of eight credit analysts to scrutinize the bonds. The junk market is thinly traded and transaction costs are high, he noted. One way to keep total return up is to minimize turnover.
Mark Vaselkiv, vice president of T. Rowe Price Associates, the Baltimore-based manager of no-load mutual funds, and an analyst in its high-yield department, also sees ''a compelling investment opportunity for aggressive investors.''
Even conservative investors could put 20 percent of their bond portfolios into high-yield funds, he suggested, to leaven an 80 percent Treasury portfolio yielding 8 to 8.5 percent. Then they will have an overall yield above 9 percent.
''It's a risky market,'' Mr. Vaselkiv acknowledged, ''but it seems to have turned with Drexel out of the picture. We're starting to see buyers who were traditional equity players.'' The T. Rowe Price High-Yield Fund had a total return of 2 percent in May in contrast to a negative 5 percent total return in the first quarter, and a $10 million positive cash flow in May after an outflow in the first quarter, results that were in line with the overall industry.
The Investment Company Institute reports sales of high-yield funds in the first four months of this year totaled $2 billion, just over half the $3.9 billion total in the 1989 period.
''For an investor who can afford to lose - who has discretionary funds to invest - there probably are opportunities,'' said Tim Kochis, who is in charge of executive financial counseling for Deloitte & Touche, ''but it's not where you put any really important capital.''
He worries that some middle-class people whose money is not discretionary are attracted by the high yields for their retirement funds, for example, and ''unwittingly exposing themselves to risk.''
''I'm very concerned about the junk bond market,'' said Joel S. Isaacson, who is in charge of personal financial planning for Weber Lipshie & Company, certified public accountants. He predicted many defaults. ''These bonds have not been through a real recession.''
But for people ''looking to bottom-fish'' in the junk bond market, Mr. Isaacson said, ''funds are probably the only way to go,'' to get the diversification and professional management that are imperative in a risky market.
Steven E. Norwitz, vice president of T. Rowe Price, suggested several criteria for selecting a fund: how widely diversified its portfolio is, both by issuers and by industry; whether at least 80 percent of its bonds make cash payments, as opposed to payment-in-kind or zero-coupon bonds, and how experienced its management is.
To be avoided are the high-yield funds that Forbes magazine calls cannibal funds, which eat into principal to pay dividends. Investors should look at the total-return figures, not just yield.

HEADLINE: Jump in Industrial Output Seen as Temporary

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Industrial production jumped by six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Federal Reserve reported today, but analysts said the sharp increase was mainly because of a temporary buildup in automobile inventories.
''I think it was somewhat of a fluke,'' said Paul Getman, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ''Excluding motor vehicles and parts, industrial production was up by two-tenths of 1 percent. That is more in line with the underlying fundamentals.'' 
The Fed also reported that the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities - which usually moves in tandem with industrial production - rose by three-tenths of 1 percentage point, to 83.6 percent in May. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity.
 
Labor Contracts Cited
Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington economic forecasting firm, contended that the building of auto inventories was related to concern over the expiration of the labor contracts of the Big Three auto makers in September.
David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York dealer in government securities, noted that the auto makers reported a drop in output in the first 10 days of June. ''So industrial production is showing only temporary strength and will probably tilt in a weaker direction in coming months as auto makers, in particular, have to scale back production more in line with demands,'' he said.
Two Government reports earlier this week pointed to slowing consumer demand as the job market weakens and wages fall. Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of economic activity, has been a driving force for the economy for much of the last eight years.
Falling consumer spending, combined with tighter credit curbs in many parts of the country, ''could threaten to push the economy over the edge into a recession in the second half of the year,'' Mr. Jones said.
In addition to auto production, Mr. Evans said some of the increased output was because of exports, which analysts have credited for helping sustain recent economic growth.
The Commerce Department reported today that exports helped shrink the United States trade deficit so far this year to an annual rate of $92.16 billion, compared with a deficit for all of 1989 of $108.99 billion.
Industrial production has risen each month since January except for April, when it was unchanged. The April figure was revised upward from a previously reported drop of four-tenths of 1 percent.
Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent in May after slipping by two-tenths in April.
Output of durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last at least three years - jumped by 1.3 percent after a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier. Manufacturing of nondurable goods such as food and clothing was up by two-tenths following a four-tenths increase in April. Mine Output Steady Output at mines was unchanged in May after an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in April. Utility production was down 1.1 percent following a rise of seven-tenths.
The operating rate at durable goods factories rose by eight-tenths of 1 percentage point, to 82 percent, while the rate at plants making nondurable goods inched downward by one-tenth of a point, to 84.3 percent.
The operating rate at mines was unchanged at 88.9 percent, while it dropped a full percentage point, to 84.9 percent, at utilities.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Mixed Abroad, Dips In U.S. After Data's Release

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar lost ground in domestic trading yesterday and finished mixed in Europe in volatile action after the release of several economic reports.
Gold prices advanced but were unable to make up for Thursday's $5-an-ounce selloff.
The Government reported that the nation's trade deficit fell sharply to $6.94 billion in April and that consumer inflation held to a modest two-tenths of a percent gain in May. Both reports were in line with expectations. 
But a Federal Reserve report showing a six-tenths of a percent rebound in May's industrial production took the market by surprise.
''This was the first time in several weeks that an economic number was reported actually stronger than the market had expected,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago.
The dollar rallied at first, in both Europe and the United States, on the notion that the Fed would not be inclined to reduce interest rates to stimulate production. Lower rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive.
But a bout of profit taking swept European markets and carried through to domestic trading.
Activity was ''very heavy and very choppy,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
Rumors circulated in the market that West Germany's Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan are prepared to intervene in coming days to support their local currencies - at the expense of the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 154.52 yen, up 0.99 yen from Thursday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 154.10 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 153.90 yen, down from 154.20 yen on Thursday.
In London the pound fell to $1.7060, from $1.7080 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7090 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7080.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6885 West German marks, down from 1.6948; 1.4330 Swiss francs, down from 1.4355; 5.6806 French francs, down from 5.7015; 1,239.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.50, and 1.1709 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1713.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $349.50 an ounce, up $2.70 from late Thursday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $348.50 an ounce, up $2.65 an ounce.
Silver prices were unchanged to higher. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $4.811 an ounce, up from Thursday's $4.770.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
LITHUANIA LEADERS URGE SUSPENDING INDEPENDENCE BID

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 16

 BODY:
The government of Lithuania endorsed a proposal today that it suspend the republic's declaration of independence, provided that the Gorbachev Government end economic sanctions and begin negotiating a compromise settlement of the sovereignty crisis.
The action by the executive branch of the Lithuanian government was in the form of a recommendation to its Parliament that it act favorably on the compromise proposal when it takes up the issue next week.
The council thus moved forward the negotiating plan devised this week in informal talks at the Kremlin between leaders of the central Government and Lithuania. A moratorium on the March 11 declaration of independence by the Lithuanian Parliament has been demanded by the Kremlin as the price for suspending its economic embargo and beginning formal negotiations. 
 
Lengthy Debate Predicted
The Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, predicted a lengthy debate on the measure. There was no immediate estimate available of the mood of the republic's Parliament, although its approval might seem likely for a plan already endorsed by the Lithuanian leadership.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev endorsed the general terms of the negotiating plan in an effort to end the three-month crisis that has increased his troubles with nationalist movements and ethnic groups around the nation. The crisis has also impeded his efforts to win United States trade concessions that could help the floundering Soviet economy.
 
End of Embargo Urged First
The economic embargo ordered by Mr. Gorbachev to deal with what he denounced as an unconstitutional action has led to the closing of most Lithuanian factories and the making idle of tens of thousands of workers.
At the same time, Lithuanian leaders have stressed that the republic's resolve for independence has only grown during the embargo.
In its announcement, the Lithuanian council stressed that it was recommending that while the Parliament not delay in declaring a temporary moratorium, it should not take effect until the Soviet embargo on fuel and other needed commodities actually has ended.
 
Independence Is Upheld
''A moratorium only means that for the duration of negotiations the use of the rights stemming from the independence act is postponed,'' the council asserted in a statement, drawing a distinction between independence in principle and the series of laws to enact an end to Moscow ties. ''The status of Lithuania as an independent state does not change.''
If the republic's Parliament agrees, it would temporarily suspend laws that attempt to exempt Lithuanian men from the Soviet military draft and expropriate property claimed by the Soviet Government, among other actions. Moscow claims such laws are illegal.
But Lithuania and the two other Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia, hold that Moscow's rule has lacked legitimacy ever since it annexed the republics 50 years ago as part of a secret pact between Stalin and Hitler.
 
Described as a Beginning
There was no immediate reaction from the Kremlin to today's Lithuanian council announcement, but Tass, the Government press agency, described it as ''an important decision'' that could mean ''the beginning of the solution'' to the drawn-out standoff between Vilnius and Moscow.
The Lithuanian executive's action was expected, since Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene had spoken of increased hope between the two sides when she headed home after the Kremlin talks this week.
The Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, had spoken in a similar tone and announced a token increase in fuel to a fertilizer factory in Lithuania as a good faith gesture to encourage eventual negotiations. A spokesman for the Lithuanian Parliament reported today that the pipeline to the Azotas fertilizer plant had indeed been reopened.
The next critical step will be the deliberations in the Lithuanian Parliament, which will provide the republic's final word on the negotiating proposal.
 
Fast Action Is Urged
At the same time, Lithuanian leaders indicated that they expected the Kremlin to be acting fast to end the embargo. Their statement emphasized that the permanence of the mutual concessions - the independence moratorium and renewal of Moscow trade - ultimately was subject to the opening of formal negotiations and their success.
''The breaking off of negotiations automatically brings an end to the moratorium,'' the republic council cautioned.
The form and substance of eventual negotiations toward a compromise agreement are not yet clear. President Gorbachev met last week with the leaders of the Baltic republics, inviting negotiations toward a treaty to help in his promised change of the nature of the Soviet Union so that all 15 republics might be treated as ''sovereign states.''
The crisis over the republics' unrest deepened considerably for Mr. Gorbachev last week when the Parliament of the Russian republic, the nation's heartland, led now by Mr. Gorbachev's chief anatagonist, Boris N. Yeltsin, adopted a sovereignty resolution that Soviet law should be considered secondary to Russian law.

HEADLINE: After Weeping for Mandela, Many Prepare to Savor Visit

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

 BODY:
For 30 years Willard Johnson fought an often thankless battle in Boston, protesting racial inequities in a country most Americans knew little about. He helped organize some of the earliest demonstrations against South Africa's system of racial separation and was even arrested for it once.
Now Dr. Johnson, a political science professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is waiting to see the face and hear the voice of Nelson Mandela, who inspired him and many others long before Mr. Mandela was released in February after 27 years in prison.
''I hope I get a chance to meet him,'' Dr. Johnson, who heads TransAfrica, the largest American anti-apartheid group, said last week. ''I'll be trembling.'' 
Hundreds of miles away, in the shadow of the Atlanta church where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. preached and near the tomb where he is buried, Kathryn Byrd, owner of the Lady Byrd Beauty Shop, was making plans for June 27, the day when Mr. Mandela is scheduled to visit Atlanta and pass by her shop.
 
'I See Myself'
Mrs. Byrd knew little about Mr. Mandela before he was released, but she plans to put a ''closed'' sign in her shop window and stand with her grandchildren on the hood of her Chevrolet Blazer to get a glimpse of him.
''I'm going to take pictures if I can get close enough,'' Mrs. Byrd said. ''When I see him, I see myself.'' All across the country, blacks who wept and cheered as Mr. Mandela walked free four months ago are anticipating the arrival this week of a man who they say has taken on greater symbolism for them than any civil rights leader since Dr. King.
Mr. Mandela, a lawyer and leader of the African National Congress and its movement to end apartheid in South Africa, was arrested and convicted of sabotage and treason in the early 1960's. Over the years he became the world's most notable political prisoner, the subject of songs and plays and an international campaign to free him. He walked free only after the Pretoria government agreed to legalize the long-banned A.N.C. and to work toward dismantling apartheid.
His 12-day tour of eight American cities, which begins Wednesday in New York City, is bringing together people of every race who are moved by his unwavering stand for his cause, people who only recently learned of him and those who have spent most of their lives fighting to gain his release.
Many of them are planning their schedules around his arrival, sprucing up the schools and parks he is scheduled to visit, learning anti-apartheid hymns, writing poems, practicing rap shows and searching for other ways to show respect and admiration.
''For once, something constructive and positive is coming that the little people, the common people, can identify with,'' said the Rev. J. Alfred Smith Sr., pastor of Allen Temple Baptist Church in Oakland, Calif., Mr. Mandela's final stop.
In Boston, residents of a housing project named after Mr. Mandela will welcome him with waves and cheers and banners as his motorcade passes. People as diverse as shop owners and Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, will turn out to greet him at Dr. King's grave in Atlanta. And at a sold-out Tiger Stadium in Detroit, a 1,000-voice choir will sing the anti-apartheid anthem in Mr. Mandela's native tongue.
''We want to give him goose bumps,'' said the Rev. Jim Holley, pastor of the Little Rock Baptist Church in Detroit. ''We want him to know he's not alone, that we're with him. Whatever the Pope means to Catholics, that's what Mandela means to us.''
To David N. Dinkins, the first black Mayor of New York City, the South African serves as an inspiration to black Americans.
''How can we fail to do well,'' Mr. Dinkins said, ''when they have done such remarkable things against such tremendous odds and oppression while the world stood silent.''
As the borough president of Manhattan five years ago, Mr. Dinkins pushed for the city's first law mandating sanctions against South Africa, and last Thursday as Mayor he introduced a bill expanding the city's policy of sanctions. ''I have been one of the many soldiers in this battle for awhile,'' he said. ''I've always had this feeling. Now I'm in the position to do something about it.''
 
'His Cause Is Our Cause'
Dorothy Clements, who owns the Auburn Avenue Rib Shack in Atlanta, said she hoped Mr. Mandela would have time to stop by for some ribs. She'll have a banner up pointing him in her direction in case he does.
''He reminds me of the civil rights movement,'' Mrs. Clements said. ''We've sort of forgotten how to do it. We don't have anybody who can get the adrenaline going like he does. I hope this will bring black Americans together if just for one day. His cause is our cause.''
The excitement over his visit has caused something of a tug-of-war over his itinerary in Boston. Blacks in Roxbury, which four years ago sought to secede from the city and change its name to Mandela, Mass., say the big rally in his honor on Saturday should be in their neighborhood instead of downtown at the Esplanade.
''Why should we have to watch him on TV and see these other people singing Mandela songs when they didn't even know him?'' asked Georgette Watson, who runs an anti-crime group in Roxbury.
But organizers say holding the event downtown will help bring out as many people as possible. ''The Esplanade wasn't good enough for some but it was a compromise,'' said Themba Vilakazi, a black South African who heads Free South Africa, an anti-apartheid group, and is coordinating Mr. Mandela's visit to Boston. ''We want as broad a coalition in this fight as we can get.''
Roxbury residents will get the morning with Mr. Mandela, who will pass the worn brownstones and storefronts by motorcade and will meet with community leaders and students at Madison Park High School.
 
Soul Searching Among Blacks
That day, Carol Palmer, a resident of the Mandela Apartments in Roxbury, will be out early with her three children to wave to Mr. Mandela. ''I can't wait for the 23d to get here,'' Mrs. Palmer said. ''I'm just so proud of the man.''
She plans to give each of her children a banner to hold up for him. ''They've been asking so many questions,'' Mrs. Palmer said. ''They want to know why this man was in jail for so long.''
The visit, which also includes stops in Washington, Miami and Los Angeles, is prompting a soul searching among blacks who appear uncertain of precisely what Mr. Mandela can do for them but who express hope that somehow he might help foster changes in this country.
Dr. Charlotte Hutton, a resident at a Boston hospital, remembers the moment Mr. Mandela was released and the physicians in the emergency room stopped in front of a television screen in the lobby to watch him. Now she hopes he can do more than inspire. ''I'm hoping for a watershed effect in this country, that we will somehow feel some unifying presence because he's here,'' Dr. Hutton said.
John Evans, a window washer in Roxbury, said that Mr. Mandela had already made his life a little easier. ''Every day it's a struggle,'' Mr. Evans said. ''The struggle is parallel. But if he can sit in jail for 27 years, I know I can try to keep doing my job.''
While black Americans are embracing Mr. Mandela as they would a long lost relative, his unflagging struggle for equal rights has a resonance for supporters of all races.
''It's hard for me to really relate to some of this as an Italian,'' said Charles Laquidara, a Boston disk jockey who led a boycott of Shell Oil in 1988, when he asked listeners to cut up their Shell charge cards because its parent company had dealings in South Africa.
''All I know is that what's going on in South Africa shouldn't be happening,'' said Mr. Laquidara, who plans to use his show to welcome Mr. Mandela. ''I look at Mandela and see a man they tried to break and couldn't.''
Older blacks, remembering the days in this country when they had to drink from separate water fountains, say they hope Mr. Mandela can put younger blacks in touch with their heritage.
''It's amazing how short memories are,'' said Dr. Joseph Reed, the chairman of the medical department at Morehouse Medical School in Atlanta who as a boy was bused 36 miles past six white schools to get to a segregated school in St. Petersburg, Fla.
''My kids drove themselves to a private prep school,'' Dr. Reed said. ''If it does nothing more than cause a reawakening, it will have been worth it.''
The Rev. Joseph L. Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Atlanta, delights in the fact that for the first time Americans have had the chance to see in Mr. Mandela a positive image of an African man.
''The only examples of African manhood known to most Americans are Tarzan and Idi Amin,'' Mr. Lowery said.
 
'Waiting for the Signal'
It is an image that civil rights leaders say could especially encourage inner-city youths lacking in hope. ''Now we have the physical manifestations as we can touch and feel the people who have been involved in the struggle and they can feel us,'' Mrs. King said at a news conference on the visit. ''For the children who will be here and who will get a chance to just get a glimpse of this man, maybe, and who will hear some of his words, it's very important.''
In the coming days, millions of people, black and white, are expected to turn out to glimpse him. Most will be too far away for him to see their faces. But Don Muhammad, a prominent black minister in Roxbury, knows just what he'll say if he gets the chance. ''If it's just for a moment,'' Mr. Muhammad said, ''we're going to say, 'We love you, brother. Keep up the good fight.' ''

HEADLINE: In Managua, Fresh Hope

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANTIGUA, Guatemala, June 16

 BODY:
President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's three-week-old Cabinet was exasperated, ready to give up.
At a meeting on May 11, one member after another recounted a daunting list of problems. Some complained that there was barely enough money on hand to buy pencils; others that their ministries contained members of the opposition Sandinista Front who were undermining almost every decision. With rare unity, the Cabinet agreed, the country was ungovernable. 
And then things got worse. Flexing their well-developed political muscles, the Sandinistas made good on their promise ''to rule from below'' and organized a nationwide civil-service strike that brought the country to a halt for six days in mid-May. Nicaragua seemed on the verge of anarchy.
But on Friday, her 50th full day in office Mrs. Chamorro flew here for her first regional summit meeting buoyed by a series of political victories that have helped to dispel the gloom that had begun to settle over Nicaragua and undermine her Government.
 
'Over the Hump'
While Mrs. Chamorro must still navigate many political and economic shoals, including a crumbling economy, rampant inflation, and an entrenched and hostile bureaucracy, she has begun to create a working administration.
''She's gotten over the hump,'' said a Western diplomat who is a friend of the Chamorro Government. ''It's been a zigzag path, but she's gotten around the corner. There's an unusual genius here.''
The President's first success came late last month, when she persuaded 16,000 contra rebels to fulfill their pledge to surrender their arms to United Nations troops and end their 10-year war against the Sandinistas.
In return, Mrs. Chamorro set aside a reserve for the rebels in the sparsely settled southeastern corner of the country. She also earmarked an estimated $47 million of the $300 million aid package recently approved by the United States Congress to smooth the contras' return to civilian life.
 
Large Political Dividends
Former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra accused the Government of giving away the store. But it appears that the demobilization will cost her remarkably little and will earn large political dividends. It has already paved the way for the announcement on Friday, with Sandinista assent, of a one-third cut in the 60,000-member army, whose officers and rank-and-file are mostly Sandinistas.
In addition, she ordered the armed forces to collect thousands of weapons distributed to civilian supporters immediately after the Feb. 25 Sandinista electoral defeat. That should provide another lift to the demilitarization and reconciliation program.
Mrs. Chamorro has learned to give with one hand while taking away with the other. She settled the civil service strike by agreeing to double wages and suspend a decree that gave her Government wide powers to dismiss workers.
 
Sandinistas Try to Make Point
Sandinista unions and many political observers saw the concessions as an opposition victory. ''This Government has had to recognize that we are a belligerent force,'' Jose Angel Bermudez, secretary general of the pro-Sandinista national employees union, said after the strike. ''From this point on, it will have to take our position into account.''
In retrospect, reports of a Government defeat seem premature. The salary increases were eaten up by inflation in the ensuing weeks. And the Government-controlled legislature returned some of the power Mrs. Chamorro conceded by passing a bill giving the President greater freedom to reorganize the bureaucracy.
''On the whole, she's risen to the challenges,'' a European diplomat said. ''She started by relying too much on decrees. But she's begun to learn how to pull other handles.''
 
Lingering Tensions
Amid signs of conflict within Sandinista ranks, the President's 14-party coalition has begun to come together. For the moment at least, the fighting within the coalition has declined, even though there are lingering tensions over the fact that Mrs. Chamorro's inner circle is composed entirely of personal friends, with none of the established coalition parties represented.
But the Sandinistas remain a potent, well-organized political opposition. The reductions in the army will be much less severe than Mrs. Chamorro had led many to expect. The vast majority of those due to be discharged will come from the reserves and the militia, a Chamorro adviser acknowledged.
In addition, Mrs. Chamorro still must create a loyal and competent government bureaucracy. Except for the most senior officials, the vast majority of civil servants are Sandinistas. They have the power to sabotage much of her program. But any attempt to replace them undoubtedly will provoke further labor strife and set back efforts to foster reconciliation. And her economic program, which includes sharp price increases on many essentials, will begin to bite in the coming months.
That leaves Mrs. Chamorro caught in a bind that has bedeviled her administration from the first moments that it took power: how to reconcile a divided society while moving a subsidized economy into private hands, all the while trying to lessen the influence of the strongest opposition party.
''There are dark days ahead,'' a European diplomat said. ''The belt-tightening inevitably has an effect on popularity until, with a little luck, you get through to better days.''

HEADLINE: Capital Residents Ready To Move On After Barry

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
As the long-running drama of Marion S. Barry Jr. sputters on in court, residents of the nation's capital are increasingly tuning out, wearily grateful that the Mayor's titillating but troubling saga will soon be off the air.
''It's time to move on,'' said Heather Taylor as she stopped to discuss the Mayor's legal and political troubles at the corner of H and 23d Streets Northwest, where doctors, scholars and economists carry attache cases from one appointment to the next.
At the H Street Connection, a video store in a northeastern neighborhood where the old scars of the 1968 riots have given way to the low-slung brick mini-malls of urban renewal, Mansour Mbaye, the 30-year-old Senegalese-born manager, said, . ''He should have gone a long time ago.'' 
In words, in silence and in sighs, these attitudes found echoes all along the four-mile length of H Street, from the brisk, button-down world of Foggy Bottom town houses near the Potomac River to the drug-sodden projects along the Anacostia River.
 
'I'm Sad for My City'
''It's sad, isn't it?'' said Stan Feldman, 63, a wine importer who is a native Washingtonian, as he walked through Chinatown. ''It's sad that a Mayor has to give up. Mr. Barry, like so many other people, had become addicted. I'm sad for him. I'm sad for my city. He has done some good.'' But then, after a pause, he said, ''He should move on.''
A journey along H Street this week found that the residents of the national capital, the residents of the drug capital and the just plain residents were tuning back into the rhythms of their own lives.
''Sorry, I'm not from North America and I'm 10 minutes late,'' said one woman, tapping her watch for emphasis as she rushed away from the World Bank building. ''No comment,'' said an elderly black man, leaning on a street sign near a weed-filled lot at H and 12th Northeast.
''Watch your camera, man. This is drug country,'' said an admitted addict, as he stood near the housing projects at H and 20th Streets Northeast.
 
Weariness Over Ordeal
It wasn't that no one had anything to say about Mr. Barry. But those who did often sounded wearied by the six-year marathon of accusation and denial, pursuit and capture, confession and contrition. And the remarks of those who didn't were reminders that for some, Washington is a way station, not a home, and that local government is a matter of little moment.
''Barry?'' said one young man quizzically as he stood near the intricately colored Chinese arch that marks the center of Chinatown at H and Ninth Streets Northwest.
''Mayor Barry,'' his questioner replied. ''Mayor Barry?'' he asked, shaking his head. Then he said: ''I'm sorry. I just came here a week ago.'' Mr. Barry's trial, resulting from a Federal sting operation in which prosecutors say Mr. Barry was videotaped smoking crack, has generated a broad spectrum of reactions. And that spectrum is reflected in the broad range of neighborhoods along H Street.
 
Relief and Regret
In the racially mixed but predominantly white professional areas, there was relief at the Mayor's decision not to seek re-election and regret that a once-promising career had turned sour. Heading east, where the majority white world shades to majority black, there is some anger at the Mayor, but more people turn their anger toward his prosecutors.
Pat Petrisin, a 63-year-old retired secretary interviewed near George Washington University, said she was thrilled by the Mayor's announcement that he would not seek a fourth term.
James Kee, 45, a professor of management at the university, said Mr. Barry had made the right decision but added that the Mayor had left some positive achievements, particularly that he ''brought a lot of pride to the black community in terms of its ability of govern the city.''
Gary Hennen, 46, a doctor who like Mr. Kee lives in Washington's suburbs but works downtown, said: ''I think he's probably guilty and realizes that he's going to be found guilty. I've always thought that he's been in over his head. First politics got out of control, then his life got out of control.''
 
'He's a Good Man'
Colleen Wright, 28, a student at a beauty academy near H and 12th Streets Northeast, said: ''I'm really disappointed that he decided not to run. I believe he's a good man. There are some things you should overlook. I voted for him every time, and I'd vote for him again.''
A few blocks away, at H and Fourth Streets Northeast, WOL radio was fielding call after call from listeners accusing Federal prosecutors of hounding Mayor Barry and expressing hope that he would prevail at his trial.
Just off H Street, in a neighborhood of row houses whose black owners are beginning to join the exodus to the suburbs, an older woman sat on her porch looking at the newspaper headlines and shaking her head.
''I still think he ought to have waited till all the facts were in before he announced'' his decision not to run again, said the woman, who identified herself only as a retired data processor.

HEADLINE: More States Trying to Curb Teen-Age Pregnancies

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Fearing the high long-term costs of adolescent pregnancies, more than two-thirds of the states have taken steps to reduce their incidence and enhance the lives of teen-age mothers and their children, according to a new study by the National Governors' Association.
State officials and experts on adolescent pregnancy said in interviews that these programs resulted in a reduction in the frequency of such pregnancies, in healthier mothers and babies and in more job opportunities for the young mothers, as well as fewer repeat pregnancies and school dropouts.
''Teen pregnancy is a bellwether statistic,'' said Jeffrey J. Koshel, who directed the governors' association's study, released earlier this month. ''It sounds an alarm. The results are not confined just to our school system or welfare system or criminal justice system. It raises questions about what to do with unemployed, undereducated adults and women who give birth at 16 and stay on welfare for 10 years.'' 
The study found that the number of states with coordinated efforts to reduce adolescent pregnancies more than doubled, to 17 from 7, while the number of states with individual agencies working on the problem increased to 27 from 20. Of the 37 states that increased programs since 1985, 6 added supervision or resources for localities, 3 others formed study groups to plan initiatives and 11 started programs to address some aspect of adolescent pregnancy and parenthood.
 
Programs Criticized as Too Small
But some experts say the expanded programs, although ambitious, still fail to reach most of those in need. Dr. Karen Pittman, director of the Adolescent Pregnancy Prevention and Youth Development Division of the Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy and research group, said, ''The problem isn't that we don't know what to do, but that we don't do it broadly enough to make a real difference.''
Many special health, education and training programs are limited to communities where there is a high incidence of adolescent pregnancy. In New York State, 24 communities, including eight in New York City, are served by a coordinated adolescent pregnancy program; in California, 32 communities are served. Some states, including California, are now considering making these programs available to virtually all pregnant teen-agers.
The Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit policy group concerned with reproductive health that does frequent population studies, reported that the number of births to women younger than 20 increased from 1 million in 1973 to 1.2 million in 1980, and then declined to 1 million in 1985, the last year for which statistics were available.
The birth rate for females under 20 is 113.2 per 1,000, the institute reported, ranging from 16.6 per 1,000 for 14-year-olds to 166.2 per 1,000 for 18- and 19-year-olds.
 
More Unwed Teen-Age Mothers
Sixty percent of teen-age births are to unwed mothers, up from 15.4 percent in 1960, 30.5 percent in 1970 and 48 percent in 1980.
''The automatic reflex to marry is not there any more,'' said Dr. Pittman, a sociologist. This has a lot to do with changing attitudes toward marriage, she said, as well as with the inadequacy of the earnings of the fathers, who are often high school dropouts who cannot find jobs that provide sufficient income to support a family.
California led the states in spending for family planning services other than Medicaid in 1987 with $27 million, followed by New York with $23.2 million and Texas with $20 million.
Forty states require or support some form of sex education in local public schools, while 15 states support school-based clinics that provide an array of preventive health services from physical examinations to family planning counseling.
Fifteen states have developed employment and training programs intended to keep pregnant adolescents in school.
In Texas, a $1 million Teen Parent Initiative in El Paso County has resulted in ''better school retention, healthier babies, and a reduction in repeat pregnancies,'' said Liz Silbernagel, who coordinates the program.
In New York State, where there were 57,000 births to adolescents last year, a four-year-old program with a budget of $7 million a year coordinates the activities of the state and localities. The program operates in 24 areas, including Harlem, the Lower East Side, Washington Heights, Jamaica, Bushwick-Williamsburg, East New York, Fort Greene-Red Hook, and the South Bronx in New York City.
A state study of the eight communities in the first group in the program found that although the statewide rate of adolescent pregnancies had increased by four percent to 87 per 1,000 between 1986 and 1988, the rate in those communities had decreased by seven percent, to 102 per 1,000.
In California, where there were 58,000 births to adolescent mothers last year, an $8.8 million a year Adolescent Family Life Program established in 1985 serves 5,500 teen-age mothers annually in 32 communities. The program teams a caseworker with those providing services like nutrition, counseling, child care and transportation.
''The program has improved the outcome for adolescent mothers,'' said Vivian R. Gammon, the state's Assistant Secretary of Health and Welfare in charge of the program. ''It's increased the birth weight of their babies, improved the nutrition of mothers and babies, and helped the mothers stay in school and find jobs.''
She added that the state's goal ''is to provide this kind of service to all teens'' who qualify for Medicare.

HEADLINE: Deirdre A. Lowe Becomes a Bride

 BODY:
Deirdre A. Lowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Lowe Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christopher C. Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Burke of Chelmsford, Mass. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel.
