HEADLINE: Campus Life: Washington and Lee;
N.A.A.C.P. Seeks Dormitory Space For Urban Poor

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
An influx of students from Washington and Lee University into low-income neighborhoods is creating friction with black residents, who charge that the movement has driven up rents to a point where some families can no longer afford to live here.
In response, the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has called on the college to open its dormitories to residents who cannot afford to live elsewhere in Lexington.
''The students come in and jack the rents up because they can afford to pay it; poor people can't,'' said Shirley Wells, a former Lexington resident who now lives in the rent-subsidized Valley View Apartments, about a mile north of the city. 
Charles Wohlrab, Lexington's housing coordinator, said that the student influx had been on the rise for five years. Frank Parsons, the college's capital planning coordinator, said that students started moving into the area in the 1950's, but added that the college did not have exact figures before this year.
 
Historically Low-Income
By the college's figures, 137 of 1,665 undergraduates at Washington and Lee, where tuition is $10,100 a year, now live in the low-income neighborhoods near the campus. Lexington has about 6,800 residents, almost half of them students. Living on campus costs about $170 a month, compared with $200 to $250 a month off campus.
The heavily black section of Lexington, which has about 500 residents overall, has been home for generations to some of the city's less affluent residents, many of them cooks, custodians and other service employees of the college and neighboring Virginia Military Institute, whose students are required to live on campus.
Officials at Washington and Lee, say rising rents are a function of the marketplace and beyond their control.
''It's all market-driven,'' said Brian Shaw, a spokesman for the college. ''If people want to live in town, they've got to pay.''
 
Robert E. Lee Himself
Mr. Shaw also said that Robert E. Lee himself, who was Washington and Lee's president after the Civil War until his death in 1870, encouraged students to live in the surrounding community to ''broaden their educations.''
J. B. Harris, president of the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter, said: ''Washington and Lee has available dormitory space. What do they do with the unused rooms? Why don't they rent that out to people in the community?''
Mr. Parsons responded, ''I don't think the suggestion is a very practical one.'' For one thing, he added, low-income residents might not like the students' noisy life style.
Mr. Parsons, who said that the college's dormitories are between 85 and 90 percent full, added that some of the off-campus houses now rented to students were empty and deteriorating before they moved in and were brought up to date by landlords. He also said that students who live off campus benefit the city's economy.
But Mr. Parsons conceded that the student migration into low-income neighborhoods had caused problems, both in housing costs and in community relations. Permanent residents sometimes complain of loud student parties and student-generated litter.
Lexington has received a $700,000 Federal grant to pay for housing rehabilitation in the neighborhood, said Mr. Wohlrab, the housing coordinator. The city also is working with banks on a plan to buy vacant houses in the neighborhood and save them for sale to low-income residents, he said.
''We don't want to displace minorities,'' said Lexington's Mayor, H. E. Derrick. ''We don't want to displace low- and moderate-income families. Something ultimately has got to be done.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Purdue;
A Short Course In Farm Advice Follows Storms

DATELINE: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind.

 BODY:
Because it is a land-grant college, Purdue University found itself last week dispensing advice on how to save and plant crops after devastating floods and tornadoes ripped through Indiana in the last month.
One responsibility of a land-grant college is to serve the public that finances it. So for two days, Purdue's Cooperative Extension Service, which supervises the state's county agents, held television question-and-answer sessions for the agents to help them instruct farmers on dealing with storm damage. 
The setting for the teleconferencing was the campus's Potter Engineering Center, where more than 20 farm experts from the university were in touch with 31 sites in the state through the Indiana Higher Education Telecommunication Systems.
''We're here to provide information, knowledge and help people make decisions,'' said Dave Petritz, the coordinator of the programs.
 
Corn and Soybeans
Chris Hurt, a professor of agricultural economics, said Indiana's farmers, particularly those who grow corn or soybeans in the southern part of the state, might have sustained losses of up to $250 million. Corn and soybeans are each $1 billion crops here.
Phyllis Van Osdol, price-support specialist for the Agriculture Conservation Stabilization Service, said more than $26 million in damage to farm structures had also been reported.
A little less than 50 percent of the corn in southern Indiana has yet to be planted, said Ralph Gann, a state statistician. Tuesday was the last optimal day to plant corn.
Mr. Petritz said the advantage of the teleconference approach was that it provided a way to reach county agents, who in turn could assist many more farmers. He said the programs were open to anyone, but were designed specifically for agents.
''They are our eyes and ears out there,'' Mr. Petritz said. There is a county agent in each of the state's 92 counties.
 
Emotional Concerns Considered
One of the first presentations in Tuesday's program dealt with how the agents should handle people who were suffering emotionally. ''It's easier to deal with the facts of an issue than the emotional side,'' said George Denton, head of child development and family studies at Purdue. ''How do we fix the feelings, the grief, the despondency the farmers are feeling?''
His answer: ''Not very much you can say. Listening may be one of the best things you can do.''
Gerry Nelson, a county agent from Ox County, called the teleconference studios to say that prison crews were being used to help in the cleanup but that additional help was needed.

HEADLINE: SOUND;
DAT Decks Stand Ready for Shipment

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL

 BODY:
The free market, as an economic principle, has been gaining new friends in many places lately. But nowhere are unbridled enterprise and competition more evident than at the Consumer Electronics Show held in Chicago every June.
Despite the magnitude of the home electronics industry - it annually grosses $44 billion at retail in the United States alone - it has remained free of cartels and other clubby arrangements to fix prices, nip trade rivalries and squelch new ideas. As could be seen at the Chicago exhibition earlier this month, small companies - especially in audio - compete on basically equal terms with giant corporations. The better mousetrap still prevails. In audio, it's still the sound that counts. At least that's true in the more critical segment of the trade, where musical interest takes precedence over merchandising. 
Granted, lots of sound equipment is sold these days as a mere commodity - an item for chain stores. And many of the larger manufacturers, dazzled by dollar volume, aim their efforts at this relatively mindless portion of the market. Yet, in striking contrast to those mass-market products, there were plenty of components to be heard in Chicago that address a more discriminating audience and bespeak a musical dedication on the part of engineers eager to link art and science. Those engineers are true practitioners of what John Updike, himself a poet, calls ''the humanistic poetry of invention and technology.''
Most of the new stereo equipment shown at Chicago will not reach the stores until summer's end. This column will report on individual items as they become available.
Despite the staggering diversity of the more than 1,400 exhibits that sprawled over McCormick Place - Chicago's vast lakefront exhibition center - a single topic dominated the audio shoptalk: the imminence of DAT (Digital Audio Tape). Three days before the show opened on June 2, the Japanese Government, through its Ministry of International Trade and Industry, announced a sudden policy change: Henceforth Japan would permit the export of DAT decks to the United States.
Until now, Japan - the only country so far to make DAT equipment for home use - had held off sending it to this country for fear of offending the American record industry, which has powerful friends in Congress. The record makers worried about DAT's ability to make perfect copies of any recording - indistinguishable from the original. They felt that such undetectable copying would lead to organized piracy of copyrighted material.
However, a recent technical development allayed their apprehensions. A digital copy lock was developed that prevents further copies from being made from the first DAT copy. The record industry is satisfied that this will forestall large-scale piracy (which involves making multiple copies from copies) while allowing private users to make single DAT copies of recorded material.
It is this development that made the American record industry acquiesce to DAT and, in turn, persuaded the Japanese Government to authorize the shipment of DAT decks to the United States. It is expected that the import of DAT equipment will be ratified in the United States Congress through a bill - now under consideration - requiring all DAT decks sold in this country to be fitted with such a device.
Now that the Japanese export barrier has finally fallen, the first DAT decks designed for home use are likely to appear in American audio shops by midsummer. At the Chicago show, Sony announced that DAT is ready and waiting at the dock. Technics and Denon said that their own DAT designs would follow soon. Only Sony has set a price: $950 for its Model DTC-75ES.
Similar pricing expected from competing brands may initially confine DAT's appeal to the more avid and affluent audiophiles. But in the long run, with gradually declining prices, DAT's unmatched sonic quality is bound to win many enthusiastic adherents. There is little doubt that the announcements made in Chicago this month will precipitate the most radical advance in home recording since audio cassettes made their first appearance in the mid-1960's.

HEADLINE: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: CRITICS' CHOICES;
Fact That Outperforms Fiction

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
The corporate nose has never been tweaked, or its leg pulled, to such serious and delirious effect as it is in Michael Moore's instant classic, ROGER AND ME (1989, Warner, $89.95). The brilliant feature-length documentary is now available on a videocassette that looks almost as mint-fresh as the movie.
In ''Roger and Me,'' Mr. Moore examines the idiocies of mankind as reflected in the economic crisis that befell his hometown of Flint, Mich., when General Motors began shutting down plants and laying off workers by the thousands. According to Mr. Moore, G.M.'s only thought was to open plants in Mexico, where the help is cheaper. 
The film makes no pretense of being unbiased. Though his manner is hayseed, Mr. Moore is an exceptionally sophisticated, witty and angry polemicist. The movie is as funny as it is bitter.
Form is given the film by Mr. Moore's Don Quixote-like attempts to track down Roger Smith, the G.M. chairman, in order to chat about G.M.'s community responsibilities.
''Roger and Me'' loses nothing in the film-to-video transfer. If anything it seems even more furious and more healthily impertinent to all things Establishment. Part of this is the new context. The movie looks especially rude when seen in a space recently vacated by commercials on behalf of America's most powerful corporations.
The video release of ''Roger and Me'' should also spur interest in the vast collection of first-rate documentaries already available in cassette form. Fiction would be hard put to match some of the real-life characters to be seen in this fact-cinema collection.
GATES OF HEAVEN (1980, RCA/Columbia, $79.95), by Errol Morris, who later went on to make THE THIN BLUE LINE (1988, HBO, $39.95), is a most revealing portrait of American manners as they relate to a California pet cemetery. Examined are the people who run the cemetery, who patronize it and who scoff at it (including a man who runs a business that recycles dead animals for profit).
Barbara Kopple's Oscar-winning HARLAN COUNTY, U.S.A. (1976, RCA/Columbia, $59.95) examines a strike by coal miners in eastern Kentucky. It took place in the early 70's but is as bitter as any labor action in the 1930's. Albert and David Maysles' GREY GARDENS (1976, Maysles Films, 250 West 54th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019, $79.95) is a disturbing portrait of gentle folk gone to seed in East Hampton: Edith Bouvier Beale (around 80) and her daughter Edie (about 50), the aunt and first cousin of Jacqueline Onassis.
BURDEN OF DREAMS (1982, Flower Films, $59.95), by Les Blank and Maureen Gosling, is a riveting picture of the making of a movie, Werner Herzog's ''Fitzcarraldo,'' in the jungles of Peru. After ''Burden of Dreams'' rent about any Les Blank film you can find. He's a master of movies about the American idiom. Go now.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
BLUEPRINT AN AIRPORT THAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
Few airports are architectural masterworks, but most are barely even tolerable as public environments. Harsh, cold, unrelentingly grim, they are designed more for the convenience of their tenants, the airlines, than for the pleasure of their users, the passengers. How often is it that people linger at airports longer than they have to, as they once did at train stations? Great train stations are celebrations of the ceremony of arrival and departure; airports are machines for shuffling people around.
And most airports aren't even very good at doing that. A case in point is the John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, ne Idlewild, built in stages since the mid-1950's and both an esthetic horror and an operational nightmare. Most of the airlines operating out of Kennedy have their own buildings, strung out along a looping roadway, and the airport is not so much a unified facility as it is a set of competing duchies. The terminals suffer from the same disease as airport buildings everywhere else - the Pan Am building, to cite perhaps the worst, has all the pleasure of a subway station - but to move from one of them to any other is worse still, given the hopeless congestion that clogs the airport constantly. 
What seemed like an innovative design when the airport was new has now turned out to be something of a disaster. Kennedy's unpleasantness is no secret: its share of international passengers boarding flights in the United States fell from 37 percent in 1983 to 32 percent in 1988, the last year for which exact figures are available, and is believed to be dropping further all the time. While some of that decline is due to the increasing number of flights abroad now available from other cities, plenty of it is due to Kennedy's fast-sinking reputation among international air travelers.
Kennedy was once the premier air gateway to North America: now it is really no more than a very busy, very difficult entrance to a very busy, very difficult city. It was with some hope of restoring the airport's role as a symbolic gateway to this country that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the airport's operator, commissioned a master plan in 1984 for the airport's expansion from the architects Pei Cobb Freed & Partners (then known as I. M. Pei & Partners).
What Henry Cobb, the partner in charge of the project, produced was a remarkable scheme that would have transformed the airport completely, made its unworkable layout coherent, and given New York its most important architectural entry since the completion of Grand Central Terminal in 1913. The plan, which was part of a $3.2 billion overhaul of the entire airport, was about to start construction when it was abruptly abandoned by the Port Authority earlier this year, ostensibly as a result of its cost. The project's cancellation - which the Port Authority prefers to describe as an indefinite postponement - is a story in which architecture, politics and the bizarre economics of the airline industry became intricately intertwined. The losers are the people of New York, who almost got both a workable airport and a noble public building - and now will have neither.
Mr. Cobb's design was based on the realization that there was nowhere for Kennedy to expand except inward, toward the center of the loop around which its terminals are strung. He proposed a vast central terminal that would contain no actual gates, but would serve as an arrival, departure and transfer point for most travelers and visitors, connected to the other terminals by means of a people-mover system. The older terminals would be somewhat expanded and upgraded, and would surround the central building like oversize satellites.
It was a daring design, since it effectively turned the airport inside out. The different airline terminals, which now make a chaotic splatter along the loop road, would have been rendered secondary to a vast structure of granite, glass and metal that at its center would have contained a domed, skylighted arrival hall, 140 feet across and 115 feet high. The hall would have been a space of both majesty and drama, Soanian in spirit, and perhaps the closest our age has come to the grand and uplifting public space of the great railway terminals.
But also like the great train stations of an earlier age, the central building at Kennedy would have been much more than an architectural monument. It would have been a kind of machine - ''the heart this airport needs to pump people around,'' in Mr. Cobb's words. The vast building would have been the central transfer point for an elaborate automated system that would have moved passengers to and from the various terminals, and it would have contained hotels, restaurants and shops, as well as expanded customs facilities, parking garages and bus platforms.
All this was to be bound up in a structure that would have been fairly nondescript on the outside, distinguished more by a sleekness and cleanness of detail than by anything else, with the finesse that is more or less assumed in buildings from the Pei Cobb Freed office. But behind this discreet facade was to have been a remarkably complex, brilliantly interwoven system of roadways, walkways, and people-mover routes, all surrounding the majestic space that would have been the architectural reward at the building's core.
The drawings and models suggest a building of remarkable refinement for a public project, particularly for one commissioned by an agency whose architectural output has tended to be more along the lines of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan. Here at Kennedy, public architecture would have achieved an impressive degree of grandeur. Perhaps more impressive still would have been the message this design sent that grandeur need not be inconsistent with efficiency: that it is possible to make the public realm more coherent at the same time that it is being made more noble.
The project was officially put aside because of finances. While the central terminal building itself would not have been terribly expensive (roughly $450 million of the $3.2 billion cost of the Kennedy master plan, well within original budget guidelines), the overall plan, with its complicated people-mover system, proved more than the Port Authority wanted to handle at a time when New York's economy is so troubled.
The Port Authority plans a limited, scaled-down set of improvements instead, without the central terminal at all. Its executives argue that they cannot spend the vast amounts of money the larger project would require without help from the airlines, which in today's deregulated, market-driven economy, balked at committing their money to the central-terminal project, especially given Kennedy's decline.
But of course Kennedy's decline was the very reason the project was initiated in the first place. The Cobb building was designed to turn the airport around, to render an unworkable place functional and to confer some dignity on the experience of arriving in the United States and in New York City. That last goal would seem to be a particularly frivolous luxury so far as the Port Authority and the airlines are concerned - after all, what traveler could be so audacious, or so foolish, as to think of anything connected with the process of arriving in New York City in terms of dignity, pleasure or excitement anymore?
It's worth saying something about the relative views of the Port Authority and the airlines here, since it was the reluctance of the airlines that really did this project in. Since deregulation, airlines have shown little interest in long-range planning; they are hesitant to plan 30 days ahead, let alone 30 years. And the stronger airlines have become more and more powerful, less an airport's tenants than its masters, and less willing to cooperate with each other than they were in an earlier, gentler era.
Paradoxically, in the current environment, the absurd layout of Kennedy makes perfect sense for the airlines: this Balkanized airport allows them to preside over fiefs of their own, and it makes transfer from one airline to another hopelessly difficult. Surely one of the reasons the airlines pulled back from the master plan was that the present state of affairs at the airport suits their purposes just fine. But if it isn't the business of the airlines to demonstrate vision, that is the business of the Port Authority, a public agency that was created to do precisely what the private sector couldn't do on its own. While it is true that the Port Authority is charged with fiscal restraint, it's equally true that its mandate is to transcend politics and make the best long-term decisions for the future of the New York region. Kennedy Airport is not only an architectural horror; its slipping market share is damaging the economy of New York City. This project seemed to offer a fair chance of reversing the airport's sad decline and, more important still, of giving this mess of an airport some sense of order - and through it, to have conferred on New York City the noble gateway it deserves.
 
CLIPPED WINGS
Amid all the architectural chaos of Kennedy Airport, there have been some attempts to create terminals of serious design. The most famous is the TWA Terminal, the swooping concrete structure of 1962 designed by Eero Saarinen. Alas, while that building's sensuous form, intended to evoke the spirit of movement and flight, remains, it is now but a shadow of its former self. The dramatic building proved unworkable both for the high-volume passenger needs of an age of jumbo jets and for the needs of handicapped passengers. And it has been so unsympathetically altered by TWA that it is difficult now to see what it is in Saarinen's majestic, earnest shapes that so stirred the spirit a generation ago. The kindest thing that could be done to this building, given how unfunctional it is today, would be to strip off all the additions and restore it as a museum of airport architecture.
The second-best terminal at Kennedy went up a decade later, in 1972, and that is perhaps why it always worked better. It was designed by I. M. Pei & Partners and is also under the control of TWA, which located its domestic flights there after taking the building over from National Airlines, which commissioned it. There is a grand and serene order to this glass and travertine building: a cool, self-assured modernist temple to flight.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Henry Cobb's remarkable design for John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, in which existing buildings would be connected via people-movers to a new central terminal - ''the heart this airport needs to pump people around.'' (Nathaniel Lieberman/Pei Cobb Freed & Partners)

HEADLINE: They're Drilling in the Oil Patch Again

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Tex.

 BODY:
Lord, they ask here in West Texas, let there be one more boom. Oil boom, of course. Then, again, no one here is exactly sure whether West Texas or the rest of the nation could actually produce one more boom. The oil people are asking themselves whether the nation has conceded too much power over oil prices to the Persian Gulf or whether too much of their old boom-time rigs and labor has simply disappeared.
Still, some of the region's prayers are now being answered, as is clear from the smiling face of Jack N. Blair when he talks about his new oil well. His so-called ''rank wildcat'' - a well drilled on the basis of ambiguous geologic data, on distances from existing wells and on a successful wildcatter's intuition - is gushing 500 barrels of crude a day. ''The major oil companies would not have drilled this prospect; it's a low-relief structure that is not easy to identify,'' he said with undisguised glee.
Nor is Mr. Blair alone in bringing new energy and renewed economic life out of the ground on this ancient seabed, known as the Permian Basin, which is one of the richest oil fields in the world. 
The number of drilling rigs in operation here has increased by about 25 percent, to 123, during the last year. Nationally the rig count is up to 940, and analysts expect the number to hit 1,000 before 1990 has ended.
 
A Glum Mood
 But ''undisguised glee'' is not the correct phrase to describe the general mood in Midland, a city of 95,000 and the economic center of the area. ''We're surviving,'' is the way L. Decker Dawson, president of the Midland-based Dawson Geophysical Company, which does seismic testing, puts it.
The long, lean years of depressed prices in the 1980's have caused experts in the American oil business, some 25 percent of which is generated in West Texas, to believe that the country's capacity to produce another boom or respond fully to another cutoff of imports has been seriously weakened. It is crucial, they say, that several factors be successfully combined if the nation is to regain a substantial measure of that capacity. More favorable prices and an expanded labor pool are two, but new and improved equipment, new technology, a more coherent national energy policy - these are regarded as essential as well.
In 1979, when the the collapse of Iran's oil industry sent prices soaring, there appeared to be no limit to oil prosperity. Within the three years, the number of rigs in operation in the United States soared to 4,500 from about 2,000, and the price-per-barrel topped $30. But during those heady times, many operators jumped into risky deals that depended on anticipated prices of $40 or $50 a barrel. Nirvana never came. The price peaked in 1981 and began to slide in 1982, when it fell to as low as $10, and those deals, along with a good many businesses, collapsed. By 1986, the number of rigs in operation dropped to 700 before starting slowly to rise again.
Now, prices appear to have stabilized at about $18, which has fired up the resurgence in drilling.
In fact, the drilling boom of the early 80's only temporarily reversed a long-term decline in domestic production. Since then, the nation has grown increasingly dependent on foreign oil. The United States now imports about eight million barrels a day, or about 48 percent of the 16.5 million barrels being consumed. And the increase in exploration that has been occurring during the past year has not significantly changed that trend.
Yet vast amounts of oil are still believed to lie here beneath the parched Texas ground and in other regions of the country.
Getting enough oil up and out to increase American production dramatically is another matter. For one thing, it is being found in smaller and smaller pools, and, for another, any large-scale increase would require workers and rigs and materials that are simply no longer available. Oil workers discouraged by long periods of unemployment have drifted off to other parts of the country, since there are few blue-collar jobs outside the oil industry here. Indeed, unemployment in the Midland area is a modest 5.1 percent. ''The people who are still here are working,'' said William Kerr, a Midland attorney. ''The surplus labor has departed.''
Similarly, many professionals have left the field. The work is very specialized. ''People were forced to go into other fields to find work,'' Mr. Dawson said. The Society of Exploration Geophysicists, for example, has seen its membership shrink 25 percent, from a peak of 20,000.
Idled drilling rigs have been cannibalized for parts by drilling contractors who could not afford to buy new parts. And drilling pipe, which has a relatively short operating life, could quickly become a critical bottleneck during a new oil boom, since little new pipe has been produced for years.
 
Danger on the Rigs
 ''I've got 15 rigs operating now out of a fleet of 56, compared to an average of eight in fiscal 1989,'' said Joe G. Roper, president of TMBR-Sharp Drilling Inc. in Midland. ''But if I got an order for 10 more rigs tomorrow, I could not staff them. It would take years to do that.'' Drilling is inherently dangerous, involving heavy, fast moving equipment. If inexperienced people were put to work on the rigs, he said, accidents would be inevitable, which could elevate insurance rates. ''You have to take it up real slow,'' he said. The reduction in capacity is not restricted to the Permian Basin. C. Paul Hilliard, chairman of the Independent Petroleum Association of America said, ''A lot of service and supply companies died in 1986 and 1987,'' when the price of oil bottomed out at $10. In Lafayette, La., where his Badger Oil and Gas Ltd. is located, there were once as many as 1,029 companies serving and supplying oil explorers. By 1987, the number was down to 372.
Oilmen have gotten little guidance from the Federal Government over the last decade. Officials in Washington do now say, however, that they recognize the dangers of increased dependence on imports. ''It is not acceptable to have substantial disinvestment in oil and gas,'' Linda Stuntz, deputy under secretary for policy, planning and analysis at the Department of Energy, said in an interview. She said the department is preparing an energy strategy which is to be submitted to President Bush before the end of the year.
But as Jack Blair is demonstrating, there is still oil to be found and money to be made in the oil patch.
At 500 barrels and $18 a barrel, his well is producing $9,000 in revenue each day it operates. That means the approximate $900,000 cost of drilling it will be recovered in a little over three months. After that it will produce a steady stream of income for Mr. Blair, who has a 25 percent interest, and his major partners, the Moncrief family of Ft. Worth.
 
Born Into the Business
 He is, in fact, a classic Texas wildcatter, with an expansive manner and instinctive approach to drilling, the entrepeneur who learned the oil business by growing up in it. He does not, like some, put longhorns on his Cadillac. His Fleetwood is equipped with a sophisticated radar detector so that he can drive fast enough to cover the long distances common here without running afoul of the police.
''I was born into the business up north in Electra'' near the Oklahoma border, he said. ''My father was a driller and oil producer.'' Now two of his sons work with him, one as a land man, or leasing agent, and another as a field supervisor.
The original idea for his new well, designated the No. 1 Weatherby, came from an independent geologist, George Ulmo. His track record with Mr. Blair is good. ''I've dug the last four deals he brought me and three of them produced. I like that,'' Mr. Blair said.
After persuading his investors to sign up for the deal, Mr. Blair arranged for Mr. Roper's company to drill the hole and for such things as drilling mud to lubricate the drill and flush out rock chips. Most of the contractors are people he has been doing business with for more than 30 years. Indeed, TMBR-Sharp is an equity investor in the well, which is why the drilling cost is lower than the $1.2 million industry standard.
''We tend to use old friends who have stuck with us,'' Mr. Blair said. ''I had some trouble paying bills for awhile and they said, 'Pay us when you can.' ''
In times past the well would have been a gusher spewing out-of-control for days, because of the intense pressure of the gas associated with the oil. With modern technology the underground pressure is containable, and the only indication is a gauge on top of the wellhead: The oil is emerging from the ground now at an unusually high 700 pounds per square inch of pressure. Mr. Blair , who is 64 years old and has operated as an independent wildcatter here since 1987, said he survived the depression of the late 80's because he had relied largely on equity investors, not borrowed money. ''I've had the same investors for years; they're good oil people. We never stopped working.'' But he had to shrink his business, closing offices in Oklahoma, southern and eastern Texas. And he had to sell his airplane, a twin-engined Merlin. ''The first thing an oil man does when he makes some money is buy a ranch and an airplane,'' Mr. Blair said. ''A few more wells like this and I'll be looking at them again.''
Indeed, he is now busy drilling another well near No. l Weatherby to gauge the size of the field, which is down more than 12,000 feet. He estimates that each well will produce 600,000 to 700,000 barrels of recoverable oil, but at this point he not sure how many wells the field will support.
 
Expansion Unlikely
 Historically, independent oil companies run by wildcatters have drilled 80 percent of the wells in the United States and produce about 41 percent of all the crude oil in the lower 48 states. They have for the most part found the smaller fields, whereas the major oil companies have focused on massive projects like Alaska and those off the seacoasts.
But there appears to be no great optimism that there will be enough expansion any time soon or enough massive projects in the works to lessen United States dependence on world markets. Too many of the dominating players in those markets are in the Middle East, where reserves are abundant and production can be adjusted quickly. ''There is no doubt that producers in the United States are price-takers, not price-makers,'' said John Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
Most forecasters, in fact, believe the United States will rely more on imports rather than less, that American production will steadily decline at least over the next five years even as consumption increases.
But as supplies tighten, prices are expected to rise, with some industry leaders such as Lodwrick M. Cook of Arco predicting $25 a barrel oil by the mid-90's.
An increase in oil prices could, in turn, begin to accelerate the drilling resurgence and reduce dependence on imports. ''If prices went up four or five dollars a barrel, it might stop or slow down the decline in domestic production,'' Mr. Lichtblau said.
A key factor in whether the United States can fully revitalize its oil industry is whether needed capital will be available. Locally owned banks collapsed at the end of the boom and the out-of-state institutions that took them over have greatly tightened lending standards.
 
Little Interest in Loans
 Samuel J. Atkins, whose North Carolina-based bank took over the remains of the First National Bank of Midland, said it is interested in increasing its energy loans to operators who have collateral in the form of producing properties. But many oilmen, who saw debt-laden competitors dragged into bankruptcy, say they are not interested in loans. ''I could care less if all the banks in the United States close their energy loan departments,'' said Mr. Hilliard of the wildcatter's association.
Midland oilmen say investors will return as economic conditions stabilize and operators like Mr. Blair demonstrate they still have, as the expression goes here, ''a good nose for oil.'' Another key is new or newly applied technology. Some oil explorers are borrowing techniques developed for offshore operations to recover oil from fields once thought to be exhausted. In addition to drilling vertically through the earth, they are drilling horizontally in an effort to tap fissures in the ground. Or more precisely, the drillers are boring down vertically from 6 to 10,000 feet, then a below-ground motor bends the bit, a little at a time. Gradually, degree by degree, the bit turns until it is horizontal. And then it can go on for up to a mile.
Thomas A. Sullivan, an offical of the Oryx Energy Company in Dallas, the nation's largest independent exploration company, said horizontal drilling is possible when drilling through a series of verticle geologic structures. ''You can tap more of them by drilling horizontally,'' he said.
Horizontal drilling appears to have revived the Pearsall field in southern Texas. This area was first drilled in the 30's, and many of the remaining wells were only producing a few barrels of oil a day. Oryx is now producing 12,000 barrels a day from 25 horizontal wells, according to Mr. Sullivan. Other companies have reported successes as well, and other regions, including formations in the Permian Basin, are being evaluated.
Horizontal drilling was developed for offshore fields because the enormous cost of establishing platforms in the open sea required that many wells be drilled from a common place.
The consensus here is that the old Texas ''elephant fields'' - those with 20 million to 100 million barrels or more of reserves - have largely been found. In fact, most of the major oil companies have moved or are planning to move their exploration operations out of the basin to concentrate on exploration in coastal waters and foreign locations.
That does not mean that they are giving up on the region. They expect existing wells to continue producing well into the next century, and, to help make that happen, they are injecting water and gas back into the ground. The injected materials penetrate the porous rocks containing the oil and force it toward well bottoms.
''The casing in some of these wells will corrode away before they are exhausted,'' said Richard Masterson, a geologist.
It does seem clear that all these factors, the persistent entrepreneurial spirit of the Texas wildcatter, the effective workings of supply and demand on price structures, new technology, new government policy - all will be needed if the nation's capacity to drill for the oil it has and wants.
The Lord, in other words, will need some help.
 
NOT TO THE RIG BORN
H. H. (TRIPP) WOMMACK 3d is the new-style, unswashbuckling, Texas oilman.
 He did not grow up in the oil fields in the mode of the classic West Texan wildcatter. He hails from the east - eastern Texas, that is - is still boyish looking and came to the oilfields only after earning a law degree.
But he has acquired six million barrels of oil reserves in the region - buying wells from operators in financial trouble.
''We do not buy from voluntary or willing sellers,'' he said. ''We buy from distressed individuals who have to sell.''
Mr. Wommack's company, Southwest Royalties Inc., operates more than 700 wells and has a nonoperating interest in an additional 4,000. Mr. Wommack said the slump in the oil patch provided his company with a one-time opportunity to buy producing properties. He does some drilling as well, but almost always in locations adjacent to producing properties.
The approach seems to be working. Southwest Royalties has grown from three people in 1983 to 58 now. With oil prices firming and drilling beginning to increase, he expects distress sales to cease within a year. Then he will have to drill more, and says: ''There are some places here where it is hard to drill a dry hole.''
 
HIGH HOPES FOR NATURAL GAS
Some wildcatters are hoping a revised Clean Air Act, now being considered by Congress, will produce increased demand and higher prices for natural gas.
Natural gas burns much more cleanly than other fossil fuels like gasoline, diesel and coal. So gas is increasingly favored by electric power plants that can switch fuels.
Natural gas can also power cars and trucks designed for gasoline, with modest modification, although the strong, large fuel tanks required can intrude on trunk space. If the new air pollution law mandates alternatives to gasoline in areas with particularly dirty air, natural gas may be one of the alternates.
''Oil consumption is not rising but the Clean Air Act may help in the gas market,'' said C. Paul Hilliard, president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America.
According to the American Petroleum Institute, the number of gas wells successfully drilled has been steadily rising in recent years andthe total is roughly equal to the number of oil wells complete.
As recently as 1985, three times as many oil wells were brought in as natural gas.

LENGTH: 1681 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
A New Game at Trump's Tables
 
Donald J. Trump had better hope he can bargain better than he can run a casino. He failed on Friday to pay about $40 million due on ''junk bonds'' and another $30 million on bank loans that financed his purchase of Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. In 1987, he called it ''one of the most successful hotel-casinos in the world.'' By Friday, it was a money-loser subject to being taken from Mr. Trump's control. But he might just wriggle free of his problems for the time being. He has 10 days of grace after missing his payments. And the bankers were said to be close to reaching an agreement with him. In return for a stake in his properties, they would give him more time and money while he tries to sell off some possessions. Mr. Trump must be well aware that the bankers have every reason to keep him afloat. Even the bondholders are better secured than some of the bankers. And who's to blame Mr. Trump for a few delays in sending a check? After all, he's celebrating his 44th birthday late, too. He marked the actual date on Thursday by having lunch at his Plaza Hotel with his wife, Ivana. The real bash waited for Saturday, at Trump's Castle. 
 
Boeing's Burgeoning Backlog
 
How to reduce the trade deficit: Figure out a way for Boeing to work off its entire, $80 billion-plus backlog this year. Boeing jets are one American product that foreigners can't get enough of. Korea Air Lines agreed last week to buy 23 long-range 747-400's for almost $5 billion, but delivery won't begin until 1994. The company recently announced sales to China and Japan totaling more than $5 billion. Peter L. Aseritis, an analyst at First Boston, calls Boeing ''far and away America's largest industrial exporter.'' Mr. Aseritis worries that the stock - up almost 50 percent last year and 50 percent so far this year - is outrunning its immediate earnings prospects. But the unanticipated size of the Korean and Chinese orders has prompted him to raise his estimate of Boeing's year-end backlog by $10 billion, to a total of $100 billion.
 
Time-Warner Adjusts Sights
 
TV-Cable Week cost $45 million before it closed. Picture Week, $30 million. Time Warner's latest new magazine, Entertainment Weekly, has cost about $40 million so far. It remains open, but with a new direction and, last week, a new managing editor. Jeff A. Jarvis, who favored tough reviews and highbrow subjects - one cover featured books about Vietnam - quit last week. His replacement, James W. Seymore, has been the executive editor of People magazine, a wildly successful Time Warner publication. The new formula at Entertainment Weekly is already evident: More celebrities. The more obvious, the better. Madonna, for instance. But with advertising off for most magazines, some analysts still wonder whether Entertainment Weekly will have a long run.
 
S.&L.-Based Indictment
 
As Don R. Dixon once explained in a California bankruptcy court, he did indeed spend funds from the Vernon Savings and Loan Association on a Ferrari. But it was no luxury car. ''It was a family Ferrari,'' he said, with four seats and an automatic transmission. Now the Government also wants him to explain how Vernon's deposits paid for political contributions, the rent on a California beach house and companions for Vernon executives and their guests. Mr. Dixon, Vernon's principal owner, was indicted by a Federal grand jury last week on 38 criminal charges. Examiners have said that the rescue of his failed Texas savings institution will probably cost taxpayers $1.3 billion.
 
In Brief
 
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company has dispatched an ambulance for RJR Holdings Inc. and its sickly bonds. The Kohlberg, Kravis medics raised $1.7 billion for an emergencycash infusion. As news of the planned treatment came out on Thursday, the company's ''junk bonds'' revived, with two issues each gaining $7 per $100 of face value. Operations and asset sales have been going fine at RJR - the largest leveraged buyout in history - but the junk bond market has been ailing.
 
*
 
Martin A. Siegel, a former takeover expert at Kidder Peabody, was sentenced Friday to two months in prison and five years of probation on insider trading charges.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Big Board - 24-Hour Day . . .
 
The city that never sleeps might have a stock exchange that doesn't either. The New York Stock Exchange has decided to hustle to keep from losing more business to Tokyo and London. A plan announced by John J. Phelan Jr., the exchange's chairman, would bring about 24-hour trading over several years and in several stages. Later this year, two brief trading sessions will be added after the normal hours. The next phases would involve stock auctions during the night, then rudimentary night trading, then continuous all-night action. The subplot here might be titled ''The Twilight of the Specialists.'' The specialists - princely floor traders who now handle every transaction - might be reduced to quaint figures showing up for six-and-a-half hours a day while computers conduct the exchange's business for the other 17 1/2. The specialists were among those blamed for the chaos when the market crashed in 1987.
 
. . . And Trading Halts Too?
 
When the game gets tough, the New York Stock Exchange might well call a time-out. A panel it created after stocks plunged last October recommended trading halts timed in proportion to the market's volatility. After a 50-point rise or fall, index arbitrage would be virtually banned; 100 points, and all trading of stocks, futures and options would cease for an hour; 400 points, and the markets would close for the day. Several Wall Street executives said the restrictions would probably prevent another crash. But some said that investors would simply switch their trades to foreign exchanges - even as the New York market is planning to stay open at night to recapture the trading it has already lost.
 
Cheaper by the West
 
''City of spires and masts,'' Walt Whitman called New York more than a century ago. ''The countless masts, the white shore-steamers, the lighters, the ferry-boats, the black sea-steamers well-model'd.'' These days, Whitman might be more in awe of Los Angeles, which overtook New York last year as the nation's busiest port. Los Angeles handled cargo worth $55 billion; New York, $49 billion. New York's port has suffered from high handling costs, a lack of manufacturing exports, growth along the Pacific Rim and traffic that delays trucks heading to the ships. Even cargo bound for the Eastern United States often bypasses New York. Asian shippers can find it cheaper to unload their goods onto trains in Los Angeles than to go through the Panama Canal and New York.
 
The Trouble With Trade
 
The nation's trade deficit shrank to $6.9 billion in April from $8.4 billion the month before - but for the wrong reasons. The figures probably say more about the weakness of America's economy than the competitiveness of its producers. Exports fell 3.5 percent to $32.3 billion, but imports fell even more, 6.2 percent to $39.3 billion. Lincoln F. Anderson, an economist at Bear, Stearns, called the lower exports ''disappointing'' but said that the dollar's weakness against European currencies might improve exports in the coming months.
 
Inflation Watch
 
Inflation is back down below the irksome levels of the first quarter. Producer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent and consumer prices two-tenths of 1 percent in May - in line with expectations but still pleasing to most economists. Though the figures reflect a slowing economy, said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company, a healthy six-tenths of 1 percent rise in industrial production last month is likely to keep the Federal Reserve from easing interest rates. ''For manufacturing, the worst is over,'' he said. ''If the Fed can hang on, and the economy doesn't cave in, the Fed's strategy of bringing inflation down ought to work.''
 
In Brief
 
A Federal appeals court threw out the Securities and Exchange Commission's ''one share one vote'' rule that has kept companies from countering hostile takeovers by issuing shares with extra voting rights.
 
*
 
Retail sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the third straight monthly decline.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Bush and Salinas Reverse Roles
 
The United States has long urged Mexico to join in a free-trade market ''from the Yukon to the Yucatan.'' Mexico, fearful of economic domination, has long resisted. But last week, Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari called on President Bush to say that a trade agreement was the only way to compete with economic blocs coalescing in Europe and the Far East. President Bush responded coolly, endorsing the concept but initiating no talks. Prof. Robert A. Pastor of Emory University, a former director of Latin American affairs for the National Security Council, called it another of the ironic reversals so frequent in the history of relations between Mexico and the United States. ''The U.S. and Mexican presidents have exchanged roles,'' he said. ''Now it's the Mexican President who's eager to move rapidly, and the U.S. President who's dragging his feet.'' To help overcome likely opposition from Democrats and organized labor, Professor Pastor recommends that President Bush quickly appoint a prominent Democrat to negotiate a pact. Otherwise, he said, the foes of free trade in Mexico might regain their sway.
 
In Brief
 
Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev got a strong lesson in democracy last week. The Soviet Parliament soundly rejected his plan to triple bread prices this summer. But the lawmakers - and lawmakers they now are - did give Mr. Gorbachev authority to break up Government monopolies and stimulate private enterprise.
 
*
 
France's finance minister blocked a bid by Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier, to take full control of Pathe-Cinema, a leading French film company.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Losing Steam at the Close

 BODY:
The dollar fizzled as the week ended. It closed slightly lower against the German mark, after managing to trade at times above the key level of 1.70 marks to the dollar. Dealers said the dollar still appeared to be locked in a fairly narrow band of trading, despite the release of a slew of economic indicators in the United States. The reason: The dealers were doubtful that the latest batch of data would spur a change in the Federal Reserve's credit stance. On Friday, a large dollar sale in Europe, rumored to be by West Germany's Bundesbank, slowed whatever momentum the currency had gained from the positive economic data released early in the day. At the close of trading, the dollar finished the week lower against all major currencies.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
A Program That Harnesses Other Software's Strengths

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
It has been less than a month since the Microsoft Corporation introduced Windows 3.0, a major upgrade of its software ''environment'' that overlays the DOS operating system with a quilt of windows, graphical symbols and English-language command menus. Even as Windows 3.0 is being hailed as a breakthrough for office personal computers, however, the Hewlett-Packard Company has come up with something that promises to be even better.
Hewlett-Packard's New Wave 3.0 is another upgraded environment; it wraps around Windows 3.0 just as Windows 3.0 wraps around DOS. It is far more than just another graphical slipcover, however. New Wave has features that Windows does not, including automated ''agents'' that can be created to perform office tasks, extensive help features and computer-based training lessons, and a remarkable facility for getting many different software applications to work together as if they had been built that way. 
''New Wave is going to make the executive's life so much easier,'' said Jim Hammons, vice president of the Sierra Group, a computer industry research company in Tempe, Ariz.
If New Wave can gain wide acceptance, the day may come when executives can send compound documents containing text, spreadsheet tables, charts and graphics, voice annotations and even full-motion video to any other machine on the network, whether the other machines are PC's, minicomputers or mainframes, and whether they run DOS and Windows, or the OS/2 or Unix operating systems. Hewlett-Packard officials said the company is committed to developing OS/2 and Unix versions of New Wave.
''New Wave is an integration tool,'' said John C. McCarthy, director of professional systems research at Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. ''Instead of trying to find or develop one program to handle all of the tasks in an office, with New Wave you can link the best features of what are essentially stand-alone programs from different companies, like Lotus 1-2-3 and Ami Professional, and harness them to meet your needs.''
Because New Wave requires Windows, it inherits all the advantages that Windows has over DOS. These include ease of use, a consistent user interface, adherence to industry standards, better management of the computer's memory, better network support and the ability to have different programs running at the same time in separate windows on the computer screen. New Wave's equipment requirements are similar to those of Windows 3.0 - a fast 80286 or 80386 processor, a hard disk and several megabytes of random access memory.
Like Windows, New Wave can work with virtually any DOS application and any Windows application. But just as Windows 3.0 users must have Windows 3.0 applications in order to take full advantage of the Windows system, New Wave users will want to buy New Wave-specific versions of their favorite programs. So far, only a handful of New Wave or Windows programs are available.
New Wave, which will cost $195 when it becomes available in August, provides a somewhat better graphical interface than Windows 3.0. With Windows the user still has to have some grasp of the way DOS handles computer files; with New Wave, DOS seems to disappear entirely. Gone are the odious DOS directories, paths and file types. On a deeper level, New Wave is significant because it uses a programming technique called object orientation. Object orientation allows software developers to re-use parts of programs that are valuable and to add new programs and features incrementally. Using objects as building blocks, software can be developed relatively easily, quickly and inexpensively; it can be fixed and upgraded more easily, and it can be re-used, said Christopher M. Stone, president of the Object Management Group, an international consortium of 70 computer makers, software developers and corporate computer users.
An object, in the computer sense, is a combination of executable computer code and a set of data. In a conventional computer system, the two are separate. For example, in Windows there might be an icon representing a word processing program, and a separate icon for a document that was created with the application. The document is really just a text file that is essentially lifeless without the application. To the New Wave user, the document is an object that contains not just the data, but also a dynamic hook to the application that created it. When the user clicks the mouse on the document icon, New Wave automatically begins the application.
Windows and Apple Macintosh computers can do that but only in a limited way, by looking for something called a file extension and matching the extension with the application that created it. But they can do it only with a single application. In the era of multiple media, business documents are increasingly composed of parts from several applications. A monthly sales report might include text from a word processor, a table from a spreadsheet, a list of names from a data base, a chart from a graphics program and so forth. With object orientation, the action of the creating application or multiple applications is bound to the data. No matter where the document object goes on the network, it will have a link back to its applications. This shields a user from the tedium of loading applications, exiting a program and loading another.
The ''agent'' function allows the user to perform an operation once, record it and then activate the agent whenever it is needed. For example, an executive might want the agent to gather and assemble the sales report described above and send it automatically to a list of senior officers by electronic mail. New Wave also allows the creation of ''hot links'' among objects, so that if the sales figures in the spreadsheet are changed, those changes will be reflected automatically in the chart in the sales report. As long as all objects adhere to common standards, it makes no difference which brand of hardware or software is used. As a result, parts of many different applications can be cut, pasted, swapped and linked to one another. Such flexibility is impossible under most systems.
Other companies have announced their intention to develop programs with similar abilities. The Digital Equipment Corporation's All-in-1 is closest to reality, but it runs only on Digital machines. The International Business Machines Corporation calls its system Office Vision, and it is still just a vision. Microsoft huffs that it will someday add New Wave-like features directly to Windows.
New Wave, meanwhile, has been endorsed by scores of hardware and software companies, giving it a good chance of emerging as a standard. But that will depend on Hewlett-Packard's marketing.
''If they really want to establish this as a standard, they have to sell it,'' said Mr. McCarthy of Forrester Research. ''It's great technology. The question is, can they effectively market it?''

HEADLINE: Switchbacks Make a Lively Ride for a New I.B.M. Line

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The market for the AS/400 family of minicomputers introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation two years ago hasn't exactly developed in a straight line.
The original target market was small companies ready to upgrade their existing systems. The response was enthusiastic - for a while. But many small companies have decided to make do with what they have or turn instead to a slew of less expensive alternatives, including powerful personal computers that offer many of the same features as the AS/400.
While sales at the lower end of the new midrange line have stalled, however, the more expensive models have found unexpected popularity among bigger companies. Some have even gone so far as to use the AS/400 to join the sweeping industry trend away from stand-alone mainframe systems - including, of course, those made by I.B.M. 
Big I.B.M. customers like Georgia-Pacific, Pepperidge Farms, Arco Chemical and Playboy have all jettisoned their aging mainframes in favor of high-end AS/400 machines. Others, including Harley-Davidson, are in the process of making the switch. And in still another twist, the AS/400 is now competing on the high end with a new family of computers - the Risc System/6000 - that is cheaper to buy and use, and much more easily linked to non-I.B.M. machines, a very appealing feature to big customers. The maker of the new system? Why, I.B.M., of course. The spectacle of its products snatching business from one another - particularly from mainframes, the traditional source of the company's profitability - is just the latest example of I.B.M.'s difficulties in trying to be all things to all customers.
But the marketing surprises wrought by the AS/400 also underscore the dramatic technological changes buffeting the computer industry as a whole. The fast pace of change can turn long-range strategy into sand, even for a company the size of I.B.M.
For the AS/400, that has meant a roller-coaster ride for sales and earnings as one marketing surprise has run into another. Last year's strong results turned into a disappointing first quarter in 1990, for example.
Overall, the AS/400 ''continues to be extremely successful,'' said David Andrews, an AS/400 consultant and an industry analyst at ADM Inc. in Cheshire, Conn. Overseas markets, notably Europe, have been particularly strong. ''But,'' Mr. Andrews added, ''its success is not what I.B.M. originally thought it would be.''
For its part, I.B.M. appears unflustered. Whether it misjudged the American market or not, the company expresses confidence that the line will do well, given its strong capabilities in the business marketplace.
''When you look at the business market, customers don't care'' about technical issues, said Bob E. Dies, assistant general manager for the AS/400. ''They want a business solution; they don't want headaches.''
What's more, I.B.M. says it is not convinced that it misjudged the market all that badly. Business on the low end will pick up as more companies need the kind of solutions that the AS/400 offers, the company argues. And I.B.M. executives, including Mark J. Ryan, director of marketing support for the AS/400 line, play down the extent to which the AS/400 has cut into mainframe sales.
When the AS/400 was introduced with great fanfare in April 1988, I.B.M. touted it as a natural upgrade for the more than 350,000 System/3X minicomputers users worldwide. For years, the company's System/3X had ruled the sleepy domain of small businesses, performing the basic applications for payroll and general ledger, manufacturing and distribution.
When it introduced the AS/400, I.B.M. ran television and print ads targeted directly at the 3X user. The ads, featuring Alan Alda, portrayed the AS/400 as the perfect system for a small business to grow up with. Because so many 3X customers were waiting to upgrade, the introduction of the AS/400 was one of the most successful ever for I.B.M. The company does not break out figures for its product lines, but researchers at ADM estimate that the line generated more than $5 billion in revenue in less than six months.
By the end of 1989, the explosive market for the AS/400 began to slow as fewer 3X users traded up. At the same time, though, large American companies were developing increasing interest in the AS/400.
Some were interested simply in downsizing from mainframes and running the same software programs more economically on smaller machines. Others saw the AS/400 as the vehicle for creating so-called distributed computing networks. These networks spread computing power to sophisticated desktop machines - work stations or personal computers - that can store and retrieve files from specially designed server computers like the AS/400. These machines, known as file servers, are the rage right now because the network approach is cheaper than mainframes yet offers more flexibility and responsiveness in handling commercial applications.
''During 1989, the smaller models of the AS/400 didn't come close to meeting I.B.M.'s expectations,'' said ADM's Mr. Andrews. ''The year was a disaster in terms of unit sales. On the other hand, it was a great year in terms of revenue and profit because sales of the large models blew through the roof.''
According to ADM, I.B.M.'s Application Business System product line, which includes the AS/400, had revenues of $13 billion last year and profits of more than $1 billion. This year, that is expected to grow to $15 billion in sales and $1.5 billion in profits.
But while sales of the AS/400 have remained strong in Europe, the rate of growth has sharply slowed this year in the United States, indicating possible softness not only on the low end but also on the high end.
And ''the AS/400 stood out as one of the weak performers on I.B.M.'s list during the first quarter,'' said Stephen Cohen, an analyst who follows the computer maker for the Soundview Financial Group. (I.B.M. is forecasting a return to strong growth in the second quarter.) Despite all the surprises, many industry analysts say the AS/400 family is assured of a lasting future. The unanswered question is whether the mid-range line will thrive or merely survive.
So far, only a little more than 15 percent of System/3X users have traded up. Increasingly, 3X users are attracted to other alternatives. For example, powerful personal computers, with a wide range of application software, are now selling for a fraction of the cost of the AS/400 line, which ranges in price from $19,000 to $1 million. And PC network companies such as Novell Inc. and the 3Com Corporation have grown rapidly by developing markets for PC networks that don't require minicomputers.
That means a lot is riding on how well the AS/400 performs on the high end. But it is in just that niche that the AS/400 must do battle with the Risc System/6000, which also can function as a network file server.
What makes the RS/6000 particularly attractive is that it runs I.B.M.'s version of the Unix operating system, called AIX. That allows it to communicate easily with machines made by other companies. By contrast, the AS/400 is designed to communicate only with other I.B.M. machines, limiting its flexibility for big customers.
Nonetheless, the AS/400 has several powerful selling points of its own. Each AS/400 has its own built-in database program, which is important to companies that need to connect dozens of offices.
''The attraction for us is in terms of our distributors and dealers,'' said Richard L. Kolbe, director of management information systems for Harley-Davidson, the Milwaukee-based motorcycle maker which is in the process of shifting from I.B.M. mainframes to the AS/400. ''We didn't make the decision on the basis of cost savings.''
The AS/400 makes more software applications available to Harley, Mr. Kolbe said, and it ''handshakes nicely with the PS/2 personal computer in a network.''
In the face of the challenges to its mainframes, I.B.M. has switched its marketing strategy for the giant machines. Conceding that mainframes may have outlived their usefulness as a stand-alone system, company executives say they are ideally suited to function as the file-server for networks.
But mainframes may be wrong even for that task, say a growing number of computer managers. They are too costly to purchase, they say, and they require extensive support personnel.
''We saw an opportunity to reduce our operating costs in the data center,'' said Paul Pavloff, senior director for information resources at Georgia-Pacific's building products division. The division has purchased 25 AS/400 machines and is preparing to discard its last I.B.M. mainframe system. (See box.) Is I.B.M. coping well with all the twists and turns that the AS/400 has taken? Mr. Pavloff thinks that the computer maker is catching on and will soon learn to market the AS/400 to large as well as small customers.
''I don't think that I.B.M. ever truly understood what we were doing with their computers,'' he said. ''We opened their eyes.''
 
Decentralizing The Data Center
The building products division of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation is one of a growing number of big I.B.M. customers to dramatically transform the way they are using the company's computers.
The Atlanta-based division has spent the past two years dismantling its mainframe data center and distributing computer power throughout the company, bringing it closer to actual users.
To make the shift, the division now has about 25 of the most powerful AS/400 computers at its headquarters and hundreds of personal computers - and some leftover I.B.M. System/3X minicomputers - in the field. The result is a network that links the division and corporate headquarters to the company's mills and other businesses around the country.
The network controls everything from order entry and invoicing to financial consolidation and electronic mail. By dismantling the corporate data center, the division has been able to eliminate operations personnel and technical support workers.
''The concept is to distribute and simplify the environment,'' said Paul Pavloff, the division's senior director for information resources. ''We believe it represents a better cost structure.'' The shift is a big one for I.B.M. customers like Georgia-Pacific, which traditionally have used so-called hierarchical computer systems. Under this structure, desktop terminals share the computing power of a mainframe.
By abandoning its mainframes, Mr. Pavloff said, Georgia-Pacific is trying ''to duplicate in the I.B.M. environment what companies like Digital now have - a peer-to-peer network computing environment.''
While this shift was once considered a radical departure, it is becoming more and more popular. Indeed, Mr. Pavloff says he regularly gets calls from other companies asking how he convinced his management to move toward network computing.
''Centralized data centers are not real popular in decentralized companies,'' he said. ''The users always feel that the costs are too high and they have no control.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Incentives for Improving Health Care

BYLINE: By G. ROBERT O'BRIEN; G. Robert O'Brien is president of Cigna Employee Benefits Companies.

 BODY:
I believe that business and government - working together - can maintain or improve the quality of the country's health care system, while making it more accessible to many uninsured Americans. And, most important, America could very substantially reduce the cost of universal health care coverage.
First, employers can make the health care system more cost-effective without sacrificing quality by expanding the use of improved management techniques. To do this, participants in the delivery of health care - employers, insurers, doctors and hospitals - are turning to integrated managed care programs to attack cost inflation and improve efficiency. 
These programs deliver quality care at lower cost by using a network of selected doctors, hospitals and other providers that are under contract and agree to meet standards of quality and cost. At the heart of the provider network is a primary care physician, who does what general practitioners of traditional family medicine were trained to do: diagnose and direct treatment and build strong relationships with patients and families.
A second major step would be to improve the efficiency of Medicare and Medicaid. America's Medicaid program for poor citizens is grossly underfunded. And a recent Congressional Budget Office report forecasts a 31-fold increase during the next 30 years in Medicare expenditures - a jump from $101 billion this year to more than $3 trillion in the year 2020.
Medicare and Medicaid have employed utilization review techniques for a number of years. So why not take the next step and adopt the financial incentives and case management techniques that work in the private sector?
Government should also offer tax and other incentives, for example, to encourage employers to provide health and retirement benefits. Insurers could change underwriting and rating practices - as the industry recently proposed - to make health insurance more affordable for the small employer. Programs that make affordable health plans more readily available to small employers and uninsured workers are critical. We can make our health care system more accessible to those now having difficulty - using the genius of competition and free-market incentives, not coercive government controls.
Until we build a stronger public-private partnership, Corporate America must continue to attack health care cost escalation vigorously and imaginatively. If recent history - both home and abroad - has taught us anything at all, it is that large, bureaucratically organized, carefully planned ''solutions'' to economic problems, like health care, do not work very well.
