HEADLINE: The Reverse LBO Survives, but in a Downsized Model

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The tumult in the equities market and the wreckage of the 1980's ''junk bond'' market has brought many of the nation's financial wizards back down closer to earth. Their leveraged buyouts are no longer flying as high as they were - and selling them back to the public is much harder than it was.
In their heyday, the leveraged buyers reaped the rewards of taking companies private with borrowed money, restructuring them and then cashing in by rapidly selling the indebted companies back to the public.
But the market's appetite for debt-laden companies has largely evaporated, and many of the specialists who have acquired large hunks of corporate America are either very quietly testing the breeze or just waiting for a more receptive climate. According to IDD Information Services of New York City, the number of reverse LBO's coming to market has fallen sharply over the past three years. In 1987, there were 45, with a total value of $2.5 billion. Last year, there were 10, worth $746 million. The pace has picked up recently, but the average reverse LBO is much smaller these days - the 13 deals done so far this year have raised just $709 million - and most analysts expect that trend to continue. 
''The equity market is not receptive to these leveraged companies right now,'' said Frank V. Colombo, a senior vice president and director of high-yield research at Dillon Read & Company.
Some LBO's are doing well and have no need to refinance, he said. For them, attempting to get money out of the existing equity market now would probably mean throwing away possible income. The price at which the stock would sell would probably fall below the company's valuation.
As for the buyout companies that are in trouble, Mr. Colombo said, and most analysts agree, they could not raise money in the equity markets if they wanted to.
''Back in the boom times, it was possible to borrow carloads of money and pay enormous prices for assets with the confidence that those assets would appreciate because someone else could borrow even more to pay to buy them,'' said James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a market newsletter.
''The bottom line is that too much money was paid to take some of these companies private and you can't replace all of that with equity,'' added Joseph F. Stivaletti, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''If in the eyes of the investment community that company is not worth as much as was paid for it a few years ago, you're stuck.''
Indeed, there is now often a gulf between the public valuation of these companies and the kind of returns the insiders want on their investment.
Perhaps the most dramatic recent example of a reverse LBO plan that backfired was an offering by TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc. It had to be scrapped because potential outside investors were far from pleased with the terms.
Reginald F. Lewis, chairman and chief executive, had acquired TLC Beatrice Foods, an international food company, in a 1987 LBO for about $1 billion. At the time, his record was sparkling from the resale of the McCall Pattern Company, which he had bought in 1984 for $24.5 million - all but $1 million of it borrowed - and sold two years later for $63 million.
After reducing much of the Beatrice acquisition debt by selling off most of the company's non-European divisions, Mr. Lewis moved last fall to sell some stock to the public. He wanted to raise $180 million for creditors and insiders - owners of the privately held stock - who would sell some of their shares. The company offered 18.5 million new shares for $9 to $10.50 each, or nearly 30 times earnings per share.
But critics contended that the company's cash flow was questionable and that the offering was structured to eventually give Mr. Lewis $250 million - at the same time leaving him with 93 percent of the voting stock and the public with shares that were of dubious value. Barron's, for one, argued that it was an attempt to replace junk bonds with overpriced junk stocks while enriching the insiders.
Many LBO's have not even been able stir enough interest to even approach the market, because of their distressed financial condition.
In fact, some have ended up filing for bankruptcy protection. Wall Street just cannot sell such issues. Investors know that in bankruptcy filings, equity investors are the last to be paid.
Even the more highly regarded buyouts are falling short of the wild promises of old.
Safeway Inc., a grocery chain taken private in a $5.65 billion buyout by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in 1986, failed to sell a 10 percent stake two months ago for as fancy a price as KKR and had hoped. The buyout firm sold 10 million shares to the public at $11.25 a share, getting about $112 million. But both Kohlberg, Kravis and the underwriters, Goldman Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company, had expected a price in the range of $13 to $16 a share - reaching for 30 times earnings.
Robert Natale, editor of Standard & Poor's Emerging & Special Situations newsletter, pointed to the Safeway deal as an excellent indicator of the stock market's lack of appetite for highly leveraged companies. It was widely regarded as a well-structured deal, and the small size of the offering indicated that Kohlberg was looking to put a high valuation on the rest of its Safeway holding and test the waters for reverse deals.
Mr. Coffee's complicated life is also illustrative. The kitchen appliance company was taken private by North American Systems in a $72 million LBO in 1987. It then sought to retire a bridge loan used to help finance the buyout and privately sold about $36 million in junk bonds with 16.5 percent coupons. Then income plummeted as interest expense soared, and it defaulted on the bonds.
So it sold 118,000 shares of preferred stock and 347,222 common stock warrants - much of it to the institutions holding the junk bonds - to help it out of default. In February, it exchanged most of the preferred shares and warrants for common stock, and then tried to sell four million shares in the public market for $11 each. It eventually did sell them - at $10, raising $27 million after expenses - but that hardly solved its problems.
Before the offering, Mr. Coffee had been saddled with about $72 million in long-term debt, representing 83 percent of its capitalization. This debt still above 50 percent of its capitalization, and the proceeds from the public offering will would go mostly to repurchasing the junk bonds. Insiders, who sold one million of the four million shares, had purchased their shares for about $7.63 each. The $10 sale price, then, represented a profit of 31 percent. Not bad for the insiders. But it's far from clear how the company will come out in the end.
Among the many LBO's still on the sidelines waiting for better prices is Warnaco Inc., an apparel manufacturer taken private in 1986 in a $464 million LBO led by Linda Wachner and the investment firm of Adler & Shaykin. Miss Wachner had hoped to take the company public in 1988, but has been delayed by troubles in the markets and in retailing. Still, Warnaco is meeting its debt obligations, and recently raised cash by selling its sportswear division - to a group that included management.
''If the window opens up in the public market, we're going to be there,'' said Miss Wachner. ''But now is not the time to offer these assets to the public because whatever they're worth today will not compare to what they will be worth when retailing is out of intensive care.''
For companies that cannot wait for the market to improve, a ray of hope is the private sale of securities to institutional buyers. These buyers pay enough to help out - but end up owning at least a portion of the companies. For example, last month Caldor's, a discount retailer straining under takeover debt, placed $300 million of securities with 50 institutions. They, in turn, obtained rights to acquire about 12 percent of its equity.
 
THOSE WHO GAIN
Not everyone is suffering miserably with the passing of leveraged buyouts from high favor.
For example, Geneva Steel, a former USX unit, was acquired by its management three years ago for $44 million. Last March, that same management tried to raise $136 million in an initial public offering of stock the company hoped to sell for $14 to $16 a share. The offering had to be scaled back and the company's shares went public at $10 each, raising only $77.5 million.
But the offering was structured so that it would bring spectacular returns to the private stockholders who sold 4.5 million of their shares. According to documents the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, these insiders had paid themselves special dividends in the years since the buyout.
Moreover, they orginally paid an average of 7 1/2 cents per share for their stock - or $864,390 for the 11.7 million shares they purchased. So in selling the 4.5 million shares to the public at $10 each, for a total of $45 million, they had a 133-fold gain.
The proceeds from the 3.25 million shares the company itself sold raised just $32.5 million; funds to be used to improve its antiquated facilities in the difficult and cyclical steel business.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Is Poland Getting Bad Advice?

BYLINE: By AMITAI ETZIONI; Amitai Etzioni, university professor at George Washington University, is author of ''The Moral Dimension.''

 BODY:
Poland is the only country in Eastern Europe that is attempting to rush from a command-and-control economy to a free-market economy. All the other countries have chosen a gradual transition. My prediction is that Poland will not make it. I base my prediction on sociological, psychological and political factors as well as economics. This broader perspective is a long way from American neoclassical economic theory, on which the ''jump now'' advice to Poland is based.
Jump-now economics assumes that Poles are good people held down by bad institutions and that if the institutional overlay of controls is scraped away, their innate qualities of entrepreneurship and industriousness will assert themselves. Thus subsidies have already been slashed, the zloty is now convertible, industries are being privatized, bankruptcies are permissible, prices are being freed to respond to the market, and so on. 
Massive inflation and unemployment have followed these changes. Neo-classical economists call them the short-term costs of adjusting. Soon, champions of the jump predict, the market incentives will work. People will find they must work harder; managers will have to be more innovative, and so on throughout the economy. This, in turn, will increase production, bring prices down, and show the world the merits of the free market.
Neo-classical economists assume people will respond quickly to the changing conditions in which they find themselves. But people respond slowly and partially. In Poland, people have deeply ingrained habits of working inefficiently, of using time at work to shop for goods or produce illicitly on the side. Even in the United States we have a hard time taking a 50-year-old steelworker and turning him into a computer programmer. Imagine the difficulty of taking thousands of Polish Communist Party bureaucrats and making them into productive workers. At best, it will take years.
Poles are enamored of the ''American'' way of life - as depicted on television - but by this they mean a high standard of living, not what is necessary to achieve it. When a McDonald's restaurant opened in Yugoslavia, which is more Westernized than Poland, 40 percent of the workers quit within the first few weeks, saying the work was too hard.
Then there is the infrastructure problem. Poland has little of the financial and communication services a modern economy requires. It has a banking system that is used to dealing almost completely in cash and is only beginning to develop a checking system. Almost everything else is backward, from the telephone systems to the ports. True, bottlenecks are an effective way to spur development, but there are so many bottlenecks in Poland that it may take a decade or more just to develop a semi-modern infrastructure.
The recommendation to jump into capitalism can generate the most dangerous form of sociological dynamite - crashed expectations. Polish hopes were out of kilter to begin with, building on the simplistic assumption that political freedoms can insure economic success. They were based on the faulty assumption that Poland can quickly reach a Western standard of living. These misconceptions are further fanned by the promise of the fruits of capitalism once Government interventions and controls are slashed.
But the brute fact is that whatever Poles do with their $1,920 per capita economy, even if they somehow double it - a feat that took the United States a generation to do in its best days - they will still be a long way from Americans' $18,543 per capita income. We need to do all that we can to moderate the Polish people's expectations so they will steel themselves for the long haul ahead.
Massive Western aid could delay the sociological explosion somewhat, especially if it is aimed at providing massive amounts of consumer goods. This would create the illusion that the transition is working quickly. But unless we are willing to shore up the resulting heightened expectations with still larger amounts of aid, grants, loans and credits, all we shall achieve is a delay in Poland's day of reckoning. The Poles will eventually have to scale down their expectations to levels they can provide, and those will be quite meager for a long time.
The specifics are impossible to foretell, but the main predictions stand out: No country can jump from Communism into capitalism. Poland will have to slow down its transition to a market economy. If it does not, frustrations will increase. Discontent already has some people in Poland urging that Lech Walesa become a dictator. We can only help the Poles if we stop fanning their dangerously unrealistic expectations.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 495 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Where's The Cash, Mr. Trump?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Is Donald a deadbeat?
Donald J. Trump's failure to come up with a measly $30 million to pay bondholders at Trump's Castle, which he bought five years ago on amazingly generous, less-than-no-money-down, credit terms, is far from the final chapter of the Trump saga. But the Trump aura will never be the same. 
The money was not paid because squabbling bankers, although willing to advance the cash to Mr. Trump, were unable to agree whether to accept the terms that Mr. Trump had offered. The bond payment was supposed to be made Friday, but there is an automatic 10-day grace period.
''It's the old story,'' said one person close to the negotiations. ''Borrow $2,000 and they'll foreclose in a minute. But borrow $2 billion and you've got them over a barrel.''
Just how big a barrel remains to be seen. In your run-of-the-mill default, the banks have a senior position to any ''junk bond'' holders, and often escape relatively unscathed. But at Trump's Castle, it was the banks that put up the money for Mr. Trump's downpayment and for working capital, while the junk-bond buyers got the first mortgage. If it all falls apart, the bondholders own the casino and hotel. So the banks seem to be unusually ill-secured, at least in that part of the Trump empire. To keep alive hopes of getting their money back, they may need to pour in more cash.
Mr. Trump has the legal right to walk away from the Trump's Castle bonds, leaving the creditors to fight over that casino. But he hasguaranteed other Trump's Castle debts to banks, among them a $50 million mortgage loan from New Jersey's Midlantic Bank and another loan for about $30 million from New York's Manufacturers Hanover. If the Castle goes down, it could start an avalanche.
The banks and Mr. Trump each seemed to recognize the weakness of the other's position, and to be determined to exploit it. Those who have played the game of ''chicken'' - in which two cars speed toward each other and the loser is the one that swerves to avoid a collision - would have been right at home in the negotiations.
So far, Mr. Trump's problems haven't affected the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average rose 73.51 points, to 2,935.89 last week. Bulls seem to be banking on their recollections that credit problems do not always mean bad news for equities. It was eight years ago that Mexico's debt problems burst onto the front pages. The Federal Reserve Board reacted by aggressively easing credit, and the great bull market of the 1980's began. As consumers grow less willing to spend, the Bush Administration is starting to step up the pressure for the Fed to try that course again. ''The credit crunch is not only affecting real estate, but a lot of small and middle-size businesses,'' complained Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher.
For Mr. Trump, Fed easing might not help that much. Bankers may not be fast learners, but they do catch on. For him, the era of easy credit is unlikely to ever return.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
gold Is Not the Safe Haven It Used to Be

BYLINE: By FlOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Gold is supposed to be a safe haven in times of turmoil. But those who fled to it last winter as Communist regimes dissolved in Eastern Europe have suffered since. Last week, gold traded as low as $341 per ounce in London, a four-year low.
The big losers from a falling gold market are the world's two big producers, South Africa and the Soviet Union, both of which need the cash now. There were reports of Soviet selling this month, but when prices bounced off the bottom, there was also speculation of Soviet buying. Given the Soviet Union's perilous economic state, such purchases are unlikely to continue.
As much as a quarter of South African production is now uneconomic, according to Jordan Estra of Oppenheimer & Company in New York. But it remains to be seen whether South Africa will cut off that production, throwing black miners out of work and depriving its economy of needed foreign exchange. If it doesn't, gold's woes are more likely to continue.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 17, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 26, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4878 words

HEADLINE: A Capital Offense; Reagan's America

BYLINE: By Kevin P. Phillips; Kevin P. Phillips, a Republican political analyst, is the publisher of The American Political Report. This article is adapted from his new book, ''The Politics of Rich and Poor: Wealth and the American Electorate in the Reagan Aftermath,'' published by Random House.

 BODY:
The 1980's were the triumph of Upper America - an ostentatious celebration of wealth, the political ascendancy of the rich and a glorification of capitalism, free markets and finance. Not only did the concentration of wealth quietly intensify, but the sums involved took a megaleap. The definition of who's rich - and who's no longer rich - changed as radically during the Reagan era as it did during the great nouveaux-riches eras of the late 19th century and the 1920's, periods whose excesses preceded the great reformist upheavals of the Progressive era and the New Deal.
But while money, greed and luxury became the stuff of popular culture, few people asked why such great wealth had concentrated at the top and whether this was the result of public policy. Political leaders, even those who professed to care about the armies of homeless sleeping on grates and other sad evidence of a polarized economy, had little to say about the Republican Party's historical role: to revitalize capitalism but also to tilt power, Government largess, more wealth and income toward the richest portion of the population.
The public, however, understood and worried about this Republican bias, if we can trust late 80's opinion polls; nevertheless, the Democrats largely shunned the issue in the '88 election, a reluctance their predecessors also displayed during previous Republican booms of the Gilded Age of the late 19th century and the Roaring Twenties. 
As the decade ended, too many stretch limousines in Manhattan, too many yacht jams off Newport Beach and too many fur coats in Aspen foreshadowed a significant shift of mood. Only for so long would strung-out $35,000-a-year families enjoy magazine articles about the hundred most successful businessmen in Dallas. Class structures may be weak in the United States, but populist sentiments run high. The political pendulum has swung in the past, and may be ready to swing again.
Indeed, money politics - be it avarice of financiers or the question of who will pay for the binges of the 80's - is shaping up as a prime theme for the 1990's. As we shall see, there is a historical cycle to such shifts: Whenever Republicans are in power long enough to transform economic policy from a middle-class orientation to capitalist overdrive, the rich get so far ahead that a popular reaction inevitably follows, with the Democrats usually tagging along, rather than leading.
But this time, the nature of the reaction against excess is likely to be different. The previous gilded ages occurred when America was on the economic rise in the world. The 1980's, on the other hand, turned into an era of paper entrepreneurialism, reflecting a nation consuming, rearranging and borrowing more than it built. For the next generation of populists who would like to rearrange American wealth, the bad news is that a large amount of it has already been redistributed - to Japan, West Germany and to the other countries that took Reagan-era I.O.U.'s and credit slips.S
SOCIETY MATRONS, WALL STREET ARBITRAGEURS, PALM Beach real-estate agents and other money-conscious Americans picking up USA Today on May 22, 1987, must have been at first bewildered and then amused by the top story. In describing a Harris survey of the attitudes of upper-bracket citizens, the article summed up the typical respondent as ''rich. Very. He's part of the thinnest economic upper crust: households with incomes of more than $100,000 a year.''
A surprising number of 1980's polls and commentaries contributed to this naive perception - that ''rich'' somehow started at $50,000 or $100,000 a year, and that gradations above that were somehow less important. The truth is that the critical concentration of wealth in the United States was developing at higher levels - decamillionaires, centimillionaires, half-billionaires and billionaires. Garden-variety American millionaires had become so common that there were about 1.5 million of them by 1989.
In fact, even families with what seemed like good incomes - $50,000 a year, say, in Wichita, Kan., or $90,000 a year in New York City (almost enough to qualify as ''rich,'' according to USA Today) - found it hard to make ends meet because of the combined burden of Federal income and Social Security taxes, plus the soaring costs of state taxes, housing, health care and children's education. What few understood was that real economic status and leisure-class purchasing power had moved higher up the ladder, to groups whose emergence and relative affluence Middle America could scarcely comprehend.
No parallel upsurge of riches had been seen since the late 19th century, the era of the Vanderbilts, Morgans and Rockefellers. It was the truly wealthy, more than anyone else, who flourished under Reagan. Calculations in a Brookings Institution study found that the share of national income going to the wealthiest 1 percent rose from 8.1 percent in 1981 to 14.7 percent in 1986. Between 1981 and 1989, the net worth of the Forbes 400 richest Americans nearly tripled. At the same time, the division between them and the rest of the country became a yawning gap. In 1980, corporate chief executive officers, for example, made roughly 40 times the income of average factory workers. By 1989, C.E.O.'s were making 93 times as much. Finance alone built few billion-dollar fortunes in the 1980's relative to service industries like real estate and communications, but it is hard to overstate Wall Street's role during the decade, partly because Federal monetary and fiscal policies favored financial assets and because deregulation promoted new debt techniques and corporate restructuring.
Selling stock to retail clients, investment management firms or mutual funds paid well; repackaging, remortgaging or dismantling a Fortune 500 company paid magnificently. In 1981, analysts estimate, the financial community's dozen biggest earners made $5 million to $20 million a year. In 1988, despite the stock-market collapse the October before, these earnings were $50 million to $200 million.
The redistribution of American wealth raised questions not just about polarization, but also about trivialization. Less and less wealth was going to people who produced something. Services were ascendant - from fast food to legal advice, investment vehicles to data bases. It is one thing for new technologies to reduce demand for obsolescent professions, enabling society to concentrate more resources in emerging sectors like health and leisure. But the distortion lies in the disproportionate rewards to society's economic, legal and cultural manipulators - from lawyers and financial advisers to advertising executives, merchandisers, media magnates and entertainers. A related boom and distortion occurred in nonfinancial assets - art and homes, in particular. Art and antiques appreciated fourfold in the Reagan era, to the principal benefit of the richest 200,000 or 300,000 families. Similar if lesser explosions in art prices took place in the Gilded Age and in the 1920's. While the top one-half of 1 percent of Americans rolled in money, the luxuries they craved - from Picassos and 18th-century English furniture to Malibu beach houses - soared in markets virtually auxiliary to those in finance.
Meanwhile, everyone knew there was pain in society's lower ranks, from laid-off steelworkers to foreclosed farmers. A disproportionate number of female, black, Hispanic and young Americans lost ground in the 1980's, despite the progress of upscale minorities in each category. According to one study, for example, the inflation-adjusted income for families with children headed by an adult under 30 collapsed by roughly one-fourth between 1973 and 1986.
Even on an overall basis, median family and household incomes showed only small inflation-adjusted gains between 1980 and 1988. Middle America was quietly hurting too.
While corporate presidents and chairmen feasted in the 1980's, as many as 1.5 million midlevel management jobs are estimated to have been lost during those years. Blue-collar America paid a larger price, but suburbia, where fathers rushed to catch the 8:10 train to the city, was counting its casualties, too. ''Middle managers have become insecure,'' observed Peter F. Drucker in September 1988, ''and they feel unbelievably hurt. They feel like slaves on an auction block.''
AMERICAN TRANSITIONS OF THE MAGNITUDE OF the capitalist blow-out of the 1980's have usually coincided with a whole new range of national economic attitudes. Evolving government policies - from tax cuts to high interest rates - seem distinct, but they are actually linked. Whether in the late 19th century, the 1920's or the 1980's, the country has witnessed, ensemble, conservative politics, a reduced role for government, entrepreneurialism and admiration of business, corporate restructuring and mergers, tax reduction, declining inflation, pain in states that rely on commodities like oil and wheat, rising inequality and concentration of wealth, and a buildup of debt and speculation. The scope of these trends has been impressive - and so has their repetition, though the two heydays of the 20th century have involved increasingly more paper manipulation and less of the raw vigor typical of the late 19th-century railroad and factory expansion.
Federal policy from 1981 to 1988 enormously affected investment, speculation and the creation and distribution of wealth and income, just as in the past.
The reduction or elimination of Federal income taxes was a goal in previous capitalist heydays. But it was a personal preoccupation for Ronald Reagan, whose antipathy toward income taxes dated back to his high-earning Hollywood days, when a top tax bracket of 91 percent in the late 40's made it foolish to work beyond a certain point. Under him, the top personal tax bracket would drop from 70 percent to 28 percent in only seven years. For the first time since the era of Franklin D. Roosevelt, tax policy was fundamentally rearranging its class loyalties.
Reaganite theorists reminded the country that the Harding-Coolidge income tax cuts - from a top rate of 73 percent in 1920 to 25 percent in 1925 - helped create the boom of the 20's. Back then, just as in the 80's, the prime beneficiaries were the top 5 percent of Americans, people who rode the cutting edge of the new technology of autos, radios and the like, emerging service industries, including new practices like advertising and consumer finance, a booming stock market and unprecedented real-estate development. Disposable income soared for the rich and with it, conspicuous consumption and financial speculation. After the 1929 crash and the advent of the New Deal, tax rates rose again; the top rate reached 79 percent by 1936 and 91 percent right after the war. In 1964, the rate fell in two stages, to 77 percent and then to 70 percent.
Under Reagan, Federal budget policy, like tax changes, became a factor in the realignment of wealth, especially after the 1981-82 recession sent the deficit soaring. The slack was made up by money borrowed at home and abroad at high cost. The first effect lay in who received more Government funds. Republican constituencies - military producers and installations, agribusiness, bondholders and the elderly - clearly benefited, while decreases in social programs hurt Democratic interests and constituencies: the poor, big cities, subsidized housing, education. Equally to the point, the huge payments of high-interest charges on the growing national debt enriched the wealthy, who bought the bonds that kept Government afloat.
Prosperous individuals and financial institutions were beneficiaries of Government policies in other ways. Starting in the Carter years, Congress began to deregulate the financial industry; but the leap came in the early 1980's, when deposit and loan interest ceilings were removed. To attract deposits, financial institutions raised their interest rates, which rose and even exceeded record postwar levels. The small saver profited, but the much larger gain, predictably, went to the wealthy. (The benefits of high interest were intensified, of course, by the declining maximum tax rate on dividend and interest income. The explosion of after-tax unearned income for the top 1 percent of Americans was just that - an explosion.) The savings and loan crisis now weighing on American taxpayers also had roots in deregulation. Before 1982, federally chartered S. & L.'s were required to place almost all their loans in home mortgages, a relatively safe and stable class of assets. But in 1982, after soaring interest rates turned millions of low-interest mortgages into undesirable assets, a new law allowed S. & L.'s to invest their funds a lot more freely - 100 percent in commercial real-estate ventures if they so desired. Like banks in the 1920's, many thrifts proceeded to gamble with their deposits, and by 1988, many had lost. Gamblers and speculators enriched themselves even as they stuck other Americans with the tab.
Reagan's permissiveness toward mergers, antitrust enforcement and new forms of speculative finance was likewise typical of Republican go-go conservatism. Unnerving parallels were made between the Wall Street raiders of the 1980's - Ivan Boesky and T. Boone Pickens - and the takeover pools of the 1920's, when high-powered operators would combine to ''boom'' a particular stock. For a small group of Americans at the top, the pickings were enormous.
An egregious misperception of late 20th-century politics is to associate only Democrats with extremes of debt. Before 1933, conservatives - Federalists, Whigs and Republicans alike - sponsored Government indebtedness and used high-interest payments to redistribute wealth upward. In the 1920's, individual, consumer and corporate debt kept setting record levels, aided by new techniques like installment purchases and margin debt for purchasing securities. In addition, Republican eras were noted for a huge expansion of private debt.
In the kindred 80's, total private and public debt grew from $4.2 trillion to more than $10 trillion. And just as they had 60 years earlier, new varieties of debt became came an art form.
Government fiscal strategists were equally loose. In part to avoid the deficit-reduction mandates of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act, they allowed Federal credit programs, including student and housing loans, to balloon from $300 billion in 1984 to $500 billion in 1989.
In contrast to previous capitalist blowouts, the fast-and-loose Federal debt strategies of the 80's did not simply rearrange assets within the country but served to transfer large amounts of the nation's wealth overseas as well. America's share of global wealth expanded in the Gilded Age and again in the 1920's. The late 1980's, however, marked a significant downward movement: one calculation, by the Japanese newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun, had Japan overtaking the United States, with estimated comparative assets of $43.7 trillion in 1987, versus $36.2 trillion for the United States.
The United States was losing relative(Continued on Page 40) purchasing power on a grand scale. There might be more wealthy Americans than ever before, but foreigners commanded greater resources. On the 1989 Forbes list of the world's billionaires, excluding royalty, eight of the top 25 were Japanese, 10 were European and four were American. Dollar millionaires, once the envy of the world, were becoming an outdated elite.
This shift partly reflected the ebb of America's postwar preeminence. Yet the same Reagan policies that moved riches internally also accelerated the shift of world wealth, beginning with the budget deficits of the early 1980's but intensifying after the ensuing devaluation of the dollar from 1985 to 1988.
If the devalued dollar made the Japanese, French and Germans relatively richer, it also increased their purchasing power in the United States, turning the country into a bargain basement for overseas buyers. This is the explanation for the surging foreign acquisition of properties, from Fortune 500 companies to Rockefeller Center in Manhattan and a large share of the office buildings in downtown Los Angeles.
The dollar's decline also pushed per capita gross national product and comparative wages in the United States below those of a number of Western European nations. The economist Lester C. Thurow summed up the predicament: ''When it comes to wealth, we can argue about domestic purchasing power. But, in terms of international purchasing power, the United States is now only the ninth wealthiest country in the world in terms of per capita G.N.P. We have been surpassed by Austria, Switzerland, the Netherlands, West Germany, Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Japan.''
Not everyone looked askance at foreign wealth and investment. American cities and states welcomed it. From the textile towns of South Carolina to the rolling hills of Ohio, foreigners were helping declining regions to reverse their fate. Yet as Warren Buffett, the investor, said: ''We are much like a wealthy family that annually sells acreage so that it can sustain a life style unwarranted by its current output. Until the plantation is gone, it's all pleasure and no pain. In the end, however, the family will have traded the life of an owner for the life of a tenant farmer.''
Nowhere was Japanese investment more invasive than in Hawaii, where real-estate moguls from Tokyo pronounced the property they were grabbing up as ''almost free.'' An economist at a Hawaiian bank warned that the state was ''a kind of test lab for what's facing the whole country.'' Indeed, in 1988, broader foreign ambitions were apparent. The author Daniel Burstein quoted Masaaki Kurokawa, then head of Japan's Nomura Securities International, who raised with American dinner guests the possibility of turning California into a joint United States-Japanese economic community.
Public concern over America's international weakness had been a factor in Ronald Reagan's election back in 1980. Voters had wanted a more aggressive leader than Jimmy Carter. For various reasons, the great things promised were not delivered. Reagan could re-create a sense of military prowess with his attacks on Grenada and Libya. But in the global economy he took a country that had been the world's biggest creditor in 1980 and turned it into the world's largest debtor. Despite opinion polls documenting public concern about this erosion, surprisingly little was made of the issue in the 1988 Presidential campaign, possibly because the Democrats could not develop a coherent domestic and international alternative.
MUCH OF THE NEW emphasis in the 1980's on tax reduction and the aggressive accumulation of wealth reflected the Republican Party's long record of support for unabashed capitalism. It was no fluke that three important Republican supremacies coincided with and helped generate the Gilded Age, the Roaring Twenties and the Reagan-Bush years.
Part of the reason survival-of-the-fittest periods are so relentless, however, rests on the performance of the Democrats as history's second-most enthusiastic capitalist party. They do not interfere with capitalist momentum, but wait for excesses and the inevitable popular reaction.
In the United States, elections arguably play a more important cultural and economic role than in other lands. Because we lack a hereditary aristocracy or Establishment, our leadership elites and the alignment of wealth are more the product of political cycles than they are elsewhere. Capitalism is maneuvered more easily in the United States, pushed in new regional and sectoral directions. As a result, the genius of American politics - failing only in the Civil War - has been to manage through ballot boxes the problems that less fluid societies resolve with barricades and with party structures geared to class warfare.
Because we are a mobile society, Americans tolerate one of the largest disparities in the industrial world between top and bottom incomes, as people from the middle move to the top, and vice versa. Opportunity has counted more than equality. But if circulating elites are a reality, electoral politics is an important traffic controller. From the time of Thomas Jefferson, the nation has undulated in 28- to 36-year waves as each watershed election puts a new dominant region, culture, ideology or economic interest (or combination) into the White House, changing the country's direction. But after a decade or two, the new forces lose touch with the public, excessively empower their own elites and become a target for a new round of populist reform. Only the United States among major nations reveals such recurrent electoral behavior over two centuries.
The Republicans rode such a wave into office in 1968, as a middle-class, anti-elite correction, successfully squelching the social permissiveness and disorder of the 60's. Significantly, each Republican coalition - from Lincoln's to Nixon's - began by emphasizing national themes and unity symbols, while subordinating commercial and financial interests.
But it is the second stage - dynamic capitalism, market economics and the concentration of wealth - that the Republican Party is all about. When Republicans are in power long enough, they ultimately find themselves embracing limited government, less regulation of business, reduced taxation, disinflation and high real interest rates. Over America's first two centuries, these policies shaped the three periods that would incubate the biggest growth of American millionaires (or, by the 1980's, billionaires). History suggests that it takes a decade or more for the Republican Party to shift from broad middle-class nationalism into capitalist overdrive, and the lapse of 12 years between the first Nixon inauguration in 1969 and the first Reagan inauguration repeats this transformation. Nixon, like the previous Republican nationalist presidents Lincoln and William McKinley, was altogether middle class, as was his ''new majority'' Republicanism. He had no interest in unbridled capitalism during his 1969-74 presidency.
In fact, many of the new adherents recruited for the Republican coalition in 1968 and 1972 were wooed with the party's populist attacks on inflation, big government, social engineering and the Liberal Establishment. Many Republican voters of that era embraced outsider and anti-elite values, and like similar participants in previous Republican national coalitions, they would become uneasy in the 1980's as Reagan or Bush Republicanism embraced Beverly Hills or Yale culture and the economics of leveraged buyouts, not of Main Street. Besides this uneasiness, reflected in opinion polls, a second sign that a conservative cycle is moving toward its climax has been the extent to which Democratic politics has been cooperative: when wealth is in fashion, Democrats go along. The solitary Democratic President of the Gilded Age, Grover Cleveland, was a conservative with close Wall Street connections. In the 20's, the Democratic Presidential nominees in both 1920 (James Cox, an Ohio publisher) and 1924 (John W. Davis, a corporate lawyer) were in the Cleveland mold. Even Alfred E. Smith, who ran in 1928, would eventually oppose Roosevelt and the New Deal. In the 20's, Congressional Democrats competed with Republicans to cut upper-bracket and corporate taxes.
Fifty years later, Jimmy Carter, the only Democratic President to interrupt the long Republican hegemony after 1968, was accused by the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. of an ''eccentric effort to carry the Democratic Party back to Grover Cleveland.'' Despite his support for substantial new Federal regulation, Carter clearly deviated from his party's larger post-New Deal norm. He built foundations that would become conservative architecture under Reagan: economic deregulation; capital gains tax reduction and the tight-money policies of the Federal Reserve. (The Fed's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, was a Carter appointee.) Congressional Democrats even echoed their policies of the 1920's by colluding in the bipartisan tax-bracket changes of 1981 and 1986.
Thus, the Democrats could hardly criticize Reagan's tax reductions. For the most part, they laid little groundwork for an election-year critique in 1988, leaving the issue to Jesse Jackson, whose appeal was limited by his race and third-world rhetoric, and to noncandidates like Mario M. Cuomo. Michael S. Dukakis was obviously uncomfortable with populist politics. Though several consultants and economists urged him to pick up the theme of economic inequality, Dukakis made competence, not ideology, his initial campaign issue. Only in late October, with his campaign crumbling, did the Democratic candidate reluctantly convert to a more traditional party line. It came too late.
Republican strategists could hardly believe their luck. Said Lee Atwater, Bush's campaign manager, after the election: ''The way to win a Presidential race against the Republicans is to develop the class-warfare issue, as Dukakis did at the end - to divide up the haves and have-nots and to try to reinvigorate the New Deal coalition and to attack.''
On the surface, this was a missed Democratic opportunity. But the lesson of history is that the party of Cleveland, Carter and Dukakis has rarely rushed its anti-elite corrective role. There would be no rush again in 1988 - nor, indeed, in 1989.
early in his presidency, George Bush replaced the Coolidge portrait hung by Ronald Reagan in the White House with one of Theodore Roosevelt, reflecting Bush's belief in T. R.'s commitment to conservation, patrician reform and somewhat greater regulatory involvement.
Yet there has not been toomuch evidence of a kinder, gentler America beyond softer, more conciliatory rhetoric. The budget remained unkind to any major expansion of domestic programs, and Bush's main tax objective was a reduction in the capital gains rate, a shift that critics said would continue to concentrate benefits among the top 1 percent of Americans.
By spring 1990, Washington politicians confronted the most serious debt- and credit-related problems since the bank failures, collapsed stock prices, farm foreclosures and European war debt defaults of the Great Depression. From the S. & L. bailout to junk bonds, from soaring bankruptcies and shaky real-estate markets to Japanese influence in the bond market, Federal policy makers were forced to realize that a crucial task - and peril - of the 1990's would involve cleaning up after the previous decade's credit-card parties and speculative distortions.
In May, the facade of successful deficit reduction crumbled as Administration officials confessed that bailing out insolvent savings and loans could cost as much as a half-trillion dollars. As it became clear that taxes would have to rise and social programs would suffer further reductions - financially troubled states were already cutting food allotments for poor women and children - even the Democrats who had previously collaborated with Republican economics began to argue that the rich who had made so much money in the 80's should bear a larger share of the new burdens of the 90's.
Some Republicans shared this disquiet. The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Russell, Kan., insisted in late 1989 that if the White House wanted to cut capital gains taxes for the prosperous, it should also raise the minimum wage for the poor. Last month, the House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Peoria, Ill., was reported to favor an increase in the tax rate for the top 1 percent of Americans, from 28 percent to 33 percent. The second-ranking G.O.P. leader in the House, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, suggested in April that conservatives, too, had to develop some ideas for economic redistribution.''
Meanwhile, opinion poll after opinion poll has shown lopsided voter support for raising the income tax rate for people making more than $80,000, $100,000 or $200,000. By last year, the popular culture was rejecting the greed and glitz of ''Dynasty'' and ''Dallas,'' and even the editor of Soap Opera Digestsaid that rich is out. The relevant culture of the 1990's, by contrast, seemed ready to reflect a new anti-Wall Street, anti-corporate and anti-greed mentality set forth in books (and coming movies) like ''Bonfire of the Vanities,'' ''Liar's Poker'' and ''Barbarians at the Gate.''
Nor was the changing mood apparent only in the United States. Kindred psychologies and political analyses could also be seen in other countries like Britain, Japan and Canada, where 1980's financial and real-estate booms likewise concentrated wealth in the hands of the rich and increased economic inequity. A headline last month in the Financial Times of London could have been written in the United States: ''The Rich Get Nervous.''
Whether the populist reactions that followed past boom periods recur in the 90's no one can know. But there could be no doubt that the last decade ended as it had begun: with a rising imperative for a new political and economic philosophy, and growing odds that the 1990's will be a very different chapter than the 1980's in the annals of American wealth and power.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 17, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42, Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3797 words

HEADLINE: Fashion: European Report;
Paris, Mixing It All Up

BYLINE: BY CARRIE DONOVAN

 BODY:
It would be facile to say that the Paris fall showings were a mess. It would be more candid, though, to describe the mise en scene as an eclectic melange. The collections were full of clothes that were, by turns, scrambles of rearranged themes from the past, reruns of 1960's affectations, lifts from theatrical turns, references to L. L. Bean and other such sporty territories, quick tours of costumery from formerly Iron Curtain countries and contented continuations of status quo style.
What this mix signaled was not so much indecision as stalling. Designers in Paris, like those in New York and Milan, are marking time since they sense that now is not the moment to launch a major style upheaval. Consumers would probably not accept it; certainly the wavering fashion economy could not handle it. Better to just stroke and tweak old ideas. Of course, because this fashion collage was assembled in Paris, it was brilliantly done. The collections, as a whole, sparkled with wit. Details and accessories were amusing and inventive.
There were enough ideas to copy to keep the rest of the world's fashion markets supplied for more than one season. And as wild as some of the styles seemed, they - or parts of them - were actually not so extreme that fashionable women would not find them wearable. Provided, that is, that they could afford them. 
Silhouettes were much as they have been, smaller in the shoulder and shaping gently to the body. Almost all skirts were short-short (though, of course, those shipped to American stores will be sent at around knee-length). Like their counterparts in New York, several designers are experimenting with skirt fullness, not always successfully. Jackets were important and usually longer in line, often reaching to the finger tips. Colors, blasts of them, were often used together in one outfit, almost obscuring the neutrals of gray and brown and definitely eclipsing black. Fabrics were mixed together, and tweed was often combined with velvet for day wear. Bodysuits and leggings were at the base of many styles. Boots staged a comeback, including the 60's over-the-knee styles. Hair styles, wigs and headbands were more 60's touches.
Stretch fibers that give all manner of fabric mobility is the most modern idea in today's fashion, and there was lots of it in Paris.
Christian Lacroix's collection best summed up the current mood of Paris. Although Lacroix, in his 1987 couture show, launched the pouf silhouette that and made him famous, his ready-to-wear efforts have subsequently been disappointing. Buyers and the press have consistently found them to be too diffuse and confusing. This time, though, everyone raved. The designer was genuinely amazed by the reception. ''I honestly don't understand it,'' he said, rolling his large brown eyes and raising his expressive brows. ''I don't even like this collection because it is nothing new. I made what I have always made because I wanted it to be easy.'' (Lacroix had been ill for months with back problems.) What made this fall's Lacroix collection so successful was that the general cycle of fashion has caught up with what he has always attempted. That is to mix and mash patterns, textures and unexpected items of clothing together with panache. Then he loads on piles of amusing and inventively designed accessories.
Emanuel Ungaro is the other master of the mix. He is also a master craftsman. As a result, you can take apart any Ungaro outfit and each item will stand by itself as fascinating fashion.
Yves Saint Laurent was hospitalized during collection week, and, of course, his absence showed. His presentation, though filled with very nice, if familiar, fashions for Saint Laurent devotees, lacked the usual flickers of imaginative pairings and the fire of his unexpected accessorizing. Jean-Paul Gaultier is also a great ''mixer upper'' of style. But his genre of design is not for the ladies who lunch. He aims his work at the sharp avant-garde young women who want to dare and be damned if they are not noticed. His clothes - as always, beautifully and knowledgeably executed - tossed together most of the current fashion icons. There were tailored men's-wear suits, sequins, hand-painted ''message'' T-shirts, Norwegian patterned sweaters, sexy theatrical stuff, thick working mens' boots and shoes, hardy outerwear and more than a few just plain outrageous revelations of nudity. The latter Gaultier manifests in body or tailored men's pants suits that, viola!, were practically bare behind. All this frolicking around somewhat camouflages the fact that he is not adventuring into new territory.
The other master showman of Paris's pret-a-porter is Thierry Mugler. Retailers report that when they got to his showroom to place orders, there were the usual sexy suits he always produces. His presentation was something else. It was a professionally staged cabaret performance with some of the world's most famous fashion models outfitted to look more gorgeous and leggy than the best of Las Vegas. They were wearing 60's style wigs, fishnet tights and marvelously imaginative costumes glittering with masses of rhinestones or Day-Glo colors. But none of this is new for Mugler.
In standing still, Mugler had several, disparate confreres. They ranged from the inventor of sexy sweaters and sportswear, Sonia Rykiel, to those makers of elegant style, the suave Messrs. Valentino and Givenchy, to, oddly enough, the out-of-town mavericks, Italy's Romeo Gigli and Japan's Issey Miyake.
Gigli, who recently electrified the Paris scene, showed more of the same. There were the plain, clinging jersey dresses, the pants suits with swallowtail jackets and stovepiped trousers, the cocoon capes and the wrapped dressings of rich embroidered fabrics. There was no forward movement whatsoever. (The designer has since said he may only show a collection once a year, because once is enough. He may be right.) Miyake kept on his abstract way, suggesting that clothes should be moveable sculptures. He continued to use the interesting Japanese-developed synthetic fabrics that allow him to create these inventions, and out came new versions of clothes that jut out, cave in and sway as the wearer walks.
Perhaps because of this holding pattern, some of the most interesting collections in Paris were those that were, above all, classic. The work of Claude Montana, Hermes, Gianfranco Ferre for Dior and one strain of Karl Lagerfeld's opus for the house of Chanel were deeply satisfying. Montana, who has made some of the most forward style statements over the years, chose this time to present a peerless rendition of his dashing classics. There were the gray-flannel suits, the jackets nipped at the waist and curved precisely over the hips. Little flicks of silver ornaments were placed to point up the seaming. There were swashbuckling short coats with face-framing cape collars, their peplums swinging out from sashed waists. All in all, it was a quietly spectacular showing. Some said Montana mounted this show as a reaction to the trouncing he received last winter, when he attempted his first couture collection for the venerable house of Lanvin. The house of Hermes has been quietly edging up into the realm of important clothing design for the last few seasons, while simultaneously the avarice for their luxurious accessories has been rapidly increasing around the world. Under the direction of Claude Brouet, previously a respected French fashion editor, Hermes's collections are getting to be first-rate. And in a season when sybaritic classicism looked refreshing, so did the firm's impeccably made jackets, coats and jodphurs, not to wear on the horse but on the streets. Its bodysuit, printed with a scarf pattern, was a knockout. After a rocky beginning, the Milanese designer Gianfranco Ferre has begun establishing a strong, if strict, dramatic look for Dior. There, classicism also reigned. The house's legendary workmanship and the luxurious materials contributed to Ferre's retelling of themes, such as shapely jacketed suits, parkas over blousons and narrow pants and dramatic evening blouses with swooshing skirts.
Nowhere near in luxe of fabrication, and workmanship, but nevertheless of the same attitude, is the work of the Austrian Helmut Lang, who shows in Paris. A favorite of young fashion aficionados and editors, his clothes are minimal to the nth degree. His severely simple stretch bodysuits in navy and black, or his short sashed coats over same, are elegant in a sporty way.
Now to look at the work of Karl Lagerfeld, the most prolific designer on the world scene. Lagerfeld designs the Fendi collections in Italy and also makes one in Paris under his own label. Both are often filled with interesting trends and ideas. But it is his work for the house of Chanel that interests fashion followers the most.
For fall, he has flung out, as usual, ideas upon ideas. He has ''Chaneled up'' versions of the current trends, including 60's influences, outdoor gear such as parkas, bodysuits, mixes of colors of fabrics, colors, etc. There were enough accessory suggestions to keep that end of the market supplied with inspiration for some time. Maybe it all looked like too much on the runway. Lagerfeld was criticized by some reviewers, who suggested that he had finally made Chanel ''vulgar.'' But the truth is that Lagerfeld has been ''vulgarizing'' the Chanel image since he took over its design direction in 1983. Since then, the success of Chanel has been stupendous. Other old-name Paris houses naturally hope to imitate the Chanel resuscitation. The latest moves in that direction have come from Lanvin. Its first failure was with Claude Montana's premiere couture collection. (But the July showing may prove different.) When it came to the fall ready-to-wear collection, a talented young designer, Eric Bergere, was given the job. Then, according to Bergere's friends, an English fashion stylist was elevated over him as a supervisor and changed everything he had in mind. Whatever transpired, the collection was a mistake. Additionally, the clothes were badly made. By now, it must be clear to whomever tries a Chanel-like renaissance, there is only one Karl Lagerfeld.
In the end, what the fall ready-to-wear collections in Paris proved is that many looks are valid today. Not every one, but many. Perhaps the most modern thinking is not to expect the day when one major shift will influence fashion everywhere. this one Fashion: European Report BY CARRIE DONOVAN PHOTOGRAPHS BY DAN LECCA FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES Paris Mixing It All Up Scrambled 'Ouevre's' Clothes made from wild melanges of fabrics, patterns, ethnic inspirations and 1960's influences dominated the Paris collections for fall. The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 17, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 5, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1445 words

HEADLINE: HOW WELL DO WE KNOW THIS MAN?

BYLINE: By MARSHALL D. SHULMAN; Marshall D. Shulman is a professor emeritus of international relations at Columbia University's Harriman Institute for Advanced Study of the Soviet Union.

 BODY:

GORBACHEV
Heretic in the Kremlin.
By Dusko Doder and Louise Branson.
450 pp. New York:
Viking. $24.95.
The face of Mikhail S. Gorbachev has become so familiar that we feel we know him better than we really do. And notwithstanding his wild popularity among Americans demonstrated just two weeks ago, he is in truth a puzzling and enigmatic figure, and is becoming more so as his troubles deepen.
We don't really know, to start with, how it came about that a man raised in the service of the Communist Party turned out to be such a radical reformer. Nor do we fully know if he started out with the intention of making controlled changes in the Soviet system in order to save it from stagnation, only to discover that he had set in motion an avalanche of unintended consequences and found himself presiding over the decline of the party and the disintegration of the Soviet empire, perhaps of the Soviet Union itself. 
On the personal level, we cannot be sure whether, in grappling with such intractable problems as the collapse of the economy, the drive toward independence of the Baltic and other national republics, the violence of nationality groups in the south and the polarization of Soviet politics, he is a master politician playing a shrewd tactical game, or is - as his critics and even some of his associates now say - a stubborn, stiff-necked, arrogant man. (I find myself thinking of something Dean G. Acheson once said when he was Secretary of State and I was working for him. We were driving through the streets of Rome, I believe it was, when we passed a statue of George Washington. ''Sometimes,'' Acheson observed, ''it is only in retrospect and in the light of how things work out that you can distinguish stubbornness from determination.'') To take the enigma of Mr. Gorbachev one step further: it is not clear whether his present efforts to gather autocratic authority into his hands reflect a personal taste for power, or a reluctant acceptance of the necessity for strong authoritarian leadership to effect a transition to a market economy and self-government under the rule of law. Nor whether even with these enhanced powers, his vacillations and delays reflect a personal indecisiveness, an understandable drain on his phenomenal stamina or our underestimation of the complex resistance he is encountering.
These are among the questions that come to mind in reading ''Gorbachev: Heretic in the Kremlin,'' by two respected journalists, Dusko Doder, the former Moscow bureau chief for The Washington Post, and Louise Branson, the former Moscow correspondent for The Sunday Times of London. The book is a narrative interpretation, written for a popular audience. As conscientious reporters with unusual access to many of the responsible actors, Mr. Doder and Ms. Branson convey a sense of the excitement attending the most intriguing political drama of our time. They cover events in considerable detail from Mr. Gorbachev's rise to power in March 1985 to the end of 1988. Their reporting is somewhat more sketchy for the period before 1985, and from 1989 to the early months of this year. (For Mr. Gorbachev's early life and career, readers will find Zhores A. Medvedev's 1986 biography more comprehensive and analytical.) The narrative jumps about a bit, and it does not pretend to provide final answers to the questions surrounding Mr. Gorbachev, but it is a useful reminder for general readers of the roller-coaster volatility of the tumultuous events of the last five years.
Mr. Doder and Ms. Branson have wrestled hard and, in the end, vainly with the problem of explaining how a man who saw himself as a committed Communist (''I am a communist, a convinced communist'') could come to see the Communist Party as an obstacle to be overcome. They note that as a law student, Mr. Gorbachev read such Western and non-Marxist thinkers as Rousseau, Aquinas, Hobbes, Machiavelli and Mill. They point out that he confided in friends his realization that in his native village the Stalinist system had not worked as pictured in the official propaganda, particularly in agriculture. And they explain that the experiences of his youth, including the arrest of his grandfather and the training in religious and traditional Russian values that he received from his mother and grandmother had taken him far from the fundamentalist dogma of the party. As a result, when he inaugurated his reforms, he perceived himself as working within the system, and saw no contradiction between the party and democratization.
The book portrays Mr. Gorbachev as an empiricist, not an intellectual - a man with an interest in ideas as tools and a deep faith in rationality, convinced that people would act reasonably if the facts were explained to them. Thus he was unprepared for the resistance he encountered from the party apparatus and from the ingrained conservatism of the population. Neither was he ready for the irrational, extreme behavior among some sectors of the nationalist minorities, for which he has shown little insight.
Through his glasnost campaign, to which he turned in his second year as General Secretary, Mr. Gorbachev hoped to make allies of the intelligentsia and to develop a revolution from below against the old-line apparatus. But the social forces he unleashed, the authors say, took on a life of their own, sweeping his revolution out of his control and creating ''the central paradox of Gorbachev's rule - the more he sought to disperse power, the more he found it necessary to concentrate power in his own hands.'' Beset by economic problems for which he had no answers, by breakaway republics, by ethnic violence, by a discredited and disintegrating Communist Party, by a polarization between conservative oppositionists and disorganized radical reformers who had in common only a mistrust of the new President, ''Gorbachev apparently came to the conclusion that the only way to succeed would be to revert to the classical 'revolution-from-above' tactics.''
The decade ahead, write Mr. Doder and Ms. Branson, will be one of turmoil and crisis though perhaps no more so, they say, than other periods of adversity that the country has surmounted in the past. But even if Mr. Gorbachev should not survive politically, they add, he will have left ''his personal imprint on the age,'' and his rule will have constituted a transitional period between authoritarianism and democracy. However, given the many complex and uncertain variables involved, the range of possible outcomes would also appear to include not only the ultimate realization of Mr. Gorbachev's reforms, but a decline into chaos and civil violence, or a conservative, nationalist and perhaps militaristic regime intent upon resurrecting the order of the past.
Even under the best of circumstances, there will be troubles ahead for the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. But there should be no doubt that it would be in the best interests of the world, the United States included, that the reform process in the Soviet Union should continue and, however long it may take, should succeed. There are some among us who believe they would rejoice to see the reform efforts collapse, but they seriously underestimate the dangerous consequences that would follow. They would, before long, come to ask themselves whether we had been sufficiently responsive to the opportunities we now have to support, at least marginally, this historic transformation.
 
NEW FACE AT THE TOP
 It is difficult to know what exactly transpired during the twenty-four-hour period following Chernenko's death. The Kremlin chooses its leaders in total secrecy. But from public pronouncements and private disclosures it is clear that Gorbachev's election was no straightforward matter. It was, in fact, a close call. . . .
The crucial role at the plenum was played by Gromyko, the senior Politburo member who had come to symbolize in the eyes of the party the continuity of more than four decades of Soviet history. Gromyko's vote of confidence carried great weight with the three-hundred-member Central Committee, whose average age was sixty-six and who were temperamentally more favorably disposed toward the familiar Grishin. Gromyko spoke without notes, an indication of the haste and uncertainties surrounding the proceedings. He was both eloquent and unusually emotional, trying to reassure the Old Guard that Gorbachev was tough and shrewd and that they should not be deceived by his youth.
''Comrades,'' one Central Committee member later quoted Gromyko as saying, ''this man has a nice smile but he's got iron teeth.''
 
From ''Gorbachev: Heretic in the Kremlin.''

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
WHAT WENT WRONG, WHAT TO DO

BYLINE: By CORY DEAN

 BODY:
PERIL AND PROMISE: A Commentary on America. By John Chancellor. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) As John Chancellor, the television commentator, looks at the United States, he sees a country facing a complex and competitive world with great power but failing confidence. This loss of faith results, he writes, from ''years of hopes raised and hopes dashed'' - defeat in the ''moral blunder'' of Vietnam, the Arab oil embargo, Watergate, the hostage crisis, inflation and the ''wanton mismanagement of the nation's finances.'' The result of this moral, political and financial battering, he writes, was the Reaganism of the 1980's and its greed, its emphasis on short-term profits, its falling savings and rising debt, and the feeling that we will be even worse off in the future. But this country is still No. 1, he writes. It can remain No. 1, and there is no reason why it shouldn't be. Mr. Chancellor offers several remedies, like all-year schooling, compulsory national service, Congressional campaign reform, a Government ''technology policy'' to aid research and development, a means test for Social Security. None are new; even his most startling idea, the abolition of Presidential primaries and the return of the nominating process to the convention floor, has been proposed before. But they are interesting ideas, and it is disappointing that Mr. Chancellor did not devote more time to them. People who have been paying attention to current events may find little to engage them. But the book seems to be aimed at the people who aren't paying attention. It is written in such simple language and assumes so little knowledge on the part of the reader that some may find it off-putting. On the other hand, if it's true that 24 million Americans cannot find their own country on a map, many people need such a user-friendly book. If they can be induced to read it, they will find it valuable and interesting.

LENGTH: 1782 words

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL

BYLINE: THOMAS GEORGE

 BODY:
Braxton Banks missed the 1989 Notre Dame football season because of a leg injury. Banks, a running back, toiled last March over a delicate decision: whether to return for his final season at Notre Dame and earn his degree in English, or enter the National Football League draft in April and lose his Notre Dame fscholarship and eligibility.
Banks opted for the draft, as did Brad Gaines, a Vanderbilt running back. Both were among 20 college juniors who were not drafted. Now most have no degree, no school, no football.
''He labored with his decision extensively, up to the last minute, and it was probably the most difficult decision of his life,'' Priscilla Banks, Braxton's mother, said of her son, who is pondering his next move. ''Our phone bill during that period was $275. He was one semester from graduating with an English degree. You hate to see the hurt in that kid's eyes.'' 
 
Shocked at Result
Gaines said he was shocked when he failed to be among the 331 college players selected through 12 draft rounds. He remains near Vanderbilt at his home outside of Nashville, training and waiting, hopeful that a pro team will call.
''I had led the Southeastern Conference in receptions with 70 last year,'' Gaines said, ''and even though I wasn't sure this was the route I wanted to go, I was confident I would at least be drafted. I've just been lifting and staying in shape. I'd like to have known what I know now. Sure, I'd like to go back to school. I'm 12 hours short of a degree in health promotion.''
When the N.F.L decided to make it easier for college juniors to enter the draft, a record 38 did, all understanding that to enter the draft, they must forfeit their athletic scholarships and college careers. Such well-known juniors as Jeff George, an Illinois quarterback, and Andre Ware, the Houston quarterback and Heisman Trophy winner, strode confidently into the draft, certain they would be among the top selections. Eighteen juniors were drafted. Twenty were not. For several juniors, the move was a high-roll risk from the start.
Chris Mongeau was ineligible for college play because he had played a year of semipro football and had signed with an agent.
Mongeau spent a year in a Maine preparatory school and the following 1988-89 year as a center at American-International. When his grandmother, great-grandmother and great-grandfather all died in May 1989, he withdrew from school and played one season for the semipro New England Crusaders.
Three N.F.L. teams expressed interest in Mongeau while he was a Crusader. Thus, in April, he decided to enter the draft.
 
Tryout With Cowboys
''But not too many teams,'' Mongeau said, ''were interested on draft day.'' Mongeau opted for a May tryout with the Dallas Cowboys.
''I just got back from the Cowboys tryout,'' he said. ''There were 500 of us boys there. Not one made it.''
Mongeau, who is 6 feet 3 inches and 300 pounds, returned to his home in South Hadley, Mass., to train and work as a bouncer at an exotic dance club. Soon that job became too dangerous, he said.
He thought he had found a new job last weekend, working at a dock near his home. But when he arrived at the dock last Monday at 5 A.M., he was told the position had been filled. That afternoon, his girlfriend broke up with him.
''It seemed like nothing was going right,'' said Mongeau, who is 21 years old. ''But now I've got another invitation to a camp, the Houston Oilers', and the Jets and the New England Patriots have contacted my agent. I'm confident I can play in the N.F.L., and I'll go any route to get there.''
 
New Plan Weighed
Dick Schultz, executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, wants college juniors to be free to test their N.F.L. market value, if they choose, by going through the draft, without risking loss of their college eligibility.
Among the groups looking into that option is the Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics, a 22-member group that includes college presidents, business executives and congressmen. The commission's chief goal is to explore ways to reform college athletics.
''When a kid first enters the draft, he's not too worried, and then it's hard for him to accept he's not one of the superstars,'' said Roger Valdiserri, associate athletic director at Notre Dame and executive assistant of the Knight Commission. ''These poor kids should be able to come back, even though a lot of them didn't listen to how slim their chances were.''
Dave Cawood, assistant executive director of the N.C.A.A., said: ''As good as the concept is, there's a lot of work to be done on it. Hopefully, we can have it in place by '91. But '92 is more practical. There is unfortunately nothing that can be done to assist these 20 individuals. No one has the authority to vacate the rules. It is unfortunate, but honest.''
 
Advice From Many
The juniors with a year of eligibility remaining were inundated with conflicting advice.
Some agents and family members urged them to enter quickly, stressing that this might be the last time for rookies to gain big contract dollars because a rookie wage scale, which was among the measures the N.F.L. club owners considered at their meeting in Dallas in May, might be in place in 1992. They were told that an injury during senior year might result in no pro opportunity at all.
Club executives and college coaches strongly advised a return to school. They said the roster limit of 80 signed players would limit an athlete's chances of even gaining a summer tryout. They said George, Ware and Barry Sanders were exceptions.
George, the first player selected in the draft, signed a six-year, $15 million contract with the Indianapolis Colts. Ware was drafted No. 7 by the Detroit Lions. Sanders was rookie of the year this season and an All-Pro running back with the Detroit Lions. In all, 8 juniors were selected in the first round, 3 in the second, and 15 by the fifth.
In the pro baseball draft, a junior does not have to declare for the draft. He is simply drafted at large and can decide to remain in college. In the pro basketball and football drafts, a junior must declare for the draft.
''The athlete has a chance, only through his university, to ask that his case be heard for eligibility and the possibility, as remote as it is, is there that it will be restored,'' said Janet Justus, the N.C.A.A.'s director of eligibilty. ''The basic priniciple of amateurism for the N.C.A.A. states that if you sign with an agent, receive money or enter the draft, you are a professional. The line has been drawn for a very long time. No player could have entered the draft without knowing this, because they signed an affidavit that said so.''
 
Limbo Situation a Concern
There is a move afoot, however, to re-draw the line. But Pat Dye, the Auburn football coach, shares the belief in the N.F.L. that the change might not be beneficial.
''I think it would be a drastic mistake,'' Dye said. ''The kid's in limbo for six months and he's thinking about his pro career instead of going to class. That would do more to damage pro football than the N.C.A.A. or the N.F.L. could do.''
Meanwhile, the 20 undrafted athletes look for other ways to continue pursuing their football careers.
One option they hope to explore is the World League of American Football, a league sponsored by the N.F.L. and scheduled to open next spring. The league, considered a stepping stone to the N.F.L., will use 700 players on 12 teams: 6 teams in the United States, 4 in Europe and 1 each in Canada and Mexico.
 
A Stark Reminder
''The 700 players will be seniors out of college, players under contract in the N.F.L. who need extra work, and all those guys the N.F.L. misses that later become pro bowlers,'' said Tex Schramm, the new league's president. ''I've always been a strong believer that young men should complete their four years and graduate before pro football. It takes painful experiences like this group of 20 to remind us.
''Everybody predicted this was going to happen. As far as trying out for our league, at their age, a year away from football shouldn't hurt them. But for some reason, they weren't drafted. A lot of it comes down to ability.''
Not all the juniors faced the same either-or situation when entering the draft. Some, like Anthony Burnett, a former U.C.L.A. defensive back, and Octavius Gould, a former Minnesota running back, were already academically ineligible and had missed the entire 1989 season.
John Mefford, a former Carson-Newman defensive tackle, has given up on his pro football dreams. He earned a degree in management last May and is interviewing with corporations. For the moment, he is home in La Follette, Tenn., working part-time for his brother.
Jeff Klemp, a former linebacker at Kansas, has traveled as roundabout a route as any of his peers. After graduating from high school in Kansas, Klemp attended a preparatory school in Boston and a spent a summer at Columbia University before joining the Kansas football team as a walk-on last fall.
 
Wants Career as Punter
''I wanted to punt, and everywhere I've been they've tried to make me everything else,'' Klemp said. ''I'm one semester short of getting a degree in economics, but being a pro punter is what I want. I'm probably one of the best punters around if I get a look. Not too many people in the pros can punt as high as I can.''
Klemp is back home in Leavenworth, Kan., working at construction jobs from 6:45 A.M. to 7 P.M. At 5:30 A.M., he's at the local high school kicking footballs, and after work, too, until about 8:30.
''If I had been at a school where I had been able to punt right away, I never would have been in the draft this year in the first place,'' Klemp said. ''I've got another punting camp coming up and I'm gonna be ready for a tryout somewhere to make the N.F.L. and to stay.''
