HEADLINE: TYSON WINS IN 1st ROUND

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 16

 BODY:
Mike Tyson, in his first bout since losing his heavyweight title, detonated a right hand on the chin of Henry Tillman and knocked him out at 2:47 of the first round of a scheduled 10-round bout tonight at Caesars Palace.
Until that point, the overeager Tyson had been unable to get the big punches in as Tillman ran and grabbed.
But once he nailed Tillman with the right hand, the fight was over.
Tillman fell backward to the canvas. He pushed the mouthpiece out with his tongue and, with a dazed expression, took the 10-count from the referee, Richard Steele, while on his back. 
 
Convincing Knockout
The convincing knockout gave Tyson some solace in his comeback after the shocking loss of his heavyweight title this past February to James (Buster) Douglas in a 10th-round knockout.
Tyson, who weighed 217 pounds, is now 38-1 with 34 knockouts. Tillman, who weighed 215 pounds, dropped to 20-5 with 14 knockouts.
George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, moved ever closer to a showdown bout against Tyson, or possibly a world-title shot, when he knocked out Adilson Rodrigues of San Paulo, Brazil, at 2:39 of the second round of a scheduled 10-round bout earlier tonight. #89-Degree Night Foreman, who worked economically in the 89-degree evening heat, exploded a three-punch combination late in the second round to get Rodrigues in big trouble. Foreman started with a jab, followed with a straight right hand then dropped the 29-year-old Rodrigues with a left hook.
Rodrigues fell onto the seat of his trunks and rolled onto his side. With his right hand, he grasped the lowest strand of the ring ropes, trying to get himself erect as the referee, Carlos Padilla, counted.
Rodrigues was unable to regain his feet and Padilla counted him out.
 
Foreman Jolts Rodrigues
Foreman, who weighed 263 pounds, stalked the circling Rodrigues in the climactic round, jolting him with uppercuts to the body and head before he landed the conclusive final combination.
Foreman had lost the first round on the scorecard of two of the three judges.
For Foreman, who says he is 41 years old, it was his 22d consecutive victory since he returned to the ring in March 1987 after a 10-year absence from boxing.
Foreman earned $1 million for his demolition of Rodrigues. Rodrigues reportedly received $175,000.
Foreman is now 67-2 with 63 knockouts. Rodrigues dropped to 36-4 with 26 knockouts.
The Foreman and Tyson bouts were designed as a prelude to a card that again would co-feature both fighters in separate bouts.
That event was predicated on both men winning tonight and was scheduled for Sept. 8 at Caesars Palace. The plan was for Tyson to box Alex Stewart and Foreman to meet a top-10 opponent.
Originally, Francesco Damiani of Italy had been designated as Foreman's opponent for the September match. But earlier today, Seth Abraham of Home Box Office, which televised tonight's bouts and has the live rights to the Sept. 8 card, said that Damiani was no longer in the picture.
 
W.B.O. Champion
Abraham said that because Damiani holds the heavyweight title of the fledgling World Boxing Organization, HBO was reluctant to have him as Foreman's opponent.
''We spent $22 million for a series that unified the heavyweight title,'' said Abraham, ''and it just doesn't make sense to me to create a situation that would encourage 'another' champion.''
Abraham also said that he sensed Tyson's promoter, Don King, and Tyson himself would be uneasy about a future Tyson-Foreman bout in which Foreman held a world title, even one as devalued as the W.B.O.'s.
''I believe Don wants the fighters to have parity when they meet,'' said Abraham.
Because of those considerations, Abraham said, Foreman's next opponent was expected to be selected from a group that included fighters like Michael Dokes, Tim Witherspoon, and Jose Ribalta.
But Bob Arum, Foreman's promoter, said Damiani could still be Foreman's next opponent.
Were Foreman and Tyson to win their back-to-back HBO co-features, then both men were expected to fight each other later this year, or sometime next year, in a bout that would likely be the biggest grossing match in the history of boxing.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2351 words

HEADLINE: The Rental Market Loosens Up a Bit

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
ACROSS the New York region, there is good news for renters. There are many more apartments and houses available for rent; rents on market-rate units are either stable or falling, and landlords are courting tenants with aggressive promotions.
In contrast to the mid-80's, when it seemed that any living unit could be rented for more than the year before, now rents, like selling prices, are on the negotiating table.
To be sure, New York and its suburbs remain among the most expensive rental markets in the nation. The region's shortage of low-income housing remains acute, businesses are limiting their expansion because homes and apartments are too expensive for their employees, and rents continue to rise for most tenants, although at a slower rate. 
But in an area where finding a decent place to rent has almost always been a daunting task, basic economic shifts appear to have made it slightly easier. Thousands of co-ops, condominiums and houses, all of them unregulated and most of them unsalable in a weak resale market, have been brought onto the rental market, heightening the competition for tenants.
In New York City, where rent increases on most apartments are limited by rent-stabilization laws, owners of the more expensive units say they often are unable to charge the maximum increases allowed by the guidelines because their tenants will move out and others are hard to find. Regulated apartments with below-market rents, however, continue to be scarce.
''There are no screaming bargains out there, but at the moment, renting appears to be the right thing to do,'' said Jeff Aron son, a financial analyst on Wall Street who last month rented a two-bedroom apartment on West End Avenue in Manhattan after selling a nearby one-bedroom co-op he had bought in 1986.
His reasons reflect the crosscurrents of psychology and economics that are reshaping the New York area housing market. Although he and his wife, Shari, a bank executive, could have bought another apartment, Mr. Aronson said they did not think the value of New York City co-ops and condominiums would increase over the next two years, and might decline.
''By renting, we don't face the financial risk,'' he said, adding that he was convinced the money necessary for a down payment on a home could be invested more profitably elsewhere. In selling his apartment, Mr. Aronson did well in a weak resale market. He said he profited from the sale. But many homeowners are unwilling to accept the prices they now would get for their houses, co-ops or condominiums, so they have put them on the market as rentals.
IN one reflection of the shift, Manhattan real estate executives say their rental listings, which had been dominated by apartments owned by large landlords and management companies, now contain an equal number of properties owned by small investors and individuals.
Indeed, the ''rent-to-buy'' option, allowing rent to be counted toward a down payment on a later purchase, is emerging as the marketing tool of the 90's. In contrast to the real estate slowdown of the late 70's and early 80's - when the problems resulted from soaring interest rates and many determined sellers turned to second mortgages or other forms of creative financing to sell their homes - hundreds of homeowners are now trying to rent out their properties temporarily, until the resale market recovers.
For some, the decision may prove wise, partly because Federal tax deductions are almost always bigger for those who rent out than for those who live in their homes. Some owners are also able to depreciate their properties, and claim tax reductions, when they rent them out.
But the landlords, small and large alike, are confronting another new reality: an economic slowdown that has reduced demand for some types of rental housing. With corporations cutting back on recruitment, and demographic shifts bringing fewer college graduates and other young apartment-seekers to city and suburbs alike, apartments that might have been snapped up in hours during the mid-80's now go begging.
''The overall trend is a decline in rents,'' said Nancy Packes, president of the Feathered Nest, a Manhattan brokerage. In an analysis of over 6,000 transactions, she found rents had declined steadily since 1987 on several types of apartments.
In one category, rent-stabilized, one-bedroom apartments in buildings without doormen on the East Side, she said, average rents fell from $1,400 a month in December 1987 to $1,100 in May. In another - market rate two-bedroom apartments with doormen on the West Side - the average rent fell from $2,750 in December 1987 to $2,400 in May.
Hardest hit by the change are people who invested in homes, principally condominiums, at the height of the region's real estate boom in the mid-80's. Many hoped to rent them out and sell later at a profit, but have so far been sorely disappointed.
''People are between a rock and hard place,'' said Arthur Baer, a Manhattan lawyer who represents several co-op boards and real estate investors who became an investor himself in 1985 when he bought a one-bedroom condominium on East 79th Street, intending to rent it out.
Things went smoothly at first, Mr. Baer said, when a tenant signed on for a one-year lease at $1,750 a month. When that tenant left, the market was softer; his second tenant paid $1,650 a month and ''skipped out in the middle of the night'' midway through his lease, Mr. Baer said.
That was in 1987, and things have gotten worse. He said two other short-term tenants moved in, paying successively lower rents, and the apartment is now leased at $1,500 a month. Meanwhile, Mr. Baer said, his taxes and other expenses on the condominium have risen and he is losing $700 a month on the investment even while it is rented. His hopes for an eventual profit await a sale when the market recovers.
Although the case is extreme, it reflects the pressures faced by landlords across New York City and its suburbs. But for those looking for a rental, options are expanding:
* In Morris County, N.J., the owners of Knoll Gardens, a complex of 1,108 garden apartments in Lake Hiawatha, are offering four-day trips to Orlando, Fla., or Myrtle Beach, S.C., to those who sign leases on some apartments that have been slow to rent. The rents range from $630 a month for a one bedroom to $845 a month for a two bedroom.
* The ''rent-to-buy'' option has become commonplace. The approach has many variations, often allowing tenants to apply part or all of their rent to a pre-established sale price.
* In New York City, one of the biggest burdens of people seeking a rental - brokers' fees that typically amount to 15 percent of the first year's rent - are no longer an inevitable expense. Increasingly, brokers say, landlords are picking up part or all of the fee themselves to attract tenants.
* The boards of co-ops, which in most cases have imposed strict rules that discourage shareholders from subletting, are under pressure to liberalize the rules. Although many have resisted the change, some now are allowing more rental tenants in their buildings to avoid defaults by people who must move and cannot sell their apartments.
* Some developers and sponsors who have converted rental buildings to co-ops and condominiums and who have apartments they have been unable to sell are under pressure from their banks to put the vacancies on the market as rentals.
The changes in the rental market appear to be having the biggest impact on the most expensive properties.
''There is market resistance,'' said Richard LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, which owns hundreds of New York City apartment buildings and ranks among its biggest landlords. ''The more expensive the property,'' he added, ''the thinner the market gets.''
Like other large landlords who operate buildings under New York City's rent- stabilization rules, Mr. LeFrak is all but assured of rent increases on most of his apartments because the guidelines have kept rents low and his tenants would not be able to find better deals.
More than 70 percent of New York City's 1.9 million apartments are covered by rent stabilization or rent control, according to a 1987 survey conducted by Michael A. Stegman, chairman of the City and Regional Planning Department at the University of North Carolina. The survey - the most exhaustive analysis available of New York City housing - is done every three years. The 1990 update has not been completed.
Current guidelines permit 5.5 percent increases on the renewal of one-year leases or 9 percent on two-year renewals. When a rent-stabilized unit is vacated, landlords can increase the rent 12 percent for a new tenant. Rent-stabilization rules also govern many buildings in Westchester and on Long Island. Other rent regulations limit increases in Fort Lee, Weehawken and other New Jersey communities.
Despite the regulations, however, landlords are unable to raise rents to the allowable limit in some cases, particularly on expensive apartments that have recently come under rent guidelines, or on apartments that have changed tenants frequently. Rents on these apartments may have risen to a point where better deals can be found elsewhere.
SOME tenants are negotiating for something less than the maximum increase. ''Rent stabilization notwithstanding, we are dealing with supply and demand,'' Mr. LeFrak said.
Other real estate executives say one of the biggest changes in the market has been the rapid increase in the number of apartments put on the market by individual owners and investors. They are not covered by the rent guidelines, and since they tend to be higher-priced apartments with high turnover rates, they are plentiful among the listings in classified advertisements and at brokerages.
David Tannenbaum, manager of the Greenwich Village office of Sopher Real Estate, said about half of his current inventory of 2,000 apartments for rent are owned by small investors or individuals. Rents have decreased in the last two years, he said, from an average of $1,100 to $900 a month for studios; $1,500 to $1,350 for one-bedrooms and $2,000 to $1,800 for two-bedrooms.
Some of the investor-owned apartments represent good rental bargains because they are often newer or in better condition than rent-stabilized units. Many are also being offered with some form of option to buy.
For those who do not intend to buy, Mr. Tannenbaum said, stabilized apartments are preferable because they offer protection to tenants against being forced to move if the apartment is sold. Usually, he added, investor-owned apartments are on the market as rentals only because their owners are waiting until they can be sold at a profit. Their rental tenants can be compelled to move at the end of their leases.
Still, unless the resale market for co-ops, condominiums and homes becomes more robust soon, executives said, they expect to see more rentals put on the market by individual owners and investors. One reason is that Federal tax laws, which eliminated many of the benefits for real estate investment with the revisions of 1986, retain some benefits for individuals who rent out their property.
One of the benefits comes from the deductions that people can claim as landlords that they could not claim as owner occupants. Since operating a rental property is a business expense, the cost of improvements, insurance, utilities, security and other services can be deducted for tax purposes.
Another benefit for some small landlords comes through rules covering depreciation. Although the benefits have been sharply reduced for those whose household income is over $100,000, people whose earnings fall below the limit can depreciate the full cost of their homes, including improvements, over a schedule of 27.5 years.
For most people making under $100,000 a year, that means they can divide the amount they paid for their home by 27.5, and deduct that much from the taxable income each year. As a result of the combined tax benefits, people who rent out their homes may be saving hundreds of dollars each month. And while the savings by themselves are rarely enough to make the investment in a co-op, condominium or house profitable, they are an incentive that has led many to rent out their properties temporarily in hopes that the resale market will improve.
''When things are not selling, the rental market is a savior,'' said Geri Sheehan, a broker who specializes in rentals for Murphy Realty in Fort Lee. Nonetheless, she added, most investors who rent out their property are not receiving enough in rent to cover all their costs.
Brokers in the region have begun new promotions aimed at helping frustrated sellers rent out their homes. One such is M. J. Raynes, with offices in Manhattan and Brooklyn, which has listings for rentals that give tenants a ''right of first refusal,'' meaning they are given the first option to buy their apartments at the same price that someone offers their landlords.
Roberta Faulstick, manager of the firm's offices in Greenwich Village, Brooklyn Heights and the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, said 20 percent of her listings for apartments were on the market as either resales or rentals, whichever would give the owner an acceptable return.
Judith Miles, a Manhattan lawyer who has been renting apartments in Brooklyn Heights for more than 20 years, said she encountered new options when she looked for a bigger apartment in April. One was an offer of an attractive rent in a co-op that had what she was looking for, she said. But she said passed it by because the owners insisted on reserving the right to sell it after a year.
Ms. Miles, who said she has no intention of buying soon, settled on a large six-room rent-stabilized apartment. Since then, she said, she has been reminded of how eager landlords are to find tenants because brokers have called her about the same apartments that are still vacant two months later. ''There are a lot of apartments that have been on the market for a long time,'' she said. ''My phone has been ringing off the wall.''

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Rent Guidelines;
Gathering Data for a Board's Judgment

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A CURIOUS thing happened this year on the way to the annual hearings of the New York City's Rent Guidelines Board. The board met May 9 and proposed new guidelines, doing so before it had in hand the cost study that is supposed to play the key role in formulating the guidelines.
Last week the study came in. It suggests that the proposed guidelines may be too low by a fair margin. So now the board may be in the position of adopting a guideline higher than the one it proposed, or finding valid reasons why other standards justify holding to its position.
At the least, the situation throws into question the wisdom of proposing guidelines in the absence of more complete information. In May the board acted primarily on the basis on hastily assembled rent information from the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, and on preliminary cost data brought forward by its staff. 
The procedural system is peculiar. The board has decided that its procedures are governed by the city's Administrative Procedures Act of 1988, a precursor to the City Charter revision of 1989.
The act requires that when any city agency drafts a new rule, it has to give 30-days' notice before the rule is adopted. Thus the Rent Guidelines Board must have a publicly announced proposal before it can hold a public hearing.
When this procedure was followed last year, the cost study was already available. The final guidelines were lower than the initial proposal.
This year the public hearings will take place on Wednesday and Thursday at Police Plaza auditorium, near the Municipal Building. The final guidelines will be adopted at a meeting June 25. All meetings are open to the public, and although people are not called upon to speak, demonstrative behavior by the audience makes the scene stormy.
The problem this year came in the Board of Estimate. It was not exactly brisk in agreeing to award the contract for the cost study. Approval came on April 18, not in time to complete the work for the May meeting.
Approval also came on a 7-to-4 vote, and only after Mayor David N. Dinkins had acceded to Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman's insistence that he call upon the guidelines board to end the surcharge it has permitted in the last few years on apartments renting for under $325 a month. Ms. Holtzman said the surcharge unfairly burdens those least able to pay. Direct intrusion by a Mayor into the setting of rent guidelines is a departure.
The Rent Guidelines Board has nine members. Two represent tenants and two represent owners. Five, including the chairman, are ''public'' members. Mayor Dinkins's appointee as chairman was Aston L. Glaves, director of Project Find, a nonprofit organization that operates low-income housing. One of the other public members, Janice S. Robinson, an assistant dean at Rutgers Law School, made the guidelines proposal May 9. It was supported by Mr. Glaves and Ellen Gesmer, a lawyer who was appointed on the eve of the hearing. The two other public members - Victor Marrero, a lawyer, and Agustin Rivera, an educator - abstained.
The proposal was for a 3 percent increase on a one-year lease and 5 percent on a two-year lease, the lowest two-year guideline ever. The allowable vacancy increase, applicable when one tenant moves out and another moves in, was proposed at 5 percent, the lowest figure since 1983.
ON May 23 the Rent Stabilization Association filed a lawsuit trying to annul Ms. Gesmer's appointment. The suit says that she lacks the five years of experience in either finance, economics or housing that the stabilization law requires of public members.
Now comes the report from the consultant, Speedwell Inc. of Duxbury, Mass. It finds that the price index of operating costs rose 10.9 percent between April 1989 and April 1990. This was the largest rise in the index in the last nine years. It went up 6.7 percent last year. Last year's guideline allowed a 5.5 percent increase on a one-year lease and 9 percent on a two-year lease.
The steep rise in the index this year was a result of large jumps in heavily weighted categories. In the taxes, fees and permits category, for example, the index went up 12 percent, mostly because of assessment increases. This was less than the 17 percent rise last year, but with an ''expenditure weight'' of 22 percent, it is the most heavily weighted of all expense categories.
The index for fuel costs rose 20.9 percent, compared with a decline in the preceding year. That was mainly because fuel prices rose last winter during the peak season for fuel use. There was also a large rise in the utilities price index - up 20.8 percent. That seems to have been caused primarily by a rise in water and sewer rates, a principal component of the utilities price index.
Next to taxes, the most heavily weighted indexes are for fuel, utilities, labor costs and contractor services. The latter two went up 5 percent and 6 percent, respectively.
How all this information is used is a matter of judgment. Other factors besides the price index are used in establishing guidelines. For example, when investments competitive with real estate pay higher returns, guidelines officials must consider whether they want to keep housing competitive.
Tenant groups have long argued that using an index of prices and costs to set rent guidelines is invalid and that a building's income and expense data should be used instead. Owners oppose ''opening the books'' to accountants representing tenants. But in the last week even income and expense data have become available.
The staff of the Rent Guidelines Board analyzed income and expense data from 500 buildings that were submitted to the Finance Department for assessment purposes. By law the department cannot make these figures public for individual buildings, but it can provide summary statistics.
There is an enormous range in the fraction of the rent dollar that buildings pay for operating costs, from 16 cents of every dollar to more than 100 cents when properties, for whatever reason, are absorbing losses.
But on average the data showed that 72 cents out of each rent dollar collected for all regulated apartments (and 65 cents for each dollar of gross rent collected, which includes rent from nonresidential space) went for operating expenses.
WHEN the data are adjusted to remove income from rent-controlled units and certain unrelated costs, the figure for stabilized units alone is estimated at 61 cents for each rental dollar. The staff says this ratio is higher than earlier studies that were based on registered rents, rather than collected rents, have indicated.
The Institute of Real Estate Management of the National Association of Realtors, based in Chicago, keeps national data on average operating costs of multifamily buildings. In 1988, they accounted for 46 percent of collected rents in the Northeast, 54 percent in the Midwest and 51 percent in the Far West, the association said.
In New York City, when the stabilization of unregulated postwar apartments began in 1969, the average was calculated at 55 cents on the dollar, or 55 percent. The ratio rose substantially in the 70's but has subsided since. The current 61 percent calculation is the proper one to use for comparability, the guidelines board's staff says, because it is based on information about building income and expenses similar to that used in 1969.
The rent money left over after the payment of operating costs and taxes goes for debt service and return on capital investment. In principle, the lower the ratio of operating costs to total rent, the larger the debt the building can support and the greater its value to a buyer.
As for New York City rent levels, the income data showed that average collected rents were $453 a month. The averages ranged from $594 a month in Manhattan to $360 a month in the Bronx. When data from the city's housing and vacancy survey were applied to adjust the figures so they would show rents in stabilized apartments only (excluding rent-controlled units), the average worked out to $483 a month.
At the May 9 meeting, the subject of average rents was a matter of great interest to board members. Data from the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal told them that the average registered rent citywide last year was $523 ($677 in Manhattan; $481 in Staten Island; $471 in Queens; $421 in Brooklyn and $403 in the Bronx).
At the public hearings this week, owner and tenant representatives can be expected to dwell on the issue of how average rents and costs have changed.

HEADLINE: Hardy Leaders Arrange Far-Flung Vacations

BYLINE: By RUTH ROBINSON

 BODY:
THE usual kind of touristy vacation does not satisfy Bill and Joanne Russell, of Fairfield. They say they would rather explore out-of-the-way places, preferably on foot or on skis, and share the experience with like-minded members of the Appalachian Mountain Club.
''It's really fun to have the camaraderie of a group, not just two people,'' said Mr. Russell, who has his own financial services business. ''It's wonderful to have a gang together,'' concurred his wife, a yacht-charter broker. 
Last March, the Russells enjoyed a week of cross-country skiing in untracked powder from a remote hut in the Shrine Pass area of the Colorado Rockies. Now, the couple and their friends are ready to hike, from July 7 to 21, in the Canton Valais of southwestern Switzerland, a French-speaking region that sees few tourists. For next summer, they plan a cruise of the Greek Islands and the Turkish coast with an archeological guide.
Two other club members, Barry and Ella May Wulff, of North Windham, both biologists, took a group hiking in New Zealand in January. They are paying their second visit to Iceland from July 1 to 15, and they have scheduled a trip to Patagonia from Dec. 30 to Jan 16.
''My husband has a great desire to see the entire world,'' Mrs. Wulff said. ''And this is a way of doing it.'' Along with the hiking, she said, their trips place strong emphasis on the natural history of the areas they visit.
 
Free Trips for Leaders
The Wulffs and Russells, members of the Connecticut Chapter of the Appalachian Mountain Club, organize major excursions for the Boston-based organization. The club has 37,500 members, including 4,744 in Connecticut.
The leaders are usually compensated with a free trip, but Mr. Russell said a lot of work is involved, especially for those who lead two or three trips annually, as he and his wife do. Responsibility for the group's welfare and enjoyment can weigh heavily, he said.
Sue Hardy, of Manchester, who has been leading major excursions since 1978, said: ''It takes a certain mentality to lead and to participate. You have to realize people in the group don't want to make a lot of nit-picky decisions. If they wanted to bother, they'd go on their own.''
The 16-member Easter week trip to Bryce and Zion National Parks that Mrs. Hardy led with her son David worked out well, she said. But an Australian hiking trip planned for June 22 to July 14 was canceled, she said, because too few people were ready to pay nonrefundable deposits for the air fare.
Mrs. Hardy and other trip leaders said they sense that the current economic situation is curtailing foreign travel for many.
 
Close Supervision
The Russells said they limit their long-distance backpack trips to 12 people, to reduce the impact on the environment. They take as many as 16 ski touring, they said, and consider 24 a manageable number on hotel trips. When cruising, they usually charter three yachts, each sleeping six.
Mr. Russell said the leaders are closely supervised by the Appalachian Mountain Club's major excursions committee, of which he and his wife are longtime members. Proposals for major excursions, defined as trips that last more than one week or take participants more than 500 miles from home, must be submitted at least eight months before the departure date. First-time leaders, like Leona Klerer, of Stamford, are required to be present at the committee meeting when their trip is being considered.
Ms. Klerer will be off to Yosemite National Park in California from July 29 to Aug. 11 with her co-leader, Judith Dortz, and 14 companions. She said she prepared herself by organizing many weekend trips and a five-day hiking excursion in Vermont for the club's Connecticut Chapter and by attending mountain leadership school in Pinkham Notch, N.H.
''I find satisfaction in leading and helping and directing people,'' said Ms. Klerer, a teacher of remedial reading. Her group will hike at elevations of 7,000 to 10,000 feet, she said, staying overnight at high camps run by a concessionaire in the national park.
The Yosemite trip costs $1,550 per person, including air fare, land transportation in California, accommodations and most meals. Such trips tend to be less expensive for participants than commercial tours, since leaders are not out to make a profit and rooms are booked in rustic mountain huts or modest inns rather than fancy hotels. Most leaders work through a travel agent or wholesaler. For trips to underdeveloped countries, the leaders usually seek aid from an experienced outfitter, like Himalayan Travel, of Greenwich.
 
Alpine Skiing
Guy and Susan Wallis, of Manchester, are using a European wholesaler for two downhill ski trips to the French Alps - Feb. 15 to 24 at Trois Vallees and March 1 to 10 at Avoriaz. They said they are getting better rates than they could line up themselves.
The cost for the March trip is estimated at $1,200 for seven nights in apartments in Avoriaz, one night in Geneva, air fare from New York, transfers in France and lift tickets. Mr. Wallis, a mechanical engineer, said he expects 30 to 35 skiers each week.
Jack Randall, of East Lyme, said he expects 24 participants for his Hawaiian Holiday from Jan. 14 to Feb. 1, at a cost of $2,300 for virtually everything except lunches. Plans call for a week each on the islands of Kauai and Hawaii, with the travelers staying in condominiums near the beach. Some participants will hike energetically, while others laze on the beach.
Rob and Connie Funk, of Manchester, have scheduled a particularly ambitious trek and wildlife safari in Tanzania from Feb. 12 to March 3, with the option of a seven-day extension to climb Mount Kilimanjaro from the Shira Plateau, rather than the typical tourist route.
Mr. Funk, who is in finance purchasing with Pratt & Whitney, and his wife, an educational consultant, both travel extensively on business. But they said they still enjoy planning club trips. ''One of the major attractions of the A.M.C. is the compatible people and the real group experience.'' said Mr. Funk.
The cost of the trip, arranged through Overseas Adventure Travel, in Cambridge, Mass., is high by club standards, around $3,225 plus airfare with an additional $2,000 for the ascent of Kilimanjaro. But the Funks said they are offering experiences not readily available on commercial tours, including an opportunity to experience the culture of the Masai tribe on a five-day trek through crater highlands of the Great Rift Valley.
Information on the Appalachian Mountain Club can be obtained from club headquarters, 5 Joy Street, Boston, Mass. 02108. The phone number is (617) 523-0636.

HEADLINE: Defense Workers Lobby to Save Jobs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
WORKERS and executives from UNC Naval Products, faced with the possible shutdown of the company's Montville plant, brought their case to Congress on Tuesday.
They told members of a House subcommittee that preserving UNC and its work force was in the best interest of the country but that time was running out.
UNC was one of two suppliers of nuclear reactors for the Navy's submarine fleet until March, when the Department of Energy decided to cut costs by giving all future marine reactor work to a single contractor, UNC's competitor, Babcox & Wilcox, of Lynchburg, Va.
Shortly after testifying before the House subcommittee on economic stabilization, the company's president, Bruce Andrews, said UNC has already reduced employment by 25 percent. ''We'll be down to 550 by the end of this year,'' he said, ''and down to 100 by the end of '91.'' 
 
Slim Chance of Retooling
Other defense contractors face sharp reductions in orders for planes, tanks and ships. New weapons systems, like the B-2 bomber, also may not survive Congressional scrutiny.
UNC Naval Products may be the first business in the nation faced with outright shutdown because of military cost-cutting measures. Unless the Bush Administration reverses its policy barring UNC from trading with foreign countries, chances are slim that the company can retool and generate other forms of business to keep going.
''The issue, we feel, is one of timing,'' Mr. Andrews told the subcommittee. ''Things have to happen rather rapidly in order to preserve the company.'' He referred to UNC's employees as ''veterans of the cold war.''
Mr. Andrews and an assistant were joined by eight longtime UNC employees, all of whom have been notified that they will be laid off within two years. The group flew to Washington for a day of testimony and private meetings with lawmakers and their aides.
They testified before the House subcommittee, which was considering legislation intended to help workers affected by Pentagon cutbacks get job training and other forms of assistance and to help companies switch into civilian lines of production.
 
Moral Obligation to Help
''This highly trained work force deserves more than 'Thank you, we don't want you anymore, goodbye,' '' said William LaChapelle, a 25-year veteran of UNC and founder of the S.O.S. Committee, set up by employees to lobby on behalf of the company. The Government, he said, has a moral obligation to help UNC.
The subcommittee's chairwoman, Representative Mary Rose Oakar, a Democrat of Ohio, agreed.
''We need to keep that industrial base alive in this country,'' she said. ''We don't want this company to fold.''
But the Bush Administration, which was not represented at Tuesday's hearing, has looked skeptically upon bills designed to convert defense industries. The Administration appears to have adopted a more free-market approach to the problem.
Also on the UNC group's agenda was a proposal by Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat from Bozrah that would allow the company to sell its highly classified reactors to such close allies as Great Britain and Canada.
Representative Gejdenson argues that close United States allies can be trusted with the reactor technology. In addition to keeping UNC in business, a change in export policy would also give the Navy continued access to a second supplier, should one be needed, without forcing the Navy to maintain business at a level sufficient to sustain two companies.
 
22,000 Signatures Gathered
The purpose of the ban on exports, Mr. Andrews said, is to prevent terrorists from obtaining nuclear fuels that could be used to manufacture weapons.
The UNC workers, who have been with their company an average of 15 years, have gathered 22,000 signatures from southeastern Connecticut and elsewhere in support of their cause.
''We wish we could save some jobs,'' said Bernie McKenna, who has been with UNC for nine years. ''We saw 50 of our friends go out the front door last Friday,'' he said, referring to the most recent round of layoffs at the plant, which now has just over 800 employees.
Mr. McKenna said he was told on April 12, his 36th birthday, that he would be out of work at the end of August.
More than half of the roughly 400 workers who have already lost their jobs are still trying to find work in the area that would pay them a salary equal to the $13 per hour they received at UNC.
For Don Wood, a 30-year UNC employee, the idea of training for another job or moving out of state to stay in the defense business is out of the question.
''What are we retraining for?'' Mr. Wood said. ''You take a person like me. I don't want to go back to college. I'm ready to retire.''

LENGTH: 560 words

HEADLINE: To Cut Costs, State Curbs Car Phones

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
CAR phones, once a symbol of power and success, are becoming a symbol of budget excess, at least for state officials.
The state is removing the phones from the cars of about 20 officials in an attempt to cut its $100,000 annual bill for car phones.
As a result of an order to cut costs issued earlier this year to all state agencies by Gov. William A. O'Neill, the Office of Policy and Management made each official with a car phone reapply for one and justify its need. 
''We made a determination as to what was absolutely necessary for public health and safety, said Dan Colarusso, executive director of information and technology in the Office of Policy and Management. ''And for those that did not fall into that category, we have issued a directive to discontinue service.''
Those who lost their car phones, effective last Friday, included some of Connecticut's top officials.
Among them were the president of the University of Connecticut, John T. Casteen 3d; the Education Commissioner, Gerald N. Tirozzi; the Human Resources Commissioner, Elliot A. Ginsberg; the Economic Development Commissioner, Stephen B. Heintz; the Banking Commissioner, Howard Brown, and the Housing Commissioner, John F. Papandrea.
Commissioner J. William Burns of the Transportation Department is giving up one of the three phones assigned to him.
Several deputy commissioners also lost phones, as did the presidents of Central Connecticut State University in New Britain and Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven.
Earlier, the State Comptroller, J. Edward Caldwell, and the Secretary of the Office of Policy and Management Anthony V. Milano, had turned in their car phones.
The State Treasurer, Francisco L. Borges, and Attorney General Clarine Nardi Riddle will keep theirs. Governor O'Neill, Lieut. Gov. Joseph J. Fauliso and Secretary of the State Julia H. Tashjian never had them.
Mr. Colarusso said that the state spent $108,000 during the last year on some 125 phones. He said it was difficult to estimate how much would be saved, but removing 18 phones is about 14 percent of the total, and he said ''we should reduce the bill by about that amount.''
The basic charge is $18 a month for each phone, plus 38 cents a minute. Officials with car phones are liable for personal calls made on them. For example, Mr. Borges and an aide who is also allowed to use the car phone, reimbursed the state more than $3,100 for personal calls made on his state car phone between July 1987 and February 1990. The Deputy Banking Commissioner, Paul J. McDonough, who is among those losing their car phones, reimbursed the state $171.46 in May for a series of personal calls he had made, The Hartford Courant reported.
In a letter to the officials losing their phones, Mr. Colarusso acknowledged that ''certainly there will be business inconveniences that result from this action; however, given the current situation, I am sure you will recognize that it is necessary to take this step.''
The phones being removed, he said, will be stored at the state's Office of Emergency Management, ''for future or emergency situations.''
Most of the remaining car phones are assigned to the Departments of Transportation and Environmental Protection, and the state police. Officials in the Departments of Correction, Motor Vehicles and Health Services also have them.

LENGTH: 1506 words

HEADLINE: School Board Group Facing Challenges

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
THE New Jersey School Boards Association, one of the state's most visible educational organizations, is under attack. In the wake of a blistering report by the State Commission of Investigation on its activities, a legislative assault and a revolt among some of its members, there is concern about the future of the 76-year-old organization.
''There are some legislators who think they hear a death rattle,'' said State Senator Matthew Feldman, Democrat of Teaneck, chairman of the Senate Education Committee and a strong supporter of the association.
The commission's highly critical report in April, charging mismanagement and fiscal irregularities, had a devastating effect on the association, which had expected some criticism after the three-yearinvestigation but was unprepared for the strong language and sharp censure in the report.
In recent weeks, however, morale has improved as the association has taken the offensive, describing how the organization began, and how it had started making changes as soon as the investigation began so that further problems could not occur. 
''No, I'm not worried about our future,'' said Jeremiah Regan, who was president of the association when the report came out and is a member of the Oceanport Board of Education. ''We've moved very rapidly and forthrightly to correct the deficiencies in our structure and particularly in our management system. I'm very confident that we will more than satisfy the Legislature and our own members that we're doing a good job. If they're not satisfied, then by God we'll go to whatever length is necessary to satisfy them.''
Questions about the association's future come at a time when boards of education across the state are already under fire for swollen budgets in tight fiscal times.
Founded in 1914, the association, which has headquarters in Trenton, represents local school boards at the state level and provides training and technical assistance for the state's 4,900 local school board members.
The trouble began in 1987 with the association's disclosure that an insurance fund administered by the organization had lost more than $800,000 because of bad investments. The commission concluded that the losses were symptomatic of ''much deeper problems'' within the association, ranging from general mismanagement to the squandering of taxpayers' money through extravagant dinners and double billing for expenses.
The commission held the association's executive director, Octavius T. Reid, ''primarily responsible'' for the problems and urged that he be dismissed. Mr. Reid, who has denied any wrongdoing, resigned last month.
Although all states have school board associations, New Jersey and Washington State are the only two with mandatory membership. The association's $7 million budget is financed largely through dues, ranging this year from $1,226 to $20,003, depending on the number of students a district has.
Even before the release of the commission report, there had been growing pressure to make membership in the association optional. State Senator Raymond J. Zane, Democrat of Woodbury, considers the current system a form of involuntary taxation.
''Currently, many districts are paying outrageous fees to belong to this association, and the money would be better spent on educating our children, especially in these difficult times,'' Mr. Zane said upon introducing a bill last month to allow voluntary participation in the association.
The association opposes the legislation, fearing that many school boards would withdraw, particularly since 48 percent of school budgets statewide were rejected by voters this year and boards have been forced to cut many items from their budgets.
 
Called a Counterbalance
In addition to offering training for school board members, the association has contended that it provides a vital service to the state by acting as a counterbalance to the teachers' unions.
''If we didn't exist, you'd have to invent something to do that,'' said Mr. Regan, whose term of office expired eight days ago. Mr. Zane's bill may face an uphill battle in the Legislature. ''I wouldn't say there is a lot of support,'' Mr. Feldman said. ''It was introduced at a timely moment when enthusiasm and confidence in budgets and school boards were at a low, but I will not be the executioner for the school boards.''
The Assembly Speaker, Joseph V. Doria Jr., Democrat of Bayonne, said: ''If you want a viable organization, you have to pay for it. It's played an important role in education for all these years, and trying to trash it now is wrong.''
Since the early 1980's, the New Jersey Education Association, a teachers' union, has supported a move to make membership in the School Boards Association optional.
''Just like membership in any association, you should do it because you think there are reasons you should have that relationship,'' said Debbie Scott, a spokeswoman for the teachers' union. ''Having to pay up to $20,000 a year depending on the number of students you have is unconscionable.''
 
Paying Dues as 'Agency Fee'
But to many association allies the union's argument is specious. Although teachers do not technically have to become members of the Education Association if the union is the bargaining agent in a particular school district, they have to pay 85 percent of the dues as an ''agency fee'' to cover the cost of negotiations.
The School Boards Association's fear that boards will leave if given the choice has not proved true in the 48 states that have optional membership. According to statistics compiled by the National School Boards Association, based in Arlington, Va., membership in state school associations ranges from a low of 84 percent in Missouri to 100 percent in 23 states, excluding New Jersey and Washington.
But Mr. Regan says he believes that New Jersey is in an unusual situation this year that makes it more vulnerable.
''Because of the budget problems this particular year and the bad press we brought upon ourselves with the S.C.I. report,'' he said, ''the environment is a tough one to work in at the moment.''
The New Jersey School Boards Association began to tighten its structure almost immediately after the insurance fund losses came to light. In addition to making the group that administers the fund an autonomous organization, it has adopted strict expenditure and accounting policies.
 
Recommendations Studied
A committee headed by Dr. John J. Petillo, president of Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey, is also studying the commission recommendations and will present its report in September.
In a somewhat odd comparison, the association's latest newsletter has likened Dr. Petillo, a former chancellor of Seton Hall University, to Toscanini, who could ''detect one wrong note from a second violin within the lush sound of the symphony orchestra.''
Dr. Petillo, the newsletter asserted, has been ''fine-tuning service organizations since 1976.''
For all the accusations in the commission's 105-page report, Mr. Regan acknowledges that it is fundamentally accurate.
''I think it was a reasonable presentation of the facts as I know them,'' Mr. Regan said. ''There was much more in there than I had ever known or even suspected.''
In the meantime, the association is facing tough economic times. Legal costs resulting from the state commission's investigation have been mounting and may ultimately exceed the $800,000 that was lost through the insurance fund investments. The association also has decided to keep next year's dues at this year's level to help offset the loss of state aid in school districts.
 
Dues Placed in Escrow
The hold on dues is not enough to keep some members happy. Woodbridge is one of several school districts placing their dues in escrow until the association permits optional membership, and even then there is a ''strong possibility'' that the district would not join, said Charles Famula, secretary to the Woodbridge Board of Education.
''We're disturbed that we're forced to be members,'' he said. ''The board feels we don't get anything out of membership outside of another lobbying organization in Trenton.'' The association is deeply troubled by such internal discord. ''It is obviously something that is of concern to the association, not so much because they're putting their dues into escrow, but because there has been an erosion of confidence in the association,'' said David Allen, a public relations consultant who is handling questions about the commission report for the association. ''We know we've got some rebuilding to do.''
Thomas Cannon, co-author of the commission report, says he believes that local school boards may hold the key to the association's future.
''Locals could very well decide the fate of the School Boards Association,'' he said. ''If the association doesn't want to bite the bullet and the Legislature doesn't want to change the law, local taxpayers and local boards could decide the fate of the association on their own.''

LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: The Task Facing Lowey's Challenger

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WHEN Nita M. Lowey decided two years ago to challenge Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, the two-term Republican from Westchester's 20th Congressional District, she faced some formidable obstacles: it was her first run for elected office, her opponent was well-financed and two other Democrats were seeking the post.
Mrs. Lowey dispatched her Democratic rivals in a primary, matched Mr. DioGuardi's $1.2 million campaign spending and demonstrated that 13 years in Albany as assistant secretary of state, an appointed position, was evidently suitable preparation for the race against Mr. DioGuardi, which she won by a margin of 2 percent.
Now, with Mrs. Lowey the incumbent, the Republican challenger in this year's Congressional race, Glenn D. Bellitto, faces a similarly formidable task: it is also his first try for elected office, his opponent is probably as well prepared financially as she was two years ago and his candidacy has been overshadowed to a degree by the awkward search that preceded it.
 
A Parade of Candidates
The first candidate to be offered the post - and to reject it - was Barry I. Slotnick, the defense lawyer best known for representing Bernhard H. Goetz in the subway shooting case. Mr. Slotnick's early statement that he was considering running against Mrs. Lowey buoyed party officials who saw him as politically astute and able, or at least as able as anyone, to match Mrs. Lowey's election-campaign chest. 
But to their chagrin Mr. Slotnick decided not to run and waited until May 23, the day before the county Republican convention, to say so. The lawyer said he intended to concentrate on helping to resolve the ''turmoil'' in New York City.
Republicans said that the nomination would have been Mr. Slotnick's for the asking and that by waiting he had undermined his party's chances to unseat Mrs. Lowey. Mr. Slotnick, a Scarsdale resident, had all but cleared the field of candidates, according to party officials.
 
Outside Party Ranks
The Republicans then reached outside party ranks for a candidate to oppose Mrs. Lowey, selecting John Schafer, a 39-year-old systems analyst for American Telephone and Telegraph Company, who had lost a race for Mount Vernon comptroller in 1989 and who had run unsuccessfully in other races as a Right to Life Party candidate.
Mr. Schafer, a Conservative, said he had been approached by Republican Party leaders after other Republican candidates were rejected or had withdrawn from consideration. In accepting the nomination on May 24 at the Republican convention in the Y.W.C.A. in White Plains, he promised a vigorous campaign.
Mr. Schafer was on crutches when he accepted the bid, the result of a fall during a basketball game earlier in the day in the same Y. Some Republicans saw Mr. Schafer's hobbled condition as a metaphor of the party's search for someone to challenge Mrs. Lowey, but Mr. Schafer pledged a vigorous fight to unseat the Democratic incumbent.
If that fight occurs, it will see Mr. Schafer coming out of a different corner, that of the Conservative Party, because one week after accepting the Republican endorsement he renounced it, saying he could not be a candidate of a party that included an abortion-rights plank in its 1990 state platform.
That left it to Anthony J. Colavita, the beleaguered county Republican chairman, to find yet another candidate. He turned to Mr. Bellitto, a 32-year-old business analyst with Kraft General Foods in Rye Brook, who had returned from a honeymoon in Hawaii to find the position open again.
''I was not in the earlier selection process,'' he said, ''but when I heard that Schafer had withdrawn I told Republican Party leaders of my interest. They knew who I was.''
Mr. Bellitto's political experience has been limited to work within the Republican Party. He began early, he said, ''handing out election-campaign leaflets at the age of 12,'' later becoming a district leader, president of the 11th Ward Republican Club and a member of the executive committee of the Yonkers Republican City Committee. He also served as vice president of the Westchester County Young Republicans Club.
Mr. Bellitto said he came from a politically conscious family, in that ''my parents were always interested in politics, although not to the extent of running for office.'' The candidate's father, Salvatore J. Bellitto, is director of U.S. banking operations for the General Motors Corporation in Manhattan and his mother, Dolores Bellitto, works in the Bronxville Library.
The candidate, a Bronxville resident since he and his wife, Kyle Moran, bought a cooperative apartment in the village after their marriage on May 6, was born and brought up in Yonkers. He attended Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains and earned two degrees at Harvard University: a bachelor's degree in government in 1980 and a master's degree from the Business School in 1984.
His wife graduated from Dartmouth College in 1980 and entered Harvard Law School at the age of 19, ''one of the youngest ever to do so,'' Mr. Bellitto said. He added that ''she and I met at the Harvard Club in Manhattan and I proposed to her in Harvard Yard last year.'' She now practices in Manhattan.
 
A Hot Line Volunteer
He worked as a financial analyst both for Trans World Airlines in Manhattan and for International Business Machines in Tarrytown before moving to Kraft General Foods. He said he also volunteers as a crisis worker on Covenant House's toll free hot line in Manhattan.
He describes himself as a ''George Bush Republican,'' which he said means ''being opposed to any new taxes, reintensifying the attack on drug use through education and deterrence and supporting the death penalty as an option for a jury when a law-enforcement officer is killed in the line of duty.''
''As for abortion, I take the pro-life position, which is against abortion except in cases of rape, incest and endangerment of the life of the mother.'' Asked how he stood on the Republican Party platform and its abortion-rights plank, Mr. Bellitto said, ''If we can't have a pro-life plank, I'd rather see the state keep its traditional neutrality on the issue.''
He said that for the last eight years the state Republican platform took no position on abortion, and that Republican leaders have said there is room for diversity on the abortion issue.
''Locally,'' he said, ''Westchester County has to start preparing for the 21st Century by rebuilding its infrastructure and modernizing the County Airport without increasing the number of daily flights.'' He said he was also in favor of building the new postal plant at the airport, which has ''good access from I-684.'' Mrs. Lowey has sought to have it placed elsewhere.
He said he deplored the exodus of young people from the county. ''We have to find ways to revitalize communities such as Mount Vernon and Yonkers so they can serve as gateways to life in Westchester for young people just starting out.''
 
A Grass-Roots Campaign
Mr. Bellitto indicated that he was ''starting at the beginning'' in terms of raising money for the campaign. ''It will have to be a grass-roots volunteer campaign,'' he said, adding that the ''exorbitant amounts of money spent in Congressional races in Westchester is disgraceful. The seat in Congress should not be effectively reserved for millionaires.''
Mrs. Lowey, meanwhile, said she has been working a seven-day week in her freshman term and that many of the domestic issues are ''a natural transition from the 13 years in state government where I ran weatherization programs, neighborhood revitalization programs, dealt with housing, child care and senior citizens, and directed a department with offices in Manhattan and Westchester.''
''A number of the issues we dealt with in Albany are Federal issues,'' she said, ''and for the most part were financed in the state by Federal dollars.''
She said that in some areas her state and Federal experiences have overlapped. ''Take coastal zone management. Now that I'm working on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, I've been very actively involved in reauthorizing coastal zone management legislation. At the state level I was responsible for administering the downstate area for coastal zone management, which calls for the balance between economic development and environmental preservation.''
Mrs. Lowey noted that she was on a subcommittee crafting the major child-care bill and on a conference committee with the Senate ''to finalize child-care legislation.''
 
Criticism of the President
Representative Lowey criticized President Bush for ''allowing the savings and loan scandal to continue at a cost of $500 billion'' and added that the President has been lucky ''in presiding over monumental changes, such as in Eastern Europe.''
He played no role in those events, she said, ''but should now be leading the nation in changing its priorities from investing in bombers and missiles into books and math and science and health programs - this is the real battlefield, our domestic economy.''
Mrs. Lowey said she spends three days in Washington and four days in Westchester, has a full-time paid staff of 16, half in each location, and 20 college-age unpaid summer interns, also half in each location.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 17, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 429 words

HEADLINE: Reflections on the Family for Father's Day

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Wellesley College's graduation ceremonies (front page, June 2) will soon be forgotten, despite controversies surrounding student protests over the selection of Barbara Bush as commencement speaker. The students did, however, succeed in forcing Mrs. Bush to confront the issues their petition raised. Her response should give neither comfort nor encouragement to defenders of the status quo. Read carefully, Mrs. Bush's speech asks Americans to reject assumptions underlying conventional ideas about economic growth, work discipline and the sovereignty of the market. 
Each of us, she said, is a ''human being first,'' a nurturing soul for whom time spent ''with a husband'' - or a wife - ''a child, a friend or a parent'' might be more important than tests, verdicts, deals and investments.
Juxtapose this argument with data on the length of the workweek (Week in Review, front page, June 3). A third of all executives - among men, nearly half - spend 49 or more hours at work. The median number of leisure hours among Americans dropped from 26 in 1973 to fewer than 17 in 1987. Why do we work so many hours? Certainly, the new technology makes it possible. Perhaps the new technology even seems to make it necessary in businesses tied to other time zones. But put simply, we do it to make more money. To make the economy grow. To compete with the Japanese.
Otherwise our standard of living will decline. We might have to live longer with outdated video and audio equipment. We might have to drive smaller cars somewhat less comfortable than our living rooms. We might have to wear clothes that look like what we wore last year.
What Barbara Bush has suggested is that we - men and women -reconsider the relationship between the gospel of production and the gospel of life.
What our First Lady is suggesting is that we all slow down a bit, stopping to smell the flowers. To paraphrase an earlier occupant of Mrs. Bush's residence, let us lower our material expectations, sacrificing them on the altar of peace of mind and human warmth. Perhaps then we will have time to understand and inhabit a world in which we - men and women - can be kinder and gentler.
But first, George Bush and his peers will have to offer to young men the same lecture that Barbara Bush has delivered to the women of Wellesley. He will also have to think about policy initiatives that will make such a revaluation of our priorities possible.
 
JAMES R. GROSSMAN
 Chicago, June 4, 1990
 
The writer is an assistant professor of history, University of Chicago.

PUB-DATE: June 17, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 246 words

HEADLINE: Reflections on the Family for Father's Day;
Isolated and Disaffected

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Every phase of economic history has its own employee health, family and financial struggles. ''Tales From the Digital Treadmill'' (Week in Review, June 3) offers a glimpse of some of today's. 
In coming articles, however, you should consider that exhaustion, mental stress and alienation from family aren't the only ways working people pay for the unforgiving hard edge and fast pace of globally competitive high technology. Broad changes in the shape of the economy have meant equally broad shifts in the minutiae of daily life.
Young couples, for instance, can't get the banking credit our parents came to expect. We're asked to dig deeper to pay for health-care plans employers once covered as a matter of course. Rising car-insurance costs have proceeded with decreases in coverage. Salary freezes and late work nights mean we take fewer vacations and can't spend them together. Layoffs and hiring freezes that eliminate colleagues and backup teams mean we move through life increasingly alone. Friends and neighbors can't help. They're working late, too. And while occasional meals out and days at the beach offer nice respite, they don't solve problems.
You say it's tough to gauge whether the economy gains from all this hard work. A better question would be: How can a working person care about a dubious economic index when his own lifestyle is nothing like the one he grew up expecting?
 
S. B. SOLECKI
 New Brunswick, N.J., June 3, 1990

LENGTH: 256 words

HEADLINE: Americans Still Don't Want to Give Up the $1 Bill for a $1 Coin

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Changing Change,'' your June 3 editorial endorsement of legislation to abolish the dollar bill, leaves me puzzled. You point out the overwhelming opposition to the proposal, but decide the voters should have to swallow it whether they like it or not. 
Potential budget savings are a good reason to hold hearings on the idea, but backers of the Susan B. Anthony dollar made similar (if more modest) claims in 1978. They said the coin would save us $10.5 million a year. It didn't. In fact, we're now using 50,000 cubic feet at the Mint and Federal Reserve Banks to store 424 million untouched Susan B. Anthony dollars.
You note that eight other countries have adopted high-denomination coins and cite Canada's new dollar, an 11-sided monstrosity aptly nicknamed the ''loonie.'' Why not emulate the 171 countries that have not adopted new coins? Finally, you say inflation has made the dollar bill out of date. Why? Would a coin stop or slow inflation? Of course not.
You put the Susan B. Anthony fiasco down to ''poor public preparation'' and failure to discontinue the dollar bill. In other words, the Government didn't jam it far enough down the public's throat. The Susan B. Anthony dollar flopped because most Americans did not want it. According to an April Gallup poll, 85 percent don't want a dollar coin now either, if it means getting rid of the greenback. We should let well enough alone and keep the dollar bill.
 
SILVIO O. CONTE
Member of Congress, 1st Dist., Mass.
 Washington, June 6, 1990

HEADLINE: Americans Still Don't Want to Give Up the $1 Bill for a $1 Coin;
Think Bigger

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Susan B. Anthony dollar failed because you can't buy anything with it. To carry an effective number of them makes a person jingle like a dog with a noisy collar. 
Let's get ahead of inflation. Skip to a $5 coin. Three or four could buy a bag of groceries. One could be a tip for dinner. We could even get change back at McDonald's again.
Once people get used to the convenience of a fiver (with five sides?), there will be a natural demand for a $1 coin to give as change. And if we design $10 and $20 coins now, the vending machine industry can plan for them and drive the demand as inflation takes us there.
Representative Silvio Conte is correct that a copper dollar (giant penny) seems ludicrous. How about recycling the heavy metals from used batteries into a useful product? Every politician's district creates trash.
 
BOB COSTA

HEADLINE: New World, New C.I.A.

BYLINE: By David L. Boren; David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The cold war is over. And some now argue that in this dramatically changed world, intelligence services like the C.I.A. are costly anachronisms that should be sharply reduced. In fact these changes have increased, not decreased, the need for the right kind of intelligence. What's called for is not less intelligence activity but the acquisition of new and different kinds of information.
For years, the Soviet military threat was the driving force behind intelligence budgets. Today, the Warsaw Pact is no longer a viable military threat, although the Soviet Union remains highly armed. Now we must begin to confront the question of how to relate to a democratic Soviet Union and how to contend with the explosion of information about that country and Eastern Europe. 
We must have a strategy, vision and discipline to guide U.S. intelligence in the future. This is particularly so because budgets will not be as large, and bureaucracies accustomed to unprecedented growth in resources cannot be allowed to sanctify the present and ignore the future.
Despite world trends toward democracy, caution is required. Our evidence shows that espionage against the United States has not diminished. Emerging East European democracies are struggling to control intelligence and security services that remain loyal to their K.G.B. masters. The Soviet Union, while moving toward cooperation with us in many areas, remains the only nation in the world capable of destroying us with nuclear weapons. As the U.S.S.R. experiences its own internal power struggles and moves through a radical transformation, we can never be certain whose hand will be on the nuclear trigger.
U.S. intelligence must be able to monitor Soviet military deployments and developments as well as the intentions of Soviet political and military leaders. We also must have the means to verify new and complicated arms control agreements and protect against technological breakouts.
While superpower tensions are easing, the world is not completely at peace. The proliferation of chemical, nuclear and biological weapons -especially in less responsible nations - threatens the entire world. Regional conflicts show no sign of abating. The political instability that feeds terrorism has not waned. Dangers of war between India and Pakistan present the world with the possibility of nuclear confrontation. The West's dependence on oil imported from the Persian Gulf continues to grow.
These are not new problems. But we should now focus on them more of our resources that were once consumed by the Soviet military threat.
The strategy to guide U.S. intelligence must be based on a number of factors. First, we have to re-emphasize classic human-source intelligence. We are weakest at determining the intentions of our adversaries and friends. Better human intelligence is critical to meeting the threats of the next century: penetrating terrorist cells, breaking the money-laundering activities of narco-traffickers and combating the spread of weapons technology.
The Congressional oversight committees are working with the C.I.A. to develop an innovative, long-term strategy that sheds cold war priorities and focuses on language and cultural skills and economic expertise.
Even in the most sensitive relationships, we must now align ourselves with the forces of change in the world. Anti-Communism can no longer justify cozy relationships with foreign intelligence services that commit or condone human rights abuses or prop up authoritarian regimes.
Second, we must understand that future American influence will depend more upon our economic strength and less upon our military strength. Nations previously followed our lead because they needed our protection. Now our influence will have to come more from economic strength and the strength of the example of our political and social systems.
The fastest growing area of espionage activities by foreign governments against the U.S. is not the theft of military secrets, but the theft of commercial secrets from private American companies to further national economic interests. This confronts the United States with serious questions of policy. How do we protect against government-conducted commercial espionage? Should we retaliate by collecting such information ourselves? If we did collect it, how could it be appropriately used by a free enterprise system with many competing producers of the same goods?
One thing is certain: Future intelligence officers will need a high level of ability to understand and evaluate economic data on subjects as diverse as currency, trade policy and new commercial technologies.
Third, the U.S. military presence abroad will be reduced. Thus the projection of U.S. forces will be much more difficult in the future, and we will need earlier warning of hostile intentions. Information must be timely and complete and in a form useful to our military commanders.
Intelligence excesses are largely behind us. We now have a body of laws and a process of Congressional intelligence oversight that aggressively seeks to insure that the C.I.A. operates in a manner consistent with the fundamental values of the American people. Critics should not ignore the fact that the intelligence community today is led by a man, Judge William Webster, who is committed to telling the truth and obeying the law.
Now is not the time to think about dismantling our intelligence service or calling for mindless budget slashing. The men and women of the intelligence community provide us with real accomplishments about which there can be little public discussion.
The transformation of our intelligence priorities is beginning. The oversight committees and the leadership of the intelligence community have begun the dialogue. The members of the Senate Intelligence Committee understand all too well that we will place our nation at risk if we do not change our thinking to reflect the changes in the world around us.

HEADLINE: The World;
Moscow Rethinks The Art Of the Deal

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
AN old negotiators' adage has it that Americans play poker, Russians play chess.
Whether the issue is limiting nuclear warheads or getting a taxi driver to go to your destination, the characteristic Soviet bargaining style is a chesslike probing for weaknesses, a stubborn patience in the end game.
Since he returned invigorated from his tour in America, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been the grandmaster, taking on all challengers simultaneously - easing into negotiations with the wayward Baltic leaders, inching toward an agreement on German unification, jockeying with his popular rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, testing the country's appetite for a market economy.
With Mr. Gorbachev, the game is still chess. But for students of the game, the past week has been filled with illustrations of how Mr. Gorbachev has altered the Soviet style of play. 
In ''Negotiating with the Soviets,'' his recent book on Soviet conduct at the bargaining table, Raymond F. Smith identifies three related rules of behavior that tend to govern Soviet officials' negotiating style. Mr. Gorbachev, says the author, who is currently counselor for political affairs at the American Embassy in Moscow, seems bent on violating all of them.
The first trait, according to Mr. Smith, is a preoccupation with authority. While Americans may start out looking for common ground, the typecast Soviet citizen, whether he is a restaurant doorman or an arms control negotiator, is keen to establish his place in the pecking order. Every relationship is initially a test of strength. Compromise, the pragmatic ideal of American civil relations, is in Russian tradition a form of submission and, worse, a sign of weak principles. Negotiations tend to be a bartering of concessions, but the idea of splitting the difference is shameful.
Second is a powerful aversion to risk. American culture tends to reward the optimist, the entrepreneur. Russian tradition and Communist practice teach that he who sticks his neck out gets his head lopped off. The Soviet negotiator takes no chances; his strategy is to draw out the proposals of the other side and snipe at them.
Josef Stalin reinforced this authoritarian, risk-avoiding Russian tradition with a pervasive central control over society. In negotiations, Mr. Smith writes, the Soviet style is to try to manipulate all possible outcomes - for example, by seeking generally worded agreements that can later be re-interpreted in their favor.
Mr. Gorbachev, it now seems clear, has set out to introduce a new political culture, one that tolerates pluralism, values compromise and rewards initiative. It shows in the style he brings to his bargaining on both foreign policy and domestic issues. But he still struggles with traditional habits, which are rooted deeply in his society and - because Gorbachev is himself a Russian of peasant stock and Communist upbringing - in his own instincts.
Mr. Gorbachev is comfortable with risk and compromise in a way that his predecessors were not. Where a traditional Soviet negotiator might have waited out the other side, Mr. Gorbachev has little patience with impasse.
Watch him coming to terms with the future of Europe, where the Soviets have measured their security in terms of control - a buffer of subjugated territory and a huge arsenal. Now the comforting buffer is dissolving and the linchpin of the Warsaw Pact military alliance, East Germany, seems in the process of defecting to the West. Mr. Gorbachev keeps reaching into his bottomless briefcase and pulling out a new compromise. Last week he announced he would not object if West Germany's army remained in the NATO military alliance, even if East Germany's troops are withdrawn from the command structure of the Soviet bloc.
When it comes to domestic challengers, Mr. Gorbachev's behavior has been more ambiguous. He has freed his society from Stalinist controls but his sense of the authoritative pecking order sometimes seems right out of the old textbook. Rivals like Mr. Yeltsin, who as the new President of the Russian Federation has been promoting sovereignty for that vast republic, have been treated with scorn. Mr. Gorbachev has dismissed suggestions that he share power with insurgents, offering them only the most subordinate posts in his Government. In his dealings with the Lithuanian separatists, he insisted that any negotiations could begin only after Lithuanian leaders had bowed to the authority of Soviet law. To drive the point home, he slapped an oil embargo on the republic.
But last week, Mr. Gorbachev invited in the leaders of all the republics, including Mr. Yeltsin, and offered to remake the union as an alliance of ''sovereign states.'' Then he met with the presidents of the three Baltic republics and proposed terms that he said could lead to their independence. If Mr. Gorbachev is sincere about treating republican leaders as equals, last week's meetings were a turning point.
On the economy, Mr. Gorbachev finds himself contending with both the cautious instincts and the authoritarian tradition of his people. He wants to move the country away from the shabby security of a state-run economy toward a free market, and he wants to do it with a measure of popular consensus. It is not clear that he can do both. Judging from the debate last week in parliament, the public fears the risk of the market, and, paradoxically, wants Mr. Gorbachev to tell it what to do. Forced to vote on the Government's proposal to raise bread prices, the risk-averse parliament issued a resounding no. But the parliamentarians voted almost without dissent for a measure instructing Mr. Gorbachev to begin dismantling state economic monopolies by presidential decree.
Clearly, in this negotiation, Mr. Gorbachev is up against a society playing by Soviet rules.
