HEADLINE: The Nation;
Designing Tankers To Minimize Oil Spills

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Lately, and to everyone's disgust, oil and water do mix. As oil globules wash ashore from a spill in the Kill van Kull and fan out from the smoldering tanker in the Gulf of Mexico, America's latest oil import crisis, getting the stuff safely to shore, is stirring new interest in tanker safety. Engineers have proposed several steps, but they often contradict each other.
In the meantime, the world drinks more oil every year, and tends to import it over longer and longer distances as wells outside the Middle East dry up.
The most widely debated safety measure is double bottoms or double hulls to provide an added layer for protection in a grounding. Some experts say that if the Exxon Valdez had had a double hull, it would have spilled far less than the 11 million gallons it spread over Prince William Sound 15 months ago. Conoco announced recently that it will order double-hulled ships, and the House version of a bill now before Congress would require them. 
That step has been bitterly opposed by the American Bureau of Shipping, a private association with some regulatory functions. It is controlled by ship owners and now headed by Frank Iarossi, who was president of the Exxon Shipping Company at the time of the Valdez grounding. Exxon maintains that if the outer layer of a double hull is pierced, water rushing into the space between the hulls will make the ship settle lower, impaling itself more firmly. Others say explosive gases can gather in the space and corrosion can proceed uninspected.
Environmentalists suspect that another factor looms larger: such a hull is about 15 percent more expensive to build.
Mr. Iarossi was said by a spokesman, Thomas J. Tucker, to be abroad last week and unavailable for comment. Mr. Tucker said of double-hulling: ''There's an endless number of changes you could in theory make. It's a question of what can be done with regard to both safety and economy. There has to be a balance between what is practical and what is considered safe.''
Another option that has attracted interest is loading the tanker so as to contain the oil even if the hull is punctured. Proposed by George C. Blake, executive vice president of the Overseas Shipholding Group, a Manhattan-based company with about 45 tankers, the idea is to load only enough oil to make the pressure on the inside of the hull equal the pressure from seawater on the outside.
Since oil weighs 86 percent as much as salt water, this means that oil would still be carried above the water line. But it would not flow through a hole in the bottom.
''This is not to say that with tides and things you wouldn't get some transfer of oil,'' Mr. Blake said. ''But you certainly wouldn't have had the wave of oil that people described when the Exxon Valdez went aground.''
This kind of loading, called hydrostatic balancing, would cut cargo capacities by 15 to 20 percent, he estimated. But the Valdez accident is proof of calculations that it works, he said; after about 15 percent of the cargo was lost, the leak stopped.
Mr. Blake says there would be a corollary benefit. Currently, tankers empty their ballast tanks when they load and refill the tanks when they empty. The ballast tanks, alternately filled with salt water and salty, humid air, are a frequent site of rust. With partial loading, the tanks could be kept filled at all times, with fresh water.
Mr. Blake blames such rust for several recent accidents, including the Khark 5 off the Canary Islands in December. The Iranian tanker spilled 20 million gallons.
Another measure that could be taken now, advanced by Swedish engineers, is putting emergency shutoff valves on the air vents in tankers. When a tanker's compartments are pumped out, these vents let air in. If they were sealed upon a grounding, then after a little oil had leaked the vacuum pressure would hold the rest in, the theory goes. Here, too, the water pressure would equal the oil pressure, which would be reduced by the vacuum.
Edwin J. Roland, the president of Amoco Transport Company and the chairman of the American Petroleum Institute's marine transportation committee, favors another way to achieve hydrostatic balance, recently presented by Mitsubishi, the giant shipbuilder. It calls for building ships with ballast tanks all the way down each side, as a kind of bumper. In the middle would be oil tanks, but instead of side by side, as in a conventional ship, they would be stacked, to keep the oil pressure low.
''It gives you collision protection, it doesn't allow leakage if you penetrate bottom, and doesn't lock you in position if you run aground,'' Mr. Roland said.
He estimated the cost at 15 to 20 percent, similar to a double hull or partial loading. That increase sounds large, but transportation accounts for only a small fraction of oil's cost, $1.50 to $2.25 a barrel from the Persian Gulf and 80 cents to $1.25 from Europe, said Peter C. Beutel, a trader at Elders Futures in New York. A 20 percent increase on a $2 shipping bill comes to 40 cents, or just under a penny a gallon.
Mr. Blake's theory is that no tanker owner will assume such expense in isolation, and that the changes should therefore be ordered uniformly. But Mr. Roland said: ''I think today we would unilaterally make that kind of investment, no matter what the competition did. It's good business to stay out of trouble with the environment.''
That will be harder as time goes on. Unless tankers become safer, the prospect is that spills will increase with the volume of oil on the water. Global demand for oil is growing at about 2 percent a year, and the Middle East, with more than 60 percent of the world's reserves, will account for a larger and larger share of production.
And tankers are growing bigger. The largest today are 30 times bigger than the largest at the end of World War II. The new ones are less maneuverable and take far more draft; the Mega Borg, for example, was too big for many Gulf ports and was offloading some oil to smaller vessels when she was hit by an explosion.
 
THINKING BIG
 
Maximum tanker sizes at the end opf World War II and today. The supertankers are harder to maneuver, and likely to spill more oil when damaged.
 
1945: 16,500 deadweight tons
1989: 550,819 deadweight tons
 
(Source: American Petroleum Institute)
 
A QUICK FIX
Some engineers advocate loading tankers less than full - to about 80 percent of capacity - as a ready way to reduce oil spills without modifying tankers.
The strategy, called hydrostatic balancing, works on a simple principle. Oil gushes from torn ships only so long as the pressure of the oil against the inside of the ship is greater than the water pressure against the outside. When enough oil has escaped so that the pressures are about equal, the hemorrhaging stops - even if millions of gallons remain aboard a badly damaged vessel, as was the case with the Exxon Valdez. So the less full the tanker is to begin with, the less pressure on its internal walls and the less oil rushes into the sea when the hull is ruptured.
To keep a less-than-full tanker from riding too high in the ocean, the ballast tanks could be kept permanently filled with water, a departure from the common practice of emptying them as oil is pumped aboard and refilling them as oil is off-loaded. Proponents say this would bring an extra advantage: ship owners could afford to use expensive fresh water if they had to fill the ballast tanks just once, and this would significantly reduce the corrosion caused by the repeated pumping of salt water into and out of the tanks.
 
(Source: American Petroleum Institute)

PUB-DATE: June 17, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1922 words

HEADLINE: The Region;
Why It Costs So Much To Run New York State

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
WHEN New York State's politicians hit the campaign trail this summer, voters can expect to hear some nasty exchanges about the state's financial problems. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is already blaming the difficulties on a national economic slowdown presided over by a Republican President. And the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Pierre A. Rinfret, is almost certain to attribute them to years of overspending under Democratic governors.
Both sides are, in some sense, correct. The immediate cause of New York fiscal problems is, as Mr. Cuomo notes, an economic slowdown that depressed tax collections and left a gaping hole in the state budget. But looked at from a long-term perspective, New York's fiscal distress appears to be a product of persistently high spending. By almost every measure available, government spending in New York exceeds that of other states.
''Apparently New Yorkers have a rich taste for services,'' said Robert Rafuse, a senior fellow at the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, a Congressional agency. ''This is not a judgment call. It is just something that is clear from the statistics.'' 
It's also clear from the statistics that New York employs more state and local government workers in proportion to its population than all other states except Alaska and Wyoming, but whether this indicates a needlessly bloated bureaucracy or reflects a high level of services is open to argument.
Indeed, statistics that measure the combined expenditures of state and local governments show that New York's per capita outlays are the second-highest in the nation, according to the United States Census Bureau. Only those of oil-rich Alaska are higher. In 1988, the latest year for which Census Bureau data are available, per capita spending by state and local governments in New York was $5,025, 50 percent higher than the national average. In neighboring Connecticut, per capita spending was $3,586, and in New Jersey it was $3,708.
 
Spending More for Everything
Behind New York's figures are higher-than-average payments for just about every service government delivers. To educate one child, New York spends $7,561 a year, more than any other state except New Jersey, according to figures compiled by State Policy Research Inc., a private organization in Alexandria, Va. For each child on Medicaid, the state spends $790 a year, a figure that is higher only in Alaska and Ohio. And to administer one welfare case, New York spends $1,118, more than every other state except Idaho and Oregon, and almost twice the national average.
New York's state and local government workers, most of whom belong to politically powerful public-employee unions, are paid more than their counterparts in all but two states, Alaska and California. The average government salary in New York as of 1988 was $31,368 a year. The national average was $26,244.
Over the years both political parties have participated in New York's extended spending spree. The state was known as a high roller in the 1960's when Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, a Republican, led the government, just as it is known as one now with Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, presiding.
''What we're looking at here are 50 years of expenditure decisions, and 50 years of decisions to borrow money,'' said Hal Hovey, the president of State Policy Research. ''There were a lot of people involved and a lot of decisions.''
Such consistently high spending, it would seem, ought to have a compelling justification. Yet none is evident. One possibility is that New York spends more because its residents have more money. But even when wealth is factored out, New York is still a big spender. For each $1,000 of personal income earned by New Yorkers in 1988, state and local governments spent $280, or 30 percent more than the national average, according to Census Bureau figures. Only three other states - Alaska, Wyoming and Utah - spent more.
 
Higher Prices and More in Need
Other possible explanations are that prices are higher in the state, while a greater proportion of the residents are in need. In recent years, however, financial analysts have come up with a complex method of comparing state spending that adjusts for both the salaries of government workers in the state and the number of people who are likely to be eligible for services there. Even when these adjustments are made, government spending in New York is higher than in any other state, and 50 percent higher than the national average.
So what are the other possible explanations? Financial analysts say that there are two. The first is that New York provides more comprehensive services than other states. The second is that it provides its services less efficiently. ''You can characterize it as service differences or you can characterize it as waste,'' Mr. Hovey said. ''The math supports either conclusion.'' A good place to try to find some of the roots of New York's high spending is Medicaid, one of the state's largest and fastest growing government expenses. Half of all Medicaid costs are paid for by the Federal Government; in New York the other half is split between the state and local governments. A study last year by the State Comptroller's office noted that while New York has only 10 percent of the nation's Medicaid recipients, its Medicaid expenditures accounted for almost 20 percent of the nation's total Medicaid spending.
The study did not identify causes for New York's disproportionately high costs, but it noted several factors that clearly contributed. For one thing, Medicaid patients in New York tend to stay in the hospital longer than patients in other states, an average of 11.3 days compared with 6.3 days in California. In addition, while other states impose tight limits on outpatient services for Medicaid patients, New York has few such limits.
What the Medicaid statistics do not show, once again, is whether New York is providing better health services or is simply wasting money. State officials dwell on the former possibility. ''Typically we do provide more services to people in need,'' said the state budget director, Dall W. Forsythe. ''And I think we can argue successfully that we often buy better services. The things that New Yorkers have decided to pay more for are very reasonable and sensible.''
State officials also speculate that New York spends more on social services because its needy population is afflicted with more serious problems. New York's Medicaid patients tend to be sicker than patients in other states, this argument goes, so the state has to spend more to treat them. The argument is hard to prove, but experts say that it probably has some merit.
''The problems of the underclass are much worse in New York than in other states,'' said Steven Gold, director of the State University of New York's Center for the Study of the States. ''And New York City's problems are more severe.''
Predictably, state officials play down the importance of inefficiency as a factor in New York's high spending. But staffing levels in the state suggest otherwise. For every 10,000 New York State residents, there are 634 state and local government employees, according to the latest Census data. The national average is 504 workers for 10,000 residents. In New Jersey the figure is 516 government workers and in Connecticut 484.
Not only does New York have a higher proportion of government workers than other states, but also the number of government workers in the state is growing at a faster rate. Between 1980 and 1988, the number of government workers in New York grew by 20 percent at a time when the population was shrinking, according to a recent study by the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey. Eight other states had faster growth rates, but most of these states, including Florida, Arizona and Texas, also had growing populations.
Taken together, these statistics show that to reduce spending, New York has few choices besides cutting back on the services it provides and on the number of workers who provide them. Making the cuts, however, means making the kind of tough political choices that neither party has shown itself eager to make. So while voters should expect to hear a lot of theorizing about the source of New York's fiscal problems this summer, they should not expect to hear a lot of talk about solutions.

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 8, Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: Preventive Medicine, Soviet-Style

BYLINE: By CAROL STRICKLAND

 BODY:
''DAVAI! DAVAI!'' or ''Go on! Go on!'' shouted the young female obstetrician to the woman in labor at Leningrad's Obstetrics Polyclinic.
''Push, push,'' 14 American observers urged, watching the baby being born. The Soviet doctor then turned to helping the mother deliver the placenta. The baby girl, swaddled in blankets so that even her face was invisible, was left alone on a table against a wall.
''I couldn't believe that no one was observing and examining the newborn,'' said Dr. Lisa Baker, a family-practice doctor at the State University at Stony Brook. ''I kept asking where was the baby.'' 
Thirteen third-year Stony Brook medical students and Dr. Baker recently spent 11 days in Leningrad investigating preventive medicine. Instead of bearing stethoscopes and syringes, they carried a 12-by-4-foot banner reading, ''Peace Begins with Friendship.'' The malady they were combating had more to do with remmants of the Cold War than the common cold. ''Prevention of nuclear war,'' said Frank Pessler, a student, ''is the greatest piece of preventive medicine in this age.''
Differences in health-care practices struck the American visitors most forcibly, but members of the Long Island group said they also found commonality.
''Both of our countries face crises in health,'' said Virginia Cummings, a Stony Brook medical student. ''The Soviet Union's great problem is a lack of money for equipment, medication and up-to-date facilities. Our great problem is the waste of money and the loss of the physician-patient relationship in a sea of technology.''
The mission linking peace and public health began in September 1988, when a group of five Soviet doctors, members of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, an organization awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1985, visited Stony Brook. They returned to Leningrad with letters from Long Island medical students to their peers in the First Medical Institute Pavlov. A lively exchange of correspondence ensued, involving 30 pen pals in each country.
Last October, two Stony Brook students - Michael Vardy and Mr. Pessler - and Dr. Baker, all members of Physicians for Social Responsibility, an affiliate of the international physicians group, attended the latter organization's world congress in Hiroshima. In Japan, they met two of their Leningrad counterparts and planned exchange visits.
 
Soviet Students Awaited>
The Americans' visit to the Soviet Union this spring was the first arranged by students, rather than Communist Party hierarchy. Next fall, 14 Soviet medical students will arrive at Stony Brook to spread the message of both student groups: In Mr. Vardy's words: ''The individual can be healthy only when society is healthy.''
To gauge the health of Soviet society, the Americans took a crash course in Soviet medicine, touring hospitals, observing operations and attending medical school classes. They discovered that mandatory course offerings in the U.S.S.R. include ''Scientific Atheism,'' ''History of the Communist Party'' and ''War Medicine.''
''Soviet health care,'' said Lisa Hall, a Stony Brook student, ''is like walking into a hospital here 50 years ago. It was like seeing an old film - very simple.''
Indeed, a 1987 internal medicine text suggests using leeches to treat malignant hypertension.
Because most Soviet hospitals lack sophisticated equipment, doctors rely on low-tech inexpensive therapies like acupuncture and ''phytotherapy,'' or herbal medicine. A hand-lettered sign at the Institute of Nephrology recommended use of birch leaf extracts for kidney infection, one student said. A postoperative cardiac patient ''was inhaling camomile vapors out of a tea can,'' said Mr. Pessler, who noted the herb's antiseptic properties.
Although they said they found medicine in the U.S.S.R. primitive, the Americans gave Soviet doctors high marks for physical diagnosis, which, said Cathy Raduns, another student, ''has become a lost art in America because of technology.''
Mr. Pessler observed the hands-on approach when a Soviet cardiologist applied two fingers to a patient's chest, felt ''something like a cat's purr'' and diagnosed a hypertrophied left ventricle and left atrium. An X-ray (held up to a window for lack of a X-ray veiwer) confirmed his diagnosis.
Although lack of advanced equipment forces the Soviets to be excellent clinicians, in other areas the scarcity of technology is a clear disadvantage.
''For every 100 people who need chronic renal dialysis,'' Mr. Pessler said, ''they can treat only 15.''
In other cases, the New York students said they believed attitudes more than meager resources caused system deficiencies. ''The feminist revolution went right by them,'' Ms. Cummings said.
Although 80 percent of Soviet doctors are women, compared to 32 percent of the student body at Stony Brook Medical School, ''Women were not in specialties considered challenging,'' said Lyn Yasumura, another strudent. ''Never did a woman speak to us as a physician in a powerful position.'' Ms. Yasumura said she also heard remarks like, ''Women do not have the moral fiber to be doctors.''
Most shocking to the Long Island contingent was official blindness to the threat of AIDS. ''They've decided that AIDS does not exist,'' said Ms. Cummings. ''They actually punish physicians who diagnose it because they don't want to hear it.''
Although Government statistics say there are 470 cases of AIDS in the Soviet Union, the Americans said they learned that there were actually thousands, and hundreds of thousands of people infected.
The Americans said they discovered that AIDS was spreading almost unchecked, with transmission primarily due to reusing unsterilized hospital equipment and transfusing contaminated blood.
Only since 1988 have the Soviets screened blood in major cities. Elsewhere, the blood supply is contaminated and disposable needles and tubing are unavailable. Even rubber gloves are washed and reused.
Living with host families, the Americans observed Soviet culture as well as medicine at close range. The contact revealed dissimilarities:
''We have a sense of freedom about ourselves and how we live,'' Ms. Raduns said. ''In the subway we talk in animated voices. There, the people whisper if they talk at all.''
The Soviet student hosts were surprised to observe their American friends openly debating every aspect of their itinerary.
''At our typical meeting, everyone was interrupting and shouting,'' Ms. Yasumura said. ''Everybody has an opinion and everybody's opinion is right. My host just couldn't comprehend it, but that's democracy.''
Despite cultural differences, the two groups developed close bonds. After one evening party, ''We had a group hug,'' Dr. Baker said, with Soviets and Americans ''arm in arm, male and female. We were able to love and accept each other so easily. Why couldn't our Governments?''
Dr. Baker's hosts called her ''our daughter,'' and tended her when she was sick with a cold. ''They called me Lizenga. It means dear sweet tiny Lisa.''
The Stony Brook students may not go back to Leningrad, but they will welcome their friends to Long Island in the fall. A roller-coaster ride and a shopping trip to a mall are high priorities for the Soviets, for whom perestroika thus far has meant belt-tightening shortages.
''My host says he thinks he'll have a heart attack when he sees a supermarket,'' said Ms. Hall.
 
'Renewed Pride in University'
The trip will include more weighty activities, too. The visitors will attend a Physicians for Social Responsibility conference and tour University Hospital at Stony Brook.
''We have renewed pride in what our university has to offer,'' said another student, Jill Kraft. ''Yet it's important for us to show them the inequities - how our system works and doesn't work.''
''We'll show them a realistic cross- section,'' Mr. Pessler said. ''We'll take them to the Harlem Hospital Center, which is as dramatic as it gets at a chronically underfunded city hospital, and then to Mount Sinai, about the most capitalistic hospital you could find.''
''We saw over and over again that Soviet health problems are economic,'' said Adrienne Kane, a student. 'Their skills and intelligence are tops. If we spent more money on health care instead of war, we'd be leaps and bounds ahead. In a sense, we're in the same boat.''
For another student, Ann Marie Alino, the most memorable moment of the trip was her encounter with a Soviet soldier who served two years in Poland.
''We see pictures of tanks rolling into Afghanistan and think of the Soviets as war-hungry militarists,'' she said. ''But this soldier said he just missed his mom and dad and dog the whole time on active duty. Now when I look at the news, I'll think of that young boy.'' Ms. Alino said.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 2, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1145 words

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: CHESHIRE;
Residents Alarmed by State Plans for Town

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
CHESHIRE is the site of two state prisons. Now that two more are under construction, slated for completion in the fall, and the state has proposed taking over almost half of a condominium project in the town for low- and moderate-income housing, people in Cheshire are saying that they are being asked to shoulder too much of the state's social responsibility.
''My town seems to be getting killed,'' said State Representative Mary G. Fritz, whose district straddles the Cheshire-Wallingford border. ''I think the state went ahead with all this because Cheshire has always just accepted these things. This is the first time the town has stood up and fought.'' 
Mrs. Fritz said she has tried without success to persuade the legislature to find some way of sharing the burden of prisons and other unwanted services. ''There is this feeling statewide that as long as it's not in my town, fine,'' she said. ''A formula to share the burden equally never comes up.''
 
Improvements Sought
Louis A. Zullo, the assistant to Chesire's Town Manager, said the town is negotiating with the state over the prison projects but has abandoned hopes of blocking them and is seeking some road or sewer repairs or other improvements in exchange.
''I'm not saying the town is looking for any favors,'' said Mr. Zullo. ''But we could use some breaks.''
Cheshire is already the site of the 672-bed Manson Youth Institute - what used to be called a reformatory - and the medium-security, 804-bed Cheshire Community Correctional Center. A spokesman for the State Department of Corrections, William Wheeler, said a 300-bed prison that could be used for minimum- or maximum-security inmates will be completed in Cheshire in August. And a 100-bed Alternative Incarceration Unit, the state's first attempt at boot-camp-style prison for 16-to-21-year-old first-time offenders who are not considered threats to the community, is to open in November.
Prisoners at the boot camp will undergo rigorous physical training, he said, and will learn vocational skills and self-help techniques. They will do community work ''like roadside cleanup and that sort of thing,'' Mr. Wheeler said. ''We're trying to be good neighbors.''
Mr. Wheeler said Edson T. Bourn of Cheshire has been named warden of the boot camp, ''so there's one person in town who's not complaining.''
But there are not many more greeting the new prisons warmly, apparently, even though they are being built near the existing ones.
The community has changed greatly since the first correctional center was built there in the 1950's, said Mr. Zullo. Since then, he said, an elementary school has been built across the street from the prison, a nursing home opened down the road, and local farmlands have been bulldozed into subdivisions. The town of some 26,000 residents ''is not a sleepy little hamlet anymore,'' Mr. Zullo said.
The prisons' neighbors ''have problems with noise out there now,'' said Mrs. Fritz, who tried to help a local group block the boot camp's construction. ''What's it going to be like when they're marching the prisoners around at 5 o'clock in the morning?''
Mr. Zullo said he knows of no other town in the state that has four prisons and few that have a prison population that approaches 10 percent of the town's.
''In terms of sheer numbers of beds, we have to be right up there near the top,'' he said. ''Cheshire feels it's borne an unfair share of the prison population.''
At the Birchwood condominiums, where the state has proposed its takeover, residents say they fear the plan will dilute the value of their units.
''Discouraging isn't the word,'' said Lynn McKee, one of the Birchwood residents who have filed suit to stop the state program. ''If this goes through, my unit won't be worth what I owe on it.''
Steven G. Mednick, a lawyer from New Haven who is representing the Birchwood owners, said the suit is not a class battle. ''The people who live there now are not much different, economically, than the moderate-income people who would be involved in this program,'' he said. ''We're not trying to undermine the program, we're trying to make sure the people who already own units there are not harmed.''
Mr. Zullo said that while the town recognizes the need for affordable housing, municipal officials have asked the state to scale back its purchase of units at Birchwood.
''Instead of the 35 they're talking about, maybe a dozen or so would be more appropriate,'' Mr. Zullo said.
The apartment owners say they fear the loss of their equity if the state takes over the rest of the 84-unit project and begins selling the apartments at bargain prices.
Ms. McKee, a single mother, said she bought her unit for $99,000 two years ago.If the state purchases of the remaining ones, she said, they will be selling for either $28,000 or $46,000, depending on a buyer's income, which will drag down the price of her apartment.
Under the state program, the Condominium Acquisition Pilot, the state would purchase apartments then sell or rent them to low- or middle- income families. If sold, the units would have deed restrictions on the resale price, so no one could make unreasonable profits.
Birchwood is one of 17 developments over which the State Department of Housing is negotiating for units. The State Housing Commissioner, John F. Papandrea, said he could not comment specifically on Birchwood, because those talks have not been completed. But he said the pilot program will not detract from anyone's equity.
''We don't determine market value,'' Mr. Papandrea said. ''Market value is determined by a variety of other factors, and at this point, we're seeing, throughout the state, the effects of a deteriorating market.''
 
Helping and Hurting
But Mr. Mednick, who represents 32 of the 33 unit owners at Birchwood and the owners at a development in Branford that might also be enrolled in the program, said the plan could lower the value of the remaining units.
Many of the people at Birchwood paid about $100,000 for their units, putting 10 or 20 percent down, so they now carry mortgages of $80,000 to $90,000. If the value of the units drop to $46,000, the price of the higher-priced state units, the lawyer said, the owners would owe $24,000 to $34,000 more than the apartments are worth and would spend years working off that debt.
''You don't want to help 30 moderate-income people by hurting 30 other moderate-income people,'' Mr. Mednick said. ''If the state is so sure there is going to be no diminution of value, it should provide an equity guarantee, so that if anyone loses money, the state would make up the difference.
''These are hard-working, middle income people, single parents in many cases, who put their entire life savings into the down payment for these condos. Now they're facing a state program that may take that away from them.''

LENGTH: 856 words

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Detour Off a Well-Worn Chinese Route

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
DO you have a yen for Chinese food, but would rather not travel the moo shu pork/egg roll route? Fu Ho in Syosset is tempting diners with the likes of black pepper veal, fresh banana chicken and shredded jellyfish. Long Island standbys are also available, but Chinese food fanciers who want to abandon well-worn culinary ruts can do so at this attractive newcomer.
Syosset residents will recognize the location as a former Friendly's. The familiar New England-style building has been transformed into a Chinese pagoda complete with green tiles over the doorway, golden dragons decorating the cupola and stone Foo dogs on guard at the door. 
Inside, no ice cream parlor echoes remain. A bracelet of lights, mirrors and a crystal chandelier are in the mode of the new, elegant, Hong Kong-style dining palaces now dotting Chinatown.
Service as well as food breaks the local mold. Instead of the Orient Express (rush 'em in, rush 'em out), the smiling owner hovers, admonishing patrons to eat slowly and enjoy the food.
Enjoyment comes easily at Fu Ho. Tempting soups are led by tofu vegetable and Fu Ho seafood, both simple, fresh and zingy with flavor. Old friends, wonton and hot and sour, are in place, but egg drop is mysteriously missing. Egg drop does make a guest appearance as part of two other soups. One, mushroom corn soup, is thin and dull. The other, snow white rainbow beef soup, is a tasty brew with chards of beef and crunchy vegetables.
Two of Fu Ho's most unusual appetizers are also its best: crouton shrimp puffs and bean curd vegetable rolls. The former are balls of shrimp paste (similar to that spread on shrimp toast) studded with croutons and deep fried until golden and crackly. The vegetable rolls pair paper-thin sheets of bean curd with julienned vegetables. They are rolled, fried to a turn and presented in a rich sesame sauce.
That same sauce enhances an appetizer of sliced cold chicken breast. Two other cold starter possibilities are the spicy Chinese cabbage salad, a perfect piquant choice for dieters, and shredded jellyfish. The latter is zippy with red pepper, but its texture is reminiscent of rubber bands.
More commonplace but of uncommon quality are the lean and tender barbecued spareribs. Honey baby ribs are tasty, but more bone and fat than meat. Dumplings - steamed, fried and Shiu Mai (stuffed with minced pork and shrimp) - are feather-light treats.
Dieters should zero in on the ''lite cuisine'' menu offerings. Steamed lobster with vegetables is prepared without salt, sugar, cornstarch or sodium. This pristine fare is made more appealing by a side dish of ginger sauce, which diners can spoon on at their discretion.
From the regular menu, drunk shrimp Shanghai style and black pepper veal take top honors. The salted, crunchy, jumbo shrimp are flamed in rum at tableside and served atop crispy Chinese vegetables. The veal, also served on a vegetable nest, is white, top of the line and fork-tender.
Three recommended entrees feature chunks of fried meat with crunchy, crisp coatings. Fresh banana chicken combines those spiffy nuggets with sauteed banana and garden vegetables in a slightly sweet mahogany sauce. A similar sauce enfolds the gold coin beef: meat chunks, sliced mushrooms, sesame seeds and broccoli. Home-style chicken adds a tad of hot Szechuan pepper to that now-familiar sauce.
The usual lo meins and chow funs dot the menu, but so do more-unusual noodle dishes like chow mee fun har moon style and Harbordine pan-fried noodles. The latter, a favorite from the Aberdeen section of Hong Kong, features a bed of crispy noodles topped with shrimp, chicken, beef and vegetables mixed with the ubiquitous house sauce. Chow mee fun is delicate angel-hair pasta entwined with baby shrimp, scallops, roast pork, shredded scrambled egg and vegetables. (The owner confided it was his favorite.) Desserts are the usual Chinese lineup, plus run-of-the-mill chocolate mousse.
Another western interloper is the full-fledged, leather-bound wine list of 24 economically priced choices starting with Wan Fu at $11.
 
FU HO
Very Good
 
4 Berry Hill Road (one block north of the Long Island Rail Road station), Syosset. 364-2828

LENGTH: 1119 words

HEADLINE: Focus: California Wineries;
Northern Operations Expand Southward

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP

DATELINE: SANTA MARIA, CALIF.

 BODY:
THE Kendall-Jackson winery, which has been producing wine in Lakeport, in northern California, for eight years, will open a new operation 320 miles south this August - the first time a Northern California operation has built a winery so far from Napa County. Lakeport, in Lake County, is about 35 miles north of Napa County. Kendall-Jackson's $6 million, 84,000-square-foot Cambria Winery 12 miles southwest of Santa Maria is slated to produce about 100,000 cases of wine a year, which will make it the largest wine producer in Santa Barbara County. It will process grapes it is growing on adjacent vineyards.
''The primary reason we are in the area is that land values are so much lower,'' said Randall C. Clifton, director of wine operations for the privately held Kendall-Jackson. 
In the last three years, Napa County's rising real estate values - it is the country's most expensive wine region - and tighter building restrictions have forced several expansion-minded wineries to seek less expensive regions. Napa Valley land is far beyond the reach of most start-up operations.
''It's priceless real estate,'' said Jon Fredrikson of Gomberg Fredrikson & Associates, wine industry economists in San Francisco. In just three years, he said, vineyard prices in Napa County have risen 58 percent, to about $55,000 an acre.
In adjacent Sonoma County, considered part of Northern California's wine region, land values have doubled in the last three years, to about $30,000 an acre, partly as a result of new technologies that over the last decade have doubled crop yields to about 5 tons of grapes per acre.
But grape prices have not kept pace. The average price of Chardonnay grapes, one of the more valuable varieties, has increased only 33 percent in the last three years, to $1,224 a ton, according to the Wine Institute in San Francisco.
Sonoma County Cabernet Sauvignon grapes have risen 57 percent in three years, to $1,123 a ton, and Zinfandels have gone up 70 percent, to $886 a ton.
At the same time, consumer demand has slowed for premium wines, the segment dominated by Napa and Sonoma County wineries. Last year, sales of such wines grew only 2 percent, to 25 million cases, Mr. Fredrikson said. As a result, about a dozen Northern California wineries have turned south to less expensive areas in the Central Coast region, which runs from Monterey County south to Santa Barbara County.
Santa Barbara County in particular, about 270 miles south of Napa County, has attracted about a dozen wineries. Vineyards here sell for about $15,000 an acre, or 65 percent of the cost of comparable vineyards in the north.
SANTA BARBARA'S drought has not yet affected the vineyards, which require little groundwater compared to other crops.
The average price of Santa Barbara County's Chardonnay grape last year was $1,496 a ton, or 4 percent more than the average price fetched in Napa County. Vineyard owners in the south get a higher price for grapes grown on land that is roughly half the cost of that in the north.
In June 1988, Wine World, which owns the well-respected Beringer Brothers of Napa, paid $13 million fo the Estrella River Winery and 530 acres of vineyards near San Luis Obispo, midway along California's coast. The price was half the market value of vineyard property in Napa, where Wine World has operated since 1971.
A division of Nestles S.A. of Switzerland, Wine World also bought Cat Canyon vineyards near Santa Maria, paying $3.5 million for 700 acres. Rather than buy wine grapes from this region, as this company had done for years, Wine World decided to produce wine in the region, said Michael Moone, president of Wine World.
Around the same time, the Wine Group of San Francisco bought Corbett Canyon Vineyards in San Luis Obispo for $12 million. It also bought 330 acres in what was formerly called Los Alamos Vineyards in Santa Barbara County for $4 million.
A few years ago, Robert Mondavi Winery of Napa Valley and Kendall-Jackson jointly bought the 2,700-acre Tepusquet vineyard here for $12 million - considered a bargain. The two Northern California wineries divided the acreage. Kendall-Jackson's new winery, Cambria, will crush the grapes plucked from its portion of the vineyard.
Factors beyond the wine industry account for the big growth of California's vineyard values. A primary reason is the rapid appreciation of California real estate, especially along coastal regions where wine grapes grow well.
In the state's northern wine country, which includes Napa, Mendocino and Sonoma counties, the median price of a home in March was $176,000, or 23 percent higher than a year earlier, according to the California Association of Realtors.
For those who can afford the address, Napa County offers a slice of the good life, with rolling hills, a low crime rate and a handful of gourmet restaurants rivaling those found in San Francisco, 60 miles south. INDEED, many working couples buy homes in Sonoma County, putting up with a 100-mile daily commute to and from jobs in the Bay Area. ''This is a better place to raise a family,'' said Barbara Wood, a working mother whose husband makes the daily drive.
The migration to the wine country has not only helped push up real estate prices, but has also increased traffic in what is considered primarily an agricultural region. Napa Valley gets about 2.5 million visitors a year; they clog two-lane country roads on their weekend wine tours. The wine industry has spawned T-shirt, totebag and souvenir shops, all of which capitalize on region's wine-making notoriety.
In an effort to preserve its precious vineyard land, the Napa County Board of Supervisors adopted an ordinance earlier this year that prohibits future wineries from luring tourists with souvenir shops and drop-in taste rooms. It also required that at least 75 percent of the grapes processed by new wineries or used in expanding production be grown in Napa Valley.
''Otherwise, the area would turn from an agricultural region into a manufacturing center,'' said John L. Brown, vice president of finance and administration at Beckstoffer Vineyards in St. Helena, in Napa County.
The ordinance caps future growth by making it more difficult to start a winery in Napa Valley, which has contributed to the rise in vineyard values to the south.
However, the Central Coast region is beginning to feel the strain. While the price of vineyards in Monterey County has remained flat at $10,000 an acre, the value of Santa Barbara County's vineyards has tripled in the last three years.
The Santa Barbara County Planning Commission is considering limiting the growth and production of vineyards and wineries in much the same way as Napa County did.

HEADLINE: Ex-Klansman Puts New Racial Politics to Test

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKLIN, La.

 BODY:
It's racial politics for the 90's - not Old South race baiting, but a post-civil-rights-era assault on welfare abuse and programs like affirmative action that his audience sees as helping blacks while hurting whites.
''I'm not a racist like Jesse Jackson,'' David Duke said recently, peering into the Cajun country blue-collar crowd of perhaps 200 people at the American Legion hall here. ''I'm proud of my heritage like Jesse Jackson is proud of his. But I believe the time has come for equal rights for everyone in this country, even for white people.''
Many in the crowd wear blue and white David Duke T-shirts or baseball caps, and they give their approval in a low rumble of ''Duke, Duke, Duke, Duke,'' a response that has made the roadshow of the former Ku Klux Klan leader the talk of Louisiana. 
A year after his surprise election to the Louisiana House of Representatives, Mr. Duke has made himself a potent force in state politics, polarizing the Legislature along racial lines, gathering a fervent statewide following and mounting an unexpectedly strong bid for the United States Senate seat held by J. Bennett Johnston.
Despite the enthusiastic crowds, analysts say there is little chance he can win the Senate race this fall. But Mr. Duke, a Republican, is threatening to elbow the party's nominee, State Senator Ben Bagert, out of the race, and he is angling to force Mr. Johnston, an 18-year incumbent, into an embarrassing runoff. If he does, some critics say, he will achieve his goal of helping to build a national white supremacist movement.
''This is not really about Bennett Johnston or Ben Bagert,'' said Dr. Lawrence Powell, a Tulane University historian. ''It's about politics for the next 10 years.''
Mr. Duke's campaign, which was helped in May when the Louisiana House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved his bill opposing affirmative action, is partly a product of the frustrations generated by Louisiana's depressed economy and partly in keeping with the state's tradition of eccentric politicians, from Huey and Earl Long to Edwin Edwards.
It is aided by the state's unusual system in which all candidates from all parties, whether party nominees or not, run in the Oct. 6 primary. If no candidate gets 50 percent of the vote, the two top finishers face each other on Election Day. If one gets 50 percent, there is no general election. So far, Mr. Johnston, Mr. Bagert and Mr. Duke are the only contenders, although a black state legislator, Willie Singleton, says he might enter the race.
 
'A Mouth That's Different'
But Mr. Duke's campaign, with its focus on issues like affirmative action, government programs that set aside a certain number of contracts for minority businesses and what he calls ''the rising welfare underclass,'' is speaking to white resentments and explosive racial issues that resonate far beyond the state's borders. He is most popular with younger voters.
''Wherever I go, I find almost universal dislike for set-asides,'' said Gov. Buddy Roemer, a Democrat. ''I don't share that. But you can't come down here and say that Louisiana has a problem that's different than anyone else's. We have a mouth that's different, but not a problem.''
Mr. Duke's notoriety stems, for the most part, from his tenure as national grand wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, and he has longstanding ties to far right and racist groups. He had little impact on the Legislature before the vote on his bill on affirmative action. But his views on race have brought him extraordinary visibility around the state. Some analysts say the vote was a sign that legislators believe he speaks for a powerful constituency.
 
Duke's Campaign
At the heart of the Duke campaign are gatherings like the one in this town of almost 10,000 people, with its white-columned, 19th century Main Street homes. Here people work in the oil industry, at local sugar-processing and carbon-black plants and in agriculture and fishing.
The fare at this gathering was Budweiser, Coke and potato chips; the contributions were stuffed in a plastic cup or exchanged for $10 Duke T-shirts or $3 Duke earrings, and the oratory was intensely personal and suffused with primal racial images.
When Mr. Duke talked about the death penalty, he placed it in the context of someone murdering his two daughters. When he talked about economic hardship, he spoke of those in the all-white crowd who cannot afford to rear children.
On the other hand, the abuses of welfare were summed up by women who receive benefits and have ''one, two, three, four, ten, fifteen, twenty'' children. Minority contracting requirements were symbolized by a black state legislator's driving a Mercedes and allegedly getting contracts while a white person in a pickup truck was frozen out.
Even the furor over his affirmative action bill had an oversized target.
''Ladies and gentlemen,'' said Mr. Duke, who has the lanky good looks of a former athlete, ''the only reason why we have problems is because the black caucus didn't get their way like they usually do. It's about time they weren't given their way.''
 
Where Frustrations Blend
In southern Louisiana, where the economy has been depressed since the oil industry doldrums began in the mid-1980's, economic and racial frustration tend to blend.
''He's against welfare,'' said Pierre Dupuis, a retiree who speaks in the melodic Cajun accent of the bayou country here. Using a racial slur, Mr. Dupuis complained that tax money goes to black people, ''with their big radios on the street, and they're laughing at us.''
But more common than slurs against blacks is a sense that white people are being victimized by affirmative action and the minority contracting programs. It is the centerpiece of Mr. Duke's speech and perhaps his most effective issue with voters.
''We don't have the same rights as black people,'' said Jay Louviere, a 29-year-old lumberyard worker. ''Duke's the only one standing up for white people.''
But critics say that the issue has more basis in emotion than economics, that programs like affirmative action evoke particular resentment from white people facing their own economic problems.
 
Furor Over Affirmative Action
''I don't think there are 500 people in Louisiana that have either been adversely affected or benefited by affirmative action,'' said Mr. Edwards, the former Governor. ''But everyone who doesn't have a job or whose son cannot get into law school believes it's because of affirmative action.''
Real or not, it taps into a powerful vein of anger that can seem the ultimate extension of the politics of sex and ethnicity.
''I believe there's a climate in this country that has become anti-Euro-American,'' said Emile Vidrine, a campus minister at the University of Southwestern Louisiana who is spending his summer working as a volunteer for the Duke campaign. ''I'm not putting anyone else down, but we have to put a stop to this idea that we can't stand up tall and say the European white man is one of the great races in the world.''
Mr. Duke's campaign exists in a complex relationship with his nearly lifelong involvement with white supremacist issues and groups. In an interview, he skirted issues he has espoused in the past, like genetic differences between white people and black people, and said his campaign was simply about equal rights for all.
''There are many liberals today who were radical leftists in their younger days,'' he said. ''I'm a conservative who might have been considered a radical rightist in my younger days.''
 
Links to Extremists
But Mr. Duke, who now heads a group called the National Association for the Advancement of White People, has maintained many links to other extremist groups. He used the subscriber list of the far-right publication The Spotlight for fund-raising, ran for President in 1988 as the candidate of the far-right Populist Party and as recently as a year ago sold Nazi and extremist books out of a building that includes his legislative office.
The Louisiana Coalition Against Racism and Nazism, a bitter critic of Mr. Duke, characterizes him as ''an extremist ideologue who uses the pool of new followers as a recruiting ground for a white supremacist and anti-Semitic movement.''
Much of his campaign depends on his ability to persuade voters that he is not a dangerous extremist, and critics say his campaign could falter if a fuller picture of his activities reaches voters.
At the same time, many supporters say his past ignites his campaign and separates him from other conservatives.
''His background is what gives the added emphasis to what he says,'' said Jim McPherson, a New Orleans lawyer and Duke supporter. ''It says he means business.''
 
Few Expect Him to Win
Experts say Mr. Duke must get 65 percent of whites' votes to win a race in a state in which black people make up 27 percent of the electorate. Few think he can do it.
But recent polls show him running second to Mr. Johnston, with the Senator by no means guaranteed the 50 percent he needs to avoid a runoff. Many analysts think Mr. Duke could get at least 30 percent of the statewide vote. Most see an extremely fluid race, saying Mr. Johnston's support is relatively soft, Mr. Duke has fervent supporters but unfavorable ratings from about half the electorate and Mr. Bagert is little-known and underfinanced. Mr. Johnston says Mr. Bagert should quit the race to reduce the chances of Mr. Duke's making a runoff. Mr. Bagert replied that as the only unknown quantity in the race, he is the only candidate with much potential to pick up more support.
To some observers, what is most disturbing about Mr. Duke's campaign is that frustrated and angry white people seem willing to forget his extremism while embracing his more mainstream views on racial issues.
''I think a lot of people are enchanted by the message and are disregarding the messenger,'' said State Representative Odon Bacque Jr., an independent. ''To me it's frightening. I believe if no one takes him seriously, he can end up winning.''

HEADLINE: A Backlash in Romania;
In Calling Out Miners to Stifle Opposition, President Forfeits Control and Good Will

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, June 17

 BODY:
Less than a month after it won elections by a landslide, the Government of President Ion Iliescu has been plunged into a crisis that shows it is at the mercy of groups and forces beyond its control.
Deserted by the police and unable to count on the army to protect it from violent attacks last Wednesday, the Government put itself in the hands of several thousand rough and angry miners, who in a single day managed to do serious and possibly permanent damage to Romania's international reputation.
With Government sanction, thousands of miners traveled to the capital from outlying areas on Thursday and roamed the streets, randomly attacking people suspected of opposing Mr. Iliescu. When the miners departed, the President praised them as ''a strong force with much civic discipline.'' 
Reports of the miners' attempts to smash Mr. Iliescu's political opposition have brought harsh condemnation from many Western countries, including the United States, putting into question whether Romania will get the aid, credits and investments it needs for its economic recovery.
''It is most frustrating,'' Ion Pascu, Mr. Iliescu's foreign policy adviser, said. ''We need Western support and assistance. I just worry that we are not being given the chance to prove that we share Western values.''
Mr. Pascu said the Romanian Government was ''annoyed'' that the West had focused all its attention on the attacks by the miners.
He said that little had been said of the danger posed by anti-Government rioters on Wednesday, when troops opened fire on demonstrators and four people were killed. Today protesters held a small anti-Government demonstration on University Square without interference by the police.
 
Breakdown in Public Order
Mr. Pascu said the Government's response to the crisis last week had been hampered from the start by misleading information and a breakdown in the forces of public order.
For instance, he said, the army was unable to fire tear gas at the rioters on Wednesday because they had no experts trained in its use.
''The system in Romania does not function in a logical manner,'' he said. ''That is not a reason to forgive, but to always expect the unexpected.''
Few observers were surprised by the events in Romania, where violence has deep roots in politics. Since the December revolution that toppled the Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, the country has been troubled by tensions, suspicions and recriminations. Much of the distrust has been directed against the ruling National Salvation Front, which is dominated by former Communists.
The Government charged last week that the opposition attacks on the police station, the Interior Ministry and the state television station were instigated by followers of Romania's fascist movement. Mr. Pascu said the accusation was based on reports that a green flag - a symbol of the fascist Iron Guard - had been placed on top of the Interior Ministry during the siege.
Mr. Pascu said those reports were still unconfirmed, although Mr. Iliescu, in a speech of thanks on Friday to the miners, again tied the rebellion to the infiltration of former Iron Guard members from the West.
 
Right-Wing Scenario
''We are dealing here with a broader scenario of European proportions,'' Mr. Iliescu said. ''There was a joint action of right-wing forces, which started from the presumption that right-wing forces in all Eastern European countries had come to power.''
The biggest crisis Mr. Iliescu faces now is the product not of right-wing forces, but of his own Government's helplessness in the face of the miners' rampage. That helplessness was evident in his speech on Friday, when Mr. Iliescu rejected accusations that the miners had attacked ''peaceful citizens'' and the headquarters of opposition parties.
Such a bald denial of the facts - the miners not only ransacked the headquarters but stayed on to occupy them - was viewed here as a sign of how deeply the Government is now beholden to, perhaps even intimidated by, the miners.
State officials have said that miners will be prosecuted for the beatings and the vandalism, but Mr. Pascu acknowledged today that for political reasons any investigations would have to be undertaken quietly.
 
Rampage 'Out of the Blue'
Mr. Pascu said that Mr. Iliescu and other top members of the leadership were unaware that the miners were attacking opposition parties and newspapers until after the violence had ended.
''The miners' response came out of the blue,'' he said.
An essential question - one that Mr. Pascu said he could not answer - was how miners from the distant Jiu Valley gained precise information not only on the location of the opposition party headquarters, but of the private homes of its leaders, newspaper offices and even the homes of gypsies.
Gypsies became a particular target for the miners because of their role in the opposition's 53-day occupation of University Square, which ended Wednesday morning when the police moved in and arrested 263 people.
Mr. Pascu said that all of the 263 people arrested were freed the same day although the Government did not issue any order, another puzzle in a week of mystifying events.
Those unanswered questions - including a delay by the army in responding to the Government's call for help on Wednesday - have fed rumors in Bucharest. Conspiracy theories have emerged, including one that accuses the Government of orchestrating the entire chain of events to justify a crackdown against the opposition.
Mr. Pascu vigorously denied the charge, noting that the National Salvation Front, Mr. Iliescu's party, had already won power in elections. He also said the Government has offered to help the opposition parties rebuild their headquarters.
In a statement on Saturday night, the Government pledged to insure ''freedom of political expression for all, with the exception of acts of instigation and of neo-fascist propaganda.''
Opposition figures took heart today from harsh criticism of the miners by political leaders appearing on state television. They also noted that the police did not interfere with the demonstration on University Square.
Even at the height of the violence and confusion, there were signs that the Government was trying to prevent the miners from doing their worst. For instance, a Government envoy intervened to rescue Ion Ratiu, the presidential candidate of the National Peasants Party, just as a group of miners was preparing to drive him away in a van.
But Mr. Pascu also made it clear that the Government has had to treat the miners with care, even though by the time they arrived early Thursday morning their presence was no longer necessary, and had even become awkward.
To accommodate the miners and to keep them busy, the Government gave them a place to stay and a place to watch the World Cup soccer game. Mr. Pascu said the miners wanted to remain two more days in Bucharest but that the Government persuaded them to leave on Friday.
He said he felt that the call for help issued by Mr. Iliescu was a mistake - a reflex that reflected the President's training in a political system that exploited mass appeal. ''He is a prisoner of the setting, although he very much wants to change the setting,'' Mr. Pascu said.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
SECURITY AGENCY DEBATES NEW ROLE: ECONOMIC SPYING

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Facing the decline of the Soviet military threat, the National Security Agency is debating plans to shift its global electronic eavesdropping network to other activities, including spying on world trade and financial transactions, Government officials and intelligence experts say.
The agency is already considering reducing some of its Soviet operations, but any further shift would mark a basic change of mission for an organization whose foremost duty since its formation 38 years ago has been to warn of a Soviet military strike against Europe or the United States.
The National Security Agency, the largest of the nation's intelligence agencies, gathers all the intelligence derived from radio signals, telephones and other electronic communications. It is formally an agency of the Pentagon, but it coordinates its activities with the Central Intelligence Agency, whose director reports to the President in the Cabinet.
 
Some Eavesdropping May Rise
Senior officials of the National Security Agency, led by its director, Vice Adm. William O. Studeman, began this spring to draft a proposal to redefine its activities in light of the political and military upheaval in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, Government officials and private experts said. 
Officials stressed that the agency must continue to monitor Soviet military and political developments as long as the Soviet Union remains a nuclear superpower and maintains the largest military force in Asia. In fact, some eavesdropping may well increase as political and social instability rises in Russia and its surrounding republics, they said.
But the officials said the emerging battles for economic primacy among Western nations and multinational companies - and not military rivalries - offer by far the most promising prospects for the agency's future activities.
 
Economic Might, Not Military
Among both senior intelligence officials and those in Congress who oversee their activities, the Soviet military retreat has given rise to a belief that American security now rests more in economic strength than in armed might. The temptation to use espionage as a weapon in the world's trade wars is fast becoming the hottest issue in intelligence circles.
Officials say the National Security Agency's discussions raise fundamental questions about the fairness of such tactics and their practicality. Even if the United States could set aside ethical objections to industrial espionage, there are legal barriers to disclosing such information and serious questions of which American companies should receive it - if, in fact, major companies with factories worldwide and joint ventures abroad can any longer be identified as American. Spying on Allies? The issue is especially delicate because some of the most attractive targets of economic espionage could well be companies or Government agencies of nations militarily allied with the United States, both in Western Europe and in Asia, notably Japan. Many of those nations are now believed to spy on American corporations.
''The real issue is do you want United States intelligence to steal the proprietary secrets of foreign nations,'' a Government official said. ''It's fundamentally anathema to our way of life. We don't do business this way.''
Industrialized nations, including the United States, routinely collect economic intelligence on their allies. The National Security Agency gathers data on financial and stock transactions and foreign government strategies that are useful in trade negotiations and other Government decisions, like the approval of foreign purchases of American companies dealing in restricted technologies, officials said.
There is a consensus among intelligence officials that the agency should gather more economic data, both to assist Government agencies involved in commerce and to detect coming economic disruptions that could affect American interests, like a collapse of financial markets or major banks.
 
Accidental Data Undistributed
National Security Agency eavesdropping outposts are also said to stumble routinely across foreign corporate trade secrets and national industrial strategies that could be of immense value to American companies competing abroad.
That information is not now sought or distributed within the Government, much less among private companies. Among the issues being informally discussed by top intelligence officials are whether the agency and other Government organizations should make a deliberate effort to collect such information, and who should benefit from it.
Neither the agency nor other intelligence groups could decide to gather such specific information on their own. Decisions on the kinds of data that agencies collect are made by committees of intelligence experts and Government policy-makers.
Among intelligence officials, there is an issue even more serious than ethics and practicality in economic espionage: whether such secrets could be shared without compromising the exotic means by which they were plucked from the airwaves, or disclosing the particular frequencies or telephone lines from which they were acquired.
''N.S.A. would go bananas if it collected data that wound up being shared with G.E.,'' said a former intelligence official who is an expert on economic intelligence. ''In their business, you don't disclose sources and methods, or your sources start to dry up.''
 
Reflections in the Budget
While little is committed to paper so far, officials said, the National Security Agency's first conclusions could be reflected in its budget for the fiscal year that begins in October 1991, which is now under review by Congress's committees on intelligence and the armed services.
Some officials cast the discussions as a belated effort to fend off advocates of sharp budget reductions.
''We've got an extraordinary investment in technical collection,'' a second official said. ''This is all so sudden and unpredictable that they don't know whether to start dismantling things, or what equipment to move, or whether they need new policies, or even how it will affect them in terms of the legality of what they do.''
The budget is classified, but its combined military and civilian components are now believed to exceed $10 billion annually. That could quickly drop by 10 percent or more, mostly through cuts in the military side of the budget, if the odds against a conventional war continue to lengthen, a Government official said.
''We have a general idea of where we want to go,'' he said, ''but we're still defining it.''
 
Operations Cannot Be Divulged
That official and others interviewed for this article refused to be identified because of the National Security Agency's longstanding insistence that its operations not be publicly described, even in general terms. The agency is among the most secretive of the Government's major intelligence organizations.
It is also one of the most effective, harvesting such an astonishing array of intercepted telephone calls, radio signals and other electronic traffic that officials generally agree that it provides the bulk of raw intelligence data.
In recent years, the agency has played roles in thwarting Iran's efforts to mine the Persian Gulf; tracking down Panama's deposed dictator, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega; exposing illicit sales of chemical-weapons-manufacturing equipment to Libya, and detecting the smuggling of American technology to Eastern Europe.
 
Focusing on Third World
The agency has already seized upon the eavesdropping opportunities presented by the South American narcotics trade, even challenging the United States Coast Guard and Customs Service for the right to monitor drug-smuggling ships and planes at sea. At the behest of the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, it also has become deeply involved in combating terrorism and the spread of strategic weapons in the Middle East.
In interviews last week, officials said the agency was likely to seek to increase those and other third world activities, in part because Africa and southern Asia are seen as the likeliest sources of future armed conflicts that would affect American interests.
The Soviet Union, however, remains the agency's bread-and-butter target. Most of the agency's largest and most expensive outposts in Europe and Asia, as well as its fleets of satellites, ships and aircraft, exist expressly to detect Soviet war preparations and changes in military doctrine.
The fates of some of those operations are thrown into doubt by the collapse of the Warsaw Pact and the withdrawal of some Soviet forces from parts of Eastern Europe, Vietnam and Afghanistan, officials said.
 
Presence in Germany to Fall
The agency probably will face growing pressure in this decade to remove ground stations targeted against Soviet forces in politically sensitive locations like Japan and the Philippines, they said. And it is certain to reduce its extensive presence in West Germany, where it maintains five major eavesdropping installations aimed at the old Warsaw Pact, the Baltic region and the western Soviet Union.
''I don't think they're survivable in the new world,'' a former senior intelligence official said of those outposts. Intelligence officials say they largely agree.
