HEADLINE: I.R.S. AUDITS RISING FOR FOREIGN BANKS DOING U.S. BUSINESS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
The Internal Revenue Service has sharply increased its audits of foreign banks that do business in the United States, after finding that many paid little or no income tax in the mid-1980's.
While tax officials said they could not estimate the amount that might be collected through such audits, they said the audits of 10 foreign banks last year produced more than $100 million in added taxes. A former I.R.S. official who now works for a large accounting firm said billions of dollars were at stake in disputes over bank taxes.
Foreign banks account for a large and growing share of the American market. They control 22.6 percent of United States banking assets and hold 28.5 percent of American business loans, according to the latest annual survey by American Banker, an industry newspaper. Seventy-five percent of large American companies now use one or more foreign banks, according to Greenwich Associates, a consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn. 
 
Audits Aroused Suspicion
Federal tax officials said they suspected that many foreign banks had taken excessive deductions for their interest expenses. The suspicion is based on audits conducted in the last few years and on the extensive analysis of data collected from the tax returns of foreign banks.
''The I.R.S. thinks that international banks are getting away with murder plain and simple, that we have emasculated the tax law or subverted it, which is untrue,'' said Andrew D. Barkin, vice president at the New York office of Tokai Bank Ltd. of Japan. He said the bank, one of the 10 largest in the world, was undergoing a comprehensive audit by revenue service agents.
Lawrence R. Uhlick, executive director of the Institute of International Bankers, a trade association that represents more than 250 foreign banks operating in the United States, said foreign banks had longstanding disagreements with the revenue service about how to compute their interest costs. He said that the agency's rules were ''incredibly complex'' and he asserted that banks from certain countries were allowed by treaty to calculate their interest deductions by other means.
 
Many Difficult Questions
Like other multinational companies, banks face hard tax questions all the time because they do business in nations with widely varying tax systems.
''These are great banks from all over the world with impeccable reputations,'' Mr. Uhlick said. ''They are not deadbeats. They do not finagle on their taxes. They take seriously their tax obligations, and they are prepared to pay their fair share.''
In 1986, the last year for which the revenue service has complete data, foreign banks with American branches reported total receipts of $26.3 billion from their American operations. They took deductions totaling $25.9 billion, according to the tax agency. Interest is the biggest expense for most banks, and interest costs, computed by a complex formula, are often the most important factor in determining a foreign bank's tax liability in the United States.
''I don't understand how foreign banks could be doing business here for 10 years and not be making any money,'' said Richard A. Ward, chief of planning and special programs in the international audit division of the revenue service. ''It raises a lot of questions. The banks came here to make money.''
The bank audits are part of a general effort by the revenue service to scrutinize foreign companies more closely. Congress recently gave the agency additional power to demand access to the books and records of such companies.
Some people see a political motive for the audits. John O. Hatab, director of international banking services for the Price Waterhouse accounting and consulting firm, who advises more than 40 banks from 25 countries, said: ''The I.R.S. appears to be following the political lead of Congress. There is a perception in Congress that foreign businesses are not paying their fair share of U.S. taxes. The I.R.S. is starting a program to see if that's true.'' 22-Agent Team Formed Federal tax officials said they had recently established a team of 22 agents to comb through the tax returns of foreign banks and identify those in which there was significant potential to collect more revenue.
As part of its inquiry, the revenue service retrieved and reviewed all tax returns filed for 1986 and 1987 by foreign banks with American branches of significant size. About half of the 189 banks were selected for auditing, tax officials said.
Nearly two-thirds of the foreign banks doing business in the United States reported no profits from their activities in this country in the mid-1980's - and therefore no taxable income - tax officials said.
 
Additional Taxes Assessed
Tokai is not the only Japanese bank being audited. The American tax director of another large Japanese bank, who asked not to be identified, said tax agents had established a year-round presence in his New York office, visited the bank's London branch, asked the bank to retrieve documents from seven overseas offices, and assessed ''tens of millions of dollars'' in additional taxes.
Such assessments are often reduced through negotiations with the Government. But tax officials said some foreign banks had paid large sums without protest.
''These are big banks, and we are not talking about small amounts of money,'' said Mr. Uhlick of the Institute of International Bankers.
The I.R.S.'s Mr. Ward said the agency was not aiming at the banks of any country but was auditing returns with the greatest potential for additional revenue.
 
Power of Japanese Banks
The attention paid to Japanese banks reflects their economic importance. Seven of the 10 largest foreign banks in the United States are Japanese, and more than 30 Japanese banks have American branches. Revenue service officials said banks based in West Germany, France, Britain and other countries were also under review.
Foreign banks with American branches reported a Federal tax liability totaling $328 million for 1986, according to the tax agency. Of that amount, $118 million was offset by credits for taxes paid to other countries. Thus, the banks paid $210 million in Federal income taxes for that year.
The Institute of International Bankers reports that at least 20 members have received letters from the revenue agency asking for an extension of the statute of limitations so that the Government can thoroughly audit their 1986 tax returns. Ordinarily, a tax must be assessed within three years after the original return is filed, or the Government loses the right to assess additional taxes. Tax officials said they would ask other banks for extensions as the need arose.
Large companies usually agree to such extensions because otherwise the revenue service is likely to protect the Government's interest by issuing a notice of deficiency to the taxpayer, the formal beginning of a collection process.
In a memorandum to foreign banks last month, Mr. Uhlick said: ''These letters are important not only because they indicate a potentially significant increase in the total number of foreign bank audits, but also because they reflect a stepped-up level of foreign bank audit activity by the I.R.S. Assistant Commissioner (International) in Washington. These activities confirm the information we have received over the last few months that the I.R.S. plans to increase the level of its audit activity of the foreign banking community on an ongoing basis.''
 
Losses in Early 80's
In his memorandum, Mr. Uhlick quoted revenue service officials as saying they had ''recently reviewed the 1986 and 1987 tax returns of virtually every foreign bank engaged in business in the United States.''
Mr. Hatab of Price Waterhouse said, ''In the early 1980's, the total tax bill for foreign banks doing business here was not very big.'' But, he added, that could be explained by the fact that many banks were just moving into the American market and were losing money. Under the law, he noted, a taxpayer can use such losses to offset profits for up to 15 years.
British officials have repeatedly complained to the United States Treasury, saying the revenue service was trying to enforce regulations that were inconsistent with a British-American tax treaty.
The tax agency rejected that argument in a formal ''revenue ruling'' last year. It said British banks must use the formula prescribed by the agency because the 1980 treaty contained no ''specific rule'' for computing the interest-expense deduction.
 
Branch Office Operations
Most international banks doing business in the United States operate through branch offices, rather than separately incorporated subsidiaries. A branch is permitted much higher lending limits because the capital and assets of the parent corporation are assumed to be available to support the branch operations.
When an individual wants to take a tax deduction for interest payments, it is usually a straightforward procedure. The amount of the deduction is the amount of interest paid.
But when the American branch of a foreign bank borrows money, the parent company is legally responsible for repaying the debt. Under Federal law, the foreign bank, not just the branch, is the taxpayer. The revenue service maintains that money borrowed for one purpose frees money for other purposes, so a foreign bank cannot meaningfully link its interest payments to the specific activity for which the loan was obtained.
In 1980, the tax agency established the formula telling foreign corporations how to decide what portion of their worldwide interest expenses could be taken as a tax deduction in the United States. The calculation is complicated because banks borrow in many different currencies, at interest rates that change from day to day. The formula requires them to compute the ''average interest rate'' for various types of borrowing.

HEADLINE: Surplus of College Graduates Dims Job Outlook for Others

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Hundreds of thousands of jobs, once performed creditably without a college degree, are going to college graduates today as employers take advantage of an oversupply of them.
College graduates are being found more and more among the nation's bakers, traveling salespeople, secretaries, bookkeepers, clerks, data processors and factory supervisors. And they are shutting out qualified high school graduates from many jobs, according to Labor Department officials, corporate executives and economists.
There are several reasons why this is happening. One, of course, is the growing complexity of many jobs that were once much simpler to perform. But more important is the current oversupply of college graduates. 
 
More Graduates in Work Force
At roughly 25 percent of the work force - higher than in any other industrial nation - college graduates outstrip the demand for their skills, the Labor Department reports. And the proportion of college graduates in the work force is continuing to increase.
Given this oversupply, many experts, including the authors of a report on the American work force being released today, say that employers are reluctant to gamble on high school graduates. In an age when public schools are accused of turning out many illiterates, corporate America has come to rely on the college degree as the safest guarantee that an applicant has the skills, discipline and maturity to tackle a job.
''The college degree, or even the evidence of having participated in college, has become the nation's major form of job certification,'' said William B. Johnston, a senior research fellow at the Hudson Institute. ''It is a rather expensive and extravagant sorting mechanism, to send people off to schools to learn skills that might not be necessary for work, but it is all that we have right now.''
The emphasis on hiring college graduates has helped to open a huge gap between the incomes of the college educated and the high school educated. Many recent studies show that the standard of living of the high school graduate fell in the 1980's for the first time since World War II, while the college graduates' standard of living, or real wage, rose by nearly 8 percent. No other industrial nation has such a wide wage gap between the two groups.
That wage gap has helped to spur more high school graduates to go to college. For decades only 50 percent had continued education after high school, but since 1982 the number has risen rapidly to nearly 59 percent, assuring the nation of a plentiful supply of college graduates for its job needs into the 21st century, according to Labor Department projections.
Russell Rumberger, a professor of education at the University of California at Santa Barbara estimates that the pool of college graduates exceeds by about 15 percent the need for their skills in professions that require college training, among them engineering, accounting, law and medicine.
The Uneducated Gain Skills Quickly The wage inequity and the growing preference for college graduates have prompted new studies to determine just how qualified high school educated Americans are. Some case studies, among them several presented at a conference of labor economists and social scientists at Brown University this month, found that many uneducated workers can quickly acquire the necessary skills to man even the most modern and sophisticated factories. If those workers succeed, then the prospect of a drastic shortage of skilled workers may be far less realistic than many had thought.
''It is pretty consistently the finding of researchers that the training process in state-of-the-art factories, with the most advanced technologies, is not that complicated,'' said Professor Clair Brown, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, and co-author of studies involving half-a-dozen major companies.
Many companies agree. A panel of businessmen, union leaders and academics, the Commission on the Skills of the American Work Force, in its report being released today, finds that 80 percent of the 400 employers interviewed said the appeal of educated workers lay not with specific skills they might have acquired at school.
Work skills can be taught on the job, they said, but education was associated with the notion that having a degree meant a person also had such qualities as punctuality, good work habits and the ability to learn on the job. For many American employers the four-year college education has become the proxy for these qualities, said Curtis E. Plott, executive vice president of the American Society for Training and Development, whose members are mostly corporate officers.
All these new findings contradict some of the most widely held perceptions about the American work force. One is that the United States has a shortage of skilled workers, making it unable to be competitive with other nations' industries, a shortage that is blamed primarily on public schools that turn out young people so poorly educated that they are untrainable.
In fact, according to Ronald Kutscher, a Labor Department official, the skill shortage has yet to materialize, except in a few areas, like nursing and medical technicians. And some major corporations draw similar conclusions. The General Electric Company, for example, reports no problem in retraining older workers to operate complicated, computerized machinery or in staffing new, high technology appliance factories in Louisville, Ky., and Decatur, Ala., with applicants who had two years of vocational school training.
''Somehow, people find their way to vocational training for jobs that pay enough,'' said Frank Doyle, a company vice president. The appliance factory pay averages $16 to $18 an hour, including $4 to $5 in benefits.
Company Fails Half Taking Test The New York Telephone Company contributed greatly to the perception of a nation of unschooled young people by reporting in 1987 that out of 90,000 applicants for jobs there, 84 percent had failed a basic literacy and math test. Unnoticed was that the people were mostly applying for low-wage, temporary jobs.
When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company gives a similar test to applicants for full-time clerical or operator jobs, positions that include health and pension benefits, the rate of passing is much higher, said Mary Tenopyr, the company's director of employee testing and selection.
''It has been our experience that when you offer a temporary job, you get a lesser quality person,'' Ms. Tenopyr said. What's more, the pool of applicants is so large that the company intentionally fails 50 percent of the test takers, qualifying only those who can score above average.
Motorola Inc. has found that even the poorly educated can be brought up to the standard fairly quickly and made ready for on-the-job training. In transferring workers from older factories to new, high technology plants that make cellular telephones, Motorola discovered that many could not pass a basic skills test that required an eighth-grade reading level, a knowledge of fractions and simple problem solving.
Most, however, mastered these skills after six months in the company's remedial training classes. ''Those who have taken longer are usually immigrants who speak English as a second language and weren't literate in their native language,'' said Edward Bales, a director of education for Motorola.
Motorola, is one of the few American companies that provides remedial training, and it resents having to do so. ''We spent $5 million on this training last year, and that came right out of profits,'' Mr. Bales said. ''The public schools should handle this task.''
But students in the public schools have no reason to believe that taking courses like mathematics will get them jobs. In a survey involving 50 high schools across the country, Professor John Bishop of Cornell University's Center for Advanced Human Resources Studies asked thousands of students who were not bound for college what mathematics courses they needed to qualify for their first choice of jobs. Fewer than 30 percent checked any math course at all.
''They weren't displaying a resistance to study, but an awareness that the job market does not reward them for taking algebra or geometry or trigonometry,'' Mr. Bishop said.
Schools' Responses Worry Employers The reason it does not is twofold: companies mistrust the caliber of the courses given, even when students take them and the companies have trouble verifying exactly what courses high school-educated applicants actually took.
When they send to high schools for students' transcripts, fewer than two in 10 schools respond, surveys show. In one case, the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company in Columbus, Ohio, where Mr. Bishop worked as a consultant, sent 1,200 letters requesting transcripts and received only 93.
The alternative is for a company to test high school educated applicants, as do Motorola, G.E. and the Ford Motor Company, among others. But smaller companies are reluctant to test because testing carries with it the risk that a rejected applicant will sue claiming discrimination. Smaller companies are not as willing as large ones to risk those legal costs, Mr. Bishop said.
Still, ad hoc ways are springing up among smaller companies to screen the high school educated. One method popular among smaller companies is probation - telling a young person to first work on the job for six months, then there will be a spot on the permanent payroll. Another is to subject even the lowest-level applicant for a clerical or janitorial job to half a dozen or more interviews. ''One object is to see if the person keeps showing up and gives consistent answers,'' said David Birch, president of Cognetics Inc., a consultant to small businesses.
Electronic Data System Corporation, of Dallas, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation founded by Ross Perot, has made applicant screening into a high skill. The company hires non-college people as computer operators and for some positions usually given to college graduates, but only after the applicant has filled out an 8-page application and gone through a series of interviews.
''A degree, from high school or college, is not a substitute for E.D.S. screening,'' said John Senderling, a company spokesman. ''We are looking for elusive, almost ineffable character traits, for someone tries hard and can succeed. Once we find that person, we assume we can teach them specific job skills.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Soviet Family's Plight: Leave for Israel or Hold On and Hope?

SERIES: LIVING IN LINE - SECOND OF TWO ARTICLES: TO GO OR TO STAY?

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
In a desk drawer in the apartment of Sergei Kuznetsov and Olga Avilova is a document that could drastically change their lives: an application to emigrate to Israel.
Deciding whether to leave the Soviet Union is a fundamental question about whether to have faith in the country's future.
Olga, a 34-year-old art historian, believes that the country will never emerge from the social, economic and ecological problems that have brought it to what she calls ''the abyss of civil disaster.'' She wants to save her family and start a new life abroad.
Sergei, a 28-year-old mathematician, says he trusts that the country is approaching a new era, however slowly, and that the country's educated professionalss have an obligation to encourage that process by staying in the Soviet Union. 
As the nation faces one of the most critical periods in its economic and political development, Sergei and Olga have been struggling, along with most everyone in the country, to deal with the monumental and often disheartening changes.
A few years ago, the hardships and doubts that the family now faces may have been much the same, but the possibility of leaving was infinitely more complicated. Since Olga is Jewish on her mother's side, more open Soviet emigration policies virtually assure that the family can leave for Israel.
The question of religion has never been very important to Sergei and Olga. Like most Soviet Jews, Olga considers herself Jewish by background, not by practice, and it was not considered unusual for her to marry Sergei, a Russian. Occasionally, she prays at a Russian Orthodox Church, a common practice among Jews of mixed heritage. But she and her family have been victims of anti-Semitism and she thinks that the time has come to end that cycle.
 
Persistent Prejudice
Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, tens of thousands of Jews have been emigrating, some to the United States but most to Israel. Some experienced years of harsh anti-Semitism and discrimination, yet the Soviet authorities long refused them permission to leave. Most lived with persistent prejudice that blocked their entry to universities or better jobs, or caused them trouble with neighbors, but they nevertheless had never considered leaving as an answer.
Over the last year or so, the subject of emigration has gradually permeated life in the crowded apartment on First Smolensky Lane that Sergei and Olga share with two daughters and Olga's elderly mother. It creeps into the most mundane conversations, like the time that Sergei bought up a case of porridge - 16 boxes - when he found it on sale in a local grocery store that was bereft of much else.
''It's good to have around the house for when fresh food is hard to find,'' he told Olga when he came home with his big purchase.
''What are we doing living in a country where our children could starve to death unless they eat groats,'' Olga snapped back. ''We should just leave, fill out the Israeli application and be done with this horror.''
Economics are a significant factor in the family debate about whether to leave. Many Jewish families taking advantage of easier emigration rules are trying to leave not out of a wish to practice Judaism freely, or because they fear anti-Semitism. They are applying to emigrate because living in the Soviet Union has become too difficult and they want a better life.
 
Fear of Economic Disaster
Olga is quick to admit that she wants to leave because she fears that the economy is falling apart. She is convinced that even middle-class people in big cities could soon be starving. She also feels that Soviet society will not be ready in her lifetime to accept and carry out the measures necessary to turn life around.
''I have a friend who aptly compares the situation here to Moses leading the Jews out of Egypt,'' Olga said. ''Before the Jewish people could get into the Land of Israel and begin a new life, Moses led them around the desert for 40 years, until all the people who had been slaves and still had the slave mentality died. God and Moses knew that only those who were not born to slavery could build a new life.''
To be sure, fear of anti-Semitism is also a major concern for Olga. She was first chided for being Jewish as a child, when the building janitor chased her out of the yard with a broom, shouting ''zhid!'' - an insulting term comparable to ''kike.''
The harassment, at turns subtle and overt, continues to this day. Liza recently came back from playing in the local playground and asked her mother what a ''zhid'' was. A mother of one of the other children had called Liza by the epithet, then ordered her own child to stay away. Olga worries that as the economy gets worse, so will the prejudice. Obligation to Stay? Sergei tries to fight her, but not with practical arguments. Though he says he believes that the economy will respond to new programs, he realizes that he has precious little proof. Instead, he argues from a personal and moral stand. He says he feels deeply that as a person of talent and drive, he owes it to his country to stay and help revive it.
Moreover, if he moves abroad, Sergei says, he will probably be forced to abandon his field at least temporarily to earn a living. He could go from a laboratory where he studies inductive reasoning to a taxi or to a kitchen. If so, it could take years before he is able to return to his work.
''What kind of life is it if I become materially richer and spiritually poorer,'' he said one day after Olga, who is on maternity leave from her job as an editor at an art publishing house, returned from a particularly grueling foray to the food stores. ''A person's entire soul changes from that kind of switch in life style. I want to change because of my own decisions, not because of external influences and some strange life.''
''Oh, Sergei, I agree with you in principle,'' Olga said. ''But it's time for me to think about my own kids. They're forced to eat terrible food and breathe this awful air. How will they grow, let alone thrive? Our bodies are learning to take so much abuse, we're all becoming mutants.
''And what about their minds? The education system is so bad. It's still bogged down by this absurd Communist ideology. Just look at this book.''
Olga grabbed Liza's second-grade textbook and began to read aloud a simplistic and dogmatic story about the young Lenin:
''Exactly at 7, Volodya woke himself up. Nobody had to wake him. Having slept, he got up immediately. He didn't allow himself to loll around in bed. He brushed his teeth, washed his hands and face well and. . . .''
And on the text went, implying that good children will train themselves well to become good Communists.
 
'But I Still Have Ideals'
Sergei slumped in his chair and shook his head. ''I know, I know,'' he said. ''But I still have ideals. I can't cast off my own country as dead. I couldn't live somewhere else peacefully, knowing that I'm in part guilty for leaving all these problems behind and not helping.''
The arguing and debating continued that day and resurfaced again and again all week. Olga's mother, Zhanna Gaysinskaya, who usually tries to keep peace in the tight quarters by holding her tongue, turned to Olga one day and said more emphatically than she ever had before: ''I want you kids to leave. There are too many reasons to leave and not enough to stay.''
By week's end, while the Government's new economic plan was being battered by politicians and workers across the country, Sergei was feeling defeated. The faith he put in the system was slowly starting to erode.
''Maybe we could fill out the application,'' he said to Olga, though he remains unconvinced that leaving is the answer, and the family debate remains alive. ''Or maybe I could get a contract with a computer firm and we could go for a year or two and see how it is. You know, now it's not so hard to come back if we change our minds.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sergei Kuznetsov and Olga Avilova are struggling with the changes in their country. In particular, they are deciding whether to emigrate to Israel. With them in their Moscow apartment were their children, Vera, 10 months old, and Liza, 8 years old, and Olga's mother, Zhanna Gaysinskaya. (Vladimir Sumovsky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Preparations Are Hectic for Mandela's U.S. Tour

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
When Nelson Mandela arrives in New York on Wednesday for a grueling, hastily scheduled 12-day, 8-city tour of the United States, he has a single, clear political objective in mind, organizers say: keeping economic sanctions and other pressure for change on the white South African Government.
''This is not some kind of a victory lap,'' said Roger Wilkins, national coordinator of the visit.
Mr. Mandela, released in February after 27 years in prison, has become the personification of the struggle against South Africa's system of racial separation, and for millions of black Americans the ticker-tape parades and rallies in ball parks will be a moment of pride.
 
Meeting With President
The deputy president of the formerly banned African National Congress, Mr. Mandela will meet with President Bush at the White House, address a joint session of Congress and make a speech to the United Nations General Assembly.
Perhaps as important, he will meet privately in New York with leading business figures, some of whom still have financial ties to South Africa, in an effort to keep economic pressure on the Government of President F. W. de Klerk. 
The eight-city tour, resembling a Presidential campaign swing, will include a ticker-tape parade to City Hall, New York's traditional hero's welcome; a rally in Yankee Stadium, and a star-studded concert in Los Angeles produced by Quincy Jones and Lionel Ritchie and including Stevie Wonder, Diana Ross, Paula Abdul and Bonnie Raitt.
Organizers have been swamped with requests for meetings with Mr. Mandela by people ranging from schoolchildren to socialites. There have been 5,000 requests for press credentials to the State Department. The cramped, makeshift offices of tour organizers in Washington and New York have been madhouses of constantly ringing telephones.
But there is also concern that the schedule may be too demanding for Mr. Mandela. He will be 72 years old next month and is in uncertain health, having recently undergone surgery for the removal of a benign cyst on his bladder.
On Thursday, the African National Congress headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, contacted the national tour organizers in Washington to ask that the schedule be scaled back. Indeed, by the weekend the schedule was still not firm, with officials emphasizing that all events were subject to change should Mr. Mandela need rest.
''Its all tentative, depending on how he feels,'' said Darlene Donloe, a spokeswoman for the reception committee in Los Angeles, toward the end of the tour. ''You have to remember he's an old man.''
Mr. Wilkins, the national director, said that one of his main goals was to protect Mr. Mandela's health by being the man to say no to the flood of organizations and individuals seeking to meet him.
''This man is not an ambulatory photo opportunity,'' Mr. Wilkins said. ''He's a 71-year old human being who's had a very strenuous life since he got out of prison.''
 
A Logistical Nightmare
With only four weeks to organize, the tour is a logistical nightmare.
''Its like running a campaign on a crash basis,'' said Mr. Wilkins.
''We're running a visit on the level of a head of state,'' said Mae Ngai, deputy director of the New York welcoming committee. ''But without being a state, so we don't have the resources, the infrastructure.''
The State Department will provide security, but the rest of the logistics will be handled by the national and local committees.
Another goal of the tour will be to raise funds for the A.N.C. Tickets to the various events range from $5 for some of the ball-park concerts to contributions from corporations of as much as $50,000 a seat for a reception in Los Angeles.
The need for the continuation of sanctions will be Mr. Mandela's main message, said Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, an anti-apartheid organization, who intitiated the trip at Mr. Mandela's request. Mr. Robinson, a Washington lawyer, directed a series of daily demonstrations outside the South African Embassy in Washington that saw 4,000 arrests there and 5,000 elsewhere in the country and is generally credited with helping to lead Congress to approve economic sanctions against South Africa in 1986.
Mr. Robinson and other organizers have said in interviews that there was concern in the African National Congress that the Bush Administration, which had opposed sanctions, would use the limited reforms thus far initiated by the de Klerk Government as a basis for lifting the measure.
The concern was heightened, Mr. Robinson and others said, by remarks on June 10 by the President's chief of staff, John H. Sununu, on a televised Sunday talk show. Responding to a question from Robert Novak, the syndicated columnist, about whether sanctions might now be lifted, Mr. Sununu replied:
''I think in terms of the law, the ability to remove sanctions is there, if I'm not mistaken. I think the President and Secretary of State Baker will be reviewing this and I suspect, over the next few weeks, there will be an evolution of what the exact policy will be.''
''Nothing could be farther from the truth,'' Mr. Robinson asserted. He said that only one of the mandated conditions for lifting sanctions had been met, the lifting of the ban against the A.N.C., but that other conditions like the repeal of the law establishing segregated living areas, the release of some 3,000 political prisoners and ''substantial progress'' toward the dismemberment of the apartheid system had not.
''Why turn off the heat when the water is about to boil,'' said Lindiwe Mabuza, the A.N.C's chief representative to the United States, emphasizing that it was the pressure of the sanctions, estimated to have cost the South African economy at least $10 billion, which helped force the climate of change.
''To withdraw the pressure is to frustrate these efforts, to send the wrong signals,'' she said. ''It is to say the South African Government has just got to do the minimum.''
The tour grew out of a meeting of about 70 supporters of the anti-apartheid movement, including Mayor David N. Dinkins, convened by Mr. Robinson in Washington on May 11.
One major city that is conspicuously absent from the itinerary is Chicago, which Mr. Mandela has been urged to avoid by his supporters there. They have criticized Mayor Richard M. Daley's policies on sanctions, contending that Mr. Daley has been too lenient with companies that have dealings in South Africa.
 
Arrival in New York
Mr. Mandela, who traveled to Canada yesterday after a similar swing through Europe, will arrive in New York early Wednesday morning to be welcomed by Mayor Dinkins. A motorcade through Brooklyn will be followed by a lunchtime ticker-tape parade through the financial district and a City Hall reception. Mr. Mandela, and his wife, Winnie, will stay at Gracie Mansion.
There will be an ecumenical service at Riverside Church on Thursday morning, a motorcade through Harlem and a ceremony at the Adam Clayton Powell state office building there, followed by a rally and concert at Yankee Stadium.
On Friday morning Mr. Mandela will have a private breakfast with business leaders, followed by an address to the United Nations General Assembly. While in New York, he will also tape television programs for Ted Koppel's ''Nightline'' and the MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour.
On Saturday, Mr. Mandela will travel to Boston, where he will have lunch with members of the Kennedy family at the John F. Kennedy Library. There will be a motorcade through minority neighborhoods, a six-hour-long public rally at the Esplanade, and an evening fund-raising reception. On Sunday, he will visit two of his daughters, Zenani Mandela-Dlamini, 31, and Makaziwe Mandela, 36, who are both college students in the area.
Mr. Mandela will travel to Washington on Sunday, where he will have a White House meeting on Monday with President Bush, followed by a meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. On Tuesday, June 26, after having breakfast with members of the Congressional Black Caucus, he will speak to a joint meeting of Congress. In the evening, there will be a rally at the District of Columbia Convention Center.
Unlike Mayor Dinkins, Washington's black Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., who is embroiled in a drug trial, will not play a role in Mr. Mandela's visit, organizers in Washington said.
Mr. Mandela will be in Atlanta on June 27 for a wreath-laying ceremony at the grave of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In the evening, he will attend a rally at Grant Field Stadium. At Morehouse College, which is predominantly black, Mr. Mandela will be awarded an honorary doctorate from 117 traditionally black colleges and universities.
He will fly to Miami on June 28 to address the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees convention, and then he will travel to Detroit for a visit to the Ford River Rouge Plant and an evening rally at Tiger Stadium.
On June 29, Mr. Mandela will fly to Los Angeles. He will travel in a motorcade to City Hall, where he will make a speech on the steps. There is a fund-raising reception in the evening followed by the concert in the Coliseum, which seats 90,000 people.
 
Rally in Oakland
The next morning, Mr. Mandela will go to Oakland, Calif., where there will be a rally in the afternoon at the Oakland Coliseum, a fund-raising cocktail party and a $100 a plate dinner at the Hyatt Regency Hotel. Oakland and the Bay Area had pressed to be added to the schedule because longshoremen there have refused to unload South African cargo and because Oakland, Berkeley and San Francisco have policies to divest themselves of holdings in companies that do business with South Africa. The area's Congressman, Ronald V. Dellums, a Democrat, has sponsored anti-apartheid measures in Congress for the past 20 years.
Mr. Mandela will depart for Britain on July 1.
Mrs. Mandela will appear at separate events in several cities, including New York, Boston and Berkeley, Calif.
The ad hoc nature of the organizing for Mr. Mandela's trip was shown by the two-day delay in selling tickets for the Yankee Stadium concert because of a dispute over the grass. Billy Joel, the singer, who has booked the Stadium for a concert, agreed to lend the Mandela committee his speakers and other equipment, including a tarpaulin and 7,000 folding chairs. But the Yankee's owner, George Steinbrenner, fearing damage if the tarpaulin and chairs remained on the field three full days, held out until he got a pledge from the city to repair any damage to the grass.
''Mr. Mandela is an international symbol of integrity, commitment and freedom,'' Mr. Steinbrenner said in a statement on Thursday. ''He is a leader by example and a world hero. The stadium grass, which will contain thousands of temporary chairs, may be demaged. But because of the importance of this event, we will move forward.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Harlem Welcoming Committee preparing poster distribution for Nelson Mandela's visit to New York. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Officials Brace for Exodus Of Foreigners from Panama

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Immigration officials say the arrest of 63 Chinese on an isolated Alabama airstrip last week was a sign that thousands of foreigners may soon try to enter the United States illegally from Panama.
The officials say the Chinese represent a painful legacy of the corruption rife in the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and are among tens of thousands of foreigners in Panama who bought Panamanian passports, visas, residency permits and identity cards to escape their troubled homelands.
The officials said a large alien smuggling ring flourished under General Noriega. The aliens detained near Mobile were from mainland China and arrived by chartered aircraft from Panama in two groups on Saturday and Monday after paying up to $15,000 each for illegal passage to the United States, the immigration officials said. 
They were sent to immigration detention centers in Texas and Florida, where they face expulsion proceedings.
 
'Targeting the United States'
''We are aware that there are significant numbers of aliens in Panama that do not have legal residence there, and we're certainly sensitive to the possibility that they might be targeting the United States to arrive here illegally,'' said Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Estimates of the number of foreigners with uncertain legal status in Panama as a result of the ouster of General Noriega vary widely. Immigration officials in Washington estimated there are 7,000 Chinese and 2,000 Cubans in Panama. But some immigration officials and Panamanian government experts said there were up to 35,000 Chinese and 13,000 Cubans along with several thousand others, including Nicaraguans, Indians and Pakistanis.
The traffic in Panamanian immigration documents was sanctioned by the Noriega government, but was cut off after the United States invasion last December. The Government of President Guillermo Endara halted the sale of Panamanian documents overseas, and faced with daunting economic problems and high unemployment, it has grown increasingly reluctant to allow those in Panama to remain.
The arrival of Chinese in Panama increased dramatically last year with the Chinese Government's crackdown of the student democracy movement. Panamanian officials estimated that nearly 9,000 Chinese bought documents, most of them through the Panamanian consulate in Hong Kong, to enter Panama.
 
As Visas Expire, Desperation
But now the temporary visas and residency permits, some issued for a year, are beginning to expire. Many foreigners, living in Panama in poverty, are willing to risk illegal entry to the United States following routes and using smuggling techniques used by drug traffickers.
The Chinese apprehended near Mobile, including some with $1,000 bills sewn into their clothing, told investigators that they paid up to $20,000 each for passports and visas to enter Panama and spent an additional $15,000 to enter the United States, said Thomas P. Fischer, the immigration service regional director in Atlanta, whose jurisdiction includes Alabama.
He said they reported traveling a circuitous route from China to Hong Kong and then to London or Amsterdam before arriving in Panama. Most of those detained said they had left China two or three years ago.
Federal prosecutors in Mobile have charged Alfonso Mock-Castillo, a Panamanian restaurateur of Chinese ancestry, as the ringleader of the operation. They have accused him of arranging the flights through an undercover agent of the Customs Service. Mr. Mock-Castillo was arrested along with a woman, described by investigators as his accomplice, on charges of alien smuggling.
 
Suggestion of Noriega Role
Immigration officials suggested that Mr. Mock-Castillo had planned to transport up to 35,000 Chinese into the United States. Some of these officials suggested that the ring was part of an alien smuggling operation controlled by General Noriega and his associates.
But Dexter Lehtinen, the Federal prosecutor in Miami, who is prosecuting Gen. Noriega on drug trafficking charges, issued a statement denying that smuggling charges were likely. ''There is no indictment currently planned or contemplated against General Manuel A. Noriega in this district that includes any allegations of alien smuggling.''
Some immigration officials in Washington said they suspect that Federal prosecutors in Miami are wary of pursuing a case that would inevitably involve the politically volatile issue of Cuban immigration in South Florida, where Cuban-Americans form a powerful constituency. But immigration officials and prosecutors in Miami denied it.

HEADLINE: How to Make Europe Secure

 BODY:
Now that President Gorbachev has reconciled himself to a united Germany in NATO, he still must find a new place in Europe. And his newly independent neighbors in Eastern Europe need a sense of security. A collective security pact for all of Europe could meet both these needs. 
As the Warsaw Pact disbands, Moscow grows ever more nervous about its future in Europe. Hungary, long a Soviet satellite, now hints that it wants to follow Germany into NATO. But that would isolate Moscow even more and do nothing to promote long-term stability.
A collective security pact that binds all states against any aggressor would be preferable to alliances that commit some states to oppose others. The idea is being talked about across Europe, and it merits the Bush Administration's careful attention.
Eastern Europe is really Middle Europe, the countries caught between Germany and Russia. These states have enjoyed periods of precarious independence, but never independence with security.
That's why some Warsaw Pact members want to preserve the old alliance in some measure. Poland has invited the Red Army to remain at least until it gets border guarantees from Germany. Czechoslovakia's President, Vaclav Havel, wants the Warsaw Pact transformed into ''a treaty of sovereign states, with equal rights, formed on a democratic basis.'' That would give the Soviet Union a place among its neighbors.
But uneasy as Poland and other states are about a powerful Germany's renewed push to the East, they don't believe Germany poses a military threat. And they are not about to spurn Germany's economic advances. In any event, having endured the suffocating embrace of their Soviet ally for 40 years, most are not yet ready to link arms again.
Another alternative for Eastern Europe might be a form of armed neutrality, like that practiced by Finland and Sweden for 45 years. But armed neutrality isn't very attractive in Eastern Europe. Instead, there is a good deal of talk about a collective security pact among all 35 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, or at least among the 23 in NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
Such a pact could commit signatories, the U.S. and the Soviet Union included, to impose sanctions on and take up arms against aggressor states. It would also meet Mr. Gorbachev's need for a place in Europe.
What would such an arrangement look like? A new European Security Council could be established, perhaps in Berlin. Through periodic meetings of permanent representatives from the member countries, the council could, for instance, verify the treaty now being negotiated to reduce conventional arms. It could mediate disputes and provide peacekeeping forces to separate the contenders.
The history of collective security is not very reassuring, but perhaps this is the time and the place to try again. The idea offers an interesting way for Mr. Bush to assure that his victory on a united Germany in NATO does not dangerously isolate the Soviet Union.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How Minorities Are Sold Short

BYLINE: By Mark Green; Mark Green is Commissioner of New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs.

 BODY:
One of the unacknowledged underlying reasons for today's racial tensions in New York City is decades of small slights and systematic exploitation of minorities by banks, insurance companies, department stores and other businesses -not just one contested incident at a grocery run by Korean-Americans.
More than 20 years ago, the Kerner Commission cited consumer fraud as one of the causes of the riots in Watts, Detroit and Newark. Since then, minority groups in some respects have moved further than ever from the economic mainstream.
The income gap between whites and non-whites has widened. The shift from manufacturing to service industries, combined with the terrible flaws in urban education, has left African-Americans and Latinos at a disadvantage when competing for white-collar jobs. And Reagan-era attacks on affirmative action and civil rights programs did nothing to enhance racial economic justice. 
But perhaps nothing is so infuriating or depressing to minority people as the daily reminders of institutional discrimination. Consider:
Auto insurance. Drivers who happen to live in certain ZIP code areas pay higher rates, no matter how good their driving record. One recent analysis showed that 79 percent of the drivers in the urban core of the Bronx are in the high-premium, assigned-risk pool. Compare this with a rate of 41 percent in the rest of the Bronx and 16 percent statewide.
Employment. New York State has filed a string of five lawsuits alleging discrimination by employment agencies. The agencies are accused of having coded job candidates' applications by race. Evidently, top skills do not always insure desirable jobs for members of minority groups.
Shopping. Few major supermarket chains locate stores in minority neighborhoods. Thus, some residents of Harlem, to cite just one example, are forced to take gypsy cabs to the West Side to shop.
It was reported recently in Crain's that a D'Agostino's supermarket at 110th Street and Broadway will deliver groceries only as far east as Manhattan Avenue. Its deliverers will not go one block farther, which would take them into Harlem.
Moreover, major department stores refuse to open outlets in shopping malls located in solidly middle-class African-American areas -even though there is significant buying power in these neighborhoods.
Consumer banking. Major banks were well represented in minority neighborhoods in the 1960's. But in the past decade, most of the branches have been shuttered. All too often, no bank means no mortgages and no convenient access to banking services by local businesses. Yet banks do business under government charters, which require them to operate in the public interest and for the public's convenience - the entire public, not just the affluent.
Adding insult to injury, there is a good chance of rejection when a frustrated Latino or African-American does try to open a checking account in some other neighborhood. According to a recent study by two state legislators, most major banks in New York City require applicants for checking accounts to live or work near - usually within 10 blocks of - the branch.
This provision effectively bars minorities from opening checking accounts, which are one of the basic tools for full participation in the economy. To make matters worse, the multi-racial ''testers'' who conducted the study found that distance requirements were usually waived for whites but rarely for non-whites.
As for access to credit, Congressional hearings last month confirmed that African-Americans are rejected for mortgages twice as often as whites - even when income and other factors are equivalent.
These everyday consumer offenses amplify the toll imposed by broad income discrepancies and restricted access to education and health care. Until the day arrives when minorities can open a checking account at any bank, successfully hail a medallion cab, have mortgage applications fairly evaluated and get equitably priced insurance, there will be a steady and generous supply of grist for the mill of racial anger.
So, instead of conveniently blaming a few provocateurs for black-white-Asian tensions, we should focus on the eroding economic health of minority consumers.

HEADLINE: We Still Need Missile Defenses

BYLINE: By John Warner; John Warner, Republican of Virginia, is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Have the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union undermined the need for continued research on ballistic missile defenses? Absolutely not. If anything, the case for some type of missile defenses is more compelling today than at any time since the advent of nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles.
We must remain prepared to deal with political and military instability. The Soviet Union is increasingly fraught with nationalist and ethnic unrest, and its economy cannot fulfill the basic needs of the people. Mr. Gorbachev's viability is questioned because of the seemingly indomitable problems facing his nation. 
The Soviet Union still possesses a formidable military capability. Most notable is its strategic offensive and defensive nuclear force modernization program. Soviet ballistic missile defenses around Moscow - the world's only such system - are being upgraded.
Consequently, our nuclear deterrent must remain, in both perception and reality, uncontestable to any foreign power. And we must consider the enormous benefits of a strategic missile defense.
Even as arms control negotiations move toward reducing the overall levels of strategic delivery systems, our existing strategic defenses -such as air defenses, early-warning and surveillance and intelligence -are clearly seen by other countries as stabilizing and unthreatening. Missile defenses will enhance this stability by assuring that our perhaps more vulnerable retaliatory forces are protected and by denying an attacker any certainty of achieving his objectives.
They also provide a hedge against cheating on arms control treaties. Indeed, effective missile defenses actually promote strategic arms control objectives by reducing the military value of multiple-warhead missiles. They also provide incentives for the Soviet Union to move to a less threatening force of single-warhead, land-based missiles.
In addition, there are many countries that now possess missiles that threaten the interests of the U.S. and its friends. Many of these missiles are capable of reaching allies like Israel and can be equipped with chemical or biological warheads, and soon even nuclear weapons.
Today, the number of developing countries possessing ballistic missiles with a range of less than 1,000 miles - such as Iraq and Syria - has increased substantially. William Webster, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, recently informed Congress that, by the year 2000, at least six third-world countries will have ballistic missiles with ranges of up to 1,800 miles, and three of them may develop ballistic missiles with a range of 3,400 miles.
Missile defenses in the U.S. and within the borders of our allies would greatly deter long-range ballistic missile use. Tactical ballistic missile defenses deployed by our allies would enhance deterrence and stability.
On a recent trip to California, I had a firsthand look at the Strategic Defense Initiative. The question is no longer whether the country has the technical ability to build cost-effective missile defenses; it is clear we do. Rather, we must now ask what role missile defenses will have in our national strategy.
As in the air defense debate in England during the 1930's, we must now ask: Does America want to be defended, and if so, with what systems? For England, the outcome of that debate was pivotal. It was England's advanced air defense systems that saved it in the summer of 1940.
It is worth remembering the words of Winston Churchill at the peak of the air defense debate: ''I think it would be a great mistake to neglect the scientific side of purely defensive action against aircraft attack. Certainly, nothing is more necessary, not only to this country, but to all peace-loving . . . powers in the world . . . than that the good old earth should acquire some means of destroying the sky marauder.''
Today, the marauder is ballistic missiles. I am convinced that we must now, more than ever before, plan for the inclusion of missile defenses in our national security strategy.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
No Time for Temper Tantrums

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When the P.L.O. betrayed the basis for talks with the U.S. by launching a major terrorist attack on civilian families on the beaches of Tel Aviv, Mr. Bush sent his Secretary of State to the Congress to lash the new Government of Israel with sarcasm.
Secretary Baker's blame-the-victim attitude invites more terrorism and a new cycle of stiffneckedness. As the supreme pragmatist, he should recognize that snide, self-indulgent wisecracks make great sound bites but impede progress.
Let's be constructive: in the Middle East, that means taking Mr. Baker's calculatedly intemperate here's-my-number, call-me-when-you're-ready blast and interpreting it in a different way. 
The new conservative (''right wing'' to those who never call its opposition ''left wing'') Government should take the Baker tantrum as good news: for a while at least, it means that Israel will be given a respite from intervention in its democratic political workings by a one-sided, anti-settlement Government in Washington eager to set up a Palestinian state under Arafat rule.
This will give the new Government, denied even the shortest media honeymoon, a chance to come up with a few surprises.
Surprise No. 1 is easy: to demonstrate it is not the gang of thugs that Arab apologists would have the world believe. The new Shamir Government has already welcomed a U.N. visitor and opened one Palestinian university facility; other demonstrations of good will should follow, unless these are met with a kick in the teeth.
The second surprise will come when the Government, always derogated as ''narrow based,'' lasts longer than a few weeks. Here is the unspoken discipline to splinter parties: when a few swing voters bring down the rightist coalition, a unity government is likely to emerge that will reform the splinters out of their seats in the Knesset. Thus, the next no-confidence vote could be their last.
The focus, Likudniks hope, will be on ''the absorption process.'' Today's enthusiastic welcoming is sure to face natural strains; young Israelis, facing unemployment approaching 9 percent, will be competing for jobs with arriving Soviet immigrants.
Housing Minister Arik Sharon can expect heavy coverage of disappointed immigrants and resentful sabras, but could confound his critics by rising to his greatest challenge - housing and employing Exodus III, which will strengthen Israel immeasurably.
Mention of that controversial character turns us to the surprises we can expect from a Labor Party no longer in thrall to the State Department. Mr. Sharon tells political friends: ''Peres is finished; our problem is Rabin.''
Yitzhak Rabin, Defense Minister until the popular Mr. Bush inadvertently knocked over Israel's grand coalition in a fit of peaking, is in the U.S.; I slipped up to New York and caught him, relaxed for a change, watching a soccer game on TV.
His longtime rival, Shimon Peres, remains leader of the Labor Party, hopeful that time will dim memories of his failed grab for power; Mr. Rabin, the most widely respected leader in Israel, knows he must move quickly to regain the party and national leadership he held in the 70's.
He would like to bring a primary system to his party, infusing it with young blood and capturing the nation's avid attention, but that might take four months to set in train; a quicker leadership decision would be through the 1,300 members of the party's central committee, most of whom owe their jobs to Mr. Peres and his cohort.
Because political parties exist to win, I'm betting on Yitzhak Rabin to bring it off. What would follow in time would be elections with an eye to the sort of reform Israel needs: a stable government of one side or the other.
Mr. Rabin envisions a prime minister elected directly, with a two-thirds vote of the Knesset needed to bring down his government - a hybrid presidential-parliamentary system. Others press a reform raising the threshold of the percentage of votes needed to rate seats in Parliament; whichever shape it takes, the need for stability is in the air.
What is the best U.S. policy? To restore our antiterrorism credibility by getting out of the P.L.O.'s snare of talks; to stop building the Iraqi threat with our trade and credits; and to get off Mr. Shamir's back as new Israeli leadership backed by an improved political system develops.
As that happens, and as Secretary Baker learns that Israeli leaders do not quake at his sarcasm, let the phones begin to ring.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
A Final Insult: It May Even Cost More on Way Out

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
When Benjamin Franklin said that nothing is certain but death and taxes he did not anticipate the inevitable outcry over taxes imposed upon death.
Wealthy New Yorkers, all but resigned to the high cost of living in the city, are balking at an inconspicuous proposal that would raise the cost of dying in the city, too.
Tucked into Mayor David N. Dinkins's tax package is a 20 percent city surcharge on the state's estate tax. The extra tax on estates valued at $1 million or more originated with the City Council. 
Among $800 million of proposed levies, the $5 million that the surcharge is projected to generate in the fiscal year that starts on July 1 might seem to many people like small change. So, to a smaller number of people, perhaps, is the roughly $25 million that the surcharge is expected to begin producing annually in two years, once its full impact is felt.
But the surcharge has become symbolic. New York is a city whose business is wealth. Its relatively glacial economy, volcanic crime rate and overheated racial climate have combined again to create self-doubts among even the most committed, but highly mobile, New Yorkers.
Mr. Dinkins, sensitive to the jitters in the business world, largely buttoned his lips about taxes in his campaign last year. Yet, when the Mayor outlined his tax proposals last month, many business leaders responded sympathetically, given the dimensions of the budget gap he had inherited and his efforts to apportion the pain fairly.
Then someone spotted the surcharge. Its potential targets, their intermediaries and a number of tax experts warn that it might prompt some wealthy New Yorkers, many of whom already own homes elsewhere, to flee -depriving the city not only of the estate tax, eventually, but also of yearly revenue, meanwhile, from the personal income tax.
''Of all the taxes that have ever been proposed,'' the president of CBS Inc., Laurence A. Tisch, said, ''this is the one where you would end up with the biggest loss of revenue. This is so bad because right now everybody's on the cusp.''
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-oriented watchdog group, said the surcharge ''undoubtedly would raise some money, but would also, in theory at least, cause some exodus.''
Many New Yorkers routinely say they are dying to leave the city. But will others now be leaving to die?
Budget Director Philip R. Michael is not looking a gift tax in the mouth. ''I don't buy the argument that, 'Ha, I'm going to die, so I'm going to move,' '' he said.
Other fiscal officials are not so sure. When the Council initiated the surcharge, said its Finance Director, Marc V. Shaw, ''a lot of people looked at it as a good social mechanism to raise revenue, that for people who have come into a lot of money, once they're dead it's not the worst thing if they give a payback to society.'' Moreover, he said, the Council viewed a 10 percent estate-tax surcharge as an alternative to further increases in the personal income tax.
''If they haven't moved out of New York City because of the taxes yet,'' he said, ''this wasn't going to push them over the edge.'' But at 20 percent, the figure incorporated in the Mayor's proposal, Mr. Shaw said that ''it's approaching the point where it might actually cause people to move.''
State Tax Commissioner James W. Wetzler expresses reservations because, he said, the surcharge might just about double the effective estate-tax rate in New York City. The state tax on a $10 million estate would ordinarily be $1,456,500, he said. A Federal credit would reduce that, to $373,700. A 20 percent city surcharge could cost the estate an additional $291,300.
How many people would be directly affected by a surcharge? A market-research company estimates that the city is home to tens of thousands of millionaires, and 2,500 people said they made $1 million or more in 1987 alone. In Manhattan, where most of them live and die, 247 estates valued at $1 million or more were filed for probate last year.
Two prior impositions of what has been called the nation's only municipal estate tax were short lived. A 40 percent surcharge in 1934 on estates of more than $10,000 expired after one year. A 50 percent surcharge in 1975 was repealed before it was to begin.
Both times, one rationale for the surcharge was to make the tax burden seem more equitable. But some experts expressed concern about its potential consequences. The tax surcharge on estates was abandoned because officials feared that by further troubling New York's wealthier households, the city might inherit the wind.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1456 words

HEADLINE: The 2d Man at the Helm of New Jersey's Taut Ship of State

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 15

 BODY:
If Jim Florio is the imperial Governor of New Jersey, then Douglas Berman, his 37-year-old State Treasurer, is both his keeper of the vault and the chief of the palace guard.
And as the campaign manager who directed the relentless assault last fall on Mr. Florio's opponent, Representative Jim Courter, Mr. Berman has also been his chief executioner, say Trenton politicians wary of his influence with the Governor.
Mr. Berman's ascendance in Trenton has been accompanied by growing complaints over the Florio administration's efforts to limit debate and access to government.
As Governor Florio has tightened his grip on the reins of government, restricting legislators' access to commissioners, reducing outside advice on the budget and funneling most news releases through his office, Mr. Berman has become the chief architect of the state's fiscal plan and virtually the sole purveyor of information about it.
 
'A Very Important Office'
''He's made Treasurer a very important office,'' said Assemblyman Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, the Republican Assembly leader. ''What are the most important things in government today? Money and spending.'' 
But that importance is compounded by Governor Florio's mandating that all questions on the budget go through the Governor's office, and designating Mr. Berman as the only person who will answer questions before the Legislature.
''If he's the only one who's answering,'' Mr. Haytaian observed, ''he's an important figure of government.''
Some complaints about the Florio administration's tight grip have been visible. On Thursday, Republican legislators gagged themselves with red bandannas to protest new rules imposed by the Democratic majority in the Assembly limiting debates to two hours.
Republicans - as well as some Democrats in private - were already chafing under the administration's decision to present only Mr. Berman at budget hearings.
 
Advisory Council Abolished
Another example of the administration's closed nature was Mr. Florio's refusal, upon taking office, to reappoint the New Jersey Economic Council. For more than two decades, under several administrations, the unpaid group of economic advisers had provided analysis and advice on fiscal and economic matters.
He even refused to meet with the council. ''We had been soliciting meetings for some time,'' said Dr. Joseph Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers who was chairman of the group. ''We had no success.''
''Our value was in our nonpartisan nature,'' Dr. Seneca added. ''That is useful and valuable.''
School officials are also complaining that they are being kept in the dark about the sweeping financial changes that public-school districts are undergoing as a result of the State Supreme Court's decision requiring New Jersey to equalize spending among rich and poor districts.
This week, for example, the Teaneck Board of Education adopted a resolution accusing the Govenor of using ''undemocratic'' tactics to further his school financing proposals. It charged that the administration had ''made no reasonable attempt whatsoever'' to share school aid figures - developed by Mr. Berman's department -''eliminating any credibility in the numbers'' used to support the restructuring.
 
Conscious Control of Information
Mr. Berman readily acknowledges that there was a conscious decision to enlarge the role of the Treasurer and a concurrent one to create a closely held information structure, similar to that of private industry.
''Budgets and flows of money determine outcomes,'' he said, referring both to political considerations and governmental policy. ''And being able to have tight control over that process is very important to the Governor.''
Mr. Florio, in pursuing his policies, has made Mr. Berman his chief political stategist, his primary liaison with the Legislature on money matters and his chief numbers cruncher.
And because of the way Mr. Florio is trying to transform politics and government in New Jersey, the responsibilities tie together seamlessly. And so in just five months in office, Mr. Berman has turned the relatively obscure office of Treasurer into what friends and enemies alike say is the second most important post in the state.
 
A Transformation of Government
''Jim Florio is trying to transform things in politics and government, and he needs Berman to help him do it,'' said a Democratic political figure with longtime ties to the Governor and who has had dealings with Mr. Berman. ''He's absolutely the second most powerful guy in the state.''
Mr. Berman has credentials as a political strategist. He was a deputy campaign manager for Senator Bill Bradley more than 10 years ago, left politics for a decade and returned as Mr. Florio's campaign manager in 1988. He is a corporate lawyer with a strong academic background - cum laude at Yale in 1974 and a law degree from Columbia in 1979.
He oversees the agency that collects taxes, creates the budgets and spends the money, and he has close to 7,000 employees to help him do it.
At the moment the budget, which is being slashed nearly everywhere, is the biggest issue in New Jersey. Mr. Berman advises the Governor on who will have to pay more in taxes - the rich, the poor or the middle class - and who will get the benefits - cities, suburbs, bankers or workers. And he is the man who arranges the numbers to get the desired effect.
 
Stifling of Debate Charged
At budget hearings in April, he was the only member of the administration allowed to testify, and Republicans accused Governor Florio of using Mr. Berman to ''stifle debate'' and ''gag department heads.''
''Governor Florio has turned the budget process into a puppet show in which he controls the strings,'' charged State Senator John H. Ewing, a Republican of Somerset County.
Mr. Berman said he was chosen to speak for the entire administration ''because I was the person making most of the decisions with the Governor.''
But is there not a pattern of tighter control of information, and even a reduced flow of it?
''There is a pattern, and there is a change,'' Mr. Berman replied.
The voters, he said, elected Mr. Florio ''to be the leader'' and ''to be responsible for the policies of state.''
That means in large measure that the bureaucracy should speak with a consistent voice, Mr. Berman said. ''We should not have three points of view,'' he said. ''The administration should have one point of view.''
 
'Sensitive to Everything'
As to complaints of inadequate dissemination of information by his office, he said that there was ''a lot of demand on computer time'' and that new figures being developed and revised almost daily could not be routinely distributed to all who might want or need them.
He also noted that ''The Governor has held a press conference almost every day.''
Assemblyman Haytaian complains that the tendency of the Florio administration to control information is part of a general strategy to avoid criticism.
''This administation takes everything very personally,'' Mr. Haytayian said in an interview. ''Forget about bad things being said - I don't think they want anybody to even question anything they do. You might as well go to Eastern Europe two or three years ago.''
''People say Doug Berman is arrogant,'' he said. ''But this administration is sensitive to everything.''
Even Mr. Berman's ostensible friends sometimes sound like enemies.
 
A Wariness About Berman
Asked what he had to say that was good about Mr. Berman, Mr. Florio's communications director, Jon Shure, responded, ''What makes you think I have anything good to say about him?''
Mr. Berman's own assistant, asked to name two people who had positive feelings about his boss, said, ''I can only think of one - and I'm not sure about him.''
And Governor Florio, serving himself a piece of cake at a joint ''birthday party'' for everyone in the press corps in the Capitol the other day, observed: ''Doing a piece about Doug Berman? Nasty piece? That should be easy. Lot of material there, lot of material.''
Very few people seem prepared to say just why they don't like Mr. Berman.
''He's so much smarter than most of the people around him,'' said a Democratic political figure who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''He just overwhelms people around him. He wears people down.''
He is also aggressively blunt in an atmosphere in which comity is at least superficially the standard of social commerce.
''Doug just acts out,'' the Democrat said. He recalled that before the election, Mr. Berman had met with other leading Democrats and had told an important legislator that the legislator had been ''Tom Kean's lap dog.''
''He just can't help himself,'' the Democrat said.
