LENGTH: 1259 words

HEADLINE: After the Cold War, the Land of the Rising Threat

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Even as the cold war fades into history, American authors and publishers are discovering a new enemy: Japan. In a deluge of recent books and books to be published soon, the country that was once depicted as the land of geishas and cherry blossoms is increasingly being portrayed as the land of a rising threat to the United States, not only as a fierce economic competitor, but also as a potential military foe.
Several months ago, for example, ''The End of the American Century,'' a nonfiction book by Steven Schlossstein (Congdon & Weed), argued that a newly militarized Japan might use its power against the United States.
Next spring, St. Martin's Press plans to publish ''The Second U.S.-Japanese War'' by George Friedman and Meredith LeBard. Professor Friedman, who teaches political science at Dickinson College, in Carlisle, Pa., said the book would contend that ''there is a good chance of a major U.S.-Japanese conflict within the next 20 years, including the possibility of an armed conflict.'' 
Howard Kaminsky, the chief executive officer of the Hearst Trade Book Group, which includes William Morrow & Company, said, ''We haven't bought any of the Japan-bashing books yet, but we've seen proposals for a lot of them.''
 
'A Rush to Fill the Vacuum'
Other publishers said that they had also seen many proposals for books critical of Japan, and that they had signed several of them, much to the distress of some scholars.
''These books that bash Japan reflect a rush to fill the vacuum created by the winding down of the cold war,'' said Ronald Takaki, a professor of ethnic studies at the University of California at Berkeley. ''The economic conflict between the two countries is being described in the language of World War II.''
Professor Takaki, the author of ''Strangers From a Different Shore: A History of Asian-Americans'' (Little, Brown), said some of the books reflected a racial panic among the authors. ''They see an erosion of America's manufacturing base,'' he said, ''and they realize that within the lifetime of our children they'll be living in an America where whites won't be a majority.''
What is distinctive about the books is not just their proliferation, but also their harsh depiction of Japanese values, ethics and ambitions. They differ substantially from many earlier books - including ''Japan As Number One'' (Harper/Colophon) by Ezra F. Vogel, a Harvard sociologist - that attributed Japanese success largely to an astute Government, to management techniques and to social discipline.
The publishing broadsides against Japan coincide with public opinion polls showing that Americans are reporting increasingly negative feelings about Japan. A New York Times/CBS News Poll released in February reported that 25 percent of Americans interviewed said their feelings about Japan were ''generally unfriendly,'' compared with 19 percent who said the same last June and 8 percent in 1985.
Publishers, however, deny that they are ganging up on Japan, or that racism accounts for the spate of books critical of Japan. Books, they say, often reflect a society's expressed or tacit concerns, and Americans, as the polls clearly show, are worried about Japan.
 
Of a Perceived Decline
This winter, Simon & Schuster expects to publish a book that is critical of America: ''The Japan That Can Say No'' by Shintaro Ishihara. The author, a Japanese legislator and former Government official, maintains that Japan holds the technological balance of power in the world and should therefore no longer be deferential to the United States. In the author's view, Japan is on the rise and the United States is declining.
It is possible, of course, that the Ishihara book could increase American fears and suspicions about Japan, helping to create an even bigger market in the United States for anti-Japanese books.
But most of the dozen or more books to be published in this country about Japan are already unmistakably unflattering. Two scheduled for publication in the fall are sharply critical of Japanese lobbbying activities in this country. ''Agents of Influence,'' by Pat Choate (Alfred A. Knopf), charges that Japan is spending $350 million a year to try to sway American public opinion in favor of Japanese interests, and is even indirectly financing American political parties.
''The Japanese Power Game'' by William J. Holstein (Charles Scribner's Sons) asserts that Japanese lobbying, already powerful, is likely to grow stronger.
''The House of Nomura: The Inside Story of the Legendary Japanese Financial Dynasty,'' by Albert J. Alletzhauser, recently published by Arcade Publishing/Little, Brown, offers a less than admiring look at the Nomura Securities Company in Tokyo, the world's largest brokerage firm.
The company's global power, the author says, was made through connections with Japanese gangsters and politicians. In late April, after the book was published in London, Nomura filed a libel suit against the author and publisher and sought an injunction halting distribution of the book. But the book continues to sell in Britain, where it had reached No. 1 on the best-seller list of The Times of London.
 
Into the Fictional Realm
Novelists, too, are beginning to label Japan as the enemy: No. 5 on the hard-cover fiction best-seller list of The New York Times this week is ''Dragon,'' by Clive Cussler (Simon & Schuster), which is about a conspiracy to force the West to accept Japan's world leadership. And this fall, E. P. Dutton plans to publish ''Avenue of the Stars,'' by Jina Bacarr and Ellis A. Cohen, a novel about a ruthless Japanese billionaire who tries to take over the last private movie studio in Hollywood.
Both novels are a far cry from ''Shogun,'' James Clavell's generally admiring novel about 17th-century Japan and the Japanese character, which was published in 1975.
Other books have been highly critical of Japan, of course. Two years ago, Daniel Burstein published ''Yen! Japan's New Financial Empire and Its Threat to America'' (Simon & Schuster). And last year, Knopf published an indictment of the Japanese social and political system, ''The Enigma of Japanese Power'' by Karel van Wolferen, a Dutch journalist who has lived in Japan almost 25 years.
In his introduction to the paperback edition, published this month by Vintage Books, the author writes that his ''pessimism concerning the ability of the Japanese poltiical system to cope with the external world has only grown since the book first appeared,'' and he notes that ''the number of foreigners who question Japanese motives is growing.''
 
A Country's Defense Budget
Assertions that the Japanese pose a military threat to the United States and to the West are not new; similar assertions were made as long ago as 1972, in ''Black Star Over Japan: Rising Forces of Militarism'' by Albert Axelbank (Hill & Wang), and as recently as 1985, in ''The Militarists: The Rise of Japanese Militarism Since WW II'' by Edwin P. Hoyt (Donald Fine).
But authors who make similar claims today can point to Japan's growing military sector.
''Japan now has the third largest defense budget in the world,'' Professor Friedman said. ''While part of that has to do with the inflation of the yen, and even though defense is 1 percent of their G.N.P., it's still enormous. It's not so much a rise in militarism, but a rise in arrogance, a sense that now they'll show the world what they can do. The question is what they will do when they are thwarted, if we cut off their supply of oil, for instance.''

The Economy
Tax officials are auditing more foreign banks that do business in the United States after finding that many paid little or no income tax in the mid-1980's. Audits of 10 foreign banks last year produced more than $100 million in additional tax revenue. [Page A1.] 
New television services allow viewers to become more involved in what they watch. One experiment lets them choose among several camera angles for football games or concerts. Other services allow audiences to take part in game shows and surveys. [A1.]
The Pentagon's plan to end the M-1 tank program shows how budget cuts will ripple through the economy and hurt thousands of subcontractors in all 50 states. General Dynamics, which assembles the tanks, said 15 percent of 120 M-1 subcontractors would have to close a plant if the tank production ends. [D1.]
Credit market analysts say the bond market's heady rally has probably stalled for time being. Over the next few weeks interest rates may tend to rise somewhat, even though fundamental factors point to sluggish economic growth. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Las Vegas Is a Winner for Casino Owners

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
As Donald J. Trump wrangled with his banks last week, Circus Circus Enterprises Inc., one of the most profitable gambling companies in Las Vegas, was able to raise $100 million in new debt with barely a yawn from the credit markets.
The ease with which Circus Circus was able to borrow money was an indication that investors and lenders continue to view the casino industry as generally well managed and financially stable, Mr. Trump's troubles notwithstanding. ''The Trump situation was a non-issue,'' said Glenn Schaeffer, the chief financial officer of Circus Circus.
And Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Golden Nugget Inc., observed: ''For Circus Circus, for Caesars, for us, for some of the others, it's been a very stable business over a very long period.'' 
The industry is not without troubles, particularly in Atlantic City, where many casinos are struggling amid overbuilding and a weak economy in the Northeastern and Middle Atlantic states that supply most of the New Jersey city's visitors. Mr. Trump's new Taj Mahal casino is doing well, but partly at the expense of other casinos in the city, including his two other properties, Trump's Castle, which missed $73 million in debt payments on Friday, and the Trump Plaza.
Excluding the Taj Mahal, the total Atlantic City gambling win - the difference between the amount wagered and the amount paid to bettors - declined 9 percent in April from April of last year, to $221.6 million.
Perhaps more distressing for Atlantic City's future, the gambling industry there has not been able to transform itself into a resort destination that attracts not just busloads of day-trippers with cups full of quarters for the slot machines, but vacationers who stay for three days or a week and are willing to spend money off the casino floor.
Las Vegas, by contrast, is booming. The city is in the third year of a casino-building craze, with virtually every gambling company in town adding to or refurbishing existing hotel-casinos or constructing lavish new ones: Circus Circus will open its $290 million, 4,000-room Excalibur casino on Tuesday; Caesars Palace is undergoing a major renovation, and Golden Nugget's $620 million Mirage casino, opened late last year, has so far been a smashing success. Moreover, every major casino is drawing more business.
''There's a very big difference between Nevada and Atlantic City,'' said Michael Mueller, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''In the case of Las Vegas, the opening of the Mirage has had the effect of increasing the size of the total market. In Atlantic City, what's happened is that you had another large new entrant, the Taj Mahal, and everyone else is down.''
Much of Las Vegas's continuing growth comes from the progress it has made in recasting itself as a resort town fit for families and vacationers for whom sitting in the sun and watching a few shows may be more appealing than the card tables. MGM Grand Inc. is even building a theme park in the biggest bet yet that Las Vegas can shed its sin-city image.
''It's a very strong industry over the long run,'' said Harold Vogel, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. ''I'm not going to say a recession won't hurt them, because it will. But the stocks have already been discounted to a degree by the East Coast recession. Most of these companies will do well, especially if their operations are concentrated in Nevada.''
Most analysts say Circus Circus is currently the strongest of the casino companies, in part because the company has not entered the Atlantic City market, choosing instead to concentrate in Nevada. The company has also stuck closely to its strategy of appealing to mass-market vacationers interested in low-cost rooms and food, lots of slot machines and some inexpensive entertainment. Excalibur is an attempt to grab that market with a huge, castle-like casino and a Renaissance-era atmosphere, complete with regularly scheduled jousting for those who tire of pulling slot machine handles.
Most analysts are also recommending the stocks of both Golden Nugget and the Hilton Hotels Corporation, neither of which currently operates casinos in Atlantic City. Analysts are less bullish on Caesars World, the Bally Corporation and the Aztar Corporation, formerly Ramada Inc., all of which operate casinos in Atlantic City as well as Nevada.
Sunbathing, Wayne Newton and gimmicks like the Mirage's fire-belching man-made volcano may attract more visitors, but it is the casino operations that are still the industry's financial engine. Caesars World, Golden Nugget, Mr. Trump's Taj Mahal and the Hilton still rely heavily on the high rollers they fly in from around the country and the world.
But for most casinos, the action now is in slot machines, which only a few years ago were virtually an afterthought for the industry. As gambling has become a mass market activity, in New Jersey as well as Nevada, the slot machine has become the game of choice, partly because it is less intimidating to inexperienced gamblers than table games and partly because the stakes are lower.
In 1978, 35 percent of the dollar volume of legal gambling in Nevada went through slot machines. Last year, the figure was more than 60 percent.
''Slot machines have become the dominant game in the industry,'' said Mr. Schaeffer of Circus Circus. ''It's not the inveterate gambler that drives the business any more, it's the tourist.''
Because they pay off to bettors at pre-set rates, slot machines provide additional stability to casino finances. Still, casinos are not totally immune to bad luck. Caesars World reported a drop in profits for its quarter ended last Jan. 31, largely because it won less money than it expected at its Nevada casinos. Analysts attributed the performance to some big losses the casinos suffered in baccarat, the game of choice for most high rollers.
But for the most part, the law of averages works decidedly in the favor of casino companies: In the long run, gamblers will lose much more money than they will win. As long as casinos can keep operating expenses and debt levels under control, analysts said, gambling companies, their shareholders and their lenders can count on a growth in profits paralleling a growth in the number of people willing to put their chips in play.

HEADLINE: U.S. Moves To Shore Up Texas Bailout

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 17

 BODY:
The Resolution Trust Corporation transferred $2.1 billion in deposits late Friday to the Federally owned Sunbelt Savings F.S.B. in Dallas from two insolvent savings institutions. The unusual deal is intended to resolve two expensive situations for the Government.
The goals of the arrangement are to attract bidders for Sunbelt's costly operations and to avoid paying off depositors of the other two institutions. The move will cost taxpayers $1.7 billion. 
Federal officials were unable to attract acceptable bids for the Bexar Savings Association and the Gill Savings Association, both based in San Antonio, said Steve Katsanos, a spokesman for the Resolution Trust agency.
 
High Interest Rates
A loss estimate of $1.2 billion for Gill Savings makes it one of the most costly rescues recorded by the Government in the savings industry crisis. The loss for Bexar was put at $483 million.
Sunbelt executives and officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed the transaction, Mr. Katsanos said. The F.D.I.C., which insures deposits up to $100,000, controls Sunbelt.
Unlike other insolvent Texas savings institutions under Federal control that were transferred to private owners, Sunbelt has been a continuing drain on the Treasury. The institution has $9 billion in assets, but only $3.6 billion in core deposits, and the difference must be financed by attracting billions in additional deposits by offering high interest rates. The high operating costs were a factor in discouraging potential bidders, Mr. Katsanos said.
Bexar Savings and Gill Savings, which collapsed after a few years of fast deals and rapid growth, were known for soliciting deposits by offering high interest rates to savers far beyond the San Antonio region. Yet Mr. Katsanos said the addition of their deposits to Sunbelt would strengthen Sunbelt's core deposits. It will also give Sunbelt a branch network in San Antonio, he said.
Sunbelt was knit together by regulators two years ago from eight collapsed savings associations at a cost that Government officials then estimated hen at $5.5 billion over 10 years. It includes three former high-flying Dallas-area institutions - Sunbelt Savings Association, Western Federal Savings and Independent-American Savings - and is now the second-largest savings institution in Texas, as ranked by assets, after the First Gibraltar Savings Association, which itself was formed from five troubled Texas institutions.
 
Criminal Charges
The former top executives of the defunct Sunbelt, Western Federal and Independent-American have either been charged with fraud or are the subjects of criminal investigations. These executives, who had many business links between 1982 and 1985 when the institutions grew rapidly, also are defendants in civil complaints that seek hundreds of millions of dollars in damages.
The Government estimated the defunct Sunbelt's losses at $1.9 billion and assets at $4.1 billion when it was seized in 1988. Losses at Western Federal were estimated at $1.4 billion, while Independent-American's losses were put at $873 million.
The new Sunbelt's headquarters and most of its branches are in Dallas. It also operates in Houston.

HEADLINE: Suppliers Brace for Arms Cuts

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
If the Pentagon follows its plan to shut the M-1 tank program in a budget-cutting move, the impact will not end with the General Dynamics Corporation, the big weapons maker that assembles the tank at factories in Ohio and Michigan.
It would also be a big setback for the tiny Lakewood Manufacturing Company in Westlake, Ohio, which makes fenders and other metal parts for the tank, and for Cadillac Gauge Textron Inc. in Warren, Mich., which makes the aiming system for the tank's gun.
Scores of other companies would also lose large amounts of business, in some cases enough to endanger their survival. In a recent survey of 120 of its M-1 subcontractors, General Dynamics found that 15 percent would have to close a plant if production of the tank program was ended.
 
A Ripple Effect
The M-1 program is just one example of how the coming Pentagon budget cuts would ripple through thousands of subcontractors in all 50 states. Such smaller companies heavily dependent on military contracts are particularly vulnerable to the upheaval and accelerated consolidation that awaits the military-supply industry as it enters the post-cold war era. 
Lakewood, for example, derives more than 50 percent of its $6.5 million in annual sales from subcontracting work for General Dynamics on the M-1 and employs half its 95 employees on the program. Its executives are already preparing for the changes ahead.
''We're aggressively trying to diversify into commercial markets, and we think we'll be able to replace some of the M-1 work, but we'll be hurt,'' said Richard C. Peplin Jr., the company's owner. ''Some people will be laid off, and the company will go backward to some extent.''
While the ranks of subcontractors include large corporations like Texas Instruments Inc. and the General Electric Company, most lack the size, the name recognition and the political influence of prime contractors like General Dynamics. But the business of supplying nuts and bolts, wing sections, radar equipment, microchips and other components is an immense enterprise that cuts across regional economies and industry lines.
On most arms programs, roughly half the budget ultimately flows to subcontractors. Last year, for example, when the Pentagon awarded $120 billion of prime contracts, more than $56 billion was farmed out to subcontractors, many of which rely on yet another tier of suppliers for the parts they need. 5 Percent Cuts Ahead Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is lobbying Congress to limit cuts in the Pentagon's $300 billion budget to about 2 percent a year through 1997. But Congress seems certain to insist upon deeper cuts, probably in the range of 5 percent a year after accounting for inflation.
Cuts of that magnitude would reduce the size of the United States military force by as much as 25 percent. They would also mean canceling, delaying or scaling back most big weapons programs. In addition to the M-1 tank program, Mr. Cheney has already recommended cuts in other high-profile systems like the B-2 Stealth bomber being built by the Northrop Corporation and thousands of subcontractors.
The weapons industry is not the only one in which subcontractors are put at risk when the business cycle turns down, as suppliers to the automobile industry have long known. But analysts and industry executives think the current political atmosphere will mean a permanent reduction in the size of the military contracting industry.
 
A Decade of Pressure
The last decade has left many military subcontractors battered by foreign competition and squeezed by new Government rules that lowered the allowable profit margin on contracts and raised the costs of dealing with the Pentagon bureaucracy, which stepped up its oversight and demanded more paperwork. A half-dozen Government and private studies now conclude that further weakening could imperil national security.
''If present trends persist, the once-mighty arsenal of democracy could become little more than an electronic laboratory, perhaps even incapable of manufacturing the materiel required for deterrence or for protecting U.S. national interests around the globe,'' said a report issued last year by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.
 
A Faster Exodus
The center estimated that the number of companies doing military contracting work decreased to fewer than 40,000 in 1987, from 138,000 in 1982. Government officials and private analysts say budget cuts will only speed that exodus. ''There is no question that we have already lost a significant number of subcontractors and suppliers,'' said Senator Jeff Bingaman, the New Mexico Democrat who is chairman of a subcommittee on the military contracting industry, ''and budget cuts are one additional element that will adversely affect them.''
Michael Quinn, the director of marketing and program operations at Cadillac Gauge Textron, a division of Textron Inc., said that if the M-1 program ended, the company would probably have to lay off at least half of its 65 skilled engineers and hundreds of production workers.
''The state of the art would stop advancing and our ability to remain competitive internationally would erode,'' Mr. Quinn said. ''More important, when there's a new generation of technology, we'll be starting over with amateurs. If suddenly the Russians weren't withdrawing or some other threat appeared, it would be at least four years until we could support a tank production effort.''
The same types of issues are already facing other subcontractors across the country. Texas Instruments said earlier this month that it would eliminate 1,000 of the 22,000 jobs in its military systems division, reflecting declining demand for its military electronics products, which are used in scores of weapons systems. The P.V. Tool Company in Westbury, L.I., a precision-tool maker that gets 80 percent of its business from the nearby Grumman Corporation, has seen annual revenues fall by almost 40 percent as Grumman programs like the F-14 Navy fighter plane and the A-6 attack plane are scaled back or canceled.
 
Paring Back Suppliers
Even where programs have not been canceled, the prospect of budget cuts is squeezing subcontractors, as prime contractors pare back the number of suppliers they deal with, seeking to give their business to those who consistently deliver the best price and the best quality.
''The aerospace industry is cutting back its supplier base, and it's doing it by selecting those suppliers that are improving their operations,'' said Ted Tiaga, the owner of Golden Eagle Manufacturing, a metal-working company in San Dimas, Calif., which makes parts for missiles and torpedoes.
The prime contractors, seeking to keep their own plants and personnel busy, are also starting to do some work themselves that they formerly would have subcontracted. ''When the defense budget is growing, it's easier to farm the work out,'' said William B. Burnett, a vice president at the consulting firm Charles River Associates. ''When the budget is shrinking, the primes are more likely to keep the work in-house.''
 
Competition Intensifies
The battle to get business from prime contractors has become increasingly intense. In some cases, suppliers are cutting their prices significantly, seeking to win enough business just to keep operating.
Lamsco West Inc. in Santa Clarita, Calif., recently bid for some additional work making portions of the outer skin of the B-2 Stealth bomber, offering to do the work at its cost. The company lost out to another subcontractor that was willing to do the work for even less.
''Some of these small shops almost have to take business at less than cost in order to at least meet their overhead expenses,'' said Gladden Baldwin, the general manager of Lamsco West.
 
More Nonmilitary Work
Many subcontractors are looking for more nonmilitary work. Golden Eagle Manufacturing, which relies on military business for 95 percent of its revenues, wants half its business to be commercial, Mr. Tiaga said. It has already had some success making parts for the water-purification industry and for medical instruments.
But most commercial markets are already highly competitive, and many subcontractors admit they are likely to have only limited success with diversification. Moreover, for many companies, nonmilitary business is not a realistic option.
''Everything we do is designed for the life-and-death defense situation,'' said Mr. Quinn of Cadillac Gauge. ''If we were to build a commercial product it would probably be overpriced by five or six times.''

''We think we'll be able to replace some of the M-1 work, but we'll be hurt,'' said Richard C. Peplin Jr., the company's owner. (Barney Taxel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Rally Is Expected to Stall

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market analysts say that for the time being the bond market's heady rally has probably stalled. Indeed, over the next few weeks interest rates may tend to rise somewhat, even though underlying fundamental factors point strongly to sluggish economic growth and a moderating inflation rate.
A heavy flow of new issues from the Treasury will supersede what remains a very positive fundamental outlook, the analysts said.
''In the three weeks from late June through the second week of July, the market will face auctions of two-year, four-year and seven-year notes, more of the Refcorp bonds, 52-week bills and regular weekly bill auctions,'' analysts at MMS International noted in a bond market commentary late last week. The bonds issued to finance the activities of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is overseeing the bailout of the savings and loan industry, are known as Refcorp bonds. 
Concern about the coming supply may have contributed to Friday's selloff, which pushed yields on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 up to 8.41 percent from a four-month low of 8.37 percent on Thursday.
Focus on the new issues is likely to intensify this week, since there are no important economic reports scheduled.
''With no major economic indicators, supply will be a bit of a worry and cause a backup in market rates,'' said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities.
 
No Action From Fed
Adding to the market's concerns is an increasingly widespread realization that the Federal Reserve, despite continued public prodding from high-ranking members of the Bush Administration, is not about to ease monetary policy.
An easing move might win some political points, but at this juncture economists said any step by the Fed would not do much to help the economy.
''I don't see anything on the horizon that could cause the economy to pick up,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, an independent economic consultant in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
''At best, we will be stuck in a range of 1 percent to 2 percent growth for the rest of the year. My own bias would be for the Fed to ease a little bit more, but in this environment I don't think it would change things very much,'' he said. ''A half-a-point drop in rates is not going to prod companies to borrow more, or prompt construction companies to build faster.''
Based on household debt figures, a decline in interest rates would probably not do much to revitalize consumer spending. Retail sales, a big chunk of overall consumer expenditures, fell for the third straight month in May, and seem unlikely to revive soon.
John Lonski, senior economist at Moody's Investors Service Inc., said that since the 1982 recession household debt has risen at an annual compound growth rate of 11.3 percent. Over the same period, personal income growth has risen by just 7.5 percent each year.
 
Household Debt Rises
As a result, household debt has soared from nearly 61 percent of personal income to a record 77 percent, Mr. Lonski said. The last cyclical peak in household debt was in 1979, when it accounted for 64.4 percent of personal income.
''The gap between debt and income growth simply cannot persist,'' Mr. Lonski said. ''Unfortunately, the process of realigning household debt growth with personal income may again help usher in a recession,'' he added, as it did in 1980 and again in 1982.
Worries about the dangers of leverage and its impact on an organization's ability to remain profitable are also cropping up in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
For much of 1989, the major concern among would-be buyers of corporate bonds was the risk associated with takeovers.
Those risks led to a sharp rise in so-called ''event-risk'' covenants that provided protection to bondholders should the issuer be subject to a hostile takeover.
With the sharp decline in the ''junk bond'' market and heightened focus by regulators on bank lending for highly leveraged transactions, those sorts of concerns have all but evaporated.
''Over the last several months interest in event-risk covenants is down very substantially,'' said Solomon B. Samson, a managing director and chairman of the rating committee for the corporate finance department at the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Indeed, through the first five and a half months of 1990 a total of 23 issues had takeover related event-risk covenants, according to the Securities Data Company Inc. By comparison, in the last six months of 1989, 108 issues included such language.
 
Covenants Redefined
''Event-risk'' covenants are not dead, but, in a reflection of the times, they have been redefined.
Over the last few months investment banks, led by Bear, Stearns & Company, have introduced so-called credit sensitive notes, securities with an adjustable coupon that is based on the issuer's credit rating.
For the most part, companies interested in using such securities carry ratings lower than A. In the event of a ratings upgrade, the coupon on the securities would be reduced. A ratings downgrade, by contrast, would lead to an increase in the coupon.
A number of recent issues, including a $1 billion offering backed by the Chrysler Corporation in late April, a $600 million offering from the Georgia-Pacific Corporation on June 6 and a $300 million offering from the Chrysler Financial Corporation, a Chrysler subsidiary, have had such features.
In the case of Chrysler Financial, the notes it sold last week through underwriters at the First Boston Corporation carry a one-time ''put'' for investors that can be exercised if Moody's Investors Service, which currently has Chrysler under review, lowers its ratings on the auto maker. Moody's said it would decide by the end of the month whether it would change Chrysler's ratings.
S.&P. last week downgraded its credit ratings for the Ford Motor Company and Chrysler.
''There are still issuers who need event-risk language,'' said one investment banker, who asked not to be identified. ''But increasingly they are issuers who have business risk. Chrysler is one example. No one is going to take them over, but they are in a business which is going through some tough times. At this juncture, would-be bondholders are concerned about issues like that.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
KOHL SEES BALLOT BY TWO GERMANYS BEFORE END OF '90

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, June 18

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that a December date for the first all-German elections in more than 50 years was ''coming near to being very, very likely.''
Mr. Kohl's comment, in a television interview, was his most assertive to date on the possibility that German unity could become a reality by the end of the year.
The Chancellor has pressed for several weeks to expand the West German parliamentary elections scheduled for Dec. 2 into an all-German vote, which he originally planned for next year.
 
Much Remains Undone
The election could amount to political reunification, since the West German Constitution envisions direct accession by former German states into the Federal Republic. But the number of internal and foreign arrangements that remain make December a difficult deadline. 
Internally, East Germany must still reconstitute the five former states abolished by the Communists in 1953, and the two Germanys must still reconcile their legal systems, property laws and the differences developed over four decades. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany has called for a second treaty between the Governments to cover those issues before unification.
The Germanys must also reach agreement with the four victorious World War II Allies - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France - in the ''two plus four'' talks on German unity.
 
November Accord Sought
The talks are being held to end the four powers' occupation rights in Germany and to devise new security arrangements for Central Europe. The two Germanys have said that whatever the legalities of the situation, they do not want to proceed with unification without four-power approval.
Bonn hopes to reach an agreement in time to present it to the 35 nations of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe for endorsement by November, but negotiations with Moscow over compensation for the loss of East Germany as an ally have been difficult.
Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany held his eighth round of talks in two months today with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, and they will meet again on Friday at a foreign ministers' session of the two-plus-four talks in Berlin.
Mr. Kohl, however, declared at a conference of his Christian Democratic party in Bonn earlier today that 1990 would be ''the year of German unity.''
His party set Oct. 1 as the formal date to merge with the Christian Democrats in East Germany, who are led by Mr. de Maiziere. The Social Democrats and the small Free Democrats have also set dates next fall to merge with their East German counterparts.
Mr. Kohl's prediction that all-German elections can be held in December draws on several developments in the Germanys that give a sense of momentum.
 
Vote Expected This Week
The Parliaments of both Germanys are to vote this week on the treaty, signed last month, uniting their currencies and economies as of July 1. The move is the first big step toward merging the two countries.
The legislatures are also scheduled to pass matching resolutions on Tuesday renouncing any designs on German territories ceded to Poland after World War II, a measure that will clear one of the foreign obstacles to unity.
The most formidable obstacle, however, is the Soviet Union's concern over its economic and military security once East Germany is out of its sphere.
As before, Mr. Genscher and Mr. Shevardnadze gave little indication of the substance of their talks, but the frequency and intensity of the meetings suggest that they are working hard to fashion a compromise, possibly in time for the next session of the two-plus-four talks on Friday.
The most immediate reason for Mr. Kohl's optimism was apparently the debate he witnessed on Sunday in the East German Parliament on an unexpected motion to proceed immediately to unification. The motion was diverted to a committee by a large majority, but the debate revealed a readiness in East Germany and in the West to move up actual unification.
 
Optimism and Caution
Mr. Kohl said his visit to East Berlin left him ''with the firm impression that the wish exists there to vote with the Federal Republic.''
Mr. de Maiziere has been more cautious than Mr. Kohl on the possibility of unity in December. He noted yesterday that East Germany must still reconstitute the former states, which were abolished by the Communists in 1952, and to prepare a second treaty on the conditions of unification.
Mr. Genscher and Mr. Shevardnadze met for six hours in the town hall of Munster in keeping with their effort to hold their talks in cities with symbolic significance for their endeavor. The Munster town hall is where the peace accord ending the Thirty Years' War was signed in 1648. Last week, the two ministers met in Brest, where the Germans first invaded the Soviet Union in 1941.
The negotiations between the Germans and the Soviets have become the focal point of the two-plus-four talks, in which the participants are working to lift the last vestiges of military occupation and to resolve the place of a united Germany in the European security structure.
Mr. Shevardnadze said the meeting was constructive and useful, but added: ''I don't want to create the impression that everything proceeded smoothly, that all outstanding issues were resolved. Some thorny problems remain.''
The Germans are rumored to be preparing a major package of financial aid, trade and security guarantees to gain Soviet support for unification.
Mr. Genscher intimated that one of the items under discussion was a form of agreement between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, possibly a non-aggression treaty.
''It is important that we try in this area for a new definition of the relations of the members of the two alliances toward each other,'' he said. ''That might happen in a joint declaration. That might happen in a treaty-like agreement.''
Moscow has objected to letting a united Germany belong exclusively to the North Atlantic alliance, and the West has rejected a Soviet counterproposal to have Germany belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

(Associated Press) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Probation Overload;
Glutted Probation System Puts Communities in Peril

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
Local and Federal probation systems, overwhelmed by the increase in drug-related crimes, are changing in ways that experts say are making communities less safe.
Probation departments have become seriously understaffed just as they are being relied on more heavily than at any point in their history; probation, rather than prison, is by far the most prevalent form of punishment.
Probation officers have become less and less involved in their traditional counseling and supervison roles, more akin to social work, and are more consumed with law enforcement, tracking down those who have violated the terms of their freedom. #1,000 Criminals to an Officer In New York last year, almost 38 percent of the criminals who had been given probation were sent to prison for violating rules, mostly for new crimes. Five years ago, 26 percent of the probationers were sent to prison for violations. 
In interviews, judges, prosecutors, probation officers, legal experts and probationers said the combination of these circumstances had become a serious community problem, particularly in neighborhoods with high concentrations of drug offenders.
''There is not a probation department in the nation that is adequately staffed to handle the needs of the new high-risk offenders,'' said Cecil Steppe, chief probation officer for San Diego County. This year caseloads in his department are running as high as 700 probationers for each officer, up from last year's high of 400.
Most experienced supervisors say it is not unreasonable to ask an officer to keep track of 30 probationers, but they add that the system begins to become unsafe when the ratio nears 100 to 1. Yet in Los Angeles, which has the nation's biggest probation department, a single officer is expected to handle as many as 1,000 criminals.
''When people say that probation is the alternative to prison, right now they have got it backwards,'' said Mr. Steppe.
 
More and Worse Felons
More than two-thirds of the nation's convicted criminals are now under the supervision of Federal and local probation departments. With drug-linked crimes clogging the judicial system from courtrooms to prison cells, judges are increasingly handing out sentences of years on probation. When a prison sentence does precedes probation, it is often for only a few weeks or months.
Probation systems are handling more felons and hard-core criminals than at any time in history. Although records showing the proportions of various categories of criminals were not kept until recent years, officials said that in the past, very few hard-core criminals were ever given probation. Today, sentences of probation only are sometimes meted out even for brutal offenses like rape and child molestation.
Even as probation departments face increased demands, they are receiving fewer and fewer resources. Their budgets are declining in relation to other segments of the court system. In New York City in 1985, for example, the budget for the Department of Corrections was $302.5 million, and for the Probation Department $30.3 million. Last year, the budget for corrections was $616.9 million, a 103 percent increase; the probation budget had risen just 49 percent, or $45.1 million.
Probation is a period of time under court supervision but not behind bars, imposed by a judge. Parole, by contrast, is granted by a board to a criminal who has served part of a prison sentence. Probationers and parolees are supervised by different departments. The intention of both is to encourage legal behavior by granting freedom to those who are seen as good risks.
Many judges, prosecutors and probation officials say that probation has become the weakest link in the judicial chain and that the public now perceives it as just another word for coddling criminals. Yet the only real alternative, they say, is to spend untold billions of dollars to expand prisons.
 
At the Roots
Tougher Sentences? 'It's a Myth'
In 1988, the latest year for which figures are available, 2.3 million people were on probation, an increase of 5 percent over the year before, according to the Federal Bureau of Justice Statistics. About one million were in prison and jails, up 4.3 percent from the previous year. Studies by the Rand Corporation indicate that in the last decade, the population of prisons had increased by 45 percent while the number of those on probation jumped by 75 percent.
The probationers are mostly male, unemployed and in their 20's, and many are illiterate. Their most common offense by far is possessing or selling drugs.
Mr. Steppe and other experts estimate that 70 to 75 percent of the probationers are addicted to drugs or alcohol, yet only a fraction are receiving treatment.
 
Community Safety at Risk
Probation is ''now the dominant place to put drug traffickers and people convicted of drug possession,'' said Mark A. Cuniff, executive director of the National Association of Criminal Justice Planners, a respected Washington organization of administrators and researchers. He added, ''It's a myth that judges are getting tougher and putting more people away.''
Los Angeles County has the largest probation department in the nation, supervising 85,000 people. Barry J. Nidorf, chief probation officer there, said that about 10,000 of the probationers, or 11 percent, are on drug testing and treatment programs. But he said at least 60 percent and perhaps as many as 80 percent of the 85,000 actually need such care because of their addictions.
''If you equate undetected drug use with crimes to support habits, as I do, then it means that community safety is at risk,'' Mr. Nidorf said.
 
Officers Walk Into Crimes
He said about half of the Los Angeles probation population is under the supervision of two-member teams that each handle 2,000 probationers. The ratio is considerably lower for the most dangerous offenders, Mr. Nidorf added, but it is still inadequate. Budget cuts that have been proposed could raise to 85 percent the share of the probationers supervised at the 1,000-to-1 ratio, Mr. Nidorf said.
Probation officers report that they are increasingly walking into the middle of criminal acts in the course of their duties. Counselors making house calls in most cities routinely enter dangerous neighborhoods and crack dens. New York probation officers chasing a probationer recently saw him drop a kilogram of crack.
 
At the Federal Level
Supervision Suffers As Jobs Multiply
In the Federal probation system, not only are caseloads higher and the probationers more dangerous, but nearly a dozen laws enacted in the last eight years have also broadened the role of officers, who are now required to perform many functions beyond merely supervising criminals.
A report last year by the Federal courts' Administrative Office concluded, ''The probation system cannot adequately fulfill with existing resources all the responsibilities that the Congress has imposed upon it by statute.'' and it cited ''increasing security risks to the community.''
Matters have become worse since the report was issued, said Judge Edward R. Becker of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia. Judge Becker is the chairman of the Committee on Criminal Law and Probation Administration of the Judicial Conference, the policymaking body of the Federal judiciary.
''It is one of the most significant problems that the judiciary faces,'' Judge Becker said in an interview. ''The probation system has been neglected for too long.''
One of the Federal system's most time consuming and newly redefined tasks, investigating convicts and preparing detailed reports for judges before sentencing, often takes priority over supervision of criminals.
''When the system gets overloaded with investigative work, supervision on the street suffers,'' said Donald L. Chamlee, chief of the Probation Division of the United States Courts in Washington. He added that probation officers had conducted more than 148,000 investigations in the last year.
 
At the Local Level
Morale Plummets As Caseloads Rise
As a consequence of exploding work loads, increased danger and a squeeze on resources, probation departments across the nation are reporting low morale and high turnover.
''We don't have enough money and we don't have enough experience and we just can't do the job with what they give us,'' said Dominic Colluccio, an 18-year veteran of the New York probation department who is now the union president for the probation officers. ''No one is here long enough to know what they are doing.''
With starting salaries for probation officers of from $23,480 to $26,327, and eventual advancement of $2,300 possible in 10 years, probation officers in New York have little incentive to stay in the jobs. Nor do they elsewhere.
A 1990 study for the Justice Department by the National Association of Criminal Justice Planners found that the average salary for probation officers is $21,800, and the average for the highest grade of officer is $33,500.
Moreover, the jobs are clearly more demanding than they used to be. Mr. Colluccio said that 15 years ago, more than two-thirds of the probation population in New York consisted of people convicted of misdemeanors and three-quarters of those who violated probation would be sent to jail.
Now, 73 percent are felony offenders and fewer than two-thirds of those who violate their probation rules are ordered to serve jail time.
 
At the Street Level
Deceit and Danger In the Bronx
Emblematic of the morale problems facing probation offices everywhere are the experiences of a corps of special officers in the Bronx.
One unit of 12 officers who specialize in drug-addicted criminals share a single cramped room in which they interview and counsel more than 800 probationers.
''Counseling is a joke in the sense that you have 5 to 10 minutes with each person and you have to fill out forms to the extent that there is never enough time to follow through,'' said Officer Carlos Ramirez.
On a recent day, three officers from another special unit, whose members make home counseling visits, talked with Shon S., a 17-year-old about to marry his girlfriend. He could not spell the name of his 13-month-old stepdaughter. Shon S. had been convicted of threatening a child with a pellet gun and demanding money. He was using two to three vials of crack a day last fall when the crime occurred, and when he was placed on probation, he was ordered to attend one of the few treatment programs available.
 
Sniffles? Allergies, He Says
Thin and boyish, Shon S. told the officers that his sniffles were from allergies. Since his sentencing, he admitted, he had stopped attending treatment. That is a probation violation, but the officers did not order him back into court, primarily because he had not been violent.
A third special unit spends its time tracking down probationers who are suspected of commiting more crimes. These officers venture into neighborhoods where crack is widely used and prowl through the urine stench of ominous apartment buildings. The officers catch about 20 violators a week.
The vast majority of those who are caught are released again by the end of the day. With the jails so overcrowded, if they have not committed a major crime, the mere fact that they did not abide by the conditions of probation is no longer good enough reason to hold them.
''Catching them is like throwing dirt in the wind,'' said Miguel Ibarra, who heads the squad and like the others carries a guns and wears a bulletproof vest. ''You finally get 2 and then there are 15 more folders waiting on your desk.''
 
At the Policy Level
Prosecutions Grow, But Not Budgets
Despite the conditions in probation departments, lawmakers and Federal and state officials say it is more politically attractive to seek resources for prosecutors, judges and prisons than to seem soft on crime by proposing more support for probation.
Indeed, President Bush's national drug control strategy includes ambitious goals for prosecutions, prisons and judges, but makes no mention of probation.
At the local level, too, the inability of probation departments to attract resources is causing frustration.
''There is a gap between what we're perceived as doing and what we actually do,'' said Catherine M. Abate, the commissioner of the New York City Probation Department, the nation's second largest.
''People perceive us as soft even as we fill a dual role of law enforcement and counseling,'' she said. ''What is not recognized by the public is that society does not have the resources to continue to build more prisons for the growing number of people it is prosecuting.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Rinfret's Record: New Scrutiny for Candidate

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET with KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Ever since party leaders seeking a gubernatorial nominee plucked his name from the address book of a New York Republican loyalist, Pierre A. Rinfret has portrayed himself as a renowned economist who has advised four Presidents and breezily turned down offers to join the Cabinet.
But for two decades, Mr. Rinfret has also fought criticism that he is equal parts showman and sage, and an examination of his record shows that some claims he has made about his political and educational experience are indeed exaggerated.
 
Echo of a Debate
Some former Nixon Administration officials disputed Mr. Rinfret's suggestions that he had been a major adviser to the President, and none remembered him being offered Cabinet positions.
And while he never earned a doctorate, the economic forecaster has long claimed the title ''Dr. Rinfret,'' using it in resumes, legal documents and 10 times in his political biography.
These discrepancies echo a debate about Mr. Rinfret's qualifications and character that began almost from the moment he joined the small fraternity of economists whose projections and opinions make news. 
 
A Theatrical Style
Mr. Rinfret's positions on the issues facing the state are little-known, and he says he has not yet had time to develop many. But his background is sure to come under greater scrutiny now that he has taken his first shot at elected office, as standard-bearer in the New York Republican Party's bid to unseat Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The portrait of Mr. Rinfret that emerges from interviews with his associates in business and politics is that of a tough-talking economist trusted by leading corporations, a theatrical speaker who may give the Governor a run for his oratorical money and a multimillionaire businessman with a knack for marketing and a style so bruising he has taken relatives and friends to court.
But some of Mr. Rinfret's fellow economists say his salesmanship and flair for self-promotion outshine his professional skills.
''A criticism that would most frequently be made is that he is very colorful, but he is a little more sound and fury than substance,'' said Paul W. McCracken, a chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Nixon Administration.
John P. Sears, a former campaign manager for President Ronald Reagan, described Mr. Rinfret as a ''good salesman.'' But he added, ''He's not looked upon in his field as someone who is an in-depth, researched thinker, but rather as someone who can take a quick look at something and give you an opinion.''
Milton Friedman, the economist, who, like Mr. Rinfret, advised President Richard M. Nixon, recalled Mr. Rinfret as ''kind of a wild man. He tended to go to extremes with whatever his views were.''
Mr. Rinfret - who is generally described as a supply sider who is skeptical of regulatory agencies - insists that any criticism stems from his outspokenness in a profession noted for its smugness and domination by what he has called ''the little gray men.'' His ability to deal with the state's growing budget problems, he says, stems from his business background, including his success in building an international consulting and commodities firm.
''I really believe the state is in trouble,'' Mr. Rinfret said. Describing his race against Mr. Cuomo, he said, ''Cuomo is Teflon, fine. Watch me take the Teflon off him.''
'Robert Allen, a Texas businessman, said he remains a fan of Mr. Rinfret's even though the candidate once took him to court for failing to pay a bill. ''He's aggressive and he asserts his will. He's a very persuasive, expansive guy.''
''He has much more of an acting quality than most economists,'' said Kenneth Lipper, a former New York City Deputy Mayor who has watched Mr. Rinfret at speaking engagments. ''He's a witty, unholy speaker. He can't win, but if he doesn't get too weird, he can do damage to Cuomo.''
 
As an Economist
A Blunt Mixture Of News and Views
During the 1950's and early 1960's, Mr. Rinfret learned the trade of economic consulting with Lionel D. Edie, a pioneer in the business.
Mr. Rinfret was hired by Mr. Edie in 1951 as a $5,750-a-year junior economist. He said Mr. Edie, president of the company, took him on as a protege and became like a father to him.
In July 1963, shortly before Mr. Edie died, Mr. Rinfret took over as chairman of the business. Mr. Rinfret left Edie & Company in 1966 to form his own consulting business, Rinfret-Boston Associates. Mr. Edie had died and Mr. Rinfret said he had a falling out with other principals in the company.
Most of the stock in Mr. Rinfret's new business was owned by The Boston Company, a holding company. Mr. Rinfret eventually bought control of the whole company and began operating it as Rinfret, Inc., which has grown into a group of consulting and financial-futures trading firms with offices in New York and Switzerland. Mr. Rinfret is its president.
Although Mr. Rinfret had earned a reputation in the industry, he did not become widely known until 1964, when President Lyndon B. Johnson, seeking to promote the economic benefits of a tax cut, cited one of his forecasts in a televised speech.
Like most economic forecasters, Mr. Rinfret's success rate has been mixed.
In 1961, he correctly forecast an economic downturn. In the 1970's, just before the nation's economy went into recession, he predicted that there would not be one.
More recently, in early 1988, Mr. Rinfet incorrectly predicted that a recession was imminent. But he says that in October of that year, just before the stock market collapsed, he warned his clients of trouble on Wall Street.
Mr. Rinfret, who lives in a Park Avenue apartment that he said may be worth as much as $12 million, works out of cluttered offices on Lexington Avenue. There he trades in what he calls ''economic intelligence'' - a mix of census data, government reports and the remarks of political leaders in newspaper articles or interviews conducted by him or one of his two dozen employees. He analyzes the information, prints it in a newsletter and sells it to major corporations at a price he will only say is ''expensive.''
Back in the 1960's, it was reported that some of his corporate clients were paying as much as $50,000 a year for his newsletter and special research requests.
''We try to meld politics, finance, economics, history and sociology into a comprehensible whole,'' said Mr. Rinfret, who sits on the board of five major corporations - Revlon Inc., the Revlon Group, Brunswick Corporation, Bally Manufacturing Corporation and Abitibi-Price Inc., of Canada.
He also makes use of his political connections. In one recent issue of ''Rinfret. Intelligence on the world,'' the economist said his analysis of the Federal deficit was based on ''a point about Federal revenues'' passed on to him by Martin Anderson, an economic adviser to President Ronald Reagan. In another, he said he knew about the Johnson Administration's budget policies because ''I was there.''
The language in Mr. Rinfret's newsletter is often blunt. ''The American people don't give a damn about the Federal deficit,'' the newsletter reported in May.
In a business that relies on contacts and reputation, Mr. Rinfret's name is important to him. Last year he filed a lawsuit charging that his nephew, Paul Rinfret, had no right to start a trading firm with ''Rinfret'' in the title. The suit, one of two against family members, is pending in Federal court in Manhattan.
 
Personal Background
When Is a Degree A Doctorate?
Though he now favors antique rifles and expensive sailboats, Mr. Rinfret said he grew up poor, one of six children. A native of Montreal who moved to New York City at age 4 1/2, he said he lived in Hell's Kitchen and that his father was a struggling salesman who had trouble making the rent.
Mr. Rinfret said he showed an early knack for science, and worked his way through school.
Despite his passion for biology, Mr. Rinfret said he did not enter the field because there was not enough money in it.''You know what a biologist made in 1945 or 1946?'' he said in an interview. ''If you got $15 a week you were lucky.''
He eventually received bachelor's and master's degrees in business from New York University after serving in an infantry division in World War II. He said he once took on a machine gun nest and singlehandedly captured 14 German soldiers. He received the Bronze Star and Purple Heart.
After the war, Mr. Rinfret won a Fulbright Fellowship and used it to study political economics at the University of Dijon. He left a year and a half later with a Diplome d'Etudes Superieures, which University officials say is the equivalent of an American master's degree.
Shortly after returning to the United States, Mr. Rinfret said, he contacted the French consulate in New York City and was told by an attache that he could refer to the degree as a doctorate of political economy. Indeed, Mr. Rinfret has often described himself in documents as holding a doctorate, including his in signed filing with the National Futures Association, which regulates commodities traders.
But last week, officials at the University of Dijon said Mr. Rinfret would have had to study at least four more years and complete a lengthy dissertation to win the French equivalent of a doctorate. And Axel Nesme, acting cultural attache at the French Consulate in New York, said ''it is a little bit erroneous for him to claim he has a doctorate.''
Mr. Rinfret said in an interview last Friday that he recognizes that ''there is an equivalency problem. You get different answers from different people. I do not deny that.''
But he said that even if the Dijon doctorate does not count, he can claim a doctorate because of the honorary degree he received in 1973 from Pepperdine, a private university in Malibu, Calif.
''I checked this with my counsel years and years ago,'' Mr. Rinfret said. ''I said, 'Does this give me the right to call myself doctor if I want to do that?'
 
And he said, 'Absolutely.' ''
Sherry Harris, senior editor of publications for the American Council on Education, said recipients of honorary degrees do not normally use them in their titles.
''The traditional rule is only an earned Ph.D. or a medical degree qualifies,'' she said. ''Some people do affect it. But it is an affectation.''
 
In Politics
'Mr. President, I'm Not Interested'
Since being nominated on May 30, Mr. Rinfret has described himself as a political insider who advised four Presidents - John F. Kennedy, Mr. Johnson, Mr. Nixon and Mr. Reagan.
In his acceptance speech at the State Republican Convention, Mr. Rinfret said he was ''offered the equivalent of three Cabinet posts'' by Mr. Nixon. He has subsequently said that the Nixon Administration also offered him the ambassadorship to India and the position of trade representative to the Soviet Union.
In an interview last week, Mr. Rinfret expanded on his ties to the Nixon Administration, saying Mr. Nixon personally offered him jobs as his Secretary of Commerce in 1972 and as a member of his Council of Economic Advisers in 1968. Additionally, he said, two aides to Mr. Nixon asked whether he would be interested in becoming Secretary of the Treasury in 1971.
Describing the offer to be Secretary of Commerce, Mr. Rinfret, an enthusiastic raconteur, recalled that he was standing near a podium, waiting to give a speech, when he was told that he had a phone call from the President.
''He said, 'Pierre, you know the Secretary of Commerce position is open. Might that interest you?' I said, 'Mr. President, what's the Secretary of Commerce do?' He said, 'I don't know.' I said, 'Mr. President, you don't know?' He said, 'Well, doesn't he add up the G.N.P. or something like that?' I said, 'Mr. President, I'm not interested in adding up the G.N.P.' ''
Mr. Rinfret said Mr. Nixon then asked if he would be interested in being ambassador to India. ''I said, 'Mrs. Rinfret doesn't like Indian food,' '' he recalled, smiling at the tale.
Mr. Nixon did not respond to several telephone messages left at his office. But several top aides in his Administration, including John D. Ehrlichman, the chief domestic policy adviser; Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally; Peter M. Flanigan, a presidential assistant; and two chairmen of his Council of Economic Advisers, Mr. McCracken and Herbert Stein, said they did not know that Mr. Rinfret had been seriously considered for any Cabinet positions.
 
A 'Passing' Enthusiasm
In his memoirs, Mr. Ehrlichman said Mr. Rinfret was ''only a passing and very controversial enthusiasm'' for Secretary of the Treasury job in 1971, which eventually went to Mr. Connally.
Several Nixon aides said Mr. Rinfret did occasionally have the ear of the President. But one top Nixon adviser, who asked not to be identified, said Mr. Nixon and his advisers consulted Mr. Rinfret ''to placate him,'' because Mr. Rinfret was prone to criticizing the Administration publicly.
''I think the concern was that he would go make speeches to forums and make predictions about the economy and the world,'' said the Nixon aide. ''Nixon was concerned about him becoming an active enemy.''
But William Safire, a columnist for The New York Times and a former Nixon aide, said he recalls that Mr. Rinfret was indeed offered a job on the Council of Economic Advisers after Mr. Nixon's election in 1968. And, by Mr. Safire's account, Mr. Nixon valued Mr. Rinfret's economic advice.
Describing his ties to the Reagan Administration, Mr. Rinfret said that Mr. Anderson, then a top campaign aide, asked him in 1979 to become the chief domestic policy adviser to Mr. Reagan. A 'Roaring Fight'? By Mr. Rinfret's account, the offer was extended after he and Mr. Reagan had a ''roaring fight'' over tax policy in a meeting that he said was set up by Mr. Sears, the campaign manager, and attended by Mr. Anderson.
Both Mr. Anderson and Mr. Sears said Mr. Rinfret was never offered such a formal campaign role, and Mr. Anderson said he recalls the meeting between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Rinfret as ''a normal spirited discussion.''
Mr. Rinfret said he had never considered running for office until a week before the State Republican Convention, when the party was still desperately seeking a standard bearer. It was then that State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Republican leader of Manhattan, asked Laurence C. Leeds, an investment banker and Republican district leader, to scan his personal telephone book in search of names.
''When I was going through my address book and got to the R's, I said, 'Roy, we've got it,' '' Mr. Leeds said.
Mr. Goodman recalled: ''I said, 'My gosh. I just saw him last week and didn't think about him. But he might do it.' ''
''I called him,'' Mr. Goodman went on, ''and two and a half minutes later the fat was on the fire.''

HEADLINE: LATIN LEADERS GET NEW U.S. AID PLAN

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANTIGUA, Guatemala, June 18

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today gave the five Central American Presidents the bare outlines of a plan to marshal and coordinate international aid to this poverty-ravaged region.
Mr. Baker made his plan public at the end of a three-day regional summit meeting, the eighth in a four-year series. The meeting, coming as all Central American wars but El Salvador's have been stilled, was the first devoted to development and not to the fighting throughout the region.
''The bottom line, I think, is this: Central America is poised as never before to consolidate democracy, achieve lasting peace and disarmament and create conditions for growth and opportunity in which all of the people of this region, particularly the poor, can share,'' Mr. Baker said at the end of his nine-hour stay here. 
 
U.S. Policy Review
Mr. Baker's trip, arranged at the last minute, follows a review of Washington's Latin American policy, ordered by the White House. American officials have said the order reflects a desire by President Bush to become more involved in Latin America.
Under the American aid plan, the developed countries and international donors and institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund would cooperate to support political and economic changes throughout the region.
While privately voicing sharp criticism, the Presidents publicly welcomed Mr. Baker's proposal. ''We look at it with happy eyes, much pleasure and much hope,'' Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador said, speaking for the five Presidents.
President Rafael Calderon Jr. of Costa Rica, speaking in an interview before a private meeting with Mr. Baker, said: ''The U.S. is taking the lead to getting aid from the world for Central America. That's very important. We all celebrated it.''
The plan as described to the Presidents by Mr. Baker was vaguer than a draft circulated by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleberger at a recent Organization of American States meeting in Caracas, Venezuela, and appeared to differ substantially from it.
Under the proposal, modeled after a plan to channel aid to the developing democracies of Eastern Europe, the United States would be the group's secretary. The United States, Japan and the European Community, possibly joined by Venezuela, would serve as co-chairmen of the group.
 
Old Resentments Aggravated
In the only public criticism of the plan by one of the Presidents, Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala said Central America should run the show. ''The executive secretary should be a Central American,'' he said after breakfast with Mr. Baker.
But President Cerezo, the host of the meeting and the senior Central American leader, said the Presidents had no time to raise the issue with Mr. Baker at their hourlong breakfast at the Ramada Inn. ''We're going to discuss it later,'' he said.
The idea of an American secretary for the aid group aggravated old resentments of the United States.
While the region's leaders may publicly praise the United States as ''the leader of the free world,'' they also privately blame it for worsening the sharp social inequities and civil wars that have plagued the area in the last decade and led to an economic crisis.
Some Presidents and their senior aides said they suspected that Mr. Baker's plan was little more than a thinly disguised effort to continue dictating developments while taking advantage of declining tensions to reduce sharply the American financial burden.
''It's not fair that those who finance a regional conflict should be the ones to enjoy the benefits of peace,'' said a Guatamalan development expert who attended the summit meeting in Antigua, 30 miles west of Guatemala City. ''The peace dividend shouldn't just go to the suppliers of weapons.''
Although many people in the region are living in worse conditions than a decade ago, United States aid to the region dropped this year to a total of $565 million from $702 million last year.
After the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua lost elections in February, Congress approved a special $300 million Nicaraguan aid package, raising this year's total bill to almost $900 million. At the same time, Congress allocated $300 million to Panama, which traditionally is considered a part of South America but which was an observer at the summit meeting, attended by the Presidents of Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Costa Rica and Nicaragua.
 
No Cut in Commitment
''Peace looks like it's coming to Central America and as Frank Sinatra used to say, 'I've done it my way,' '' said a development official, who described the Baker plan as an American effort to cut costs.
But the Presidents reported that Mr. Baker had repeatedly said his plan would not lead to any reduction in United States commitment to the region. The leaders said the Secretary told them that the money would ''complement'' rather than replace aid. In response to concerns that the United States would be secretary of the group, he assured them that the structure of the organization could be negotiated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, left, talking with President Rafael Calderon Jr. of Costa Rica yesterday at a Central American summit conference in Antigua, Guatemala. Mr. Baker presented the five Presidents at the session with a plan to coordinate international aid. At right was an interpreter. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Japan to Help Clean Mexican Air

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 18

 BODY:
Japan said today that it would provide $850 million in loans to Mexico to help battle air pollution there. It will be Tokyo's first expenditure from a $2 billion fund intended to help poorer countries deal with environmental problems.
The Government took the occasion of a visit from President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico to announce a series of loans. The loans are to be used to remove sulfur from heavy fuel oil and diesel fuel burned in Mexico; to produce lead-free gasoline, and to refurbish locomotives to improve the cargo-handling capacity of Mexico's rail system, reducing the number of trucks in Mexico City. 
 
Loans at Low Rates
Part of the money will come in the form of loans by the Export-Import Bank, which is trying to send some of Japan's huge trade surplus to poorer countries. The interest to be paid by heavily indebted Mexico will be far less than that paid on ordinary loans.
Japan's efforts are an attempt to resolve two international problems: resentment for amassing hundreds of billions of dollars in trade surpluses in recent years, and criticism that Japanese companies have pursued environmentally unsound practices, such as financing logging operations in some parts of South America and Southeast Asia that destroy rain forests.
 
Pledge Last December
The Government initially announced its intention to help improve the environment in poorer countries last summer at the economic summit meeting in Paris. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu visited Mexico last September, and pledged to make the first such loans to the Latin American country.
In a speech here today, President Salinas was frank about Mexico's problems, but he made a strong appeal for more Japanese investment. Mexico is discussing a free trade pact with the United States, similar to a pact the United States already has with Canada.
Given that such an agreement would open the Mexican and American markets to each other, President Salinas hinted that Japanese companies might find it attractive to use Mexico as a gateway to North America.

HEADLINE: Mandela Urges Canadians to Maintain Sanctions

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 18

 BODY:
Nelson R. Mandela appealed today to the Canadian Parliament to continue economic sanctions against South Africa.
''As an expression of humanity, and not as an act of charity, we ask you to walk the last mile with us,'' Mr. Mandela told a joint session of the House of Commons and Senate in Ottawa, which accorded him prolonged ovations before and after his address. It was a theme that the African National Congress leader is expected to repeat when he arrives in the United States on Wednesday. 
Introducing the 71-year-old anti-apartheid leader, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said that Canada, long a leader in the push for international isolation of South Africa, should not relax the trade and economic sanctions it imposed against the Pretoria Government's racial policies.
Some countries, notably Britain, have argued that sanctions should be eased to reward President F. W. de Klerk for his moves to dismantle apartheid and to encourage whites in South Africa to continue supporting racial liberalization.
Since taking office last year, Mr. de Klerk has freed Mr. Mandela, legalized his organization, the African National Congress, and moved to end segregation of hospitals, parks and other public facilities. But more fundamental issues, like residential and school segregation and the white-dominated political system, remain to be resolved.
''Apartheid in all its repugnance is still the law in South Africa,'' Mr. Mulroney said. ''At this critical juncture, the Government of Canada believes the way to advance the progress toward democracy is to maintain the sanctions.'' $4.3 Million for Repatriation He said tonight that his Government would also donate the equivalent of $4.3 million to a new fund for repatriating African National Congress supporters living in exile.
For Mr. Mandela, who was released from jail four months ago after serving 27 1/2 years for political offenses, the visit here has been an occasion to measure the esteem in which he is held around the world. He flew to Ottawa from London on Sunday aboard a Canadian Government executive jet dispatched by Mr. Mulroney. Together with his wife, Winnie, he was greeted at the Ottawa airport by the Prime Minister, other senior ministers and a scarlet-jacketed guard of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
After his speech to Parliament today he flew to Toronto, where tens of thousands people gathered in front of the provincial legislature to hear him. Mr. Mandela had canceled another appearance in Toronto earlier in the day, complaining of fatigue. But he showed no sign of tiredness as he spoke.
He is scheduled to visit Montreal on Tuesday. On Wednesday, he will continue his six-week foreign tour by flying to New York.
The highlight of his Canadian visit was the speech to Parliament, an honor usually granted only to visiting heads of state or government. He began his address by thanking the legislators for ''allowing us, who were outcasts only yesterday'' to speak in a place dedicated to the principle that people should govern themselves.
''The fact that we have not had the opportunity to do the same thing in our own country, even as guests, emphasizes the iniquity of apartheid,'' Mr. Mandela said. He praised Canada for its anti-apartheid role in the United Nations and in the Commonwealth, the group of nations that were formerly colonies of Britain.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nelson R. Mandela, left, after addressing the Canadian Parliament in Ottawa. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, right, said there should be no relaxation in the trade and econommic sanctions imposed by Canada against the South African Government to oppose its racial policies. (Agence France-Presse)
