HEADLINE: TRIAL FOR BARRY IS READY TO BEGIN

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
After five months of legal maneuvering, defense and prosecution lawyers finally chose a jury today to hear the Federal Government's drug case against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. The panel will be sworn in Tuesday, then hear opening statements.
The selection of the 12-person jury, with six alternates, took less than an hour in Courtroom 2 of United States District Court here. But it was a measure of the charged legal, political and racial nature of the Barry case that it took lawyers on both sides more than two weeks of preliminary questioning of more than 150 prospective jurors to reach that point. 
 
Panel Mostly Black and Female
For their efforts, they ended up with a panel of Mr. Barry's peers, including alternates, that is mostly black, middle-aged and female. As is usually the practice, those who are alternates will not be identified until final arguments have been heard.
Of the 18 prospective jurors, 15 are women, 13 are black and five are white. Among them are a hospital clerk, a hospital administrator, a clerk in the city Employment Department, an accountant in the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, a history teacher at a private school and an art gallery manager. Two are unemployed.
As soon as the final juror had been chosen, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ordered all 18 sequestered in a local hotel. He said more than a month ago that he did not want to risk any juror's being influenced by news reports or rumors during the trial, which he called ''highly charged.''
Mayor Barry, who faces 14 counts of using drugs and lying about it, has denied using illegal drugs but has been treated for addiction to prescription drugs and alcohol. He contends he is a victim of overzealous, vindictive prosecutors.
Last week he said that while he planned to go through with his trial and expected to be vindicated, he nevertheless would not seek re-election because both he and the city needed to ''heal'' as a result of his troubles.
His detractors say his announcement as a ploy to curry favor with jurors. The Mayor's chief defense lawyer is R. Kenneth Mundy. On the prosecution side will be Richard Roberts and Judith Retchin, assistants to the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, Jay B. Stephens, who is not expected to particiaate actively in the trial.
Mayor Barry is charged with 10 misdemeanor counts of possessing cocaine and 3 felony counts of lying to a grand jury about drug use. He also faces a single misdemeanor charge that he conspired on at least 20 different occasions with at least 10 different people to obtain and use drugs.
If convicted on all counts, he could be sentenced to 26 years in prison and fined $1,850,000.

HEADLINE: Wary Negotiators Nearing Crossroads in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
This may be the week something finally happens in the budget talks between Congress and the White House.
If it isn't, it ought to be, say lawmakers and officials of the Bush Administration who have spent the last month examining every possible permutation of the budget but have not agreed on even the size of the deficit, let alone how to cut it.
''Why are people in that room?'' asked Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip. ''Mostly because they couldn't get out of it. The President's men decided it was time to have a summit, Republicans are there because they like to be accommodating to the President, and Democrats are there because they couldn't say no.'' 
When the negotiators reconvene on Tuesday they will hear from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on how a 25 percent cut in ships, planes and troops would translate into savings in the military budget over the next five years. Mr. Cheney is expected to outline deeper cuts for the Army and Air Force than those services have suggested in their own budget plans, while making more modest cuts in the Navy.
 
Back to the Starting Point
Tuesday will also be the first time the negotiators broach the subject of taxes as part of their noncommittal review. An update by the Congressional Budget Office on the economy and projections for the 1991 deficit will complete the review, bringing the negotiators to precisely where they started a month ago: haggling about who will make the first offer so that real bargaining can begin.
''Like Yogi Berra said, when you reach the crossroads, take it,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee. ''The pressure is on both Republicans and Democrats from our colleagues to either get this thing moving or find a way to diplomatically get out of it. We're operating on a fuse that probably lasts until the July break.''
As far as Democrats are concerned, the first move is up to the Administration. What they expect is an Administration proposal showing the spending cuts and tax increases that would be needed to slash $45 billion to $60 billion from the deficit in the fiscal year 1991 and at least that much in each of the next five years.
''We are very wary invitees to this dance,'' said Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., a Georgia Democrat who is a member of the negotiating team. ''They are going to have to show us.''
Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the senior Republican on the House Budget Committee, said the maneuvering to get a deficit package would be trickier than that. ''I think the shaping of the plan is going to have to be without attribution,'' he said. ''People have talked about an immaculate conception, but I think this conception is going to be very untidy.''
Politics aside, the budget arithmetic is daunting. The estimate the negotiators are to receive this week from the Congressional Budget Office is expected to show a deficit of about $140 billion, requiring spending cuts and tax increases of up to $76 billion to reach the $64 billion deficit ceiling for 1991 imposed by the budget-balancing law.
None of those figures account for the cost of operating the Federal agency that administers the bailout of failed savings and loan institutions or removing the surplus in the Social Security Trust Fund from the calculation of the deficit, two thorny issues the negotiators will also have to settle.
If the deficit reduction numbers are staggering, the alternative could be worse. The budget-balancing law imposes automatic spending cuts, half in military programs and half in domestic programs, if lawmakers and the Administration cannot come to an agreement by October. Richard G. Darman, the Director of Management and Budget, is expected to outline the extent of such automatic cuts and how they would fall on individual programs when he presents the Administration's midyear economic forecast on July 15.
 
'Pain and Heartache' Predicted
Mr. Panetta calls that presentation ''the kickoff of the doomsday machine,'' but other negotiators say it may take a few months of living with the automatic cuts to force decisions on paring popular programs like Social Security and raising taxes.
''The pain and heartache that will go into those decisions is such that Congress will not do it until after the November election,'' said Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee.
Most of the other negotiators say a solution has to come sooner than that, and Mr. Cheney's review may prove at least a partial icebreaker. The Defense Secretary has already told the negotiators that the 25 percent cut in ships, troops and aircraft over five years will not reduce Pentagon spending in 1991 much beyond the $3 billion envisioned in the budget that the Administration presented in January. But the chairmen of the budget and armed services committees say the savings could be twice to three times that much.
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Comittee, has completed an analysis of the 25 percent reduction in ships, troops and planes. His analysis shows that substantial cuts in spending can be achieved over five years, depending on how the reductions are made.
Mr. Aspin said the most important factor in determining the amount of savings in the military budget was the pace of modernizing weapons.
Mr. Cheney's study is expected to apportion the 25 percent reduction unevenly among the armed services, with the Army and Air Force bearing a larger share of the cuts than the Navy. Administration officials say the study assumes that the number of Army divisions would be cut from 18 to about 12; that air wings, each consisting of 72 planes, would be cut from 36 to about 25, and that the Navy's 14 battle groups would be reduced to 12.
Even if the negotiators' view prevails, they will still be a long way from reaching the deficit reduction goal of $45 billion to $60 billion that Mr. Darman outlined at a recent budget session. Like the lawmakers who have participated in the talks, he said a major concern was selling a package to the rest of Congress.
''We're going through a necessary consultative process because if and when we do something, we have to be able to bring people along,'' he said. ''It's always been the case that we have the option of waiting for a crisis. The trouble with that is that it would be irresponsible.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who is to tell budget negotiators today how a 25 percent reduction in military spending would translate into savings. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Cuomo The Statesman

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
Mario Cuomo took a traditional step last week to show that he is ready for the White House: He made a speech on foreign policy. What he showed is that he has a long way to go before he can be taken seriously as a candidate for President.
The Governor spoke to a dinner of the United Jewish Appeal in New York. His subject was American policy toward Israel - President Bush's policy, which he pictured in extravagant terms as a threat to Israel's survival. 
At the recent summit meeting, Mr. Cuomo said, Presidents Bush and Gorbachev made little progress. But ''they did seem to agree on one thing: that the emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union to Israel might be contained or limited.''
How's that again? George Bush agreed with Mikhail Gorbachev on limiting Soviet Jewish emigration? He did not, and he would not. The charge was pure demagogic invention.
Mr. Gorbachev, the Governor went on, ''continues to play the same deadly game the Soviets have played for decades'' in the Middle East. He continues ''to build a web of diplomatic, economic, political, military and intelligence alliances with the most dangerous actors in the region, people who intend to damage and, ultimately, to destroy Israel.''
In fact, Mr. Gorbachev has been reducing Soviet activity and commitments in the Middle East as elsewhere. He rejected Syria's request for massive new weapons supplies. He told the P.L.O. to forget its military dreams and get on the path of peace with Israel. Why would Mario Cuomo want to ignore the facts in favor of a Red scare?
''Our Administration in Washington has sent strong signals indicating a lack of support for the Israeli Government,'' Mr. Cuomo said.
The Administration has been critical of Prime Minister Shamir and his new Likud-based Government for its reluctant attitude toward negotiations. But Governor Cuomo made his charge far broader. He said the Bush Administration was mortally threatening Israel.
''This is not about Likud or Labor or personalities,'' he said. ''It is about Israel herself. It is about Israel's survival. . . .
''The weak support for Likud policies is in fact weak support for the underlying policies that Israeli Governments have evolved over a period of time, going back essentially to the 1967 war.''
Is it possible that Mr. Cuomo sees no difference in Prime Minister Shamir's policies? For 40 years Israel held itself open to negotiate with any Arab partner. Mr. Shamir has turned away from that path, putting up one objection after another to even talking with Palestinians.
The new Shamir Government is pledged to build more Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. It includes extremist parties that want to expel the 800,000 Palestinian residents from the West Bank.
Prime Minister Shamir was ''correct,'' the Governor said, in refusing to give any assurance that Soviet immigrants would not be settled in the occupied territories. Every U.S. Government since 1967 has opposed such settlements. Does Mr. Cuomo want to retreat from that policy? From the American commitment to United Nations Resolution 242, which calls for Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories in return for peace and secure borders?
Mr. Cuomo condemned the ''peace process'' supported by President Bush. He said ''it depends on assurances of peace from people still committed to the destruction of Israel.'' In fact, the Bush policy was devoted to getting talks going between Israel and a Palestinian delegation that Israel itself would have to approve. It was an attempt to carry out Mr. Shamir's own plan for talks - which Mr. Shamir then killed.
In this country it is normal, and fair, for a politician to identify with the dreams of different ethnic groups. To pander to extreme nationalist emotions is another matter. Jewish audiences are wise enough to know the difference.
Indeed, the leading American Jewish organizations do not agree with Mr. Cuomo. They are extremely anxious about the power of the far right and religious fundamentalists in the new Israeli Government. They oppose the policies of settlement and permanent occupation. They hope that somehow the peace process -the plan for negotiations - can be revived.
Governor Cuomo should beware of talking loosely on a subject of which he knows so little. Ranting like Ed Koch is not likely to play well in national politics, and it does not become Mario Cuomo.

HEADLINE: Florio Tax Plan Clears Hurdle in Assembly Vote

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 19

 BODY:
The state Assembly late last night passed Gov. Jim Florio's plan to double the income tax for New Jersey's most affluent taxpayers. The vote was the first hurdle in the new Governor's attempt to enact a host of bills that would raise taxes on the wealthy and provide aid to low- and modest-income residents and school districts.
Early today, the Assembly followed up an earlier Senate vote and approved the $12.4 billion budget for fiscal 1991, 11 days before the deadline set by the state Constitution. But to pay for that budget, which includes deep cuts in most state services except welfare and prisons, the Legislature must still pass a number of other new taxes. 
The Senate passed the budget by a 21-17 margin, the Assembly by 44-34.
 
Doubling Highest Bracket
The income-tax vote, 41-36, in the Democratic-controlled Assembly was on a bill that would raise the tax from 3.5 percent to 7 percent for families with incomes of more than $150,000 and single people with incomes of more than $75,000.
Although the bill must still be passed by the Senate, which the Democrats also control, last night's vote represented a major step for Mr. Florio in his agenda of changing - quickly and drastically - the way New Jersey raises and spends money. A group of about a half dozen North Jersey legislators had wavered over the prospect of higher taxes and a new school financing plan that they said would cost suburban areas like theirs heavily.
Under intense pressure from the admininistration, Assemblyman Thomas J. Duch of Garfield and Louis J. Gill of Passaic gave Mr. Florio the 41 votes necessary to pass the tax bill in the 80-member house. But other Democrats, Joseph A. Mecca of Clifton, Neil M. Cohen of Union and Cyril Yannarelli of Paterson, opposed the income tax rise.
The income-tax vote was also the first real test in a week of voting by the Legislature on nearly a dozen proposals crafted by Mr. Florio and his Democratic allies.
The new taxes to support the budget for fiscal 1991 - the fiscal year that begins July 1 - include an increase in the sales tax from 6 to 7 percent and a giant hike in taxes on cigarettes and other tobbacco products, new taxes on alcohol and new taxes on petroleum products.
The second package of legislation includes a new formula for school aid and a $1.2 billion increase in the income tax, and a reduction in property taxes through new rebates of up to $500 for homeowners and renters.
 
Narrowing the Gap
The object of the Florio reforms, the Governor has said, is to narrow the gap in school financing between rich and poor disticts, and to provide property tax relief for homeowners. The administration has said that the state has depended too long on property taxes, which help affluent areas and hinder those with low property values.
The school aid formula and the income tax had been a particular focus of anxiety among Democrats running for re-election next year, particularly the Bergen County legislators, who said their districts had been treated unfairly under the original Florio proposals. The speaker of the Assembly, Joseph Doria, as well as Douglas C. Berman, the state Treasurer and a top Florio strategist, and Steven Perskie, the Governor's chief of staff, spent most of yesterday in private discussions with reluctant legislators.
''We were confident that the legislative leadership was in control of this process,'' Mr. Berman said. ''The results bear us out.''
 
Two-Hour Debate
During more than two hours of debate before the income-tax vote, Reublicans repeatedly attacked the Florio plan as a rebirth of ''tax and spend'' liberalism, at a time when New Jersey is slipping into a recession. The tax plan, they said, would discourage economic growth and force businesses and jobs into other states.
''New Jersey's prosperity is not paved with higher taxes,'' said Assemblyman Robert Franks, a New Providence Republican. ''It's absolutely unfair, inexplicably so.''
The next major test of the Florio program, legislative leaders here said, will be a vote on the school formula by both houses.
Mr. Doria and top administration aides said they hoped to pass the budget, tax and school aid bills by the end of the week.
While legislators met behind closed doors, the Statehouse was surrounded by demonstrators from the New Jersey Education Association, the state's teachers union, which opposes Mr. Florio's plan to shift the payment of pensions from the state to school districts.
Demonstrators carried signs saying ''One term governor,'' and, playing off of the description of Mr. Florio by his critics as Robin Hood, ''Bergen County is not Sherwood Forest.''

HEADLINE: Real-Estate Board Urges Tax Breaks for Business

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
The Real Estate Board of New York proposed a major new tax-incentive program for businesses and developers yesterday, saying that the plan would keep and attract enough jobs and encourage enough investment to more than pay for itself.
In what seemed an expression of a commercial real-estate industry burdened by slackened demand and rising vacancy rates, the board issued nearly 20 recommendations. They included tax credits for businesses that sign long-term leases and create jobs, an expansion of tax breaks for renovations and the shifting of more of the property-tax burden to housing. 
The board, the major real-estate trade organization in the city, argued that its proposals would stimulate enough activity to be ''revenue-neutral.''
 
Given to Dinkins
''I don't think we have proposed outrageous abatements or concepts here,'' the president of the board, Steven Spinola, said at a news conference. ''I think the time is now to start discussing it, rather than wait another year, when we may be in worse shape than we are today.''
Mr. Spinola said the proposal was given to Mayor David N. Dinkins on Thursday. Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, said the administration considered the plan comprehensive and thoughtful and had begun to study it. She also said the administration had asked for a one-year extension of the Industrial and Commerical Incentive Program, which is to expire at the end of the year.
The incentive program phases in tax increases on new or renovated office buildings at different rates in different areas, except for the financial district and the East Side of midtown, which are excluded.
Earlier yesterday, State Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan, released his analysis of the program based on a study of 800 applications for incentives that he said would cost nearly $470 million over 10 years. About $250 million of that cost, Mr. Leichter said, went to projects that he asserted would have been built even without subsidies or that had failed to create jobs leading to better positions.
 
Thousands in Tax Credits
Mr. Leichter cited exemptions for luxury hotels, movie theaters and doctors' offices, among other projects, and said, ''Much of this is a gift by the taxpayers of the City of New York, because that development would occur even if there were no benefits whatsoever.''
Under the real-estate board proposal, businesses signing 10-year leases would receive a combined $2,000 state and city tax credit for each worker living in the city or a $1,000 state credit for each employee who is a state resident. In an acknowledgment of the city's fiscal troubles, the credit would be phased in after five years.
A business would receive a credit of $250 a year on the commercial-rent tax for each employee it hired who lives in the city. The rate of that tax would be gradually lowered.
The board called for the incentive program to be extended for four years and for exemptions for renovations in the excluded parts of Manhattan. The plan also proposed other ways to reduce the tax burden on renovations and commercial and loft buildings that are converted to housing.

LENGTH: 1559 words

HEADLINE: Advances Raise Hope For Crops That Grow In Salty Conditions

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AGRICULTURAL scientists say advances in identifying and developing plants that thrive in salt water and salty soils may help alleviate severe food shortages in developing countries.
In the last decade, scientists have domesticated wild plants known as halophytes, which thrive in salt water and are sources of food, fodder and fuel. They have worked to make conventional crops more salt-tolerant through crossbreeding and have developed hybrid species that can repair soils ruined by salinization and supplement food supplies for animals and people.
Farmers are beginning to increase food supplies by growing grasses in the sand dunes of the Nile, and food grains on the coastal dunes near Bhavnagar, India, lands once believed to be too soaked with salt to support crops.
 
Salt-Tolerant Tomatoes
Sweeter, tastier tomatoes and melons made more salt-tolerant through crossbreeding are being grown with drip irrigation in desert settlements in Egypt and Israel. In Pakistan, a hybrid grass called sordan is not only providing food for cattle but also improving soil ruined by poor farming practices so that it can once again grow conventional crops. 
Methods used in these areas can work in Africa and other parts of the third world, the scientists say.
While current research provides a basis of hope for combating food shortages, there are still many unanswered questions and problems in saline agriculture, including the high costs of many methods. Scientists are divided over which aspects of saline agriculture offer the most promise for increasing the food supply in poor nations.
Scientists like Dr. James W. O'Leary, director of the Environmental Laboratory at the University of Arizona in Tucson, say they believe that the most promise lies in the domestication of salt-tolerant plants.
Others, like Dov Pasternak, an agricultural scientist and professor at Ben Gurion University of the Negev in Israel, say that making conventional crops like tomatoes, cotton and melons more salt-tolerant will be more useful.
Researchers at the United States Salinity Laboratory in Riverside, Calif., are studying the genes and development of hybrid plants to create new salt-tolerant species.
Millions of acres of land worldwide are not used for crops because they are too salty or the available water is too salty for irrigation. These lands include coastal deserts where only seawater is available, former farmland with soil that has been ruined by poor irrigation practices and arid areas atop salt lakes or underground brackish water.
Scientists say there is an increasing need to develop saline agriculture as the world's population grow and available farmland decreases.
''There is today big pressure on the semi-arid and arid land of the world - population pressure,'' said Dr. Pasternak. But he added that those countries have saline water that can be used to feed people who are starving in those areas.
''I believe that the knowledge that we have developed can be used in all deserts of the world,'' he said, asserting that every desert has saline water that has not been used to grow crops.
Scientists say that salt has reduced productivity on about 49.4 million acres of the world's irrigated land, threatening the economies of arid countries like Egypt, Iraq and Pakistan, where irrigation is the foundation of agriculture.
A report published in April by the National Research Council listed hundreds of salt-tolerant plants, including grasses, shrubs and trees, that ''could contribute significantly to the developing world's supply of food, fiber, fuel and fodder.''
Dr. O'Leary said many of the plants discussed in the report, like several salt-tolerant grasses that can be used to feed cattle and whose seeds can be used to make bread, could make good crops and bring into use lands that now cannot be used for agriculture.
The report addresses a problem faced by more than a billion people in developing countries who rely on forests for fuelwood but are faced with rapid deforestation. It identifies salt-tolerant shrubs and trees like those belonging to the genus Prosopis or Eucalyptus, that can be grown on salty, marginal lands and can be used for cooking and heating.
Other plants identified in the report include several species of a halophyte called Acacia, found in Australia, which are rich in nutrients and higher in energy, protein and fat than wheat or rice. Aborigines have ground the dry, ripe seeds of these plants to make a coarse flour that can be used to bake bread on hot stones or in the ashes of a fire.
But scientists say several problems remain: the management of such crops requires advanced and carefully planned irrigation, and Dr. O'Leary said the cost of carrying out many crop management programs has not yet been addressed.
''I think a realistic projection would be 10 years for when you will see large-scale planting of halophytes, or in 10 years, halophyte research will be on the junk pile,'' Dr. O'Leary said.
''It's not going to be cheap,'' he said, referring to the high cost of labor and materials like pipes and pumps.
Dr. Pasternak recently abandoned research on halophytes because he has been more successful in increasing the salt tolerance of conventional crops like tomatoes, cotton and some melons and irrigating them with brackish water.
Calling halophytes the answer to the third world food crisis ''is too presumptuous,'' Dr. Pasternak said. ''It has not been proven yet. The only use for halophytes is for forage.'' Dr. Pasternak, using drip irrigation, works primarily with water containing 5,000 to 7,000 parts per million of salt. Seawater contains 35,000 to 38,000 parts per million.
Dr. O'Leary conceded Dr. Pasternak ''is probably right'' in focusing on conventional crops instead of halophytes. But he said it was ''highly unlikely that conventional plants will be adapted to high levels of salinity'' of 10,000 parts per million and above.
 
Drip Irrigation Method
Dr. Pasternak recently completed a project in Egypt where he introduced drip irrigation in sand dunes of the Nile to produce melons out of season. In drip irrigation, instead of periodically wetting an entire field, water is constantly dripped on the soil right around the roots of plants through a hose run along crop rows. This method greatly restricts the amount of water sprayed over an entire field, preventing salt buildup, but it insures that soil around the roots is almost always moist. Dr. Pasternak said the salinity produced tastier and sweeter fruit. Scientists at the United States Agricultural Research Service in Kimberly, Idaho, have worked successfully in Pakistan with a hybrid grass called sordan, which can be used as feed for cattle and can repair damaged land.
 
Repairing Damaged Soil
In Pakistan and other parts of the third world, a major main problem for farmers is the prevalence of lands called sodic. Unlike saline soils, sodic soils no longer have a high concentration of different types of salts of magnesium, sodium, calcium but contain only sodium that has been chemically adsorbed on the clay. This makes the clay too crusty to admit air and water easily, making it unsuitable for growth of crops.
Sordan grass, the result of breeding between a plant called sorghum and Sudan grass, can repair the damage in sodic soils and reclaim the land so that it can once again be used to grow conventional crops.
David L. Carter, director of soil and water management research at the Agricultural Research Service in Kimberly, Idaho, said that sordan ''is going to produce some good forage on these marginal soils and at the same time will reclaim some of these soils for crops for human consumption.''
What the plants do when grown on sodic soils is to release organic acids into the earth through their roots. The organic acids dissolve calcium carbonate, or lime, which is found in most arid lands.
The calcium that is released displaces the sodium left in the soil. The sodium goes into solution and joins with the carbon dioxide from the lime to form sodium bicarbonate. This compound is then washed away by water from rain or irrigation.
After growing sordan on sodic lands for about two years, farmers can often re-use the soil for conventional crops.
 
Crops for Salty and Damaged Soils and Water
 
Tecticornia
This salt-tolerant plant yields seeds that the Australian aborigines grind into a flour that can be used for bread. It grows in coastal mud flats above the normal tidal level.
 
Sordan grass
This grass repairs soil made crusty by sodium compounds. It releases acids that dissolve calcium carbonateto release calcium and carbon dioxide. Calcium displaces sodium in the soil. The sodium dissolves and joins with carbon dioxide to form sodium bicarbonate, which washes away.
 
Source: ''Saline Agriculture'' (National Academy Press); David Carter
 
Using Saline Water, Drop by Drop
In drip irrigation, tubes release controlled amounts of water, most of it into the soil just around the roots of plants. The method allows frequent irrigation to keep the soil almost constantly moist but reduces the total amount of water used. This is especially important when using saline water because it also reduces the amount of salt deposited in the field.
 
Sources: Dr. James W. O'Leary; Netafim Irrigation Inc.

HEADLINE: Dow Down 53.71 to End At 2,882.18

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Stock prices took their worst tumble in five months yesterday, with analysts attributing the fall to heavy computer program selling, a weak bond market and renewed worry over corporate profits and the interest-rate outlook.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 53.71 points, to 2,882.18, with 12 blue-chip issues in the 30-stock index showing losses of a point or more.
The 1.83 percent drop was the Dow's worst one-day loss since Jan. 22, when it fell 77.45 points, or 2.89 percent.
Three American financial exchanges announced plans yesterday for all-night trading of stocks and options, starting in 1992, putting them in potential conflict with a similar system announced last week by the New York Stock Exchange. [Page D2.] Volume at 133.47 Million The market slid steadily throughout the session in light volume, with no rally to take stocks to higher ground after Friday's record close at 2,935.89. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.03, to 356.88, and declining issues outstripped advancing ones, 1,230 to 353. 
Volume reached 133.47 million shares, compared with Friday's heavy trading of 205.13 million shares.
''I think the main reason for the drop was a lot of sell programs pushing the market down,'' said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. ''There was no fundamental news to trigger such a decline.''
He added that the decline in the bond market had a big impact on stocks, as did some of the economic numbers that were issued last week, causing anxious investors to take some profits after Friday's rally.
The economic reports, investors had hoped, would show a weak economy that would convince the Federal Reserve that it could trim short-term interest rates.
Last week's figures showed, Mr. Sohn said, that the economy is weak but the inflation rate is unacceptably high for the Fed, dashing any hopes that the central bank will ease credit in the next few months.
On Friday, the Government reported that consumer prices rose two-tenths of a percent in May; on Thursday, it said prices at the producer level rose three-tenths of a percent last month.
 
Focus on Earnings
''There's a tug-of-war between corporate profits and interest rates in the stock market,'' Mr. Sohn said. ''When corporate profits are not doing well that tends to pull the market down. But that has been more than offset by optimism regarding low interest rates. Now that it seems we're not likely to get low interest rates, the focus is back to profits.''
Earnings results for the second quarter will start to come out in early July, and investors who believed this market would finish out the quarter with a strong kick may be surprised, said Robert H. Stovall, head of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers Inc.
''A few more days like today, and it might not look so bad to be underinvested when the quarter closes,'' he said.
I.B.M. lost 1 5/8, to 118 3/4, in heavy volume, leading some technology stocks down.
Among other blue-chip losers, Procter & Gamble dropped 1 7/8, to 82 1/2; Philip Morris, 1 1/4, to 42 3/4; 3M, 1 1/4, to 86 3/8; Chevron, 1, to 71; Kodak, 1, to 41; General Motors, 1 1/8, to 49 1/8; International Paper, 1 1/8, to 53 1/4; General Electric, 1, to 69 1/8; Merck, 1 3/8, to 81 1/2; Boeing, 1 1/8, to 59, and United Technologies, 1 3/8, to 58 7/8.
Among technology stocks, Compaq Computer dropped 4 3/8, to 123 5/8. An Oppenheimer analyst, Edmund Spelman, dropped the issue from his recommended list, citing its recent price appreciation.
Southeastern Banking led the most-active list, down 1/2, to 10 1/2, after Moody's Investors Service downgraded its senior debt and commercial paper ratings, citing a weak Florida real estate market.
Wells Fargo lost 2 1/2, to 77, and another Western banking institution, HomeFed, fell 1 1/4, to 22 1/4. BankAmerica lost 1, to 29 7/8. Citicorp dropped 1/2, to 23, and Bank of New York fell 1 1/8, to 33 3/8.
Among financial issues, Federal Home Loan Mortgage lost 1 5/8, to 75 1/2, and Federal National Mortgage 1 1/2, to 40 1/8.
 
Chrysler Gains
Chrysler bucked the trend and finished up 3/8, to 15 1/2. Analysts said speculation about a possible alliance between Chrysler and Fiat had intensified.
Walt Disney, which gained last week on good reviews for the movie ''Dick Tracy,'' fell 4 5/8, to 127 1/8, after weekend box office results were lower than those of some other blockbuster film debuts.
Plum Creek Timber fell 2 5/8, to 25 1/4. An article in The Wall Street Journal about the company's forest-cutting policies described it as ''one of the Pacific Northwest's most controversial corporate citizens.''
Scott Paper was ahead 1, to 47, on a buy recommendation reiterated by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, while Stone Container, another paper products company, lost 1 3/4, to 17 3/4.
Software Toolworks, which makes software for Nintendo machines, sank 4 7/8, to 19, in over-the-counter trading after an article in Barron's characterized the company's outlook as lackluster.
The Nasdaq composite index sank 6.76, to 460.79. In over-the-counter trading, Nike, the athletic shoe company, lost 2 3/4, to 76; Sun Microsystems dropped 1, to 32 7/8, and Intel fell 1 1/4, to 47.
The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 3.27, to 360.76.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Smith Barney Hires Lawyer at Davis Polk

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
John J. McAtee Jr., a lawyer, will join Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company on July 5 as a vice chairman with responsibility for the firm's domestic and international investment banking. The appointment was announced yesterday by Frank G. Zarb, the investment and brokerage firm's chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Zarb stressed Mr. McAtee's breadth of experience as adviser to investment bankers and corporations during 27 years at Davis Polk & Wardwell, the big New York law firm. 
''I think it will add a new dimension to my experience,'' Mr. McAtee said yesterday, ''and I will not have to focus just on legal matters.''
He does not think he will need skills different from his legal ones in the new job, but he added, ''I will be managing more people than I do as a law partner.''
Smith Barney's corporate finance staff has almost 250 professionals. It provides general underwriting services, merger and acquisition advice, merchant banking and real estate financing. The firm is a subsidiary of the Primerica Corporation.
As to increasing the staff, he said: ''The group is on a move upward. The climate is perfect for Smith Barney, and last year was a record one in its investment banking as well as in securities brokerage activities.''
As a lawyer he enjoys most ''getting clients out of jams involving mergers and acquisitions,'' an area in which he has specialized in recent years at the law firm.
Saying he thrives on stress, he recalled one transaction involving a British company he represented. ''Intense negotiations went on all one week,'' he said. ''I made two round-trip trips to London, taking overnight flights and arriving back by the Concorde the next morning.'' Despite some jet lag on his part, the acquisition was completed successfully.
Mr. McAtee joined the law firm shortly after graduating from Yale Law School in 1963, and in a fast six years became a partner. Before that he served as a Navy officer for about two years following graduation from Princeton University in 1958, where he majored in economics. Like his father and grandfather, he had decided to be a lawyer, possibly in St. Louis, where he grew up.
Mr. McAtee, who is 53 years old, plays tennis or squash every week year-round ''with the same group for 20 years.''
''I scuba dive well but play golf badly,'' he added. He lives in Greenwich, Conn., and has two children.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Rethinking Business Education

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
IT is no secret that one of today's overriding challenges is the need to make changes in graduate business schools. In fact, a recently published report, ''Leadership for a Changing World - The Future Role of Graduate Management Education,'' discusses some of the steps business school deans and business leaders consider necessary.
John Rosenblum, the dean of the Darden Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia and a co-chairman of the academic commission that prepared the report, spoke about some of the more provocative ideas in an interview last week.
One of the big concerns among the deans is how the already crowded M.B.A. curriculum will deal with a host of newly emerging topics, including ethics, the environment and international business. 
As one answer, Dr. Rosenblum and others have been discussing changes in the traditional two-year M.B.A. program, with many criticizing the European idea of an intensive 11-month program and the 15-month program offered at some American graduate schools. Dr. Rosenblum said there are some creative alternatives.
''A few of us on the commission discussed a year program right after college, a second year about six years later in a person's career, followed by a two-month program in another six years,'' he said. ''I think the idea is worth considering. It would help free ourselves from the paradigm, or box, of the traditional two-year M.B.A. program.''
Such a plan would allow students to gain experience, while giving experienced managers an opportunity to continue their formal educations. ''Managers need to constantly reinvent themselves,'' Dr. Rosenblum said.
Another concern has been that some business school professors spend too much time on research that is not helpful to business. In its report, the commission stressed that business schools had tended to concentrate on ''elegant, abstract models'' that seek to unify world economic systems rather than help students understand ''the messy, concrete reality of international business.''
The commission, while stressing the importance of ''effective scholarship,'' urged that professors acquire more business knowledge to ''relate their scholarship to problems facing business leaders.'' The report also noted that some knowledge and skills ''may be best provided by faculty with managerial experience.''
Dr. Rosenblum agreed wholeheartedly with that last point and said he had added experienced corporate managers to his faculty - not just as adjunct professors but as full players.
''Faculty are enriched by diversity,'' he added.
One of those managers is Thomas C. MacAvoy, 62 years old, a former president of Corning Inc., the upstate New York glassware company.
''He is a chaired professor who teaches a course called 'Innovation and Technological Management,' '' Dr. Rosenblum said. ''And he has collaborated in the design of our new course in leadership, which will be given this fall for the first time.''
Another is Robert J. Sack, 56, who was a partner for 25 years in the former accounting firm of Touche Ross, which is now Deloitte Touche, and was also chief accountant for the Securities and Exchange Commission.
''He has come here to teach international financial reporting and also a course on communicating corporate value,'' Dr. Rosenblum said. ''In both cases they are the kind of professionals that would fit well as members of the tenured faculty.''
Dr. Rosenblum also said that many graduate business schools should find niches.
He applauded Rollins College's Roy E. Crummer Graduate School of Business, where the dean, Martin Schatz, hires only older, experienced professors with Ph.D.'s.
Dr. Rosenblum noted that Rollins stressed teaching and course development over research.
The campus at Winter Park, Fla., obviously also has an attraction for many older professors at a time when business school professors are in short supply.
''The difference between a teaching faculty and a research faculty is in what the faculty publishes, rather than if the faculty publishes.'' Dr. Schatz said. ''We encourage our people to publish material that improves the teaching process. Unlike many other schools, we value the publication of textbooks.''
Dr. Rosenblum called this a powerful niche strategy. ''I think we should celebrate differences among graduate schools of business,'' he added. ''More schools need a self-identity. We hope that this booklet will be a catalyst to more creative thinking like this.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Lower; Gold Slips in U.S. Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday, buffeted by technical factors and expectations of lower interest rates in the United States.
Gold prices rose modestly overseas, but slipped lower in later United States trading.
The dollar spent most of the day drifting downward in a continued response to last week's United States producer and consumer price reports. The data indicated weaker domestic demand and heightened prospects for interest rate cuts, dealers said. 
Traders believe the Federal Reserve, which sets the nation's monetary policy, is more likely to nudge interest rates lower to stimulate the economy amid signs of a slowdown. Such a move would be bearish for the dollar, which is more attractive to investors when United States rates are higher.
 
Technical Factors Cited
Jerry Rothman, a trader with Merrill Lynch Futures, said there was no news to affect the dollar and that investors were testing the currency to see how far it would go. However, he said, the dollar was likely nearing its lows.
A dealer in London said that ''it's really a technical market right now.''
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar fell in New York trading to 153.65 yen, from 153.90 yen late Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, it closed at 153.88 yen, down 0.64 yen from Friday's close, and in London, it was quoted at 153.75 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7130, from $1.7060 late Friday. Later in New York, the pound rose to $1.7145 from $1.7090.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6760 West German marks, down from 1.6885; 1.4157 Swiss francs, down from 1.4330; 5.6395 French francs, down from 5.6805; 1,230.00 Italian lire, down from 1,239.00, and 1.17455 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17085.
Gold fell 20 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $349.30 a troy ounce. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $348.25, down 25 cents.

HEADLINE: Report Urges Job Training

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Most American workers ''will see their dreams slip away'' unless society invests far more in improving their skills in school and on the job, a commission led by two former Labor Department Secretaries officially reported today.
The report offered a blueprint for changing the way schools, business and government prepare workers for an increasingly complex economy. 
It recommends that United States companies devote at least 1 percent of payroll to skills training and that no one under 18 be allowed to hold a job until earning a certificate proving mastery of basic academic skills and work qualities.
It also recommended that states, with Federal assistance, create local youth centers for insuring that all dropouts aged 14 to 21 earn mastery certificates. The report estimated such centers would cost $8.2 billion a year.
The study was produced by the 34-member Commission on the Skills of the American Work Force. The panel included top business, education and labor executives. Its chairmen were two former United States Labor Secretaries, Bill Brock and F. Ray Marshall, and Ira Magaziner, an international business authority.
The report was based on about 2,000 interviews conducted at more than 550 companies and agencies since last July in the United States, Germany, Sweden, Denmark, Ireland, Japan and Singapore.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 20, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A brief article by The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday about the Commission on Skills of the American Work Force described its recommendation on job training incompletely. It recommended that no one under age 18 be allowed to work without earning a ''certificate of initial mastery'' of basic skills or enrolling in a program toward the certificate.

HEADLINE: THE MANDELA VISIT;
Mandela the Messenger: Celebrated, Yet Life-Size

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, June 19

 BODY:
Since he was freed after 27 1/2 years in prison, Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela has shed his legend as one of the world's most celebrated political prisoners and emerged as a consistent and tough spokesman for the African National Congress.
Over the last four months, Mr. Mandela has been content to serve as a disciplined, if very prestigious, member of the liberation movement that he joined 46 years ago. Though he carries the title of the congress's deputy president, its domestic leadership has been entrusted to his old comrade, Walter Sisulu.
By declining to exploit his celebrity for his own political ends, Mr. Mandela, who is scheduled to arrive in New York on Wednesday to begin a 12-day, 8-city tour of the United States, has both exceeded and fallen short of expectations engendered among South Africans, black and white, during his long incarceration.
 
Most Popular South African
When Mr. Mandela walked out of prison on Feb. 9, his patrician bearing and unfailing courtesy encouraged hopes that he could become the first black president of a nation where nonwhites make up more than 85 percent of the population. Even today, he remains the most popular man in South Africa. 
By setting an example of resistance to apartheid devoid of personal animosity, Mr. Mandela has inspired people of color in and beyond South Africa, among them many Americans of African descent.
''When we used to talk of freedom, we believed it was just a dream,'' said Thabo, a high school student in Soweto who did not want his last name used. ''But now we believe it is something that can happen.''
But some South Africans who wanted Mr. Mandela to move dramatically to foster national reconciliation have been upset by his insistence that it is too early for foreign countries to drop the sanctions against South Africa or for his organization to renounce its armed struggle against the white minority Government with which he has opened a dialogue. And white businessmen have been concerned about his defense of nationalization and redistribution of wealth, which the African National Congress has long viewed as necessary to let blacks share equitably in the country's resources.
 
Demonstrates Devotion
Such is his devotion to the congress that Mr. Mandela, who celebrates his 72d birthday on July 18, embarked on an exhausting six-week tour of 13 countries only a day after he was discharged from a Johannesburg hospital after surgery to remove an inflammatory cyst from his bladder.
Some supporters expressed concern that Mr. Mandela was undertaking too much on behalf of the congress. ''He must also be told that he is more valuable here at home than globe-trotting trying to convince the world that our struggle is a just and noble one,'' City Press, a black-oriented newspaper popular in the segregated townships around Johannesburg, said in a recent editorial. ''He could have done that after full recovery from his operation.
''What is the wisdom? Does the A.N.C. hope to gain selfish politi-cal mileage out of parading a tired man in front of overseas audiences? We hope not.''
While calling President F. W. de Klerk a man of integrity and urging white South Africans to support him, Mr. Mandela has complained that Mr. de Klerk was not doing enough to eliminate apartheid.
''Twenty-seven years ago when I went to jail, I had no vote; 27 years thereafter, I still have no vote, and that is due to the color of my skin,'' Mr. Mandela told a joint news conference with President de Klerk on May 4.
He has been criticized by Mr. de Klerk in turn for espousing a continuation of the guerrilla struggle that the African National Congress declared against the Government in 1961 after its peaceful appeals for change were rebuffed. The Government contends that the call for armed struggle has encouraged violence in black townships. It is a charge that Mr. Mandela has rejected.
''The only type of violence that we accept is organized violence in the form of armed action which is properly controlled and where the targets have been carefully selected,'' Mr. Mandela said on June 2.
 
Softening on Nationalization
Mr. Mandela has hinted at a softening of the African National Congress's old call for key sectors of the economy to be nationalized.
Last month, he assured a meeting of white businessmen that nationalization and redistribution were not the only words in the congress's vocabulary.
But he has rejected arguments that large-scale Government ownership has contributed to economic failure in some African countries. At a news conference on June 2, Mr. Mandela took exception when a reporter asked if the African National Congress would avoid the ''complete mess'' in which some African countries found themselves economically.
''If there are any economic problems in Africa today, the responsibility for such mess, as you call it, must be laid squarely on the shoulders of the former colonial powers,'' Mr. Mandela said.
Any inconsistencies in Mr. Mandela's remarks seem to reflect the diversity of thinking inside the African National Congress rather than his own dissent from its policies.
''He has never regarded himself as an individual apart from the A.N.C.; he has always been very, very firm on that and he has just not changed,'' said Ahmed Kathrada, a comrade who was in prison with Mr. Mandela.
Mr. Kathrada, who is the congress's information secretary inside South Africa, said the Government sought to drive a wedge between the African National Congress and Mr. Mandela while he was in prison by presenting him as the more acceptable face of the organization.
''They tried to project the image of him as the moderate A.N.C.,'' Mr. Kathrada said, but Mr. Mandela would not cooperate. Mr. Mandela has described his talks with Mr. de Klerk and other officials before his release as facilitating a dialogue on behalf of the African National Congress.
 
A Passion for Discipline
Mr. Mandela's passion for organizational discipline was expressed at a rally in Port Elizabeth on April 1.
''Anyone who has an agenda of their own and conducts their activities in ways which are not compatible with the guidance of the president and the N.E.C.'' - references to Oliver Tambo and the congress's National Executive Committee - ''is a threat to our discipline, cohesion and organization,'' Mr. Mandela said. He called such individualists dangerous.
On rare occasions when Mr. Mandela found himself at odds with the congress, he has adjusted. Worried about the factional violence in Natal between members of the Inkatha, a conservative Zulu political and cultural organization, and supporters of the United Democratic Front, a congress ally, Mr. Mandela agreed in March to share a platform with the Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the Inkatha leader. He backed out after front officials from Natal objected.
Mr. Mandela can still draw tens of thousands of supporters to a rally, but they may not do what he urges. He was cheered in Durban on Feb. 25, when he urged those involved in the factional fighting in Natal to throw their weapons into the sea and make peace, but the violence did not stop.
In traveling for the African National Congress, Mr. Mandela has embraced Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in Lusaka, Zambia, and compared the Palestinian struggle against Israel to the struggle of black South Africans against Pretoria.
In Luanda, Angola, Mr. Mandela spoke of liberty in Fidel Castro's Cuba. And in Tripoli, he described the Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi as a worker for human rights.
''I am not expressing any opinion as to what is going on inside the countries thyat I visited,'' Mr. Mandela explained on May 29, when a reporter asked about his choice of foreign friends.
''What concerns me is the foreign policy of those countries, especially insofar as it relates to us. Those countries who are fully committed to assisting the anti-apartheid forces in this country are our friends,'' he said.
 
Support for Israel's Rights
As for the Palestine Liberation Organization, Mr. Kathrada explained that Mr. Mandela was expressing the African National Congress's solidarity with a kindred liberation movement.
''We were aware of the repercussions that the meeting with Arafat would have, but we have a relationship with the Palestine Liberation Organization and he didn't find it necessary to hide that,'' Mr. Kathrada said. Mr. Mandela subsequently assured a group of American Jews that he also supported Israel's right to exist.
Mr. Mandela has further defended African National Congress's long alliance with the South African Communist Party, saying the congress would not abandon old friends. ''I have been working with them,'' Mr. Mandela said at his first news conference on Feb. 10. ''Their immediate objective is similar and it is natural for us to work closely together.''
If Mr. Mandela has political ambitions within or beyond the African National Congress, he has yet to reveal them. A few days after his release, Mr. Mandela was asked whether he aspired to become South Africa's first black president. He said no.
''My ambition is to see to it that we have peace in the country and that we can appreciate each other's talents, each other's contribution to the future of South Africa,'' he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS TO RETURN LAND IN OKINAWA

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 19

 BODY:
The United States and Japan announced today that the American military had agreed to return about 4 percent of the land from its base installations on the southern Japanese island of Okinawa, in a long-awaited move that appears likely to leave the strongly anti-military residents of Okinawa unsatisfied.
After two years of negotiations, prompted by an emotional appeal from the Governor of Okinawa in April 1988, the United States agreed to return a little more than 2,000 acres, about 4 percent of the land it has occupied since taking the islands after a hard-fought battle in the closing months of World War II. The 2,000 acres was far less land than the Okinawans had sought.
 
Antenna Sites and a Golf Course
The parcels to be returned are spread over 23 sites, and range from a smattering of antenna locations to a golf course and an oceanside site that the Okinawa government has said it wants to develop as a resort to invigorate the local economy. 
The United States formally returned control over Okinawa and some neighboring islands to the Japanese Government in 1972, but still keeps bases on about 20 percent of its land, much of it in prime locations. Some other parcels were returned in 1980.
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is scheduled to visit Okinawa on Saturday to attend a memorial service for those who fell in the battle. Saturday is also the 30th anniversary of the security treaty that has governed America's long and sometimes difficult military involvement in Japan.
 
Bitterness Toward U.S. and Tokyo
The announcement today thus appeared to have been timed to smooth his visit, which could be tense because of resentment among many Okinawans over the state of the local economy and what is perceived to be Japanese condescension toward the islanders. In a recent poll, 61 percent of the Okinawans questioned said they were opposed to the American presence, for which many islanders blame the Government in Tokyo.
''From the standpoint of the Okinawan people, the land being returned is not sufficient,'' Junji Nishime, Governor of Okinawa Prefecture, said through a spokesman. He nonetheless thanked the American and Japanese negotiators for their efforts. ''We appreciate this as an advance toward our goal and hope the Government continues discussions on gaining the return of the parcels that were excluded from the present agreement,'' he said.
The Okinawans, who are among the poorest of Japanese citizens, are seeking oceanfront and harbor sites that they hope to develop into resorts to improve the islands' tourist trade and to develop a free-trade zone.
 
Land Return Could Take Years
Officials on both sides emphasized that the agreement announced today is unrelated to Defense Department plans to scale back the heavy American military presence in Japan and the rest of Asia in response to a shrinking budget and the sharp reduction in cold-war tensions.
The return of the land could still take years, since the transfer of several parcels, like the golf course at Camp Zukeran, are contingent on offers of new sites for the American forces.
Today's announcement came just a few days before the 45th anniversary of the battle through which the American military won the islands. It was the last major battle with Japan before the conclusion of World War II, and ended with hundreds of Japanese killing themselves in underground bunkers rather than surrender.
Nearly 75 percent of the American forces in Japan are in bases on Okinawa. During the 1970's, bases in the Kanto region, the plain surrounding Tokyo, were consolidated and a number of sites were returned. A housing complex on Okinawa was also returned in 1980.

HEADLINE: If Communism Is Waning, Asia Defies the Trend

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, June 15

 BODY:
About the same time that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was ending his visit to the United States and voters in several Eastern European countries were heading into multiparty elections, the Communist Party of India was issuing a statement that began, ''The U.S. imperialists have intensified their aggression against Cuba.''
This month, the Communist Party of India-Marxist, the largest and most influential leftist party in the country, issued a 33-page indictment of Soviet change and of the overthrow or renaming of Eastern European parties. It defended Stalin and branded European Communism a ''deviation.''
In Nepal, parties of the left have begun unity talks as a prelude to making a move for power in voting next year. In Vietnam, a roundup of dissidents is under way, and in China there was the silent anniversary of the crackdown on the democracy movement in June 1989. 
Communist and other leftist parties in Asia have not only bucked the trend that has swept their counterparts from power in most of Europe, they have continued to grow in strength and to attract new followers, particularly in South Asia, where poverty is stark and development slow.
New parties of the left are appearing in India, where a peasant-based Indian People's Front entered Parliament for the first time last year, and in Nepal, where new and sometimes radical groups with shadowy leaderships have been emerging from underground since multiparty democracy was restored in April.
 
The Old Icons Go Up
While pictures and statues of Marx, Lenin, Engels and Stalin come down elsewhere, they are going up here.
''In Asia, we still have feudalism to fight,'' a Nepalese journalist working in the Philippines said. In Katmandu, leftist leaders say no other political organization is bold enough to offer real change or well enough organized to bring it about.
In India, leftists say they can play a major role in combating the growth of religious fundamentalism while battling the evils of caste and class. They avoid debate on the collapse of Communism elsewhere, saying the problems of European socialism are not necessarily relevant to them.
''The masses of people in these countries are obviously suffering from so many very severe problems, what would be the alternative to socialism?'' Indrajit Gupta, general secretary of the Communist Party of India, the smaller of the two main leftist parties, asked in an interview last month.
''The alternative of private enterprise and capitalism, I don't think would wash here,'' he said, sitting under a portrait of Ho Chi Minh. ''
 
Urban and Intellectual
Mr. Gupta, who is 71 years old, joined the Communist movement at Cambridge University in the 1940's and after returning to India concentrated on building bases among the disadvantaged.
His only regret, he said in another interview nearly two years ago, was that Indian Communism has remained an urban, intellectual phenomenon. Its voters have been drawn from the most literate constituencies. But they have joined through choice, and Mr. Gupta sees this as an advantage.
''The leaderships of the Communists in Eastern Europe never made their own revolutions, and that was a big handicap,'' he said, comparing the course of European socialism with many Asian examples. ''Power was handed to them on a plate by the Soviet Army.''
In Hanoi in April, Le Mai, a Deputy Foreign Minister, argued similarly, saying that the Vietnamese Communist Party was a home-grown nationalist movement that brought the country independence and unity. But he ruled out putting it to the test of a vote, saying the economic rebuilding of the country took precedence.
 
Communists in Big Roles
He and other Vietnamese also repeated a theme heard frequently in Southeast Asia: that Asian societies are different, preferring consensus and living more comfortably with one-party states. Vietnamese Communists point to Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore as an ardent capitalist with a closed political system.
Indian Communists are in an unusual position in Asia. They head state governments in West Bengal, which includes Calcutta, and Kerala. At the national level, they support the centrist Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh without joining his coalition.
Their important role in national politics has given them additional strength at local and state level, particularly in West Bengal. The state's Chief Minister, Jyoti Basu, a leader of the Communist Party of India-Marxist, has become one of Prime Minister Singh's advisers.
Mr. Basu's decision before elections in November to cooperate with the Hindu-based Bharatiya Janata Party in fielding candidates so as not to dilute the opposition vote played a major part in the defeat of the former Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, and his Congress Party.
He continues to play a stabilizing role, while his state reaps the development and investment rewards that it was denied while the Congress Party was in power.

HEADLINE: Dole Predicts a New Budget Plan

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said today that the Administration had told him that the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, would present a negotiating proposal when budget talks resume Wednesday. Mr. Dole said he had not seen the proposal, but described it as ''enough to satisfy the Democrats' request.''
According to officials close to the negotiations, Mr. Darman will propose a $20 billion cut in domestic programs, with $17 billion of that coming from a variety of popular programs like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, veterans benefits and farm subsidies. The officials said the Darman plan would seek a reduction of only $3 billion to $6 billion in military spending, far less than Democrats want. They also said it would have no tax increases beyond those proposed in President Bush's January budget. 
The budget that Mr. Bush presented included about $36 billion in measures intended to cut the deficit, including $13.9 billion in revenue increases and $5.6 billion in user fees.
 
Democrats Want Deeper Cuts
Democrats have insisted that the Administration be the first to come forward with suggestions to reduce the deficit because it was President Bush who initiated the budget talks five weeks ago. Representative Leon Panetta, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said today that Democrats would not consider any Republican proposal credible unless it showed deficit cuts in the range of $50 billion to $60 billion.
Negotiators are scheduled to begin their Wednesday session with an update on the economy.
Despite the lack of an accord, the House began appropriating money for the next fiscal year over the protests ofg Republicans.
Its began by raising by $350 million what President Bush would spend on cleaning up the nation's atomic weapons complex next year and launching 25 new water projects opposed by the Administration.
The House by a vote of 355 to 59 approved a $20.8 billion energy and water spending bill that is $575 million more what President Bush requested in his budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.
The bill also increases by some $400 million what President Bush wanted to spend on 637 water projects. But it also grants his request for $318 million to begin construction of an $8 billion atom smasher in Texas.
Amendments calling for across-the-board cuts of 10.5 percent, 5 percent or 2 percent were overwhelmingly defeated.
As passed, the bill would provide the Army Corps of Engineers $3.6 billion, nearly half a billion dollars more than it received last year, for its 550 water projects. The 87 water projects run by the Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation would get $957 million, nearly $7 million less than this year but still $42 million above what President Bush sought.

HEADLINE: Hiring Ban Is Shrinking Military's Civilian Force

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Five months after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney imposed a freeze on hiring, the military's million-member civilian work force is slowly shrinking.
But the goals of the freeze have been scaled back. Since it was announced in January, the Pentagon has granted several exemptions in response to a chorus of complaints from civilian employees and military commanders who found themselves desperately short of everything from typists and mess-hall cooks to doctors and airplane mechanics.
Pentagon officials had planned to eliminate more than 50,000 jobs from the work force of 1.07 million civilians by Sept. 30, when the freeze is to expire. The officials now say that perhaps 40,000 jobs will be dropped from the $39 billion civilian payroll by the deadline. About 22,000 had been dropped through the end of April, the latest figures show. 
 
Savings Went for Aid
But the $83 million that Pentagon officials had expected to save was instead shifted last month by the Administration to a a supplemental appropriation bill that provided economic aid to Nicaragua and Panama.
Nonetheless, at a time when Mr. Cheney is facing reductions in military forces, Pentagon officials say freezing civilian hiring is a relatively painless way, politically and administratively, to make reductions.
''The objective was to stockpile as many vacancies as possible to avert layoffs later, and the freeze is meeting its objective,'' the acting Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for civilian personnel policy, Frank P. Cipolla, said in an interview.
The civilian reductions are separate from Mr. Cheney's plan sent to Congress Tuesday outlining the effects of a 25 percent cut in military forces.
Because of the uncertainty surrounding the budget talks between Congress and the White House, which are certain to force troop reductions, Mr. Cipolla said it was unclear whether the freeze would be extended beyond Oct. 1, the start of the new fiscal year.
Mr. Cheney's original order also imposed a freeze on promotions and transfers to fill vacant jobs.
The Pentagon last imposed a hiring freeze in 1982. It lasted a few months.
 
Construction Freeze Extended
In an unrelated decision, Mr. Cheney last week extended until Nov. 15 a worldwide freeze on $7 billion in American military construction projects and said through a spokesman that he would ask Congress to cancel many of them. The freeze, which was also imposed in January, had been scheduled to expire last Friday.
As for the hiring freeze, military installations report that while the reductions are no longer hampering daily operations, other workers have to pick up the slack as vacancies go unfilled.
''Across the board, people are having to do extra things,'' said Lieut. Col. Duane Roberts, a spokesman for McClellan Air Force Base in Sacramento, Calif., which has lost about 200 of its 12,500 civilian workers. ''You can do that for a while, but it takes its toll and people burn out.''
In Maryland, Fort George G. Meade has lowered its civilian work force by 200 people to 5,292 since January. The engineering and housing department, for example, has lost 15 positions, including four mechanics, a pipefitter and a bulldozer operator. ''With a dwindling resource pool, you do the best you can with what you have,'' said Don McClow, a spokesman at Fort Meade.
 
Critics See Lack of Planning
Critics of the freeze contend that reducing the work force through attrition is an unreliable substitute for long-range personnel planning.
Lawrence J. Korb, who served in Ronald Reagan's Administration as Assistant Secretary of Defense for manpower, installations and logistics, said a freeze would produce proper work force levels only by ''pure happenstance.''
Problems cropped up almost immediately after the freeze took effect on Jan. 11. Mr. Cheney's original directive was tightly drawn, exempting only a few categories. These included hiring commitments that had been made before the effective date of the freeze; medical, safety and security workers, and people identified by the heads of a military department or Pentagon agency as ''essential to maintain an important national defense capability.''
But the Pentagon quickly added to the list recent college graduates recruited to fill entry-level jobs in important areas like logistics, financial management, engineering and procurement. ''We didn't want the pipeline to dry up,'' Mr. Cipolla said.
In addition, the ban was lifted for civilian employees working at military exchanges, clubs, day-care centers and other activities where the employees' salaries are paid by the fees of those using the service.

HEADLINE: Babies, Rice Farms and Diplomas

 BODY:
Can it be that Japan's alarmingly low birth rate is the Government's fault because it encourages women to get a higher education? That's what Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told the Japanese Cabinet last week. He has since been backing and filling, but there seems little doubt about the original sentiment - the more women in college, the fewer in accouchement.
Women have not attained full equality in Western societies either, but Mr. Hashimoto's views sound surprisingly quaint. He implies that women do not merit the same chances as men, and that the duty of Japanese citizens is to subject their private lives to the interests of the state, as interpreted by members of its ruling elite like Mr. Hashimoto. 
If Japan's goal is to raise its birth rate, keeping its women uneducated seems hardly the best way. Japanese undoubtedly choose to have small families because of the same demographic transition to low fertility and mortality rates experienced by other modern industrial societies. This transition is intensified by the price of land, which has been allowed to reach preposterous heights. The value of Tokyo's land is now said to equal that of the entire United States. The grounds of the Emperor's palace alone are valued at $70 billion, more than all the land in Florida.
The high price benefits Japanese companies, which can borrow vast sums on their land holdings and out-invest their Western competitors. It's less of a boon to young Japanese couples, who must live in cramped quarters and take out 100-year, three-generation mortgages to buy a house.
As Finance Minister, maybe Mr. Hashimoto could do something about the tax system that sustains Tokyo's curious breed of urban rice farmers. If they could only be induced to sell their downtown rice farms, the price of land would fall to more natural levels and the number of rooms per Japanese household would rise, doubtless followed by the birth rate.
That's just a theory, of course, but it would surely win a lot more votes than Mr. Hashimoto's idea of turning back the clock.

HEADLINE: Judaism's Alive and Well and Living in America;
The Nature of Identity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Seymour Lachman and Barry Kosmin (Op-Ed, June 4) make assumptions that, unfortunately, are shared by many non-Jews as well as Jewish religious sects. The most common is that being part of the Jewish community consists of affiliation and participation in a Judaic religious sect. 
They equate this assumption with another questionable one: ''Christian American norms of piety and affiliation.'' There's a better equation in the number of Christians and Jews whose ''affiliation'' rests on the celebration twice a year of Easter or Passover, and Christmas or Hannukah. Attendance at church services by Christians for these holy days is best compared to the large attendance of Jews at synagogues or temples on Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year.
Another section of the Jewish population that makes a point of celebrating these holidays is the growing number affiliated with local chapters of the Society of Secular Humanist Judaism. This suggests that Jewishness may or may not depend upon piety or religious affiliation. Jewishness is a ''club'' from which one cannot resign, even though attempts have been made by conversion, assimilation, denial (name change) or intermarriage. This is because, again and again, Jews have been made the scapegoats for social, economic and political ills.
Whether we are American Jews, French Jews, English Jews or Eastern European Jews, this sense of community has an international aspect. Our survival as Jews has depended upon that most vital aspect of community that meant helping one another in times of stress; keeping our history, certain ethnic and cultural traditions alive, especially the value of education and life itself. Religious, or not religious, we remain Jews.
 
GRACE SEGAL AVILES
 Chevy Chase, Md., June 4, 1990

HEADLINE: For Industrial Growth, Give Risk Capital a Break

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker states (column, May 28) that ''much of today's high-tech industry was spun off from federally financed military and space research,'' and he calls for an industrial policy that would apparently target certain industries for Federal support.
As a venture capitalist for 30 years, I can think of few company spinoffs from Government-sponsored military and space research. Some of our companies have benefited from Federal support of scientific research. More often they refuse military and space-related funds because of the concomitant change of direction from commercial products.
The best way to encourage industrial growth is to restore the lower tax rate on long-term investments in risky enterprises we had from 1922 to 1986. To quote John F. Kennedy, ''The tax on capital gains directly affects investment decisions, the mobility and flow of risk capital from static to more dynamic situations, the ease or difficulty experienced by new ventures in obtaining capital, and thereby the strength and potential for growth of the economy.''
 
KENNETH W. RIND
 Stamford, Conn., June 1, 1990
