HEADLINE: Excerpts From President's News Conference on the P.L.O. and Other Issues

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Huntsville, Ala., yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the Cable News Network:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Based on the recommendation of the Secretary of State, I have decided to suspend the dialogue between the United States and the P.L.O. pending a satisfactory response from the P.L.O. of steps it is taking to resolve problems associated with the recent acts of terrorism, in particular that May 30 terrorist attack on Israel by the Palestinian Liberation Front - a constituent group of the P.L.O.
By way of background, on Dec. 14, 1988, Yasir Arafat, speaking on behalf of the P.L.O. executive committee, recognized Israel's right to exist. He accepted the United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 and he renounced terrorism.
Now, subsequently, the United States announced that because the P.L.O. had met our long-standing conditions for dialogue, we would begin a substantive dialogue with the P.L.O. And at at the time we applauded Chairman Arafat for taking these essential steps and we have conducted such a dialogue with the P.L.O. through our embassy in Tunis.
Over the past 18 months, representatives of the United States and the P.L.O. regularly exchanged views about the political and security situation in the region.
On balance, we believed that these exchanges contributed to progress in the peace process. 
 
A Raid by Sea
On May 30, 1990, the Palestinian Liberation Front attempted a seaborne terrorist infiltration into Israel. Palestinian Liberation Front leader Abu Abbas represents the P.L.O. [sic] on the executive committee of the P.L.O. The size of the force and the geographical target area strongly indicates that civilians would have been the target.
That day we issued a statement deploring this attempted terrorist attack. On May 31 we raised this incident with the P.L.O. in Tunis. We told them that it could not avoid responsibility for an attempted terrorist action by one of its constituent groups and needed to take steps to deal with the matter by condemning the operation, disassociating itself from it and by also beginning to take steps to discipline Abu Abbas, the perpetrator.
We've given the P.L.O. ample time to deal with this issue. To date, the P.L.O. has not provided a credible accounting of this incident or undertaken the actions outlined above.
The U.S. does take note of the fact that the P.L.O. has disassociated itself from this attack and issued a statement condemning attacks against civilians in principle. But as we previously indicated, this is not sufficient. This alone is not sufficient.
The U.S.-P.L.O. dialogue has demonstrated that it can advance the Arab-Israeli peace process. And at the same time, the dialogue is based on the assumption that the P.L.O. is willing to abide by the conditions it accepted in December 1988, including renunciation of terror.
At any time that the P.L.O. is prepared to take the necessary steps, we are prepared to promptly resume the dialogue.
In the meantime, we would hope and expect the peace process would proceed as intended and without delay.
We remain committed to the pursuit of a comprehensive settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict and to a just and lasting peace. And as we've often stated, it is our view that such a peace must be based on those two resolutions - U.N. Resolution 242 and 338 and the principle implicit therein as territory for peace and provide for Israel's security and Palestinian political rights.
We believe that Palestinian participation is vital to any successful process and that there are real opportunities for Palestinians in this process. We strongly hope that Israelis, Palestinians and the Arab states will recognize these opportunities and take the necessary steps to create an environment in which a viable peace process can thrive. We denounce violence in the area and call upon all parties to eschew violence and terror and opt instead for dialogue and negotiation. We're prepared to continue working with the parties toward this end.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
The Moves Toward Peace
Q. Doesn't your announcement of today coupled with Secretary Baker's words that the Israelis should call the White House when they're serious, mean that the U.S. position in the peace process for the Middle East is dormant right now?
A. John, it's not moving forward right now and the offer still stands. I have sent a letter to Prime Minister Shamir. I have very specifically asked questions that relate to seriousness about the peace process but I would like to see the peace process move forward, nothing herein should indicate anything different because here we're simply taking an arrow shot at, at terrorism. . . .
 
Savings and Loans
Q. Mr. Marlin seemed to have lit a fairly short political fuse with his comments on the S. & L. bailout and accusing the Democrats of having a big part in that mess. Are you ready to play that game this election year and blame the Democrats for a problem that others have laid on years of permissive regulation by the Reagan Administration?
A. Norm, you're almost getting me into the fight by the way you asked the question, but I know I'm not going to. I want to get the savings and loan problem solved. And Marlin properly, seeing a couple of shots across my bow from certain distinguished members of the United States Senate decided not to acquiesce in those attacks without some response. What he did was appropriate.
But what I'm trying to do is not respond to individuals and to simply keep moving forward on this process, and not try to be out there saying here's who's to blame and here's who's not to blame. . . . I think more important than continuing to pour fuel on that spark is to work cooperatively with the Congress in trying to get this mess solved and of course that is a part of what will be discussed in the, in the budget process. I would say to the American people on this one, the obligation is to protect the depositor. That's what our obligation is. And another obligation is to prosecute those who have broken the law and there's been an active prosecution under way.
 
Allies and P.L.O.
Q. Is it true that none of our allies, with the exception of course of the Israelis, wanted you to suspend these talks with the P.L.O.? . . .
A. . . . I think there will be a, a lack of agreement with what I've done here on part of some of our strongest allies. And I know this is true on the part of some of the most reasonable and moderate Arab states. But I would simply remind them of the conditions upon which the dialogue started in the first place and I would also remind them that if they look at this statement, and remedial action is taken, the dialogue from the U.S. side can promptly be restored.
 
Mandela and Sanctions
Q. Mr. President, as you know, Nelson Mandela arrived in the United States today and you're going to meet with him next week. What are you going to tell him on the sanctions question? And the second part, there have been reports - oh, some weeks ago - that the United States [unintelligible] agency was a fraud, and a process led that led to his arrest many years ago. And there've been suggestions that you should apologize in behalf of the United States Government and the American people. Will you do that?
A. No. I will take my leadership on that question from Mr. Mandela, who put it very well when he said, let bygones by bygones. And that is not to agree with or disagree with the charge. On the second point - your first, my second - the sanctions under the law cannot be listed [sic] until certain additional steps are taken by South Africa.
Let me be very clear: I salute Mr. de Klerk for what he's done. He's come a long, long way. And I salute Mr. Mandela for his approach to de Klerk; I think that demonstrates a willingness to talk that few of us might have predicted a couple of years ago. But there still are things that have to be done, under our law, in order to lift the sanctions. . . .
But in any event, there has to be progress. And I'd like to find a way to show Mr. de Klerk that we, the United States, are grateful for this new approach; that is, having South Africa evolve to a much more open society and, hopefully, one day to one which is color blind in terms of participation in the political process.
But I can't lift the sanctions under existing U.S. law . . . I had some original reservations about the sanction approach. But I will say that it seems to - if you can credit sanctions with the evolution of - towards democracy in South Africa, I'd have to say, well, it seems to be - you know, there's some good things to it.
But it's delicate, because I want to find a way to show our appreciation to de Klerk, and yet I don't want to pull the rug out from under Mr. Mandela.
 
Aid for the Soviets
Q. Mr. President, are you planning to support a G-7 initiative, for economic reasons, to the Soviet Union at next month's economic summit? And if so --
A. No, I'm not planning to do that. I expect, though, that matter may be discussed. There are - I've tried to very upfront with Mr. Gorbachev when he was here about the difficulties in terms of financial support. I talked to him in Malta about that. Indeed, we presented him with a list of things that might be done to improve our ability to work in full cooperation with them on that. But I don't plan a new initiative and yet I want to see perestroika continue. I haven't changed my view that economic reform is important, and I recognize that support from the West can well help the economy.
But there's an awful lot of reform that has to take place - in the market, in the distribution systems. There's some political problems that we have that I've discussed very frankly with Mr. Gorbachev - not the least of them $5 billion a year going down to Cuba - so we've still got some problems there. But discount the fact that we are planning some bold new initiative. On the other hand, I'm perfectly prepared to talk to our allies on any subject, and I think that will probably be one of them.
 
Dealing With P.L.O.
Q. Back on the P.L.O., one of the theories passed around in your own Administration was that the intent of this terrorist attack was to derail the peace process. Are you at all concerned that by suspending the dialogue you're playing into the hands of the hard-liners, like Abu Abbas? And is there also --
A. Yes. Let me stop you there, just to respond, so I don't forget the question. Yes, I am concerned about that. Go ahead.
Q. Well, if you're concerned about it then why did you - why did you take this action?
A. Well, because we had to weigh the whole question, and the question was complicated by the fact that there were three specific undertakings, one of which - a very important one, in my view - has clearly been violated. So - but it's not an easy call because I know some feel that the P.L.O. dialogue is totally unproductive and, as I indicated in this statement, I don't. And the question up here was, well, do our allies - will they agree with the steps that I've taken here in Huntsville today? And the answer is, no, some of them will not agree because they do feel that the dialogue has kind of helped calm things in some parts of the Middle East.
So what the answer to it is, is for the P.L.O. to take the action that I've called for and to satisfactorily - to satisfy us that those who were responsible will be disciplined, and condemn this specific act. It's not enough to simply reiterate - reiterate one's concern on terrorism.
Q. Is there a danger, too, that those Palestinians who had put some hope in the dialogue between the P.L.O. and the U.S. might now throw up their hands in desperation and resort to violence?
A. Well, I hope that's not the case, and yet I would refer you to the very last page - of my last paragraph or two of the statement, when I did call for no violence. And I think it's fair to say that any time you're dealing with something as complicated as the Middle East, you worry about that. But I hope that's not the case, and I hope they'll see in my statement a rather temperate view here that, though we're specific in calling for the condemnation of this particular terrorist act, that if - once that is done, in keeping with Arafat's undertaking -that we can resume talks.
There has been a frustration, Jim, in the Arab world, that the - that this dialogue has not resulted in more -more progress. And I understand the frustration. I don't happen to agree with it. I think things are better because we've had the dialogue. But Israel has strongly objected to it, and some Palestinians have been, as we can clearly see, concerned about it. But I believe that we ought to try to find a way to get it back at some point.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
At Romanian Inauguration, Promises and Doubts

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, June 20

 BODY:
Ion Iliescu was inaugurated President today, ending six months of provisional rule that began with the violent overthrow of President Nicolae Ceausescu last December.
In an auditorium whose walls and ceilings are adorned with the names and images of Romania's cultural and political pantheon, Mr. Iliescu in his inaugural address promised free-market economic reforms, the rule of law, full recognition of individual and minority rights and improvements in Romania's social safety net and moral fabric. He also put forth a defense of the Government's violent breakup of a protest last week.
It was uncertain, despite the promises, whether Mr. Iliescu would transform his words into deeds and heal the trauma of the Ceausescu era, given Romania's highly charged, confused political atmosphere. 
The United States Ambassador to Romania, Alan Green, boycotted the ceremony today to show concern over the Government's violent breakup of a seven-week protest against Mr. Iliescu in a central square last week. Officials have said 6 people were killed and more than 100 hurt as the police broke up the protest, before the Government called miners to the city in what it said was a move to defend Romania from a coup attempt.
 
Seeks Distance From Miners
Besides beating up anti-government demonstrators, the miners attacked scores of innocent people, ransacked private homes and opposition party offices and newspapers, and manhandled and threatened opposition leaders.
Mr. Iliescu publicly thanked the miners last week. In his speech today, however, he sought to disassociate the Government from the illegal acts the miners committed.
Mr. Iliescu said today that the violence last week exposed serious inadequacies in the country's military and law enforcement agencies and called for a strengthening of Romania's security apparatus and greater discipline in the armed forces.
''The state and government leadership was faced with a direct challenge that it could not cope with efficiently,'' he said. ''Under those circumstances an appeal was made to the population to support the authorities.''
People who said they watched last week's events reported seeing army troops encouraging an attack by anti-Government demonstrators on police headquarters. Western reporters said they saw troops giving victory signs to groups of demonstrators milling around University Square, the plaza where the protest took place, after the first police attempt to clear the square.
 
Aid Is Suspended
The pro-Government violence prompted Western governments, including the United States, to halt non-humanitarian aid to Romania, a move that is certain to make the promises that Mr. Iliescu voiced today all the more difficult to fulfill. Mr. Iliescu stressed in his speech that the Romanian Government is counting on international aid.
In a statement released Tuesday, Mr. Green, the American Ambassador, called on the Romanian Government to condemn the acts of vigilantes, to guarantee the safety of people who exercise the right to free expression and to engage in constructive dialogue with democratic opposition groups. United States Embassy officals, however, will continue to meet directly with senior Romanian Government officials, the statement said.
The ceremony today, which was delayed for almost a week because of the violence, came off without incident. The hundreds of heavily armed soldiers and security troops who surrounded the auditorium wound up facing only a few onlookers and small crowds of flower-carrying Iliescu supporters, who were kept a safe distance from the building.
 
Strike at University
At Bucharest University today, a number of students and professors started a three-day strike in protest against the continuing detention of students taken into custody last week by the police and miners.
Rumors abound in Bucharest that there are rifts between elements of Romania's army and the security apparatus and that a split has developed between Mr. Iliescu, who won last month's presidential election here by a wide margin, and Prime Minister Petre Roman. Despite those reports, Mr. Iliescu today reappointed Mr. Roman to run Romania's Government until Parliament takes up the formation of a new government.
Mr. Iliescu's chief opposition party rivals, Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party and Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party, expressed satisfaction with most of the speech.
''I liked particularly the passages in which he guarantees human rights, respect for the individual, assembly, and all of the freedoms we are yearning for in this country,'' Mr. Ratiu said.
But, Mr. Ratiu added, ''If what he said about the events of last week are a guide to his sincerity, then I am very worried because the way he presented the events of last week is totally wrong.'' Mr. Ratiu charged that there was total collusion between the security forces and the miners.
Mr. Campeanu said ''the important role will be taken by the opposition to force the Government to make the transition from words to deeds.''

Mr. Iliescu reappointed Prime Minister Petre Roman, right, to run the Government until Parliament forms a new one. They waved to supporters at the ceremony.; Romanians in Bucharest waving the national flag and chanting yesterday in support of Ion Iliescu, who was sworn in as President. (Reuters)

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1499 words

HEADLINE: After Renaissance of the 70's and 80's, Philadelphia Is Struggling to Survive

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 20

 BODY:
The urban renaissance here, marked by the frenzied construction of $5 billion worth of downtown office buildings and the rebuilding of frayed neighborhoods in the 1970's and 80's, is sputtering out. The new urban issue here, as framed by the city's austerity budget for next year, is survival.
''If we raised taxes any more than we did, we would have had to expand the highways to the suburbs for all the moving vans,'' said City Councilman John F. Street, who earlier this month successfully pressed for $65 million in reductions in city services, including programs for the homeless and street cleaning.
Philadelphia's taxes are among the highest in the nation, and are three times those in its suburbs, which have better schools, less crime and many jobs, according to the Pennsylvania Economy League, a nonprofit research group.
 
City Is Facing Insolvency
But without more tax revenue, the city could become insolvent. Some city officials, including the finance director and the controller, say deficits expected in the next year or two could mean severe reductions in city services and could set off a fiscal crisis. 
On June 8, Standard & Poor's, the Wall Street rating agency, reduced the city's bond rating two notches, to the lowest rating, BBB-, held by any major city. St. Louis and Detroit, the two next lowest rated, are rated BBB.
Mayor W. Wilson Goode, whose proposal for more taxes was defeated last month, says the city will be able to hold on until the state comes to its rescue after the fall elections for governor and much of the State Legislature. But incumbents have not shown much eagerness during the campaign season to help Philadelphia.
The city wants to increase revenue by adding taxes on cigarettes and gasoline; creating a new sales tax, and making its wage tax, now about 5 percent for everyone, progressive like Federal taxes. The city needs the Legislature's approval for these changes.
 
A Critical Stage
Urban specialists say most older Northeastern and Midwestern cities share Philadelphia's problems, but they say the problems have reached a critical stage here. ''Sadly enough, Philadelphia is showing the way,'' said George Sternlieb, professor of urban planning at Rutgers University.
''We didn't genuinely redevelop our cities in the seven fat years we just went through,'' Professor Sternleib said, ''so we face some real troubles in the seven lean years ahead. There was a momentary euphoria in downtown monument building in the 1980's, but those monuments are beginning to look like tombstones surrounded by the old crumbling cities.''
Like many other cities, Philadelphia, the nation's fifth largest, is in a desperate competition with its suburbs. More than 400,000 people, largely middle-class whites and blacks, have moved to the suburbs since 1950, when Philadelphia reached a peak population of 2.1 million. The flow out left behind a city with an increasingly poor, elderly and needy population that is about 45 percent black and about 5 percent Hispanic and Asian.
One of every four Philadelphians, including almost half its homeowners, lives below the poverty line. More than 260,000 residents receive public assistance, representing about 40 percent of the state's caseload. The city also produces about half of the prisoners in the state.
 
Decline in Federal Aid
While the city's population has shrunk and become poorer, problems like AIDS, homelessness, drugs and crime have increased rapidly.
Federal aid to Philadelphia declined from more than $250 million in 1981 to $54 million this year. County governments help other Pennsylvania cities like Pittsburgh, but Philadelphia is a county unto itself and, thus, cannot raise revenue from its suburbs.
Nor can the city tax its own residents as it wishes. State law limits the city's taxing authority, said Betsy Reveal, the city's finance director.
''My favorite example,'' she said, ''is that all the Ma and Pa groceries stores paid $3 million in taxes in 1988 while all the banks paid less than $500,000.'' The state limits the revenue taxes Philadelphia can impose on highly regulated business like banks and insurance companies.
Philadelphia has the nation's highest wage tax and the nation's highest transfer tax on real estate sales; both are about 5 percent. In addition, the city has the nation's highest automobile insurance rates, state officials say. People here also pay the highest fares for public transportation and taxi cabs. Housing, however, is relatively inexpensive, averaging $68,500 a house.
 
'An Evacuation Mentality'
Some academics say the city has spun out of control. ''I believe there is a total lack of faith in city government,'' said Jay Lamont, director of the Real Estate Institute at Temple University. ''There is definitely an evacuation mentality that has been accelerating in the last 12 months, particularly in Center City,'' he said, referring to the neighborhoods in and near downtown.
Overall residential real estate sales in the city slowed by 27 percent in the last six months, while sales in Center City slowed by 39 percent, according to the Philadelphia Board of Realtors. ''Our residential phone stopped ringing about last August; it's terrible,'' said Charles F. Seymour, chairman of the Jackson-Cross Company, a brokerage.
The boom of the 1970's and 80's, though dying, is still delivering some good economic news: five new hotels, major highway repairs and a huge convention center that is scheduled to open in 1993. The city has had moderate growth in jobs since 1983, after a 20-year decline, said Ted Hershberg, a professor of public policy at the University of Pennsylvania.
 
Mayor Defends City
Mayor Goode says the city is no worse off than any other major city and is in better condition in some respects, like safety. ''We're responding well to the crisis we find ourselves in,'' he said in a recent interview.
He said the city would be able to weather the financial crisis in the short term by selling property and restructuring debt. But he said the city could not remain ''competitive'' unless its tax system is revamped.
He also defended the quality of city services and challenged assertions of a growing disenchantment. ''I don't think there is an evacuation mentality at all,'' he said. ''Some people, because of crime, want to move, but that's no different than in Boston or New York.''
The city's crime rate increased 15.7 percent last year, the biggest one-year increase since 1980, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In Center City the Philadelphia police report a sharper increase. Even so, Philadelphia has the lowest crime rate of the nation's 10 largest cities, with 6,978 crimes per 100,000 residents.
 
'Situation Is Far Worse'
''The situation is far worse than the statistics show,'' said Craig Snyder. He is director of the Criminal Justice Task Force, a group of city leaders who advocated changes to speed the judicial system, and he is a Center City Republican running for the State House of Representatives this year.
''The fact is that property crime has been legalized in Philadelphia,'' Mr. Snyder said. ''There are 30,000 fugitives on the streets that no one is looking for,'' people who have been arrested for nonviolent crimes and released pending a court hearing because jails are full. Many then do not show up for the hearing.
Even Philadelphians who say they love the city say they hate what has happened. ''My property taxes have quadrupled in the last year and a half, and all I hear from city government is, 'We don't have enough money, we don't have enough money,' '' said Robert Kershaw, president of the Victoria Park Neighborhood Association in Center City.
More reductions in city services are likely this year because the $2.1 billion budget for the fiscal year 1991, which starts July 1, is based on the proposed new sales tax, which the city has no authority to impose but hopes the State Legislature will approve.
The budget also makes no provision for uncontrollable expenses, including pay and benefit increases for city employees and higher borrowing costs. Officials say those expenses could exceed $200 million. In lowering the city's bonding rating, Standard & Poor's said the new budget ''does not bode well for restoration of fiscal stability.'' Moody's Investors Service, the other large rating agency, has already given the city its lowest investment-grade rating and is considering reducing it further.
The reduction in bond rating could increase the city's borrowing costs, possibly by $10 million a year if Moody's also reduces the city's rating, said Ms. Reveal, the city's finance director.
She said the city could become insolvent if unbudgeted expenses rose to $100 million.
''The next 18 to 24 months are real touch and go, but if we get through those rocky waters we should be in for some smooth sailing,'' she said. If, that is, the State Legislature permits Philadelphia to revise its taxes.

HEADLINE: White House Urges $51 Billion Cut in Deficit

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The Bush Administration sought today to initiate serious bargaining with Congressional negotiators on how to cut the 1991 Federal budget deficit, proposing a plan aimed at reducing it by $51 billion.
The proposal, under which most of the cuts would come from reductions in spending for domestic programs, was presented as budget experts on both sides informed the negotiators that the 1991 deficit was now likely to be $20 billion higher, reaching a total of about $160 billion, than projected when preliminary talks began a month ago.
The new estimate does not include the costs of bailing out the savings and loan industry, an effort that will add tens of billions of dollars to Federal spending in the fiscal year 1991, beginning on Oct. 1 The Administration's proposal today came after Democrats on the Congressional negotiating team insisted that the White House make the first move in the bargaining process, warning that if serious negotiations were not under way in the next 10 days the talks might collapse.
 
Reluctance on Both Sides
With the November election campaigns preparing to shift into high gear, both sides have been reluctant to be identified with the kind of spending cuts or tax increases that would be necessary to cut the deficit significantly. 
In any case, lawmakers acknowledged that given the new estimate for a deficit of about $160 billion, even their most ambitious goals for a compromise package of spending cuts and tax increases would leave them far short of the amount needed to bring the deficit down to the $64 billion ceiling set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
Thus, it appeared more likely than ever today that Congress would have to raise that ceiling, although the negotiators pointedly refrained from saying so.
The Administration's proposal was offered in an oral presentation on Capitol Hill by Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director. Precise details were lacking, but the plan calls for the bulk of the $51 billion deficit reduction to come from spending cuts in domestic programs.
The proposal envisons some additional savings in the military budget that President Bush proposed in January, but no additions to the roughly $20 billion in user fees and other revenue increases that the President suggested then, according to Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee.
 
Some Private Complaints
While Democrats responded to the proposal publicly by calling it a starting point for serious talks, they were more critical privately, complaining that it placed too heavy a burden on domestic programs and too little on military programs. They also said it did not address the need for more revenue.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, also expressed concern that the savings envisioned over five years, estimated at $450 billion by Mr. Darman, fell short of the the $500 billion to $600 billion that Democrats have called for.
To complicate matters for the budget negotiators, the new deficit estimates do not include the costs of a bailout of failed savings and loan institutions. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that operating costs for the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency managing the bailout, would add $68 billion to the deficit in 1991, while the Administration said that the bailout cost would add from $23 billion to $43 billion to next year's deficit.
Some lawmakers on the negotiating team said they were stunned when Mr. Darman told them today that the Administration was now estimating the deficit at $159 billion. That is just $3 billion less than the latest estimate by the Congressional Budget Office, whose projections of the deficit have customarily been far higher than the Administration's. Just a month ago, Mr. Darman had told the negotiators that his highest estimate of the deficit was $138 billion.
 
Similar Economic Forecasts
The Administration and the Congressional Budget Office also agreed on assumptions about the economy over the next year, projecting growth of about 2.5 percent, inflation of slightly more that 4 percent and short-term interest rates at just under 7 percent.
But Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told reporters that part of the reason for the unusual concurrence was that his agency had been ordered by lawmakers to assume adoption of a significant defict-cutting package this year.
He said the economic forecast also assumed that the Federal Reserve Board would ease interest rates as a way to cushion the impact that deep spending cuts would have on the economy.
While the Administration and the Congressional Budget Office agreed on the forecast for next year, their projections for 1992 and beyond diverged, with the Administration taking a more optimistic view on growth, inflation and interest rates.
The economic assumptions are a critical factor in projecting the size of the deficit, since changes in unemployment rates, economic growth and inflation influence both the spending for various Government programs and the level of tax collections. Interest rates also have a large impact because they determine how much the Government must pay investors to finance the cost of the national debt.

HEADLINE: Both Parties Fault U.S. on Competitiveness

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
Trying to tap an issue that could figure in campaigns this fall, Democratic and Republican lawmakers today criticized the Bush Administration's policies on economic competitiveness.
Most surprising were the comments of Representative Newt Gingrich, a conservative from Georgia who is the Republican whip in the House of Representatives. Although Mr. Gingrich praised the Administration's efforts to reduce the capital gains tax to create more capital for private investment, he said House Republicans ''would probably be more aggressive and more intense'' than the White House.
Mr. Gingrich said House Republican leaders were seeking ''more activism from the White House.''
Neither the Democrats nor the Republicans provided a cost for their proposals for nurturing American industry, which were released at separate news conferences. The Democrats urged direct Government aid to high-technology companies. The Republicans' package focused on Government strategies like tax incentives and regulatory reform to help create private capital for American companies.
''This Administration has no strategy for dealing with high technology or the global marketplace,'' said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader. ''And this failure means we're losing.''
Mr. Gephardt noted the rift in Republican ranks. ''There is a group in the Republican Party that is ideologically opposed to the Government doing anything to make sure America remains competitive,'' he said, ''but there are many Republicans who want to work with us.''

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Cheering a Flip-Flop

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
When a politician changes his position, he or she is usually derided for a ''flip-flop.'' But here are two cheers for President Bush's about-face decision to help poor countries stop using chemicals destructive to earth's vital ozone shield.
A third cheer will be due when Mr. Bush flip-flops again and decides -as mounting evidence dictates - to take action now against global warming, the so-called ''greenhouse effect.'' Under counseling from his iron-fisted chief of staff, John Sununu, Mr. Bush is so far willing only to call for more study. 
That's like seeing Willie Horton at your front door, and asking him in to state his intentions before you call the cops.
Also on Mr. Sununu's bad advice, the President had welshed on a U.S. pledge to put up $25 million of a fund to help poor nations pay for substitute chemicals more ''ozone-friendly'' -but more expensive - than the damaging chlorofluorocarbons they've agreed to phase out. Under strong international and domestic pressures - including some from within the Administration - Mr. Bush reversed himself and Mr. Sununu last week.
That's not only an ozone-friendly flip-flop; it should also have profitable U.S. economic consequences. Nations like China and India, as they abandon chlorofluorocarbons, will need the substitutes - for instance, in China's home refrigeration program. Those countries alone have 40 percent of the world's population, and thus can offer a substantial market to U.S. manufacturers of chlorofluorocarbon substitutes.
Mr. Bush still is virtually isolated in the world in his reluctance to do anything about global warming. Standing alone, of course, is not necessarily a reason to change; nor is Mr. Sununu wrong that there is scientific uncertainty about the climatic consequences of the steady increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere - an increase that is not in doubt.
The White House has insisted on awaiting an exhaustive study by more than 300 experts on the climate brought together by the United Nations. Last month, however, an ''executive summary'' of the U.N. survey was published in London - and it largely discredited the Sununu-Bush do-nothing policy.
With only a few dissenters, the panel concluded that if worldwide ''business as usual'' continues, the earth's global mean temperature could increase by 5.4 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century. That would produce a global mean sea-level rise of 25 to 26 inches, with significant regional variations.
That's still an informed prediction, not an absolute certainty, since mathematical models of the atmosphere can vary; but it was the most authoritative conclusion yet reached by a credible scientific body. It was good enough, moreover, for Prime Minister Thatcher, who promptly announced her decision to reduce the projected growth of Britain's carbon dioxide emissions, stabilizing them at 1990 levels by the year 2005.
But just cutting the rise in emissions is too little, too late. The United Nations report called for a 60 percent immediate reduction in current greenhouse gas emissions, just to stabilize concentrations of those gases already in the atmosphere. Britain, moreover, emits only about 3 percent of carbon dioxide worldwide; the United States is responsible for about 25 percent.
Meanwhile, in an evenhanded article in next month's Scientific American, Robert M. White, a former chief of the U.S. Weather Bureau, suggests a rational list of high-priority, common-sense actions demanded by what is already known about global warming.
Mr. White, now president of the National Academy of Engineering, concedes the ambiguities of atmospheric models and projections and the seriousness of some scientific reservations. He concludes, nevertheless, that ''a wise course'' would be ''one that recognized uncertainty but would not permit that uncertainty to forestall action.''
He would begin with steps that also make sense ''for other economic and environmental reasons'' - first priority going to energy conservation and efficiency. A shift from coal and oil to natural gas would substantially reduce carbon dioxide emissions; a more drastic move to non-fossil energy sources would be of even greater benefit. Reforestation and forest preservation would help absorb greenhouse gases.
Even such beginning steps will not be easily taken. Mr. White doubts that any policy course can do more than ''retard'' climate warming. And if even that much is to be accomplished, George Bush - or maybe only John Sununu - needs to do another flip-flop, soon.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Hailing Mandela Can Be Easier Than Hailing Cab

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
During the nine years that he has lived in New York, Victor Mashabela has grown accustomed to the vicissitudes of getting a taxicab in Manhattan. ''It's a problem,'' he said. First, Mr. Mashabela figured some cabbies were simply reluctant to go as far as the Bronx, where he lives, from the office building in which he works on Second Avenue in midtown. Then he suspected another motivation. After all, some drivers hadn't even stopped to ask his destination. ''They just pass me by,'' he said. Mr. Mashabela is a 34-year-old black man. He works for the African National Congress in New York. And yesterday while many New Yorkers were hailing Nelson Mandela, the A.N.C.'s deputy president, some of them, simply because they are black, were still having trouble hailing a cab.
Drivers' typical rationale for bypassing them underscores two trends that conspire to make black people disproportionate targets: lingering fears about personal security, which routinely prompt many whites to shun blacks on the statistical grounds that they are predisposed to crime, and racial segregation, which may suggest to a cabby that any neighborhood in which a black passenger is likely to live is one that the driver would rather avoid. 
Legal barriers to integration here were dismantled years ago. Yet while the official policy evoked by the word apartheid no longer exists in this country, the legacy of the word's derivation - the state of being apart - nonetheless endures.
That Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black teen-ager, apparently had no compunctions about going to Bensonhurst, a predominantly white Brooklyn neighborhood, last summer reflected an emerging ubiquity among blacks.
That he was killed by a gang of whites, largely because he was black, suggested that the city may be more like an ill-fitting jigsaw puzzle than the gorgeous mosaic that David N. Dinkins, New York's first black mayor, often celebrates.
In Mr. Dinkins's victory itself last year, blacks hurdled an electoral bar that had been bending inevitably, but slowly, to political gravity. But gains in integrating politics or the work place have not been matched in housing, in particular.
For years, additional blacks were barred from certain city housing projects and high schools to maintain artificially a racial balance acceptable to whites, who are typically more tolerant when they constitute a majority.
While New York is not the nation's most segregated city, by one measure four in five blacks would have to move in order for the races to be randomly distributed in the New York region.
While class and economic differences are factors, ''it's pretty clearly race,'' says Dr. Douglas S. Massey of the University of Chicago's Population Research Center. ''Blacks earning $50,000 or more are almost as segregated as those earning less than $2,500.''
Two years ago, Dr. Richard R. Green was named the city's first black schools chancellor. But he was apparently unable to penetrate another white refuge. Dr. Green and three other black executives - Darwin N. Davis, a senior vice president of Equitable Life Assurance Company; John L. Jones, personnel director of Xerox's American operations, and George Lewis, vice president and treasurer of the Philip Morris Companies - regularly played golf at public courses because, Mr. Davis said, no private country club in Westchester or Fairfield Counties invited them to join. (Mr. Lewis has since joined St. Andrews Golf Club, in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.).
No country clubs are on Mr. Mandela's itinerary this week. Instead, at Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, where more than 9 in 10 students are black, he implored youngsters yesterday to raise money for better schools in South Africa, where parents were alarmed last year when only 42 percent of black high school seniors passed their final examinations.
Of those students who graduated from Boys and Girls last June, only 2.3 percent received Regents-endorsed diplomas. Tonight, Mr. Mandela is to tour Harlem, where the death rate for blacks under the age of 65 is almost three times that of American whites.
To a city drained by recurring rancor from last summer's killing in Bensonhurst, lionizing a hero from abroad offers an uplifting launch to summer, 1990 - more uplifting than hunting villains or parallels at home.
''New York is better than South Africa,'' Seloka Phirwea, of the African National Congress's New York office, said yesterday. ''But there is not unlimited access. It's not legal, but at the same time there is a race problem.
''You can't legislate people's attitudes,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Authorities Release Profile of Gunman Haunted by Zodiac

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
The gunman who the police believe has shot three people since March 8 and is obsessed with the 12 signs of the zodiac is a loner with a limited education who may be acting out of a desire for attention, authorities theorized yesterday.
But a profile prepared by a special police task force also indicated that the publicity the gunman has already received may be enough to satisfy his need for attention. 
''His desire could be satisfied,'' Chief of Detectives Joseph R. Borrelli. ''We may never hear from him again.''
 
Analyzing the Letters
Chief Borrelli said the the task force had enlisted the help of astrologers, graphologists and psychologists to analyze letters and other evidence in an attempt to produce an accurate profile of the gunman, who has wounded three people in an eight-block area of the East New York section of Brooklyn and neighboring Woodside, Queens.
The police say the man has written three cryptic letters with information about the shooting, sending two to the press and leaving one at the scene of the third shooting.
Based on the manner and style of his writing, Chief Borrelli said the task force has reported that the man may be unemployed and may, at best, have a high school diploma.
There have been no witnesses to the shootings and the only description came from a 78-year old man who was using a cane when he was shot on May 31. The man described the gunman as an unkempt man in his early 30's, about 6 feet tall and 180 pounds, with a mustache and beard. In the last shooting, the police said that the gunman wore a Navy watch cap or a ski mask.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Give the Loot to the 'Amateurs'

BYLINE: By Ira Berkow

 BODY:
The $64 million question for the National Collegiate Athletic Association is: What to do with the extra $64 million - or even as much as $75 million - it will receive from its new television basketball contract with CBS?
It was reported yesterday that an N.C.A.A. committee responsible for disbursing some of the revenue obtained through a rich television agreement with CBS made its first recommendations on Monday. But it failed to come up with a formula for distributing the windfall. I have the formula: Give it to the players. Split up those millions among the entertainers themselves who make the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament such a great attraction. The tournament is not an academic event. It is such a high level of entertainment, in fact, that the TV deal calls for the N.C.A.A. member schools to receive $1 billion over the next seven years. 
In round figures, that total looks like this: $1,000,000,000.00.
The players are the ones who labor, who in essence are the employees of the university, and who are generally overworked and underpaid. Even Bear Bryant said these people aren't student athletes. ''They are athletes first and students second,'' said the Bear. That is, they are pros.
It's true that players are given scholarships to school. But in too many cases, they don't get an education. They just get a tuition.
Some will quibble about that, and talk about educational opportunites. But the number of hours needed for sports, and the lesser hours available for studies, hamper the academic pursuits of even those who are truly interested in books.
Others, like Sean Higgins, who just left the University of Michigan after his junior year of eligibility to try his luck in the N.B.A., are, as he said, in school to showcase basketball talents.
Some critics will say, well, aren't there other good areas in the field of education where these millions should go, such as to disadvantaged students, or to teachers, or even to a library? The answer, of course, is yes, and no.
At most universities with big-time sports programs, the athletic department is independent from the rest of the university, and the money it generates often goes right back into a larger and larger program. And when an athletic department does give money to some other needy exponent of the university, it is often news.
Last November, the athletic department of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill donated $100,000 to the general library system on campus. This was so unusual in the athletic course of events around the country, apparently, that it inspired the university to send press releases from coast to coast heralding this largesse.
But in the free-market system, the accepted economic structure of the United States of America, the money that is triggered by the players should go in some equitable part to those who labor for it. They earned it, toiling with success in the basketball vineyards for six months.
Rock stars get their financial due, but revenue-producing college athletes don't. In his article ''Sports and Antitrust'' for the June 1990 issue of the Notre Dame Law Review, Lee Goldman of the University of Detroit Law School notes that in 1987, the Nebraska football team reportedly earned $11 million in revenues, and paid out $150,000 in scholarships. Something's amiss in the system.
The working stiffs should get greater compensation. It's only right, morally, ethically and maybe even legally, as Professor Goldman contends.
Meanwhile, there's $64 million or more floating around. Prof. William L. Silber, in the department of economics and finance at N.Y.U., and Henry Feldman, a Manhattan C.P.A., helped me with the following figures for my idea of disbursement of the minimum $64 million:
If each of the 64 teams in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament has 15 players, then each player in the first round would be guaranteed $48,483.85. The players on the top 16 teams would each receive $96,969.70. The players on the top four teams $193,939.90 apiece.
There are many other ways to break this down, of course, including the players on the No. 1 team getting more than No. 2, and No. 2 getting more than Nos. 3 and 4.
One might also just make it easy and let each of the 64 teams split the $64 million evenly, $1 million for each team. Or allow each of the nearly 300 Division I schools to split the $64 million.
Now, the coaches might holler. But many of them are getting large amounts of money to begin with - as much as $1 million a year from enterprises including TV shows and sneaker deals, which players, as ''amateurs,'' are not allowed to share in. Of course, players could vote their coach a share of their earnings; it's up to their individual sense of generosity, or it depends upon what they will have agreed - or just a greed.
It is, after all, the American way.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 21, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 2; Home Desk

LENGTH: 1045 words

HEADLINE: House of 2 Faces: Prim and Romantic

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTHOLD, L.I., June 15

 BODY:
Perfection it was not.
Four years ago, Douglas Peix purchased an unassuming one-story saltbox, which the previous owners, to borrow a phrase from historic preservationists, had ''remuddled.'' Out went the cutesy shutters, the phony plastic scallop-shell sink, the fake stained wood, the mousy wall-to-wall carpeting and the dreaded dropped ceiling that hid 17th-century beams in the dining room.
In came a folly in the backyard and a two-story porch that Mr. Peix, a partner in the New York architectural firm of Peix & Crawford, describes as ''small-scale monumental.'' 
While architects to the south in the Hamptons are busy building ''modernist houses vying with each other for attention,'' Mr. Peix (pronounced ''pikes'') said, he chose a different route.
He bought the small six-room 1653 house on a quarter acre next to an abandoned orchard and transformed it from a maiden aunt into a tasteful but glamorous belle.
From the street, the house looks like Puritan New England. But behind the clematis-covered trellis in the backyard, it goes wildly romantic. The dual personality suits its architect, who has a passion for the picturesque. ''I've always liked towers,'' he said of the 18-foot-high folly in the backyard. ''I wanted it to be romantic and mysterious, like Rapunzel's tower.''
To create his weekend world-within-a-world, Mr. Peix did not add space. Rather, over four years, he worked with the existing 1,500-square-foot house, prized, he said, because ''it had a lot of character - it leans.'' By tearing down a few unsightly sheds and taking out a few walls, then adding his own imagination plus some unheated space, he altered it forever.
Hedge House - ''I suppose I was looking for alliteration,'' Mr. Peix said - was remodeled at a cost of approximately $58,000. The folly cost about $8,000, and the porch, around $16,000. The house is ''a laboratory,'' the 45-year-old architect said. ''I try to work on things here that clients might say don't make any sense.''
Like many old houses, Mr. Peix's was a warren of little rooms. The first thing he did was to install a window with both stained glass and leaded panes to open up the view in the dining room.
In a move that might seem ornery, he next sealed off the front door, keeping the side door open for visitors. The proximity to the sidewalk was too close for his comfort. A nonworking front door is ''the ultimate solution for warding off door-to-door salespeople,'' he said.
The architect's property is not exactly rambling. To make the yard look bigger, he used a visual trick beloved of Renaissance painters: forced perspective. The lattices and fences that surround the house actually recede, starting at a height of about seven feet and getting slightly shorter toward the back.
Perhaps only an architect could look at a tumbledown shed and see visions of an electric train set. In one of the most dramatic transformations, Mr. Peix tore down the shed and replaced it with a copper-roofed folly inspired by Lionel's rail-yard towers (''I envision a switching mechanism up there,'' he said).
The folly, a device often used by dotty 19th-century British landscape architects, now houses garden tools on the ground floor and a futon and deck chairs in the nook above. It is a cozy, meditative place, ''a place to have a vacation from the house,'' the architect said.
In the summertime, luxurious thickets of clematis snake their way up the sides, adding to the poetic mood. Mr. Peix drew on regional vernacular architectural styles, including clapboard shingles and sloped roofs. Over the steps leading to the top of the folly, there is a birdhouse, a copy of a house Mr. Peix designed in Warren, Conn.
The architect positioned the folly at an angle to the main house, visually expanding the backyard still further. Unaccustomed to follies, dubious local building inspectors, concerned about zoning codes, dropped a tape measure to verify the height. The neighbors are now won over, the architect said, but one fretted that the folly was going to ''look like a border guard tower.''
Inside the house, Mr. Peix rebuilt two living-room fireplaces into one with secondhand bricks. Upstairs, he converted a bedroom into a bathroom and dressing room, adding crown moldings, an old tub and a window by Frank Lloyd Wright for atmosphere. He inserted an octagonal window where two tiny windows used to be.
But chiefly, he redid the kitchen. The architect wanted a double pitched roof, to disguise the flat tract-house slope of the remodeled original. He added an old arched weathered door, a work island and vaguely Viennese beams with cove lighting.
To rebuild the kitchen, he had to tear down another ramshackle shed. Its demolition led to the architectural tour de force: a two-story open-air porch worthy of Tara. The porch was inspired at least in part by economy. ''It's cheaper to build open than enclosed,'' Mr. Peix said. The porch is 12 feet by 12 feet, the same dimensions as the late unsightly shed. It has a red hip roof, as opposed to the driftwood gray familiar on Eastern Long Island. Although small, it feels heroic, due to the presence of a skeletal wall of columns, a sort of classy architectural tick-tack-toe board. It may be the only renovation in America whose look is based on a facade painted by Piero della Francesca in his fresco series, ''The Legend of the True Cross.''
But Mr. Peix added an unabashedly childlike element: a built-in stepladder, which handily transports the intrepid architect upward to the gutters and skylight, an idea borrowed from an Off Broadway theater. ''I didn't want to have to drag a ladder out to do the cleaning,'' he said.
The porch is now an outdoor living room, complete with ceiling fan. Sitting there, overlooking a garden filled with herbs, blueberry bushes, arborvitae, peonies, foxgloves and poppies, it feels both monumental and intimate, a ''juxtapostion of formal and informal,'' the architect said.
The house keeps its historic character while accommodating its architect's yen for innovation. As with all houses, there is a moral to the story. You might think of it as ''The Little House That Could.''
''Spend money on doors and windows,'' Mr. Peix advised. ''Even a simple house can be wonderful.''

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Vision Beyond the New Gilded Age

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

The Politics of Rich and Poor
Wealth and the American Electorate in the Reagan Aftermath
By Kevin Phillips
Illustrated. 262 pages. Random House. $19.95.
In his first book, ''The Emerging Republican Majority'' (1969), Kevin Phillips correctly predicted the coming conservative era in American national politics. Now, two decades later, in a book that he might well have called ''The Emerging Democratic Majority'' but that he has chosen instead to name ''The Politics of Rich and Poor: Wealth and the American Electorate in the Reagan Aftermath,'' Mr. Phillips predicts that in the 1990's the pendulum will swing back again and a shift to more liberal politics will ensue. 
This will happen, he reasons, because wealth has become too concentrated as a result of the Reagan era's policies. ''The 1980's were a second Gilded Age,'' he writes, ''in which many Americans made and spent money abundantly. Yet as the decade ended, too many stretch limousines, too many enormous incomes and too much high fashion foreshadowed a significant shift of mood. A new plutocracy - some critics were even using the word 'oligarchy' - had created a new target for populist reaction.''
The pendulum must swing because it has in the past, he states. Though Mr. Phillips warns against making too much of ''historical parallels,'' he can't resist comparing the 1980's to the Gilded Age and the Roaring Twenties, each of which resembled the other in 10 significant ways (''conservative politics,'' ''difficulties for labor,'' ''tax reduction,'' ''concentration of wealth,'' and so forth), and each of which was followed by eras of relative progressivism.
''Lacking a hereditary aristocracy or Establishment,'' he writes, ''our leadership elites and the alignment of wealth are more the product of political cycles than elsewhere.'' As he concludes, ''The genius of American politics - failing only in the Civil War - has been to manage through ballot boxes and electoral votes the problems that less fluid societies resolve with party structures geared to class warfare and even with barricades.''
How will the next shift occur and what will it bring? Mr. Phillips - who has also written ''Mediacracy: American Parties and Politics in the Communications Age,'' ''Post-Conservative America'' and ''Staying on Top: The Business Case for a National Industrial Strategy'' - scrupulously avoids predictions.
Instead he concentrates most of his book on analyzing exactly how the Reagan Presidency altered the nation's economic landscape. He shows, for instance, how ''it takes a decade or more for the G.O.P. to shift from broad middle-class 'nationalism' into 'capitalist overdrive,' '' and how Richard Nixon, ''an altogether middle-class figure,'' did not ''unleash capitalism'' nearly to the extent that Ronald Reagan did.
He examines closely the traditional Republican methods of disinflation, limited government, less regulation of business, reduced taxation and high interest rates by which wealth was concentrated during the Reagan era, and he shows how the resulting shift of a few percentage points in the share of income held by the top 1 percent of Americans led to ''the emergence of four dozen U.S. billionaires . . . with a supporting cast of a hundred thousand decamillionaires.'' This represented ''a plutographic revolution comparable to that of the late 19th century.''
Finally, he analyzes who was hurt because of the shift in income, and concludes that it was young people, women, blacks, union members and farmers, precisely the makings of a revived Democratic coalition.
His analysis is compelling, if occasionally tedious in its poring over statistics and charts. If it seems odd that he now appears on the side of the Democrats where he once served as chief political analyst for the 1968 Republican Presidential campaign, one can only conclude that he shares the vision of the economist Joseph Schumpeter, who, Mr. Phillips writes, viewed capitalism as being ''profoundly unconservative by any standard except its respect for market forces and moneymaking.'' As Mr. Phillips concludes: ''Populists and progressives are not alone in opposing the 'malefactors of great wealth.' ''
His analysis is also a little frightening. According to the chart in which he compares three Republican ''heyday periods,'' the Gilded Age ended with the Panic of 1893 and ''subsequent depression,'' the Roaring Twenties ended with the Crash of 1929 and ''subsequent depression,'' and the 1980's ended with the ''Crash of 1987, mini-crash of 1989 and relevant events of the 1990's.'' This sounds ominous, to say the least.
Of course, one might seek comfort in the one significant way that, in Mr. Phillips's analysis, the 1980's have differed from the earlier heyday periods of capitalism - namely, the creation of the enormous national deficit and the consequent raising of foreign countries' stakes in the country's fortunes. Perhaps the increasing foreign ownership of America's property and resources will help to soften the impact of what Mr. Phillips refers to so chillingly as the ''relevant events of the 1990's''?
Mr. Phillips doesn't hold out that hope. He merely speaks slightingly of the way we have been selling our birthright: ''Policies of sharp tax-bracket reductions, unprecedented Federal deficits and borrowing at high real interest rates, along with deregulation, permissive finance, massive borrowing overseas and consequent sales of U.S. assets and companies, accelerated America's relative economic decline beyond what would have occurred in a less avaricious environment.''
And his final words leave the reader up in the air: ''What would develop . . . remained to be seen. But normally optimistic Americans spoke of the future with foreboding, and the decade ended as it had begun: amid a rising imperative for a new political and economic outlook, and with the imminent prospect of a very different chapter in the annals of the wealth and power of the United States.''

THE ECONOMY
 
The savings bailout effort has a high potential for fraud and abuse, Government officials and real estate experts say. LENGTH: 782 words

HEADLINE: Leadership Changing At Chase

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
In a changing of the guard that reflects the ascendancy of the consumer banking business, the Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that Willard C. Butcher, chairman, would be replaced by Thomas G. Labrecque, president, and that Arthur F. Ryan would become the new president.
The changes, which will be effective at the end of October, were not surprising but were announced sooner than planned. Mr. Labrecque, 51 years old, has been president and Mr. Butcher's heir apparent for nine years. Mr. Ryan's success at developing Chase's consumer banking businesses had made him a favorite for the No. 2 job.
Mr. Butcher said the changes were announced several months earlier than expected in order to precede a major revamping and cost-cutting program in the bank's corporate finance businesses. ''We wanted to make the line of succession clear and avoid speculation,'' Mr. Butcher said. ''We now have a man of judgment in Labrecque and a great implementor in Ryan.'' 
Arthur P. Sotor, a banking analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said, ''The promotion of Art Ryan is a reminder of the fact that Chase and Citibank, two of the biggest wholesale banks in the country, are today making as much or more profit from their retail activities than from the traditional banking activities with corporations.''
 
Branch Network Improves
Under Mr. Ryan, Chase improved its branch network in New York City and greatly expanded consumer financial businesses like credit cards, student and mortgage loans, and automobile leasing. During 1989 those activities and others included in the individual banking group earned more than $300 million, or about half the profit the company would have earned had it not taken special charges to cover things like troubled loans to less developed countries.
''Nobody will ever mistake me for an expert in mergers and acquisitions or a credit officer,'' Mr. Ryan said. But he added that earlier in his career, when he was head of the data processing area, he became familiar with the basic operations of corporate lending and other areas of the bank.
A quick-smiling, fast-talking executive who will admit to a more than occassional urge for a cigarette, Mr. Ryan, 47, was born in Brooklyn and has a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Providence College in Rhode Island.
Mr. Labrecque, who many analysts credit as the executive most responsible for the decisions to expand retail banking activities and tighten expense controls, has been a prominent executive since the mid-1970's when he was involved in New York City's financial crisis. Tall and smooth talking, Mr. Labrecque has spoken frequently about the need for American banks to have broader powers in the securities and insurance businesses.
Mr. Labrecque said that as chairman, ''My primary focus will be the strategic and competitive positioning of the bank, corporate financial management, and helping Art on the day to day issues.''
Mr. Butcher, 63, who succeeded David Rockefeller as chairman of Chase in 1981, led the bank during a decade when its traditional strength as a lender to businesses was hard hit by competition from foreign banks and the shift by large corporations to raising money in the securities markets rather than borrowing from banks.
Besides reductions in personnel and other expenses in the corporate finance or wholesale lending part of the bank, Mr. Butcher said, ''We have to deal with some real estate things.'' As a major lender for commercial real estate projects, analysts expect that Chase has been hit in recent months with a large increase in problem loans, which will require it to set aside addtional reserves to cover losses.
 
Pending Changes
The three executives declined to comment on the reorganization at Chase, except to say that it is pending. Analysts say they expect the banking company to announce major cuts in employment, concentrating on its wholesale lending business in the United States and Europe. Chase, which is currently the second-largest banking company in the country behind Citicorp, may also announce the sale of some assets or even whole businesses.
The retail banking business, which has been growing by more than 15 percent annually, is not expected to be much affected by the revamping. With profits of about $1 for every $100 of assets, the retail banking businesses managed by Mr. Ryan earn a return of about 20 percent on the equity capital needed to operate them.
The star of the retail banking business is Chase's credit card business. Mr. Ryan has pushed the business to higher profits by overseeing the development of computerized systems to spot risky customers and reduce the transaction costs.

HEADLINE: House Unit Votes Curb On Insurers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The House Judiciary Committee approved legislation today that would strip insurance companies of most of their exemptions from antitrust law.
The approval was the first a Congressional committee had ever given to any amendment to the 45-year-old McCarran-Ferguson Act, which gives the insurance industry protection from the antitrust restrictions that apply to other industries.
The measure is not likely to become law this year, but the committee's action indicated that the issue is expected to be a hot one in Congress next year.
''The Judiciary Committee has crafted a bill that will allow the brisk winds of competition to blow in the insurance industry,'' said Representative Jack Brooks, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee and chief sponsor of the legislation. 
He said his measure would lead to lower rates and better coverage for consumers.
The insurance industry vigorously opposes the bill, mainly on the ground that unlike most other businesses that are free of regulation, its prices and products are regulated by state agencies.
 
Supported by Democrats
The committee approved the bill by a vote of 19 to 17. All the votes in favor of the measure came from Democrats. Three Democrats joined the panel's 14 Republicans in voting against it.
Congressional aides said Mr. Brooks would bring the bill before the full House for a vote this year if a preliminary nose count showed it would pass. The close vote in his committee probably reflects the division of the House as a whole, and aides on both sides of the question said they could not predict how such a vote would go.
In any event, a vote in the Senate is not scheduled this year. A subcommittee is holding a series of hearings and plans to hold more next year.
That means that even if the House passes the measure this year, the bill will die and will have to be reintroduced in a new Congress next year.
The McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945 exempts insurance companies from all rules against monopolies except for acts of ''intimidation, coercion and boycotts.'' In practice, that has meant that companies selling casualty and liability insurance, primarily automobile and homeowner policies, have been free to share data and set prices among themselves. Life insurance companies for the most part do not do this.
 
Challenged by Consumers
Consumer groups have long contended that the exemption was unjustified. But the insurance lobby, which has representatives in every Congressional district, is one of the most influential in Washington, and the industry has been able to thwart all previous attempts to rewrite the law.
The bill was given political impetus by a revolt in many states in recent years against the high cost of insurance. California voters, for example, approved a referendum two years ago that rolled back automobile insurance rates. Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, who was elected last November, made an attack on the insurance industry a centerpiece of his campaign.
The Brooks bill would outlaw price-fixing and the allocation of markets by regions. It would also prohibit the common practice of tying the sale of one form of insurance to another. Some companies, for example, will not sell automobile insurance to a customer unless that customer also buys a homeowner policy.
 
Democrats' Strategy
One of the reasons many Democrats in the House would like to bring the Brooks bill to a vote this year, even though it stands no chance of becoming law, is to force Republicans into what might be an uncomfortable vote on the side of the industry.
David Farmer, who heads the Washington office of the Alliance of American Insurers, one of the main industry lobbying organizations, said today that the bill would not result in lower rates for consumers. Insurance rates, he argued, are ''driven by losses, and this bill does nothing to address the rising cost of medical care, safer cars or tougher highway enforcement standards.''
Mr. Farmer said consumers profited from the ''economies of scale'' that resulted from insurers working together. Moreover, he said, insurance companies deserve an antitrust exemption because they are required by state regulators to offer certain lines of unprofitable coverage, like policies for poor drivers, and to participate in pools in which successful companies cover the losses of those that go out of business.
He said the industry would fight the legislation vigorously.
On the other side, J. Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, said insurance companies had become ''the Eastern Europe of American enterprise.''
The practical effect of the Brooks bill, he said, would be to spur the growth of more efficient companies and ''reduce prices over time as competition takes hold.''

HEADLINE: Fed Report Sees Growth As Sluggish

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The economy is continuing to grow sluggishly, although the construction sector appears to be weakening, the Federal Reserve said today in releasing results of a survey of its 12 district banks.
''The tone of district reports suggests continued slow growth in the economy with little change in the underlying inflation rate,'' a summary of the survey said.
The results of the survey, completed June 8, were similar to those of three others this year that found slow but continued economic expansion, with moderate inflation. 
The survey was conducted by the Cleveland district bank for use at the meeting on July 2 and 3 by the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy.
 
Worry About Tight Credit
The Fed has kept a tight grip on credit to slow the economy and reduce inflationary pressure. Some officials and economists say the economy has slowed too much and could slide into recession if the Fed does not loosen its grip.
One sign of sluggishness, the survey found, was ''very little growth, if not a decline, in real consumer spending for durable and nondurable goods this quarter from last.'' Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Retail sales, about half of consumer spending, fell in May for the third consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported last week. The last time that retail sales declined for three straight months was in the fall of 1981, during the last recession.
''Both residential and nonresidential construction have been edging downward in recent months in most districts,'' the survey said, ''and indicators of future construction suggest further softening.''
 
Excess Supply of Office Space
The report said, ''An underlying problem in commercial construction is an apparent excess supply of new office space in many parts of the country,'' particularly downtown Manhattan and in metropolitan areas of the Dallas district.
Credit demand appears to be easing, while real estate, consumer and business loans are still growing, although at reduced rates, the report said.
''Lenders are reported to have tightened standards, especially for real estate loans, but there is still little information that suggests credit restraint is spreading to other markets,'' the survey found.
 
Manufacturing Sector Flat
It reported that manufacturing production has been relatively flat for several months. This sector has been particularly affected by the Fed's high-interest rate policies, since many of its products are purchased with loans.
Automobile and related industries have been a drag on manufacturing in the Atlanta district, but Chicago and Cleveland respondents noted some strengthening in production.
''In contrast, the aerospace industry is a source of strength in several regions of the country (Boston, Minneapolis and San Francisco) and the energy sector is expanding (Dallas and Kansas City),'' it added.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 1.74 Points on Sluggish Volume

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices ended the day with a thin gain, after rising in early trading and then quickly falling. Volume continued to be sluggish.
By closing time, the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 2,895.30, up 1.74 points. Volume rose slightly, to 137.42 million shares, from 134.9 million the day before, with 777 issues down and 668 ahead. 
The big drag on the stock and bond market appeared to be yesterday's survey of economic conditions around the country as reported in the so-called beige book from the nation's 12 Federal Reserve banks.
''The tone of district reports,'' said the Federal Reserve's summary of the findings, ''suggests continued slow growth in the economy with little change in the underlying inflation rate.''
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said, ''What they're saying is that economic conditions are weakening and the beige book is confirming that. The upshot is that economic weakness is accumulating and inflation is becoming less of a concern.''
Gains among the 30 industrial blue chips were relatively minor. Alcoa - up 1, to 66 - was the only stock in the group to gain as much as a point. Alcoa officials said they knew of no reason to account for the rise.
Upjohn, the pharmaceutical company and long a rumored takeover target, rose 2 1/8, to 42 1/8, in heavy trading. Schering-Plough, another often-rumored takeover candidate, rose 1, to 46, also in heavy trading.
 
Haven in Drug Stocks
Schering's chairman, Robert P. Luciano, told analysts that the company expected earnings this year to rise at least 18 percent. But drug stocks are a traditional haven during uncertain times and volume in drug stocks yesterday was particularly strong.
Abbott Labs rose 1, to 40, with more than one million shares traded after Mimi Cutler Willard, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton, recommended the stock. Bausch & Lomb rose 1, to 65 3/4. Warner Lambert rose 1 5/8, to 63. Johnson & Johnson gained 7/8, to 64 5/8.
Nike, which makes athletic shoes, rose 2 5/8, to 77 5/8, in heavy trading after Heidi Steinberg, who follows the stock at Salomon Brothers, recommended it on price weakness and because she expected strong profits this year.
On the Amex, Binks Manufacturing rose 2 1/4, to 42, on news of a takeover bid. Kelso Management, which owns 7.7 percent, said an unidentified Chicago company had offered much more than the $45 earlier bid by the Illinois Tool Works.
