HEADLINE: House Panel Approves Measure on Penny Stocks

BYLINE: By GREGORY A. ROBB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
A House subcommittee today approved by voice vote a measure that calls for increased Federal oversight of the penny stock market.
The legislation is a compromise version of a bill that would have banned certain types of penny stock practices considered abusive but that still increases the amount of information available to investors.
Congressional aides predicted that it would now move quickly through the House. But they said it was still unclear whether the Senate would pass the measure. The legislation was approved today by the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance with little debate. 
 
Powers for S.E.C. Voted
In a separate vote, the subcommittee, as expected, approved a package of new enforcement powers for the Securities and Exchange Commission. That bill would allow the commission to seek monetary fines for Federal securities law violations besides insider trading and would give the agency the power to impose temporary cease-and-desist orders.
Penny stocks are low-priced securities that trade over the counter but are not listed on the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations system. They trade chiefly in the so-called pink sheets, the printed listings of brokers' offers to buy and sell that are distributed daily among dealers in the stocks.
The S.E.C. and the National Association of Securities Dealers had opposed the provisions of the original penny stock bill as unneccessary because they believed that significant progress had been made by Federal and state regulators in policing the industry.
 
Objections Removed
Since the bill was introduced, negotiations among the staffs of the parties involved have led to changes, and the securities commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers removed their objections to the current measure.
Under the legislation passed today, the S.E.C., which had been seeking more flexibility to set rules governing penny stocks, was given the power to pass rules increasing the amount of information that penny stock brokers must disclose to their clients.
The original measure would have banned ''blind pool'' and ''blank check'' offerings, which allow only cursory disclosure of business plans and which critics say are a common vehicle for fraud and abuse, but the S.E.C. felt that such a ban would have curtailed legitimate capital-raising by small companies and the commission sought the power instead to increase disclosure.
A ''blank check'' company proposes to sell stock to the public and use the investors' money to shop around for some other business to buy. No business plans or details are provided. A ''blind pool'' offering simply indicates the general sector of the economy in which investments will be made.
In addition, the bill restricts use of the proceeds raised from such ''blind pool'' and ''blank check'' offerings until the issuer gives details about how the money will be used and shareholders will be able to rescind their stock purchases if they are not pleased with the decisions.
In another area of compromise, the new bill instructs the S.E.C. to facilitate the development of an electronic trading system for penny stocks instead of mandating such a system.
The N.A.S.D. had opposed a measure in the original bill that would have mandated that it review all penny stock offerings. This measure was shelved. Instead, the S.E.C. will report to Congress in one year about the adequacy of all stock exchange and N.A.S.D. rules relating to penny stocks.
''What we've tried to draft here is a laser beam piece of legislation, zeroing in on the penny stock market,'' said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, the chairman of the subcommittee and a co-sponsor of the bill.

HEADLINE: A Savings Fiasco in Texas Ends at a Fire-Sale Price

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 21

 BODY:
In the mid-1980's the Stonebridge Ranch, a 6,250-acre development planned as a sprawling community of million-dollar homes, scenic golf courses and 13 man-made lakes, symbolized the vigor of the North Texas economy and the optimism of the aggressive savings and loan that poured an estimated $330 million into buying and upgrading the property.
The Federal Government on Wednesday agreed to sell Stonebridge Ranch, 30 miles north of Dallas, to a Japanese industrialist for $61 million. The savings and loan that once backed the development so eagerly was seized by the Government 18 months ago, after it was declared insolvent. The losses of nearly $270 million will be paid for by the American taxpayer.
The sale is a striking example of the losses the Government is likely to face as it sells off the real estate it has seized from insolvent savings and loans - a crucial element in the Federal bailout of the industry. 
''We taxpayers aren't going to realize anything close to our cost in Stonebridge and hundreds of other similar projects,'' said Frederick E. Roe, a Dallas investment manager. ''It's probably typical of what we can expect in the future.''
The short history of how Stonebridge Ranch absorbed and then lost so much money is a story of the unrestrained ambition of local developers, heedless lending by aggressive savings executives, and the connections between the two groups.
 
Prominent Shareholders
In this case, the story includes politically prominent Texas businessmen who were important shareholders in the savings and loan that backed the development: Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic Party during the Carter Administration; his son, Richard C. Strauss, and J. Livingston Kosberg, a nursing home owner and an active fund-raiser for the Democratic Party in Texas.
Although their roles have been examined by regulators, none of the three have been charged with misconduct in the failure of the Gibraltar Savings Association and its parent, the First Texas Financial Corporation, or in the losses suffered by Stonebridge Ranch.
The new owner of Stonebridge Ranch, assuming a bankruptcy court approves, is Yukio Kitano, an industrialist in Osaka, who has large real estate holdings in Hawaii. Real estate experts said it was the largest investment by any Japanese business in Texas real estate.
Mr. Kitano's agent, George Meyer, said his client hopes to persuade Japanese manufacturers to put American operations at the site. He said that part of the site is zoned for light industry and that the Government had kept the property in ''beautiful condition'' since taking control of it. ''There's not a blade of grass out of place,'' he said.
He said Mr. Kitano visited the site for the first time last week. ''He could see the possibilities, and he just loved it,'' Mr. Meyer said.
The area is near a cluster of offices of American corporations. The J. C. Penney Company is building its new corporate headquarters within 15 minutes of Stonebridge Ranch. Sprawling suburban office complexes of large companies, including the Frito-Lay division of Pepsico Inc., the Electronic Data Systems division of the General Motors Corporation and Texas Instruments Inc. also are nearby.
Mr. Kitano won the right to buy Stonebridge in a competitive auction. Other bidders included the Mobil Corporation and H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer entrepreneur.
 
Government Defends Price
For its part, the Government says that given today's real estate market in Texas, the price was reasonable.
''The sales price we received is a good indication of the market value of the asset,'' said Frank Campagna, a Government official who has acted as manager of the project.
The 270 homeowners living at Stonebridge Ranch have apparently suffered little from the development's financial troubles. The sidewalks, roads, golf courses, hiking trails and lakes are already built. The development is designed for some 27,000 homes and apartments, with the management company selling land to private contractors, who then build homes on the lots. Since it opened in 1988, the prices of lots sold to home builders have risen somewhat.
Still, by the time the project opened the development funds were already sunk into the Stonebridge Ranch and real estate prices had plunged from the levels of a few years earlier.
 
A Symbol of Ambition
Stonebridge Ranch was the most ambitious real estate undertaking that executives and owners of Gibraltar Savings conceived for the fast-growing Texas economy in the early 1980's.
Mr. Kosberg had acquired Gibraltar and the First Texas Savings Association by 1983 and soon handed to Richard Strauss, a real-estate developer and member of the First Texas board, the responsibility for transforming Stonebridge from thousands of blueprints into a gleaming reality.
The younger Mr. Strauss, fortified with a loan of more than $100 million from Gibraltar, outbid Mr. Perot for the Stonebridge property in 1984.
Real estate professionals said Mr. Strauss, who headed a real estate subsidiary that was wholly owned by Gibraltar, paid $17,000 an acre at a time when nearby parcels were finding buyers at more than $30,000 an acre.
The North Texas economy was booming along with the finance, military and aerospace industries, and this prairie farmland far beyond North Dallas was considered some of the most valuable in the state.
Gibraltar later financed $150 million in improvements that included two high-quality golf courses, a beach and tennis club, an equestrian center, 13 lakes and more than five miles of hiking and biking trails. In all, the savings institution had approximately $330 million in loans to Stonebridge, according to people in the Dallas real estate industry.
But Gibraltar's big dreams for Stonebridge collapsed with the Texas economy in 1986, as oil prices plunged and the staggering oversupply of office space, housing and other developed real estate became apparent. By the time Stonebridge offered its first homes for sale in 1988, Gibraltar was nearly insolvent.
 
A Deal With Perelman
Federal regulators seized Gibraltar Savings and First Texas Savings in the waning hours of 1988, and sold them along with three other institutions as one new institution to a group headed by Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Inc.
The Perelman group paid $315 million to the Government for the new institution, First Gibraltar Savings. First Gibraltar, with $12 billion in deposits, is now the largest savings institution in Texas.
The Government estimated the net worth of the institutions combined to create First Gibraltar at a negative $866 million, with most of the losses recorded from troubled loans at Gibraltar Savings and First Texas Savings. That figure would include the loss estimates from the more than $300 million in loans to Stonebridge Ranch. The total cost to taxpayers of the First Gibraltar rescue has been estimated at $5.1 billion over 10 years.
The Perelman group never played a role at Stonebridge Ranch. Control over the Gibraltar subsidiary that owned the project, the Ranch Development Company, was transferred by regulators to the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.
When Congress ordered the disolution of that agency last year, Stonebridge Ranch and thousands of other properties acquired from insolvent savings institutions were transferred to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. That agency managed the sale of such seized properties until the Resolution Trust Corporation was created last August.
 
Arrangement Is Criticized
After Gibraltar's demise, the Government retained Richard Strauss as manager at Stonebridge Ranch. Henry S. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee, last year criticized what he termed Mr. Strauss's ''sweetheart'' contract to manage Stonebridge.
That and other public criticism appeared to have persuaded regulators not to accept Mr. Strauss's offer to buy Stonebridge last year. M. Danny Wall, who was then the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, had reached a tentative deal for the Government to sell the property to Mr. Strauss last June. In September, Mr. Strauss withdrew the bid.
Mr. Strauss's company was dropped as manager of Stonebridge in March, when regulators put the Ranch Development Company into a reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The Club Corporation of America, the largest manager of golf, tennis and dining clubs in the nation, has operated Stonebridge for the last three months.
For his part, Mr. Strauss says he remains an active developer in Texas. According to business associates, his life style and spending habits have not changed noticeably because of the financial reverses of Stonebridge and Gibraltar Savings.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
2 Germanys Adopt Unity Treaty And Guarantee Poland's Borders

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, June 21

 BODY:
The Parliaments of the two Germanys adopted matching measures moving them another step closer to union today, one a resolution guaranteeing Poland's existing borders and the other the treaty on monetary and economic union.
The outcome of the votes was never in doubt, but both measures carried a burden of hope, anxiety and controversy. The debate in both Parliaments was at times strident and emotional.
The sessions in Bonn and East Berlin also marked the first time that the Parliaments approved matching measures, and the act joined a flurry of activities that gave a sense of quickening momentum to unity. 
The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and the two Germanys are to meet Friday for the second ministerial session of the ''two plus four'' talks at which the foreign powers are negotiating an end to limitations on German sovereignty left from World War II.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d of the United States arrived in West Berlin today and met with the foreign ministers of West Grrmany and East Germany, Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Markus Meckel.
After his meeting with Mr. Meckel, he urged the ''two plus four'' participants not to let their deliberations fall behind the speeding pace of unification.
''It is important that there not be a hiatus between internal unification, that is, political and economic unification of the two Germanys, and a resolution of the external aspects of unification,'' Mr. Baker said.
The main issue before the talks has become finding a way of extricating East Germany from its military and economic links to the Soviet Union.
So far, Moscow has opposed letting a united Germany join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. There are rumors of a large Western aid package for the Soviet Union in exchange for its endorsement of unification.
 
Monetary Union on July 1
Then on July 1, the monetary and economic union is scheduled to take effect. While the measure will enable East Germans to exchange their money for West German marks, it is also expected to cause many East German enterprises to collapse, creating at least a temporary surge of unemployment.
Forming a backdrop to these developments has been Chancellor Helmut Kohl's new effort to advance the first all-German election, and so reunification, to December.
Addressing the West German lawmakers during their 13-hour session, Mr. Kohl said, ''Rarely in its history has the German Parliament faced such important decisions as the ones confronting us today.''
He said both sides would have to make sacrifices for the goal of unity. But if economic union was delayed any further, he said, a flood of East Germans to West Germany would resume and ''this would have meant the immediate collapse of the G.D.R.''
The comment was in part a sally at the Social Democrats, who fought a hard internal battle after their standard-bearer, Oskar Lafontaine, proposed opposing the treaty.
His stance threatened a split when a majority in the party leadership declared that opposing the treaty would arouse considerable resentment in East Germany.
 
'Incalculable Risks'
In the end, the Social Democrats decided to vote for the treaty, but a bloc of 25 members broke ranks and voted against it. ''We do not want to take responsibility for the incalculable risks of this policy,'' said Peter Glotz, spokesman for the group.
The treaty was ratified by a vote of 445 in favor, 60 against and one abstention. It now goes to the upper house for final adoption.
The debate was equally emotional in East Berlin, where the treaty was passed by a vote of 302 to 82 with 1 abstention.
Most of the opposition was from the Communist Party of Democratic Socialism, whose leader, Gregor Gysi, was jeered when he spoke of the measure as an ''act of violence'' that would touch off social unrest.
When the vote was announced, members of the governing coalition embraced one another on the floor while the opposition sat in glum silence. Richard Schroder, floor leader of the Social Democrats, declared the treaty ''the second act of our revolution.''
 
Loss of Lands Condemned
There was less debate on the Polish border resolution. But in his speech Mr. Kohl delivered a strong condemnation of the postwar border shift that transferred a broad stretch of German land to Poland and resulted in the expulsion of millions of Germans.
The issue became a heated dispute earlier this year when Poland demanded that the two Germanys guarantee that a united Germany would not claim the territories.
Mr. Kohl initially resisted, largely for fear of alienating the powerful lobby of the Germans expelled from those territories, but he retreated before an international outcry and agreed to the matching resolutions that were adopted today.
''Let no one be mistaken,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''Today we face an absolutely clear choice. Either we confirm the existing border, or we gamble away the chance of German unity.''
But he also voiced considerable sympathy for those who had been expelled, whom he described as people ''forced to pay a high price for crimes committed by others, without being guilty themselves.''
 
'A Grave Injustice'
''The truth is - and this should not be suppressed on a day such as this -the expulsion of the Germans from their native regions was a grave injustice,'' Mr. Kohl declared. ''There was no justification, either moral or legal. Nor can we say decades later that it was legitimate.''
The resolution approved by the Parliaments also cited both Poles and Germans as victims. It noted that the Poles were ''subjected to terrible suffering by the crimes that were committed by Germans and in the name of Germans.'' But it also said that ''a great injustice was done to millions of Germans who were expelled from well-rooted homes.''
The resolution affirmed the existing border along the Oder and Neisse rivers, and called on a unified Germany to finally confirm them in a treaty.
It passed in the West German Parliament by a vote of 487 in favor, 15 against and 3 abstentions. Most of the negative votes were Christian Democrats representing organizations of the expelled people. The vote in East Germany was 361 in favor, 6 against and 18 abstentions.
In the debate on the resolution, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher declared that ''West Germany and its government are giving up nothing that had not already been lost long ago, lost as a result of a criminal war and a criminal system.''
The resolutions predictably drew bitter comments from representatives of the expelled Germans. Herbert Czaja, head of the main organization of Germans who fled or were driven from their homes, said it was ''bitter that the expellees were expected almost exclusively to bear a special sacrifice for the whole of the people.''

HEADLINE: Arabs Split in Reaction to Bush's Move on P.L.O.

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, June 21

 BODY:
The United States decision to suspend contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization produced forecasts today of increased violence from many Palestinian and Arab commentators, but some Arab nations sought to dampen the furor with more muted expressions.
In formal statements, Egypt and Jordan registered ''regret'' over the United States decision, announced yesterday by President Bush, and said that they hoped the discussion would soon resume.
Westerners said that Egypt in particular seemed to be signaling both to the Arab world and to the United States that it still supported efforts to reach a peaceful settlement of the Middle East conflict and that it hoped for continued Washington engagement in peace efforts.
''While welcoming the U.S. Administration's emphasis on the importance of Palestinian participation in establishing peace, Egypt hopes that this suspension of the U.S.-Palestinian dialogue will be lifted as soon as possible,'' President Hosni Mubarak's office said in a statement. 
Diplomats said that Egypt had sought to avert a suspension of the contacts.
 
A Raid Attempt Is Key Issue
Mr. Bush said that the decision had become necessary because the P.L.O.'s chairman, Yasir Arafat, failed to meet American demands that he specifically condemn an attempted Palestinian raid on Israeli beaches and that he punish Abbul Abbas, the head of a small P.L.O. faction that took responsibility for the assault.
Mr. Arafat and senior P.L.O. officials in the organization's Executive Committee gathered in Baghdad today to discuss the move by Washington. But there was no immediate word on their conclusions.
Egypt is the most prominent Arab ally of the United States in regional diplomacy and receives $2.3 billion a year in economic and military aid to fortify its position as the only Arab nation at peace with Israel.
Despite Cairo's cautiously worded statement, some officials and diplomats said senior policy-makers were angered by the United States decision. The suspension of the discussion is viewed among Arab analysts as likely to bring to a complete halt the faltering peace effort of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
''Everyone will be locked in immobility for the next few months,'' said Tahsin Bashir, an authoritative Egyptian commentator.
 
'Whole Situation Sliding'
A Westerner said that Egypt ''sees the whole situation sliding and is trying to get a hold of it.''
But it was unclear how Cairo would revive its role as a moderator and diplomatic conduit between Arab countries, the P.L.O. and the United States.
''From the Egyptian side, it's going to be hard for them to engage the P.L.O.,'' the Westerner added.
For the last 18 months, since Mr. Arafat renounced terrorism and acknowledged Israel's right to exist, Egypt has championed Washington peace moves in the Middle East.
But, as diplomacy has faltered, Cairo has lost ground to more strident forces demanding a tougher line toward Israel, and those forces have been strengthened by several United States decisions seen by many Arabs as shielding Israel and its effort to crush the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
That, in turn, has led to a surge in anti-American sentiment and frequent forecasts that Arab and Palestinian frustrations at the failure of the peace strategy will lead to violence.
 
'Violence and Extremism'
''We hold the United States responsible for the violence and extremism which will sweep the region as a result of this decision,'' Salah Khalaf, a senior P.L.O. official, said in Tunis.
Mr. Arafat is said by his advisers to be caught between Washington's demands and an increasingly vociferous Palestinians demanding more militant policies now that the diplomacy sponsored by the United States and Egypt is perceived as having failed.
The American suspension of the dialogue with the P.L.O. brought strong responses from Palestinian groups outside the P.L.O that reject its avowed moderation. ''All Arab patriots should threaten U.S. interests worldwide because America is completely biased towards the Zionist enemy and should be punished for this,'' the Damascus-based Fatah Uprising said.

HEADLINE: The Mandela Visit;
In Harlem, a Name to Add to Martin and Malcolm

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
Geneva Valladares calmly brushed her daughter's hair, but her voice was coated with excitement because soon, she said, ''Nelson Mandela will actually be in Harlem.''
''He reminds me of Martin Luther King,'' Mrs. Valladares said of Mr. Mandela, the South African anti-apartheid leader. ''He fought for his people. And he's not going to give up now. He's a survivor, just like I am.'' 
Harlem is also a survivor. For generations the community was known as the Capital of Black America, a mecca for artists, entertainers and political leaders from Marcus Garvey and Malcolm X to New York City's first black mayor, David N. Dinkins.
But Harlem has fallen on hard times, or been pushed by governmental and political neglect, many people on its streets contend. Poverty, drugs, unemployment, inferior schools and poor health are part of Harlem's daily life.
Yesterday, all along Harlem's avenues and boulevards named after black American heroes, posters of Mr. Mandela were displayed in shop windows like flags on Memorial Day. Mr. Mandela's visit to Harlem was a dose of pride and inspiration and for many a rallying cry ''to clean up our own backyard,'' Mrs. Valladares said.
''I hope he will open some people's eyes,'' she said. ''We need to do the same thing.''
As Mrs. Valladares talked, her 9-year-old daughter, Alaya, tugged at her sleeve.
''Mom, why did he go to jail?'' Alaya asked. ''For fighting for his people.'' ''Is he black?'' ''Yeah. African.'' ''Is he going back to jail?''
''I hope not,' the mother said. ''He was an innocent man. He just wants some justice for his people. That's what we want right here in Harlem.''
 
'We Need Help Ourselves'
Frank James, 61, a laundry worker, sympathized with Mr. Mandela's struggle but was skeptical of the support that Harlem could provide.
''Sure we sympathize with his cause,'' Mr. James said. ''But that's about all we can do. We need help ourselves in this prejudiced country, America, my home.''
Phyllis Tripp left her Brooklyn apartment early yesterday with her two daughters and headed for Harlem to wait for ''just a glimpse'' of Mr. Mandela. ''He's been like a myth the whole 27 years he was in prison,'' she said. ''We didn't known what he looked liked. He's like something that came out of a fairy tale book.''
It was 11 A.M., about seven hours before Mr. Mandela was scheduled to speak at a rally at the intersection of Martin Luther King Jr. and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards, also known as African Square. Mrs. Tripp and her children had already been waiting for two hours.
''As an African-American woman,'' she said, ''I have been confronted by racism plenty of times right here in New York City. Our struggle is the same.''
John Simpson, 42, a street vendor who ''sells everything in general and nothing in particular,'' refused to be caught in the Mandela excitement.
''The people love the man because he struggled and because he's one of us,'' Mr. Simpson said. ''But Mandela has no business trying to negotiate with the South African government. It's like playing three card monte. You're going to lose because it's a crooked game. There should be no negotiating about freedom.''
But the jazz musician Dizzy Gillespie said he was thoroughly excited about Mr. Mandela's visit to Harlem.
''It's going to give the people hope,'' he said, standing in a light rain in front of Sylvia's Restaurant, on Lenox Avenue near 126th Street. ''We haven't got much hope from anywhere else.'' ''
In the glow from the marquee of the Apollo Theater Wednesday night, Neville Bird was doing a brisk business selling several different kinds of T-shirts of Mr. Mandela.
But Mr. Bird said he also sells a lot of T-shirts of Malcolm X, or of a man holding a boy's hand. The inscription on the shirt reads: ''What Our Young Males Need Most Today Are Strong, Positive And Courageous Role Models. Be One.''
''Mr. Mandela,'' Mr. Bird said, ''fits that description very well.''

LENGTH: 513 words

HEADLINE: The Bailout: No Savagery Required

 BODY:
Chairman Dan Rostenkowski of the House Ways and Means Committee startled a meeting of mayors this week by declaring there would be no peace dividend for the cities. Why? Because the Federal money freed by defense cuts would be gobbled up by the bailout of bankrupt saving and loan institutions. At the same conference, Mayor David Dinkins of New York lamented that the bailout ''sinkhole'' would swallow resources needed for mass transit, education or drug enforcement. 
These thoughts are well meant. But they are also, at least as a matter of economics, dead wrong. The bailout, though gigantic, need not subtract one dime from the nation's ability to build railroads or treat drug addicts.
There is a better way to pay for the bailout: Borrow the money. Unless politicians understand that this is responsible, even in a period of huge deficits, they will squander a golden opportunity to finance starving social programs.
Building missiles and tanks requires skilled workers and equipment. For Congress to cut back on these, with the end of the cold war, would free workers to build schools, for instance, or high-speed trains. This is the peace dividend.
The thrift bailout, unlike defense, produces nothing. It transfers money, from taxpayers to depositors of failed thrifts collecting their Federal deposit insurance. Administrative costs aside, the transfer uses neither skilled workers nor valuable equipment. Because the bailout only affects money - pieces of paper - and not productive resources, the nation's capacity to produce schools and trains is undiminished.
Even so, Congress must find enough dollars -by one estimate, $150 billion - to pay the insured depositors at failed thrifts.
It could cut other Federal programs, almost certainly sacrificing needed social investments. It could raise taxes. But large tax hikes are politically improbable and economically damaging. The right answer is to borrow the money, waiving the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law accordingly. That's the politically expedient but also the fiscally responsible way out.
For one thing, the thrift bailout is a temporary problem that justifies no catastrophic jolt to taxpayers or social programs. For another, Gramm-Rudman's purpose is to limit how much money Congress drains from the private capital market.
But borrowing for the thrift bailout poses no such threat. It merely replaces money that depositors at federally insured thrifts already assume they have. These depositors are no more likely to spend the replacement funds than they were to spend the original deposit. The replacement money would remain in the capital market, available to corporate borrowers.
Gramm-Rudman should not be waived, however, for the subsequent interest cost. Interest on the loans, unlike the bailout itself, will represent ordinary claims on the nation's capital market.
The S & L bailout is routinely cited as the reason America can't attend to its cities, children or other constituencies. Economic reality doesn't require that sacrifice. Congress can responsibly borrow the money.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

INDUSTRY: NAICS524128 OTHER DIRECT INSURANCE (EXCEPT LIFE, HEALTH, AND MEDICAL) CARRIERS (55%); SIC6399 INSURANCE CARRIERS, NEC (55%);

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
The Essential Mandela

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela is both a symbol and a political leader. In celebrating the first, Americans should not overlook the realistic burdens - the very heavy burdens - of the second.
The cheering crowds in New York, and the admirers around the world, see in him a man of extraordinary conviction and strength. He survived 27 years as a political prisoner with his commitment to a democratic South Africa undimmed. 
But it is not survival alone that matters. If Mr. Mandela had come out of prison as a man full of hate, many would understand but not admire. What gives him such power in our imagination is his lack of bitterness. He gives us optimism about the possibilities of human nature.
From the moment of his release he has refused to criticize those who imprisoned him. They were caught up in an oppressive system, he said, and it is the system that has to be changed.
''You look at what can be done today, and you forget the past quite easily,'' he said in March. ''It would be unfair to think in terms of any measures of revenge. It would be absolutely unfair.''
To black Americans, of course, he is a particular symbol. He resisted white oppression of an especially malignant kind. But again his qualities of character matter as well as the fact of his successful resistance.
There is a sense of serenity in him, of confidence and courtesy. Archbishop Desmond Tutu said: ''He's got the manner of royalty, because he is royalty among the Xhosa people. But he's also incredibly humble.''
His character was a crucial factor, I believe, in bringing President F. W. de Klerk to the remarkable steps he has taken: releasing Mr. Mandela and other prisoners, ending the ban on the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid organizations and starting talks with the A.N.C. Two Cabinet ministers had been greatly impressed on meeting him in prison, and so was Mr. de Klerk when he had three meetings.
Mr. Mandela, for his part, has told black South Africans that President de Klerk is a man of good faith. He has praised individual Cabinet members as enlightened.
All this makes clear a fundamental political fact. Nelson Mandela is the one man in South Africa now who has sufficient respect in the white Government and the black community to make negotiations possible.
That is an enormous burden. Just think about feelings in the black community, for example. After generations of brutal discrimination, impoverishment and dispossession from the land, many blacks, especially young people, reject the very idea of negotiations. They doubt that anything but force will win them equal rights in their country.
And then there is the reality of white power, still overwhelming in money and weapons. Mr. Mandela's American tour itself shows how unequal the A.N.C. side of the bargaining table is in terms of resources. He and his colleagues have no Government airplanes or staff. They are trying to raise money to keep going and organize as a party.
How does Mr. Mandela deal with those realities? He emphasizes that the foundations of apartheid are still in place: He could not vote when he went to prison 27 years ago, and he still cannot. He calls on the world, especially the United States, to continue the sanctions that have made a vital difference in bringing white South Africa to the table.
He does it with a presence as commanding as any political figure in the world today. People worry about his stamina at the age of 71, but in interviews he is sharp and vigorous. He is informed on all kinds of issues, in detail, despite the 27 years in prison. He stands up to a television interviewer as determined as Ted Koppel.
But there is an odd contradiction in all that. It is the man who commands attention. But he cares about the message, and he resists the personal attention.
He comes across as a man who will not compromise on principles. Yet he could not have gone as far as he has in these few months since his release if he were not a practical man. He has already signaled that the earlier A.N.C. talk about nationalization is yielding to practical concerns for a productive economy - so long as there is redistribution of wealth.
Nelson Mandela knows that successful negotiation means compromise. Mr. de Klerk and his colleagues have recognized that they will not find a more reasonable partner. The question, amid pressure from the extremes, is whether there will be world enough, and time.

HEADLINE: 12 Indicted As Mob Rulers Of Painting

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Twelve men, including eight top painters' union leaders, were indicted yesterday and accused of participating in a Mafia-led conspiracy that rigged bids for almost every major public and private painting contract in New York City for 12 years.
The indictments portrayed the Lucchese organized-crime family as the secret power in the city's multimillion-dollar painting industry for more than a decade. Through threats and control of the painters' union, the indictments said, the Mafia imposed a hidden 10 percent tax on municipal contracts for painting subways, bridges, schools and highways and on bills paid by private developers who built skyscrapers and apartment buildings.
Law-enforcement officials estimated that the conspirary had cost the city tens of millions of dollars in inflated contracts in the last decade and had resulted in higher rents for commercial and residential tenants.
 
Focus on Industry Conspiracies
Yesterday's indictments were the latest in a campaign by Federal and state law-enforcement agencies to rid the city's construction industry of corruption and Mafia influence by concentrating on construction-industry conspiracies instead of separate corrupt acts. Recent indictments involved corruption in the concrete and carpentery trades. 
The new strategy is also intended to cripple the city's Mafia leadership. Previous investigations of traditional organized-crime activities - narcotics trafficking, illegal gambling, loan sharking and hijacking -rarely resulted in felony charges against the Mafia's hierarchy in the city.
A prosecutor in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, Michael G. Cherkasky, said the undercover inquiry into the painters' union began two years ago when - in a rare occurrence - a painting contractor complained that union officials had demanded payoffs from him.
Law-enforcement officials have long maintained that extortion is widespread in the construction industry but that contractors are reluctant to expose it because they fear for their safety from the underworld if they cooperate with investigators.
Many contractors in the building trades have said privately that they shun jobs in the city because of corruption and its inherent danger, even through the cost of payoffs can be passed along to developers and tenants.
Named in the state indictments yesterday were two suspected chiefs in the Lucchese family - Anthony (Gaspipe) Casso and Peter (Big Pete) Chiodo -two painting company executives and eight top officials in the city's painters' union, the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades District Council 9.
 
Millions in Payoffs Charged
In announcing the indictments, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said an undercover investigation had obtained evidence that the Lucchese family and District Council 9 officials shared ''millions of dollars'' in payoffs by rigging ''virtually every significant paint contract in the city for the last 12 years.''
Mr. Casso was identified by prosecutors as the underboss, or No. 2 leader, in the Lucchese family, one of five Mafia groups operating in the New York area. Mr. Casso and the man who law-enforcement officials say is the boss of the Lucchese group, Vittorio (Vic) Amuso, disappeared last month, shortly before they were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges for helping rig bids for $142 million in window contracts given by the City Housing Authority.
Mr. Amuso was also named in yesterday's indictments as an unindicted conspirator who helped run the painting rackets.
The central 153-count indictment against the 12 defendants asserted that the Lucchese family handpicked top executives in District Council 9. The council is the administrative unit for six locals, and with 6,000 members, it is the third largest construction union in the New York metropolitan area.
 
Threats of Violence Reported
Companies that sought major painting contracts - those totaling several hundreds thousand dollars or more -were ordered by District Council 9 officials to kick back 10 percent of their gross payments, the indictments said. Contractors were said to have been warned that the union leaders were associated with the Lucchese family and that violence might occur if bribes were withheld.
In return, compliant contractors cut costs by obtaining labor peace, and they were allowed to violate union regulations through ''sweetheart deals.'' The bribe-givers were permitted to hire nonunion workers at lower wages and with fewer fringe benefits than union members got.
Other favors given to contractors in exchange for payoffs were said to be permission to speed up work by using spraying equipment instead of brushes.
''These indictments demonstrate just how deeply organized crime has infiltrated the construction trades in this city through bribery, threats and violence,'' Mr. Morgenthau said at a news conference.
 
A 'Textbook Case'
Chief Anthony M. Voelker, who is in charge of the Police Department's Organized Crime Control Bureau, said the evidence was a ''textbook case of an assault by organized crime on the economic health of New York City.''
Investigators from the bureau and the Federal Labor Department's New York Office of Labor Racketeering participated in undercover tactics that included secretly placing court-authorized eavesdropping devices and a video camera inside the offices of District Council 9 at 45 West 14th Street, near Fifth Avenue.
Prosecutors said they had videotapes of union officials dividing bribes.
''These union officials subverted the power of their union to satisfy their own greed,'' said Gustave A. Schick, assistant inspector general for the Office of Labor Racketeering. ''They stole from the men and women in their own union they were supposed to protect.''
The indictments described only about $150,00 in bribes in the last two years from three unidentifed Transit Authority contracts. Mr. Cherkasky, who is the chief of the Investigations Division in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, said a description of the full extent of the payoffs would compromise the continuting investigation.
 
Public Officials Investigated
Other potential targets of the inquiry include public officials, contractors and organized-crime figures, Mr. Cherkasky said in an interview.
Two executives of painting companies were indicted: Frank Huber, president of the Huber Decorating Company in College Point, Queens, and Daniel Rech, projects supervisor for the Leeds Painting and Decorating Company in Rego Park, Queens.
Mr. Huber's company got more than than $20 million in public contracts in the last five years, including the painting of the IRT subway line along Jerome Avenue in the Bronx and state highways.
Both men were identified in the indictments as associates in the Lucchese family. Law-enforcement officials characterize an associate as someone who cooperates with a Mafia family but who is not an inducted or sworn member.
The indictments also said that Mr. Chiodo, said to be a Lucchese family captain, Mr. Rech and another defendant, Edward Capaldo, the business manager of Painters Local 1486, last year threatened James D. Bishop, the former secretary-treasurer and chief executive of District Council 9. Mr. Bishop was shot to death last month near his home in Whitestone, Queens, in what authorities said was a gangland execution.
 
Contract for Murder Charged
The indictment said Mr. Bishop had been an associate in the Lucchese family and had cooperated with the Mafia during his term in office from 1973 to 1989. According to law-enforcement officials, Mr. Bishop was linked with previous leaders of the Lucchese family and when Mr. Amuso, Mr. Casso and Mr. Chiodo rose to power in the late 1980's, they distrusted him and ordered his ouster as union head.
Federal prosecutors in court papers last month said Mr. Amuso had placed an ''open contract'' on Mr. Bishop's life. No one has been charged in Mr. Bishop's murder.
Other painters' union officials indicted yesterday were Paul Kamen, secretary-treasurer of District Council 9; William Courtien, the council's international representative; Aaron Lefkowitz, business agent of Local 28; Salvatore Savarese, business agent of local 20; Joseph Candiano, business agent of Local 24;, Edward Filancia, business agent of Local 19 and Seymour Strelzik, coordinator of the council's apprentice program.
All 12 men were indicted under provisions of the state's Organized Crime Control Act, which carries a maximum prison sentence of 25 years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Twelve men were indicted yesterday and accused of a Mafia-led conspriacy to rig bids for painting contracts in New York City. One of the indicted, Edward Capaldo, a union official, was led from a police van to State Supreme Court in lower Manhattan. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 5 in the Arts Are Awarded A $100,000 Japanese Prize

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CASSIDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 21

 BODY:
The American composer Leonard Bernstein and the Italian film maker Federico Fellini are among the five winners of the 1990 Japanese Praemium Imperiale awards for lifetime achievement in the arts, it was announced at Claridge's Hotel here today.
Mr. Bernstein won for his contributions to music; Mr. Fellini for theater and film; Arnaldo Pomodoro of Italy for sculpture; James Stirling of England for architecture, and Antoni Tapies of Spain for painting.
Each winner is to receive $100,000 and a medal at a ceremony in October in Tokyo. The prize is financed primarily by the Fujisankei Communications Group, a conglomerate of which Hiroaki Shikanai is chairman and chief executive. Mr. Shikanai is the chairman of the prize's organizing committee and vice chairman of the Japan Art Association. 
The Praemium Imperiale, or Imperial Prize, was created in 1988 by the Japan Art Association on its 101st anniversary. It was the vision of the younger brother of Emperor Hirohito, Prince Nobuhito Takamatsu, Mr. Shikanai said on Wednesday.
 
An Artistic Tradition
Honoring those who have significantly contributed to international arts and culture, the prize is also intended to show that ''art can overcome the many, many divisions in the world - individual, racial and international - and promote peace,'' Mr. Shikanai said.
The organizers also hope, he said, that the prize will show another side of Japan, which has a rich artistic tradition but which is widely regarded only for its economic success.
David Rockefeller, chairman of the Museum of Modern Art in New York and an international adviser for Praemium Imperiale, said at a news conference today that while the prize was still somewhat unknown to the public, its prestige was growing in the arts world.
''In the very near future,'' he said, it could be to the arts what the Nobel Prize is to science and literature.
The Praemium Imperiale's other international advisers were also at the news conference. They are the former Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain; Jacques Chirac, the Mayor of Paris and former Prime Minister; Amintore Fanfani, former Prime Minister of Italy, and Helmut Schmidt, former Chancellor of West Germany.
Each adviser had his own committee, which made recommendations to the Japan Art Association's trustees, who selected the winners.
To show the world that the prize is truly international, and not just a means of promoting Japan, no Japanese artists will be nominated for the prize for several years, Mr. Heath said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Credit Is Sufficient

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, said today that lax lending standards by banks and insufficient supervision by regulators in the 1980's were two key elements that have forced bankers in certain areas of the country to restrict credit to businesses.
Mr. Greenspan rejected suggestions, as he has several times, that there is currently a nationwide credit crunch that could threaten economic growth.
Appearing before the Senate Banking Committee, he predicted ''continued modest economic growth'' and said that ''enough credit appears to be available to fuel this growth.''
 
Some Reduced Lending
Still, the Fed chairman conceded that in some areas, like New England, banks had reduced lending. He said that in those regions, the reduction in the amount of lending available was primarily a result of banks trying to compensate for the excessive lending and poor credit decisions in the 1980's. Those decisions fueled overbuilding and left a legacy of vacant office buildings, defaulted loans and falling real estate prices. 
''We are going from lending standards that were clearly more lax than they should have been, back to a sound and more normal one,'' Mr. Greenspan said. ''The process feels very restrictive; it gives the impression of abnormal tightening.''
And he said that regulators were also to blame for the overbuilding that has now produced weak real estate markets and tighter credit.
''The overbuilding was supported in part by the ready availability of credit from thrifts and banks that, in hindsight, partly reflected lax lending standards and unfortunately insufficient attention by supervisors,'' he said.
Mr. Greenspan added that at this point, the Fed did not see any major economic problem because of tighter credit in the real estate sector. ''I don't think we see anything of substance that raises a caution flag,'' he said. ''But we are watching it very, very closely.''
 
The Credit Debate
The hearings today continued a debate that has been brewing in Washington as to whether tougher actions by Federal regulators this year have forced banks to cut back on their lending to many small businesses around the country.
While regulators deny that they have changed their formal lending standards, they do not deny that they have gotten tougher in enforcing those standards in response to a weakening economy and real estate market. The regulators primary message is that bankers should not stop lending to creditworthy borrowers.
Nevertheless, senators said today that they were under intense pressure from local businessmen to take action.
''We are hearing almost every hour from businessmen who are having trouble getting loans,'' said Senator Christopher Dodd, a Democrat from Connecticut.
Some in the Administration have cited evidence of a reduction in credit beyond the scope described by Mr. Greenspan. Both Jack Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Robert A. Mosbacher, Secretary of Commerce, told Congress last week that there was a credit crunch that has extended well beyond New England and beyond the real estate sector.
Irvin B. Maizlish, chairman of the Leo Eisenberg Company, a real estate management concern based in St. Louis, said before the Senate panel today that members of his International Council of Shopping Centers had ''experienced a sudden, sharp decline in credit availability'' and that the drop-off had been of such a magnitude that it was ''not justified by sound banking practices or economic reality.''
One aspect of the debate seems to center on whether a weak economy, produced by excessive borrowing and leverage in the 1980's, has forced regulators and bankers to be more cautious with their lending, or whether regulators are inducing economic weakness through tougher examinations of banks.
Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, who has come under intense criticism for imposing excessively tough examination practices for banks, told the banking committee today that the regulators were just responding to market conditions and that bankers and borrowers had ''misconceptions'' that regulators wanted banks to cut off credit to sound borrowers.
''Blaming the O.C.C. is unwarranted,'' Mr. Clarke said. ''That assumes that the O.C.C. tells bankers when to lend and makes individual credit decisions.''
 
Congress in a Strange Position
What both sides agree on is that the position of the regulators has to be clarified so that market expectations do not produce even tighter credit conditions.
The debate puts the regulators and members of Congress in a strange position. In recent years, they have often come under fire for advocating lax regulation in the savings and loan industry. Today they noted the irony that pressure is now mounting for them to be more lenient with borrowers.
Some members of the panel defended the regulators.
''If you are gong to err, err on the side of tough regulation,'' said Senator Jake Garn, Republican from Utah.
''In my view, banks are to be applauded for tighter credit standards,'' said Paul Fritz, director of the division of supervision at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. ''We are in favor of the banking industry tightening lending standards and returning to basics. However, this tightening does not mean banks should stop making loans. Instead, we expect and urge banks to continue making loans to creditworthy borrowers.''
Mr. Fritz warned, however, that problems in the commercial real estate markets were spreading beyond New England and the Southwest and were likely to get worse before they get better.
''We don't think it's bottomed out in New England yet,'' he said. ''We see some softness beginning to develop in California. And we don't expect the problems to continue at this pace, but we do not see them going away.''

HEADLINE: Pathe Deal For MGM Extended

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 21

 BODY:
Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier whose attempt to acquire the MGM/ UA Communications Company has been on the brink of collapse in recent days, said today that he had reached an agreement with MGM that will give him four more months to come up with the cash he needs to complete the deal.
Mr. Parretti's Pathe Communications Corporation said the deadline for closing the transaction will be extended to Oct. 23, from Saturday. Under the new terms, holders of MGM's common and preferred stock would receive $21.50 a share, or about $1.3 billion, up from $20 under the previous agreement, to compensate them for the delay.
Under the new agreement, shareholders would receive a payment of $4 a share, or about $250 million, on July 20 - essentially a nonrefundable deposit that would not require shareholders to give up an interest in the company - with the remaining $17.50 to be paid on or before the October deadline. 
 
History of Failed Deals
The new agreement is the latest twist in Mr. Parretti's faltering attempts to establish himself as a force in the film business by acquiring MGM/UA. Mr. Parretti has been something of a mystery man in Hollywood since acquiring the old Cannon film studio and merging it into Pathe two years ago, and industry executives have long been skeptical about his ability to raise money to complete the MGM/UA deal.
The extension is also an embarrassment to Kirk Kerkorian, who controls 79 percent of MGM/UA's shares and has been trying unsuccessfully to sell the company for two years. A previous agreement to sell the company to the Qintex Group of Australia collapsed last year when Qintex encountered severe financial troubles. Mr. Kerkorian had earlier turned down a bid from Rupert Murdoch in favor of a slightly higher offer from Qintex.
Another deal that fell apart two years ago would have put the film and television studio under control of a group including Jon Peters and Peter Guber, the producers who now run Columbia Pictures for the Sony Corporation.
 
Effect of Time Warner Pact
Mr. Parretti has secured $650 million in financing from Time Warner Inc. for the deal in return for the right to distribute Pathe and MGM films. But that agreement requires that he contribute $450 million of equity to the deal, rather than bank financing or other debt, and Mr. Parretti has yet to arrange financing in a way that meets that demand.
Although there were widespread rumors that Time Warner was backing out of the deal or that Mr. Parretti was seeking a partner to replace Time Warner, Time Warner executives said their agreement with Pathe was still in place. ''We assume that the purpose of obtaining the extension was to be able to continue negotiating with us,'' said Marilyn Harris, a spokeswoman for Time Warner.
Mr. Parretti has so far raised about $370 million through Comfinance S.A., a holding company he controls in Luxembourg. Comfinance has said the finances are a combination of bank loans and asset sales. Mr. Parretti has argued that the $370 million should be considered equity as far as Pathe is concerned, because under the terms of its agreement with Comfinance, Pathe could repay the advance in Pathe stock.
 
Other Concessions to MGM/UA
In addition to raising the price, Mr. Parretti had to make other concessions to MGM/UA to keep the deal alive. To provide added security for MGM shareholders, Mr. Parretti agreed to place an additional $100 million into an escrow account in two installments in August and September. The escrow fund is intended to be a pool from which MGM shareholders might recover damages in litigation should the deal collapse.
The $4-a-share payment next month will be financed in part by the $200 million in cash that Pathe had deposited into the escrow account as security for the original deal. Pathe will be required to pay an additional $53 million into the account to finance the $4 payment.
MGM continues to insist that it is conducting business as usual, but with all the uncertainty about its future, its film production and distribution activities have fallen off. The only two films it now has in release -''Lisa'' and ''Daddy's Dyin' . . . Who's Got the Will?'' - have drawn a total of only $5 million at the box office.

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rise Put at 1.9% In Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
The economy grew faster in the first quarter than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today, but the 1.9 percent annual growth rate remained the second lowest in two and a half years.
In fact, the upward revision itself pointed to a slowing economy, since it was created in part by higher-than-expected inventories of unsold goods. Combined with slack demand, indicated by a downward adjustment in consumer spending, it pointed to bloated inventories in the second half of the year.
''Weaker consumer spending and a bigger inventory overhang suggest the second quarter is not going to be as strong as thought,'' said Jerry Jordan, senior vice president of First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. 
 
Lower Inflation Estimate
The department's figure for first-quarter gross national product growth was revised from a 1.3 percent annual increase estimated a month ago. The department also lowered its earlier estimate of inflation for the January through March period.
The implicit price deflator, a broad gauge of inflation that measures price changes in a basket of goods and services, rose at a 5.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, instead of the 5.7 percent rise estimated a month ago. It was still the biggest rise in the inflation measure since the third quarter of 1982, when it rose at a 5.8 percent rate. The inflation rate had risen 3.2 percent in the final three months of 1989. 2.1% Initial Growth Initially, the Government reported in April that the first-quarter G.N.P., the nation's total output of goods and services, had risen 2.1 percent. But that was scaled back in May to a 1.3 percent increase because the Government had predicted higher auto production in its first estimate than acutally took place in the quarter.
Today's 1.9 percent growth figure is the final adjustment. The upward revision was attibuted in part to higher figures for net exports. But analysts said that more noteworthy were the downward revision in personal consumption spending and the increase in inventories.
''In contrast to a surface impression of an upward revision, this really reflects a weaker economy than we had seen earlier,'' Mr. Jordan added.
Treasury bonds eased only fractionally and the dollar was barely changed after the figures were announced, dealers said. The stock market also took the report in stride.
Cynthia Latta, senior financial economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass., said the upward revision in first-quarter growth effectively borrows from the rest of the year.
''We're seeing consumer spending weaker than we thought, and that is consistent with an economy that's likely to remain sluggish,'' Ms. Latta said.
The economy had expanded at an anemic 1.1 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of 1989, the weakest since an eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in the third quarter of 1986.
 
Rate Easing Doubtful
Prospects for any early easing in interest rates to stimulate the economy seem slim, and on Capitol Hill today, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, testified he thought the economy was continuing to grow modestly without danger of recession.
The Fed, which controls monetary policy, has consistently stated that it wants to continue efforts to curb price rises.
Today's report said that inflation was given an upward push early in the first quarter by higher prices for imported oil and food caused by record cold weather late in 1989. Prices have since eased after heating oil inventories were rebuilt and new crops came to market.
 
Corporate Profits Revised
The department also issued a revised estimate of first-quarter net corporate profits, showing profits up 1.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $158.5 billion. A month ago, the department estimated first-quarter profits had risen only two-tenths of 1 percent, to $157 billion, after rising 2.8 percent in the fourth quarter last year.
Corporate profits for all of 1989 fell 4.7 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $161 billion after taxes, from the 1988 total of $168.9 billion. In 1988, after-tax profits rose 18.9 percent from 1987.
For the full year 1989, total output of goods and services increased at an inflation-adjusted rate of 3 percent, compared with 4.4 percent in 1988 and 3.7 percent in 1987. It was the weakest annual growth rate since 1986, when the economy grew only 2.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
National Security: New Priorities

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney this week submitted a proposal to Congress for cutting the armed forces by 20 to 25 percent over the next five years. But his plan would reduce military spending by only 10 percent, because savings from force reductions would be largely offset by rising outlays on antimissile defenses, procurement of new strategic nuclear weapons systems, purchases of new conventional weapons and more spending on research and development of new weapons.
At the same time, Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has offered Congress a revised plan for hitting the Gramm-Rudman deficit targets. He has raised his estimate of the deficit for the fiscal year 1991 to $159 billion, from $137.9 billion less than a month ago, and proposes to cut it by $50.4 billion. Reductions in military spending would yield less than $6 billion next year, with the rest coming from programs like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, veterans benefits and farm subsidies, plus $13.9 billion from higher tax revenues and $5.6 billion from higher Federal fees. 
Mr. Darman says his budget plan would save $444 billion over the next five years - $153 billion more than the savings projected in the Administration's budget in January. But the Democrats are calling for five-year savings of $500 billion to $600 billion, and want to see more of these coming from the military.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, writing in the current New York Review, says of the cold war: ''We won! There will be plenty of troubles ahead. Plenty of horror and pain. But the age of totalitarianism is over.'' And he poses a critical issue: ''How do we now demobilize? How do we move from a national security state to a Government that merely asks what are our interests abroad and our needs at home, and calmly and openly pursues them? What a wonderful challenge!''
Similarly, Theodore C. Sorensen, who was a speech writer for President John F. Kennedy, says in the new issue of Foreign Affairs: ''The primary threat cited over 40 years in justification for most of our military budget, bases and overseas assistance is gone.'' And he warns, ''If the President cannot soon lead the way to a consensus among our national security decision-makers on credible new goals to guide our basic foreign policy and military planning for the long term, the current strategic vacuum is likely to be filled not only haphazardly but unwisely as well.''
What does economics have to contribute to developing a new concept of national and international security?
The collapse of the Soviet military threat and that of the Warsaw Pact countries resulted from their economic failure rather than from direct military action by their adversaries. And, in the post-cold war environment, threats to a nation's economic interests, Communist or capitalist, are coming to be regarded as a greater danger than threats to its territorial integrity.
Prof. Martin C. McGuire of the University of Maryland contends that in the past a nation could become a ''takeover target'' for an aggressor when the aggressor nation saw the opportunity to extract wealth, in the form of arable land, minerals, gold or other property, from its victim. But in modern industrial societies, if a conqueror requires the cooperation of the local population to obtain surplus wealth, it may not pay him to go to war, particularly if the defender has the means of inflicting unacceptable damage on the aggressor.
The Soviet failure to make its conquests in Eastern Europe ''pay'' was doubtless a key reason why Mikhail S. Gorbachev was willing to let the Warsaw Pact break up and search for peace with the West. Indeed, a powerful new incentive influencing the balance between war and peace, Mr. McGuire suggests, will be the comparative benefit of the alternative to conquest - that is, the benefit from production and exchange, or peaceful migration of people, capital, technology and knowledge.
''As between offering a carrot in the form of desirable consumer goods, and a stick in the form of despotic occupation,'' he says, ''the modern industrial state has a comparative advantage in the former.''
But even if threats of territorial war between industrial powers have diminished, with the lack of rational incentives for aggressors, other threats to security remain, like local and regional wars in developing countries, risks that fanatics will explode nuclear bombs, spreading drug use, international terrorism, cross-national threats to the environment, or economic and financial catastrophe. ''Economic hazards,'' Mr. McGuire says, ''are central rather than peripheral as before.''
Thus, the changing nature of the risks faced by the United States and other industrial nations provides the basis for a new security structure. The defenses against those risks need to be international, not just national, as in times past.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Garfinckel's In Chapter 11

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
In a move reflecting continuing problems in the retailing industry, the owner of the Garfinckel's department store chain said today that it had filed for bankruptcy protection and would liquidate the inventories of its 10 stores.
''It has become increasingly apparent over the past six months that Garfinckel's does not have the economies of scale to be a competitive retailer in this marketplace,'' said George Kelly, the chairman and chief executive of the Garfinckel's Holding Company. 
The company, which investors rescued Garfinckel's from a financial crisis two years ago by recruiting new managers and providing money, also laid off 200 of its 850 employees.
The Washington-area retailer, which catered to affluent shoppers, attributed part of its problems to its ownership having changed five times since the early 1980's. This resulted in different marketing strategies that had affected its image, the company said.
Garfinckel's said it had filed for Chapter 11 protection at the Federal Bankruptcy Court in the District of Columbia.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Rebound in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday, stemming what had been a four-day slide.
The slight spurt came as a surprise to some dealers, who said they saw mostly sellers and few buyers.
''I am a bit confused, since we have heard about nothing but selling,'' one government bond trader said.
''But on a fundamental basis the market is reasonably attractive. Yields are about 20 basis points higher now than they were late last week, and people loved the market then. So even though we haven't seen much of it, evidently there is some buying going on.'' 
Market reaction was limited to the Commerce Department's final revision of first-quarter economic growth, but there was only a slight selloff in prices after the numbers were released even though the figures were pushed upward by more than half a percentage point, to 1.9 percent from 1.3 percent.
Most of the increase was a result of an upward revision in exports, but some analysts said the most telling parts of the changes related to consumer activity.
''The large downward revision in personal consumption expenditures, which was pushed down by $6 billion, was the major news,'' said Gary Schlossberg, a vice president and senior economist at Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco.
''To me, despite the big upward revision in the overall number, the decline in consumption expenditures was an indication of economic weakness, not strength.''
Prices weakened later in the day after the Treasury announced that its deficit in May was $42.6 billion.
The figure, which was higher than expected, pushed yields on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds as high as 8.53 percent. Those levels attracted buyers, and yields subsequently eased.
''There is definite support for securities at roughly 8.50 percent for the entire coupon list, but especially for the bond,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''That seems to underscore strong market sentiment that rates will be moving lower over time.''
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent bonds were offered at a price of 102 27/32, up 10/32, to yield 8.48 percent. Late Wednesday the closely watched Treasury bond was offered at a price to yield 8.51 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 102 14/32, up 6/32, to yield 8.50 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, up 1/8, to yield 8.45 percent.
In when-issued trading, the two-year notes to be auctioned on Tuesday were offered at a price to yield 8.36 percent. And the four-year notes that will be sold on Wednesday were offered at a price to yield 8.46 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.75 percent, up one basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.63 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Burlington Resources Inc. priced a two-part, $300 million offering through an underwriting syndicate led by Lehman Brothers, a division of Shearson Lehman Hutton, which is a unit of the American Express Company.
Half the issue consisted of 9 5/8 percent 10-year notes. The notes, which mature June 15, 2000, were priced at $99.77 to yield 9.66 percent, 1.13 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $150 million were 9 7/8 percent 20-year bonds.
The bonds, which mature June 15, 2010, were priced at $99.77, to yield 9.901 percent, 1.40 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 at the time of pricing.
Both parts of the issue are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by the sale of $254 million worth of Criminal Justice Facility bonds for Palm Beach County, Fla.
The issue, which is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, consists of serial and term bonds.
Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6.30 percent in 1994 to 7.20 percent in 2005. The largest term bond carries a 7.35 percent coupon and matures in 2011.
Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was light, dealers said.
Prices of most actively quoted corporate bonds rose by about 1/8 point. Municipal bond traders said that prices of most tax-exempt issues rose by a similar amount.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended June 11. The narrowest measure, M-1, dipped by $600 million.
The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Brazil Backed on Economy

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 21

 BODY:
United States Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher expressed strong support today for President Fernando Collor de Mello's sweeping economic changes and the opening of Brazil's economy.
In a luncheon speech to the American Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Mosbacher praised Mr. Collor's ''ambitious program of open markets and limited government.'' 
Mr. Collor, who took office on March 15, immediately froze nearly two-thirds of the nation's money supply in an attempt to slow the inflation rate, which was more than 1,700 percent last year. He also vowed to trim the huge public sector and open the economy to foreign investment.
Although some Brazilians and executives of foreign corporations have expressed disappointment in the slow pace of opening the economy, officials traveling with the Commerce Secretary said the Collor administration was expected to announce a much wider opening on Monday.
The changes expected to be announced include permitting companies manufacturing in Brazil to import up to 40 percent of the components used in many products. Under current law, about 90 percent of the parts must be from domestic sources.
Mr. Mosbacher is in Brazil with nine American executives, heading what he called the first trade and investment mission under a new trade promotion coordinating committee of the Bush Administration.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Light Day As Gold Increases in Price

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other major currencies yesterday, gaining against the yen but falling against the West German mark in light trading.
Gold advanced domestically and overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose 20 cents a troy ounce, to $350.70. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York reported a late bid of $349.90 an ounce, up 30 cents from Wednesday. 
Dealers said the mark advanced overseas on news that East German lawmakers had overwhelmingly approved a historic economic merger with West Germany, the most difficult step toward unifying the two nations.
A vote by the two houses of the West German Parliament was expected by today. That Parliament was also expected to pass the treaty, which outlines the monetary and economic merger of the Germanys by July 2.
In European trading the dollar rose to 1.6795 marks from Wednesday's 1.6785. But later in New York, the dollar eased, closing at 1.6760 marks, down from 1.6783 late Wednesday.
The dollar gained against the British pound after sterling rose overseas. In London, the pound rose to $1.7255, from $1.7225 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.7200, down from $1.7220 late Wednesday.
Sterling had been advancing on speculation that Britain would join Europe's exchange-rate mechanism this year.
The dollar also gained ground against the yen. Analysts said investors were moving funds from the yen to the dollar to take advantage of higher United States interest rates, given the relative stability of exchange rates.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.62 yen, to a closing 154.60 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 154.78 yen, and in New York it closed at 154.70 yen, up from 153.95 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.4135 Swiss francs, up from 1.4130; 5.6265 French francs, down from 5.6410; 1,228.25 Italian lire, down from 1,231.00, and 1.17575 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17275.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $350.25 a troy ounce, up from $349.15 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $350.50 an ounce, up from $347.25 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.80 to close at $351.65.
Silver bullion rose in London to $4.84 a troy ounce from Wednesday's late bid of $4.82. In New York, silver for current delivery closed at $4.824 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, down from $4.832 late Wednesday.
