HEADLINE: Bonn to Aid Kremlin Reforms With a $3 Billion Bank Credit

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, June 22

 BODY:
The West German Government said today that it would guarantee a bank credit of five billion Deutsche marks, or about $3 billion, for the Soviet Union in an effort to bolster President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's flagging reform program.
It is the largest single credit that the Soviet Union has received from Western banks, and the conditions are extremely favorable, economists said.
They described the credit as part of an effort by West Germany to extract concessions from the Soviet Union on German reunification.
The announcement was made as the ''two plus four'' talks on German reunification got under way in Berlin, and the timing reinforces that view. It also underscores a difference of opinion between the United States and its Western European allies over the question of linking Western aid to the Soviet Union to further Soviet political and economic reforms. 
 
Removing Unification Barriers
Foreign ministers from the two Germanys and the four World War II Allies - Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union - began two days of talks today in Berlin on removing the foreign policy barriers to German reunification.
The credit is almost double the $1.6 billion credit line that West German bankers extended to the Soviet Union in October 1988 to help Moscow modernize its food and consumer goods industries. At the time, that was the largest Western credit ever offered to Moscow.
Bush Administration officials say they believes economic aid for the Soviet Union should be given only after deeper reaching political and economic reforms are in place.
But Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France rejected that view at a news conference today after their meeting Assmannshausen, a village on the Rhine.
Mr. Kohl said that he and Mr. Mitterrand believed that the Soviet Union ''needs help to help itself.''
''If we wait until the reforms are ready, we could have to wait a long time,'' he said. ''I do not think we have a lot of time. Perestroika is something which helps us all.''
Mr. Mitterrand said that the Soviet situation is urgent and that there would be no reform if there is no aid. He is pushing for Western nations to discuss aid for the Soviet Union at meetings over the next three weeks. He would not say whether France was prepared to follow West Germany's lead in guaranteeing bank credits.
A West German Government spokesman, Hans Klein, said the 12-year bank credit was the result of recent talks between Chancellor Kohl and President Gorbachev and should encourage other Western countries to join in support of the Soviet leaders' reforms.
The credit is not tied to any specific projects, West German government officials said. But economists believe much of it will be used to finance business between West German companies and the Soviet Union.
Extending credit does not mean that the money must be used. West German bankers say the Soviet Government, which has long been wary of becoming overly dependent on Western credit, did not use all the previous credit until the latter half of 1989.
Economists say that because of the inefficiency of the Soviet Union's centrally planned economy, about a third of the equipment purchased with that money has yet to be installed.
 
Moscow Under Pressure
Because of the rapid deterioration of the Soviet economy, however, experts say they believe the credits offered today will be used quickly either to finance German-Soviet business or to import consumer goods in an attempt to lessen the growing frustration of the Soviet people with constant scarcities.
''That would ease pressure on their domestic markets and significantly improve the mood of the population,'' said Jan Vanous, research director of PlanEcon in Washington.
The terms of the loan are far better than those commercial borrowers receive. The Soviet Union has a six-year grace period on payments. The interest rate is below commercial rates; the rates to the Soviet Union are 0.5 percent over the London Interbank Offered Rate, known as Libor, the interest rate that international banks charge each other for large loans. The rate is now 8.4 percent for dollar-based loans.
Deutsche Bank AG and Dresdner Bank AG, West Germany's largest and second-largest banks, will act as joint leaders of the international loan consortium.
Mr. Klein said the terms should give the Soviet Government enough breathing room to carry on with its reforms. He also pointed to the important role Soviet reforms have played in developments in East Germany. ''What is currently taking place in the process of German unification would not have happened without reforms in the Soviet Union,'' he said.
But he denied the loan was linked to negotiations with the Soviet Union over withdrawing its 420,000 troops from East Germany, saying ''No, there is no direct relation.''
Economists and foreign policy experts said the loan comes at an excellent time for the Soviet Union, but that it is clearly linked to Soviet concessions on German unity.
''That's quite a plum,'' said Ed A. Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington. ''I'm convinced it's part of a not-so-subtle negotiation where the Germans say, 'We'll support perestroika and the economy and you help us with unification.' It won't be put that bluntly, but it is fairly transparent.''
Mr. Hewett said the Soviet Union needs the money to ''dig itself out of a hole.''
''Over the past six months they have had cash-flow problems,'' he said. ''Some bankers have required them to repay on short-term debt because of the payment problems.''
Mr. Vanous said West Germany's eagerness to overcome Soviet objections on the issue of a united Germany's military alliance membership is also a factor.
''This is the time,'' Mr. Vanous said. ''If the Germans get the right concessions, like a united Germany being part of NATO or the withdrawal of Soviet troops, then they are willing to commit themselves to a lot of financial aid.''
Persistent rumors in Bonn government circles claim West Germany has agreed to provide up to 20 billion marks ($11.9 billion) in immediate aid to the Soviets, a figure Mr. Vanous said seems realistic.
Mr. Vanous said he expected that the new credit would be followed soon by other assistance. ''There will be a deal No. 2,'' he said. ''Either a long-term loan or forgiving some of the Soviet Union's hard-currency debt, which was $60 billion at the end of last year and is probably up to $64 or $65 billion now.''

HEADLINE: Toll in Iranian Quake Is Put at 29,000

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, June 22

 BODY:
Thousands of people, dead and alive, were dug today from the rubble of what appeared to be Iran's worst earthquake. A global relief effort got under way and a stunned nation began to grasp the magnitude of the disaster, which killed thousands and laid waste to a region half the size of New York State.
The official Islamic Republic News Agency said 29,000 people had been killed and 28,000 injured in the quake, which shook northern Iran early Thursday. United Nations relief officials in Geneva quoted the Iranian Foreign Ministry as saying at least 35,000 had died and more than 100,000 had been injured.
 
Toll Expected to Rise
The numbers were only rough estimates based on surveys taken amid widespread confusion and crippled communications. Iranian leaders said the toll was expected to rise in the coming days as relief teams using bulldozers, dogs and bare hands search the rubble of more than 100 cities, towns and villages that were heavily damaged or destroyed. There was no estimate of the number of victims still trapped in rubble. 
The Iranian Red Crescent Society estimated that 400,000 people were left homeless by the temblor, which struck heaviest in Zanjan and Gilan provinces, a densely populated region of mountains, plains, hilly farmland and beach resorts in Iran's Caspian Sea coast area.
The earthquake, which struck at 12:30 A.M. Thursday, was measured at Teheran University at 7.3 on the Richter scale, indicating a severe quake. It combined with more than 100 aftershocks to cause huge landslides that blocked roads and relief convoys, knocked out electricity and water supplies in many areas, destroyed crops and left many villages isolated and thousands of people buried in the rubble of their homes.
 
Villages and Towns Wiped Out
''For the next 10 days, we will be digging through the ruins for corpses,'' an official of the Red Crescent Society said today after returning from the stricken region.
''There are dozens of villages, particularly in Gilan, that have completely disappeared,'' he added. ''Whole towns were flattened as if they never were there. We have no way of getting to many, because the roads are blocked by falling boulders and rocks, and planes have had difficulty landing in the mountains.''
Iranian television showed masked rescuers in white aprons pulling dust-covered bodies from under jagged chunks of concrete and placing them on blocks of ice in open trucks, and survivors as if in a daze rummaging through the remains of homes for loved ones and possessions.
Airborne cameras captured mile after mile of flattened homes and apartment buildings. Hospitals were shown overflowing with victims, including Shakineh Shevediny, a 16-year-old from the village of Manjil, in Gilan province, who recalled waking to find herself buried in debris.
''I could hear the screams of my grandfather,'' she said. After many hours, she was rescued.
''But it was too late for grandfather and my little brother,'' she went on. ''We waited for help on the street. Again at noon, another strong earthquake came, and again and again, until nothing was left of the village.''
Elsewhere in Manjil, a woman held her dead daughter in her arms as workers unearthed the body of another daughter. And a man in Rudbar, a mountainside village in Gilan province, told Iranian television that ''a rock as big as a building'' had crushed his home, killing four of his six children. His wife lay in the ruins for hours before help came.
 
'Not a Single House'
''There is not a single house in this area that has been left standing,'' said Ali Mohammadi, a farmer in Rudbar, where at least 6,000 people were reported to have been killed.
Rescuers used dogs to search for victims and survivors trapped beneath the rubble, and relief officials said in television interviews that thousands had been found alive. Television broadcasts from Rasht, the capital of Gilan province, showed young men frantically digging for victims, cranes lifting concrete slabs and bulldozers clearing roads for ambulances and other rescue vehicles.
About 3,000 trained relief workers and 3,000 tons of supplies were flown into the stricken areas northwest of Teheran aboard 50 flights today, officials of the Red Crescent Society said. Earlier, bad weather and poor visibility had hampered the airlift.
The Teheran airport was thronged with people trying to reach the quake zone to learn the fate of relatives, but only relief flights were going through. Iranian news reporters were in the stricken area, but foreign reporters were not allowed to travel there. Iranian authorities said they would be allowed into the area on Monday or Tuesday.
As military helicopters, C-130 transport planes and special Iran Air flights ferried medical personnel and tons of supplies into the region and flew 6,000 injured survivors out to hospitals in Teheran and other cities, President Hashemi Rafsanjani said the death toll was bound to rise as rescue teams reached thus-far inaccessible towns.
 
President Asks for Aid
''Realistic casualty figures would be a lot higher than those already announced,'' President Rafsanjani said as he stood beside a helicopter in the destroyed village of Rudbar and appealed for foreign assistance. ''Everyone is helping,'' he said, ''but with a calamity this disastrous, nothing could be enough.''
Despite Iran's recent history of diplomatic isolation, many nations rushed to offer humanitarian assistance and condolences. Those offering aid includied Iran's bitter enemy Iraq and the United States, which has not forgotten the 444 days when 52 members of the American Embassy staff here were held hostage in 1979-80.
''I convey my sincerest condolences and declare that we are ready to provide any assistance you may require,'' Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, said in a message to President Rafsanjani. Iran and Iraq each sustained heavy losses in their Persian Gulf war from 1980 to 1988.
The Red Cross in Geneva said Iran had requested antibiotics, tents and blankets, surgical equipment and thread, blood bags, food, vehicles and heavy equipment to lift and move rubble. It said the Red Crescent Society had indicated that doctors, technicians and other medical personnel were not needed.
Offers of assistance were received from the European Community, France, Britain, Japan, Israel, Syria, Finland, Sweden, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Greece, the Netherlands, the Soviet Union, Poland and other countries.
 
Tons of Supplies Sent
Tons of supplies and relief workers were being flown to Iran today, and many more planeloads were expected over the weekend. A senior official in Washington said Iran had accepted the Bush Administration's offer of aid, and the American Red Cross said the organization was raising money for earthquake relief in Iran.
While the full extent of casualties and destruction was unknown, it appears that the quake was the worst ever to strike Iran and - if the casualty estimates hold true or become worse - the world's worst since 200,000 people, by official estimates, died in an earthquake at Tangshan, China, in 1976. Other estimates say as many as 800,000 people may have died in that quake. Iran's worst previous quake killed 25,000 in 1978.
The quake caused damage estimated in the billions of dollars, ravaged one of Iran's major farming regions and could have serious implications for the nation's economy.
The deaths of thousands of laborers, the need to rebuild vast tracts of housing and commercial property, the destruction of irrigation systems and large crops of fruit, rice and wheat are all expected to have major effect on an economy already strained by years of war.
Reza Asghari, an insurance salesman, reached by telephone, said many people were stranded on the streets of Rasht looking for relatives and children. He described the damages in the city as minor compared with surrounding villages like Fuman, Manjil and Rudbar. The Islamic Republic News Agency said the town of Abbar was 100 percent destroyed. The Loshan Dam near Manjil was said to have been damaged by cracks and flooded surrounding areas, the agency said.
In Zanjan province, 4,000 bodies were found and more than 8,000 people were injured, reports indicated early today. In many areas, not a single structure was left standing. The towns and cities of Teheran, Qum, Hamadan, Arak, Saveh, Mahallat and Ashtian suffered minor damage to buildings.

HEADLINE: U.S. DECLARES OWL TO BE THREATENED BY HEAVY LOGGING

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, June 22

 BODY:
The northern spotted owl was formally declared a threatened species today, clearing the way for protection of the ancient forests in which the owls live and setting in motion a plan that could bring further economic trouble to timber towns in the Pacific Northwest.
The decision, announced by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, would make it illegal to harm the owls or destroy their critical habitat, most of which lies in national forests.
The move, which had been expected, has broad political support, although some in Congress criticized Federal officials today for delaying an announcement on how the owls, of which there are about 3,000 known pairs, will be protected. Federal officials said today that they would announce their plan for protecting the owls' habitat, including how much forest will be set aside and how much logging will be allowed there, on Tuesday.
 
Bitter Ecological Battle
The owl, said to be threatened by heavy logging of the nation's oldest and biggest trees, has been at the center of one of the bitterest environmental fights of the last decade. It is a battle that has been fought with lawsuits and with scientific studies arguing the cases for preserving the livelihood of thousands of timber workers on the one hand and for saving rich forestland that has been cut at the rate of 70,000 acres a year on the other. 
''The biological evidence says that the northern spotted owl is in trouble,'' said John Turner, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, a division of the Interior Department. ''We will not, and by law cannot, ignore that evidence.''
If the Wildlife Service decides to reduce logging in 17 national forests in Washington, Oregon and Northern California by 50 percent, as advocated by a panel of Federal biologists, the action would amount to one of the biggest land protection measures ever for a single species. That could cost up to 28,000 timber jobs in the next 10 years, according to Federal estimates.
 
Little Effect on Building
The giant cedars, Douglas fir and redwoods here are particularly prized by builders for their grain and strength, but the owl decision is not expected to have a discernible effect on the overall price of housing, economists say. The cutting of ancient timber in the Northwest provides only a small percentage of the lumber used to build homes in this country.
In recent weeks the price of lumber has dropped, reflecting a glut on the market as timber companies have cut more in anticipation of the owl listing. A slowdown in new home construction has also brought lumber prices down.
The decision to list the owl as threatened shows that ''the Administration recognizes the mistakes of the past which allowed massive clear-cutting of our last remaining ancient forests,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat from Vermont who is chairman of a Senate committee overseeing forestry. But he accused the Bush Administration of ''delaying the tough news until later.''
President Bush had said he would not interfere with the Wildlife Service's decision and has ruled out economic aid to help timber towns make a transition. He compared their fate to that of coal miners in areas where jobs will be lost to meet provisions of the amended Clean Air Act.
In the Reagan Administration, by contrast, political appointees in Federal agencies were accused of trying to alter scientific reports about the owl to make less of the logging industry threat. A senior Forest Service official even recommended cutting down all old-growth forest on Federal lands, calling them a biological wasteland.
Since the passage of the Endangered Species Act in 1973, there have been 577 species in the United States declared endangered, which means they face extinction, or threatened, which means they are likely to become endangered. A species listed as threatened qualifies for the same legal protection. Few listings have ever generated as much heat or passion as the decision over the northern spotted owl.
 
Comprehensive Study Cited
The announcement today ''is based on the most comprehensive scientific inquiry ever made by the Fish and Wildlife Service in preparation for a listing decision,'' said Mr. Turner.
Reaction was generally favorable among environmentalists and fiercely negative among timber industry groups.
''We think the listing will be a catalyst for positive changes in the timber industry and the management of our national forests,'' said Bill Arthur of the Sierra Club. ''At the current rates of logging, the remaining stands of old growth will be gone in the next 20 years.''
Although forest economists have long predicted a decline in both jobs and the remaining ancient forests, the decision on the owl will force immediate changes.
Some timber groups predict that up to 50,000 jobs will be lost over an unspecified period, a figure environmentalists say is inflated.
''Our worst nightmare will come true if Federal decision makers do not respond to our distress signals,'' said Bill Shields, chairman of the American Forest Resource alliance, an industry group.
 
Industry Seeking Delays
Timber industry leaders are trying to get the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management, the two agencies that control the owl habitat, to delay protection of the bird or to come up with a plan other than the one suggested by Federal biologists.
That plan, based on a year of study by biologists from different agencies, could mean 4 million more acres of ancient forest would be made off limits to logging. Some forestry officials have estimated that 1.5 million acres are already off limits to logging in wilderness areas and national parks in the Northwest.
''We do not feel the science is there to warrant taking such drastic action,'' said Chris West, the vice president of the Northwest Forestry Association, an industry group based in Portland, Ore. ''We don't believe the owl is threatened, we think environmentalists are trying to put us out of business.''
Environmentalists in the Northwest say that if significant areas of ancient forests are not protected, they will reactivate lawsuits in Federal Court. Last year similar litigation held up much of the logging in the national forests here.
Forest Service officials say reducing log exports - thereby freeing more timber for domestic mills - and increasing the cut from private timberlands would ease the economic crunch from the owl protection.
 
Efforts to Bar Exports
About 25 percent of all trees cut in the Northwest last year were shipped overseas. Exports are already outlawed in Federal forests, and a bill that prohibits log exports from state lands is in the final phases of consideration in Congress and is expected to pass.
The economy of the Northwest is generally booming, adding more than 120,000 new jobs last year. State economists say logging accounts for only 2 percent of employment in Washington and about 6 percent in Oregon.
But in the small timber towns that are dependent on national forest cutting for their economic well-being, a 50 percent reduction in logging could lead to record unemployment rates, state officials in Washington and Oregon say.
To survive, the towns need to move away from their dependence on ancient forests, said Larry Tuttle, Oregon representative of the Wilderness Society. He said years of overcutting had led to the current crisis.
''We're talking about an industry with record harvests, record profits, record exports at a time when workers' wages have been rolled back and jobs lost to automation,'' Mr. Tuttle said.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Shevardnadze Seeks Curbs On Forces in New Germany

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, June 22

 BODY:
The Soviet Union proposed unexpectedly today that an international endorsement of German unity include provisions for a staged withdrawal of all foreign troops from a united Germany and strict limits on its military.
The proposals, introduced by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at today's second ministerial session of the ''two plus four'' talks on German unity, were promptly rejected by the other participants - the United States, Britain, France and the two Germanys - as an unwarranted restriction on the sovereignty of a future Germany.
At a concluding news conference, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said the Soviet plan would ''restrict German sovereignty and would do so for some years.''
Mr. Baker also rejected a related Soviet proposal that all foreign troops be withdrawn from Berlin within six months of the city's unification, noting that this would leave the city ringed with the 300,000 Soviet troops that are expected to remain for some time in the eastern part of a united Germany. 
 
No Significant Progress
Apart from Mr. Shevardnadze's surprise proposals, the six ministers apparently failed to make significant progress in their effort to negotiate an end to the Allied rights over Germany left over from World War II.
The session ended with what Mr. Baker described as a tentative agreement ''on the interim outline of the elements of a final settlement.'' The ministers also agreed to have experts prepare a list of remaining ''areas of concern'' and to propose appropriate forums for their resolution.
Much of the session was reportedly dominated by debate over Mr. Shevardnadze's proposals. Members of the Western delegations speculated that the Soviets had undertaken the initiative in part for domestic consumption, noting that a congress of the Russian Republic's Communist Party was in progress, and that today was the 49th anniversary of Nazi Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union.
Participants at the talks noted that Mr. Shevardnadze also stressed in his comments that the Soviet Union was eager to reach agreement in time for an all-European conference, scheduled for November, so it can endorse the outcome of the two-plus-four talks. The summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe could clear the way for all-German elections in December, the date Bonn is increasingly working toward.
The West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said at the news conference that he had informed his colleagues ''about the wish of the Germans to vote in a united voting area in December.''
 
Disavows Obstructionism
Mr. Shevardnadze took pains at the news conference to stress that Moscow was not seeking to block progress toward unity. ''I want to emphasize something very important, that we expect to have a final agreement that will resolve all aspects all of German unity by the end of this year,'' he said.
Despite such assurances and the suspicion that Mr. Shevardnadze was at least partly playing to a domestic audience, the Soviet position underscored the difficulties remaining in reconciling Moscow with the loss of its most important military and economic ally, East Germany.
Much of the real negotiating in the two-plus-four process has taken place between Mr. Shevardnadze and Mr. Genscher, who have held 10 meetings in recent months.
Beyond Mr. Shevardnadze's specific proposals lay differences in the basic approach to the two-plus-four talks.
Foremost is Moscow's continuing insistence that the wartime Allies set a transitional period after German unity during which they would retain some of their rights. The Soviets have also sought to include substantive security issues, like the size of the future German army, the alliance to which it would belong, or the withdrawal of Allied forces, into a two-plus-four final settlement.
The Soviet concern apparently is that without these conditions, Moscow would lose any leverage over a united Germany.
 
Other Forums Favored
The Western allies have countered that all such security issues may be debated in the two-plus-four forum, but that they must be resolved only in other international negotiations, such as the Vienna talks on conventional arm reductions, where Germany would not be singled out for continuing special treatment.
The allies have also argued that a united Germany's choice of alliance must ultimately be made by the Germans, and that the task of the two-plus-four talks is only to end all vestigial Allied rights and responsibilities over either Germany or Berlin.
In his package proposal, Mr. Shevardnadze said the final document should include measures to limit the size of the future German army and to shape it in such a way that it would be ''incapable of offensive operations.''
He also proposed that Germany would remain bound for five years by all international treaties signed by West and East Germany, including those involving the Warsaw Pact and NATO. The proposal echoed earlier Soviet demands to keep Germany in both alliances, an idea rejected by the West.
 
To Renounce All Rights
The Western outline of a draft settlement, as presented by Mr. Baker at the news conference, took an entirely different approach. It called on the four powers to renounce all their ''remaining rights and responsibilities,'' including those over Berlin, and to codify the achievement of ''full and complete sovereignty'' by a united Germany.
Mr. Baker also vented unusually direct irritation with Moscow.
''We are trying for our part to meet Moscow's appropriate security concerns,'' he said. ''But I have to say it is incumbent on the Soviets to understand the concerns of the German states and of others in Europe and in the United States as well.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Foreign Ministers Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, left, and Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany at a meeting of the four World War II Allies and the two Germanys yesterday in East Berlin. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: The Mandela Visit;
Mandela Backs Sanctions And Meets U.S. Executives

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela pressed his call for continued economic sanctions to force change in South Africa in an address at the United Nations yesterday, and perhaps more importantly, at a private meeting with major American business executives and investors.
''Nothing that has happened in South Africa calls for a revision of the position that this organization has taken,'' Mr. Mandela told the world body. ''The sanctions that have been imposed by the United Nations and by individual governments should remain in place.''
He hoped, he said, that no country would ease sanctions, creating ''any situation in which those who are opposed to change in our country find encouragement to resist change.''
 
Three Goals
Organizers of Mr. Mandela's hectic United States visit regarded his morning meeting with the executives, many from Fortune 500 corporations, as well as foundation executives and New York movers and shakers as perhaps the most important single stop. 
Mr. Mandela's goals in the meeting, they said, were threefold: to keep up economic pressure on the white South African Government, to allay fears that the African National Congress would impose a socialist economic system through nationalization of industries and to seek future international investment.
Out of the meeting came a proposal by the president of the Rockefeller Foundation, Peter Goldmark, for the creation of a South African development bank to be ready to channel international investment into a newly democratic South Africa. Mr. Goldmark did not offer a plan to finance the bank.
His idea appeared to generate strong interest among the executives at the breakfast meeting, people who were present said, and Mr. Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress, called the proposal ''constructive and imaginative.''
 
Start With a Walk
Mr. Mandela also found himself facing strong criticism from Jewish groups for his continued public support for the Palestine Liberation Organization.
His day began, as it had on Thursday, with a brisk walk from Gracie Mansion through Carl Schurz Park and along the East River. It ended with $2,500-a-person fund-raisers at the East Side town house of the film executive Arthur Krim and at Robert De Niro's trendy TriBeCa Film Center. Mr. Mandela wore his customary gray suit and tie for the walk; his host, Mayor David N. Dinkins, who dresses to the occasion, a blue jogging suit.
The private breakfast meeting in the World Trade Center included such major financial figures as Thomas Johnson of Manufacturer's Hanover Trust; James R. Jones, chairman of the American Stock Exchange; Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation; Donald Marron, chairman of the Paine Webber Group; William A. Scheyer of Merrill Lynch; Muriel Siebert, the first woman to gain a seat on the New York Stock Exchange; Theodore Sorenson, the author who was President John F. Kennedy's special counsel; G. Richard Thoman, president of American Express International; Maurice Tempelsman, whose firm specializes in precious minerals, and; Marvin S. Traub, chairman of Bloomingdale's. There were also such important New York figures as Lewis Rudin, the real-estate executive and Howard J. Rubenstein, the public relations consultant.
 
'Crackling Excitement'
The meeting was organized jointly by the New York City Partnership, a business group established during the city's fiscal crisis, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. A condition of the meeting was that no reporters be present.
In a city so mesmerized by Mr. Mandella's visit that the Empire State Building is lighted up in the African National Congress colors of black, green and yellow, even an audience of executives was not immune to Mr. Mandela's presence, giving him a standing ovation as he entered and departed.
''There was a crackling excitement in the audience,'' Richard Leone, the chairman of the Port Authority, said later. ''I've spent a long time on Wall Street, and you don't usually see that in an audience of this type. It was quite an exciting thing.''
''The idea of continued sanctions was received warmly,'' said Gordon J. Davis, a lawyer and former City Parks Commissioner, who attended the breakfast. ''This was a very mixed group, a cross section of the city's financial powers.
Mr. Goldmark suggested the creation of a South African Development Bank during a brief question period after Mr. Mandela's speech, people present said, likening it to the Marshall Plan, which helped war-ravaged Europe, and efforts now being made to help Eastern European countries recover from Communism.
 
Restructure Economy
It would serve first as a visible symbol to the rest of the world, Mr. Goldmark said, that the international community stands ready to invest in South Africa just as soon as it has a truly democratic Government.
The development bank, Mr. Goldmark suggested, could help restructure the economy by generating investments and channeling development loans that reflect the priorities of a freely chosen, multiracial Government. At the same time, he said, it would need a rigorous structure to gain the confidence of investors.
It would be hard to see how the bank could be started with the present conditions, Mr. Goldmark said, but it was time to begin thoughtful preparations so as to have the mechanism for development investment ready when the country does have a truly democratic Government.
Mr. Mandela appeared intrigued by Mr. Goldmark's proposal, saying at a brief news conference after the breakfast, ''If we have sufficient resources from that institution, it is not necessary for us to look at any other option.''
The economic proposal would appear to lend strength to Mr. Mandela in his negotiations with the South African Government of President F. W. de Klerk.
 
Seeks Mixed Economy
Seeking to ease fears of nationalization, Mr. Mandela told the executives that for the future, the congress sought ''a mixed economy, though we have no blueprint as to the makeup of that mix.''
But he insisted, ''We are convinced that this economy will have to be restructured, so that it is able to serve the material interests of all of our people and not just the white minority.''
''We are sensitive to the fact that as investors in a post-apartheid South Africa,'' Mr. Mandela went on, ''you will need to be confident about the security of your investments, an adequate and equitable return on your capital and a general climate of peace and stability.''
He returned several times to his theme that ''the pressure must be maintained,'' saying at one point, ''You should continue to isolate apartheid South Africa.''
Those at the meeting are used to lives of limousines and opened doors, so they found themselves out of their element in the tight security and closed-off streets imposed for Mr. Mandela's visit. One man laughingly showed a memo his staff had written to him. It bore instructions on how to use the subway and had a token taped to it.
 
'Feverish Pace'
At the United Nations, Mr. Mandela warned that white South African terrorist groups were plotting to kill him and other congress leaders to prevent the dismantling of apartheid.
Some white South Africans, he said, are ''working at a feverish pace to establish paramilitary groups whose stated aim is the physical liquidation of the A.N.C., its leadership and membership as well as other which these right-wing terrorist groups see as a threat to the continued existence of the system of white minority domination.''
Adding that other die-hard armed opponents of change were entrenched in the ranks of the police and the South African army, Mr. Mandela said, ''We cannot afford to underestimate the threat that these defenders of a brutal and continuing reality pose to the whole process of working toward a just political settlement.
''There are many among our white compatriots who are still committed to the maintenance of the evil system of white minority domination,'' he added, some because they are ideologically committed to racism, others because they fear democratic rule.
 
Standing Ovation
Police marksmen stood on nearby rooftops, and police boats patroled the East River as Mr. Mandela received a hero's welcome from cheering United Nations employees.
He addressed the United Nations Special Committee Against Apartheid, although it appeared that most of the General Assembly delegates attended, giving him a standing ovation as he entered. The General Assembly is not in session, and the meeting was specially called to hear Mr. Mandela.
An amatuer boxer in his youth, the South African leader included among his guests the boxers Mike Tyson, Sugar Ray Leonard and the boxing promotor Don King.
''Victory for a united, democratic and nonracial South Africa is within our grasp,'' Mr. Mandela told a cheering audience.
 
'Rancor or Vengeance'
But he also warned that ''the apartheid system remains in place'' and that the encouraging start to his talks with Mr. de Klerk in Cape Town last month ''should not lead us to conclude that further progress is assured or that we will not have to confront major obstacles in the future.''
Before Mr. Mandela spoke, the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, praised the absence of ''rancor or vengeance'' in his statements since his release after 27 years in prison. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York called him ''a symbol of hope for the world.''
But Mr. Mandela has also come under criticism from Jewish groups for his continued support of the Palestine Liberation Organization and its chairman, Yasir Arafat, particularly for remarks Thursday night on the ABC News program, ''Nightline,'' in which he also appeared to condone the Governments of Cuba and Libya.
And in Miami yesterday, the City Commission dropped a planned resolution of welcome for Mr. Mandela, who is to speak at a labor convention in Miami Beach on June 28. Some Cuban exiles called for demonstrations during his visit here to protest Mr. Mandela's praise for Fidel Castro.
Mr. Mandela did not waver from his position in his speech to the United Nations yesterday, saying at one point:
''We also take this opportunity to extend warm greetings to all others who fight for their liberation and their human rights, including the peoples of Palestine and Western Sahara. We commend their struggles to you, convinced that we're all moved by the fact that freedom is indivisible, convinced that the denial of the rights of one diminish the freedom of others.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nelson Mandela called for continued economic sanctions to force change in South Africa as he addressed the United Nations yesterday. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Is at Least on the Right Track

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Efforts to achieve racial equality in the United States have made scant progress since the 1960's, but if Michael Levin's June 9 letter (''Affirmative Action Bears Great Moral Costs'') is an accurate guide, our capacity for careful reasoning about racial issues has shown no improvement at all.
Professor Levin claims that the ''main argument for affirmative action appeals to compensatory justice.'' It is probably true that the best-known arguments for affirmative action appeal to compensatory notions. But the best arguments about affirmative action, pro and con, are framed in noncompensatory terms. 
The principal issue is not whether or not blacks have suffered harms for which they should be compensated (they have certainly suffered harms, but it is unclear that these harms can be compensated for in a meaningful way). It is whether or not we believe our society should allocate privileges to some groups and severe disadvantages to others along largely hereditary lines. This is a political question the answer to which depends upon a decision about substantive values.
Professor Levin asserts that affirmative action programs are unjust to whites who fail to gain positions they might have won if the criteria for allocating these positions were not race-conscious. This argument tacitly assumes that familiar meritocratic criteria for allocating positions are just. But these criteria are determined in light of a heterogeneous mix of public and private objectives, including economic efficiency and productivity, rather than by considerations of justice. There is no good reason why the promotion of racial equality should not be one of these objectives.
Affirmative action is a problematical instrument for advancing racial equality. It is not sufficient for the purpose, which could be achieved only through a national commitment to prevent the continuation of disadvantages by providing the young members of disadvantaged groups with educational resources of a much higher standard than many receive, together with provisions for child care, health care and other forms of support. Affirmative action may not even be necessary for the advancement of racial equality if racial barriers that were a familiar part of the American landscape only a short time ago can be prevented from reappearing.
But affirmative action may be a useful, if highly imperfect, means of edging toward racial equality, especially in the absence of a serious national effort to achieve this objective in a more satisfactory way. In any case, affirmative action should be evaluated for its likely consequences, not by misplaced appeals to compensatory notions.
 
DAVID JOHNSTON
 New York, June 9, 1990
 
The writer is an assistant professor of political science, Columbia U.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Nonproliferate Peace

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: GENEVA

 BODY:
The assumption that the Soviet-American arms race has ended, and with it the risk of global nuclear holocaust, has spread much faster than the facts. Some troubling new issues are coming to the fore as countries contemplate the role of nuclear weapons in a world not dominated by East-West confrontation.
There was a striking example here after the chief American and Soviet negotiators on strategic arms reduction spoke to a meeting on the future of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The Groupe de Bellerive, headed by Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, was meeting to look ahead to a review conference on the treaty scheduled this summer, and to the 1995 deadline for renewing the treaty or letting it lapse. 
The U.S. negotiator, Richard Burt, and his Soviet counterpart, Yuri Nazarkin, noted important differences they still had to settle. But they were clearly in the same boat, allies against critics from all over, including American and British activists.
Some of the anti-nuclear militants now share the problem of cold warriors, furiously insisting that nothing has really changed so they don't have to reconsider their crusades. The bigger difficulty comes from other parts of the world that have yet to undergo a sea change on the ideas of war and what constitutes security.
There's a certain apple-pie stamp of goodness on the Nonproliferation Treaty, but it's fading. True, there aren't nearly as many more nuclear powers in the world as was fearfully anticipated.
But as one speaker said, there are a number of ''latent and blatant proliferators'' who show little sign of backing away from being or becoming bomb-capable. Although it has proved to be an economic dud for energy supply, plutonium is being produced at a rate that threatens to become uncontrollable. That should be stopped. On present plans, Japan alone will have 400 tons in 30 years, twice the present holdings of the U.S. and U.S.S.R. combined.
Some attack the Nonproliferation Treaty as a failure because even if the superpowers cut their arsenals by half, they would have three times as many warheads as when they signed the treaty in 1968 with a promise to reduce. Others say it's a way to institutionalize military inferiority and inequality in the third world.
The status symbol of nuclear weapons still has a powerful appeal. There's no conceivable military or security reason for South Africa to want them, given its huge arms machine. India, which exploded a ''device,'' says it has no intention of producing weapons, but comforts the ambition of assuring its place as regional superpower by keeping alive the possibility. Pakistan won't renounce its effort to counter.
An Israeli said even the most ardent doves in his country wouldn't give up the last-resort option on which it counts for survival, despite threats of chemical war from Iraq. While Jerusalem keeps mum on the subject, there is reason to think the famous revelation of Israel's arsenal by Mordechai Vanunu was seen as a boon by Israeli strategists.
Mr. Vanunu was kidnapped from London after spilling the nuclear beans to The Sunday Times, tried and sentenced to 18 years. But the incident served to establish Israel as a nuclear power without the onus of conducting a test or admitting to being able.
Now that the big powers agree that deterrence worked between them, others are saying, why not us? It's a tough question, something like the idea of legalizing narcotics. Nuclear weapons, like drugs, are doubtless bad for people, but if making them available reduces violence, is that worse than ineffective attempts to police them?
Of course, there are some important differences. A technical one is that it is increasingly evident that nuclear capacity has spread almost entirely by exports from advanced industrial countries, which could police themselves better. An existential one is that not all states will be rational, the key assumption of deterrence; and a little nuclear slippage is a vast catastrophe.
As they reduce conventional arms, East and West may rely more on their nuclear deterrence, certainly if other countries rattle rockets. A hypothetical excuse for superiority, said an Indian. An inevitable response, said a Frenchman.
The underlying point is that making the world safer has to come from political change and recognition that wars are a net loss to all concerned. That's started in Europe; it needs to proliferate. Meanwhile, the Nonproliferation Treaty must be kept and strengthened.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: All New Jersey Schools to Face New Limits

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

 BODY:
Restrictions on spending await both the troubled urban school systems in New Jersey that are gaining millions of dollars under the state's revised school-financing formula, and the wealthy suburban districts facing sharp cutbacks in aid.
The poorest urban districts will be able to spend their windfall only on programs that the State Education Department will help them draft before their new money pours in for the 1991-92 school year.
And the wealthy districts face a cap on their spending, cutting their powers to raise unlimited money through local property taxes. To suburban superintendents, this is one of several bitter financial pills forced on them by Gov. Jim Florio's sweeping redistribution of state educational spending. 
As for the controls on urban schools, Florio administration officials, sensitive to fears that the sharply higher aid could be wasted, say they want to keep tight reins on the money and insure that it goes for approved and educationally sound programs.
That policy will be directed at the state's 30 poorest urban districts. They include Newark, Paterson, Jersey City, Camden and Trenton and serve about 29 percent of the state's 1.1 million schoolchildren. Traditionally, the 30 urban districts have had the state's deepest social ills and weakest student performance. In the five years starting next summer, the 30 will receive most of the new aid generated by Governor Florio's $1.2 billion in income tax increases and the millions in state aid being shifted from wealthy and upper-middle-class suburban districts, almost all of them in Bergen, Essex, Morris and Passaic Counties.
By 1996, aid for Newark, Camden, Paterson, Jersey City and Trenton alone will increase to $1.28 billion, from $728.6 million in 1990-91, under the ''foundation'' spending system created by the new law.
In the next few weeks, state education authorities will start meeting with urban superintendents to select and plan for new educational programs for the 1991-92 school year.
''That's going to be the highest priority -helping them put together policies and programs that are effective,'' said Thomas B. Corcoran, Governor Florio's chief education adviser. ''We're going to give them a list of things they should consider. If they want to do other things, we're going to ask for educational justification.''
Mr. Corcoran said programs being considered included an extended school day, smaller class sizes in kindergarten through third grade, full-day kindergarten, guidance counselors in elementary schools, higher-level academic courses and improved vocational and career guidance in high schools, and broader offerings in science and social studies in middle schools.
''These things would give urban students the same full range of opportunities offered in other schools,'' Mr. Corcoran said. ''These kids are the future work force and the future taxpayer, and if they're not taxpayers, they will be on welfare. We in this country have got to succeed with these kids.''
As for New Jersey's wealthiest suburban districts, the new law's cap on their future spending increases creates a double impact on them - declining state aid between 1992 and 1996 and less freedom to offset the loss with higher local taxes.
 
Spending Caps Opposed at First
The cap ranges from 7.5 percent to 15 percent, depending on how much a district's budget for the 1991-1992 school year exceeds the foundation budget that the state will assign it starting July 1991. For instance, a district spending 50 percent above the foundation budget for 1991-92 will be allowed to increase spending by 7.5 percent. A district whose budget is equal to the foundation budget can spend 15 percent more. Only the 30 poorest districts are exempt from the cap.
The Florio administration initially opposed limiting the wealthy districts for two reasons. When they proposed the new formula on May 24, Florio aides said they feared a spending cap could prevent a high-performing innovative district from creating new programs that ultimately could be copied in urban districts. They were also concerned that a state-imposed spending restriction on a premiere local district could diminish its reputation and impede economic growth in the region around it.
The administration initially planned to cut aid only to the wealthy districts to help finance the sharp increases for the poor districts.
But the State Supreme Court's school-aid ruling on June 5 forced a change in administration policy.
 
Equal Spending for Poorest
The ruling ordered spending parity between pupils in the state's 28 poorest districts and its 54 richest. The court placed no obstacles on spending by the rich. But it ordered the state to aid the poorest enough to equalize their spending with the richest.
Thus, unless the Governor's new law capped the richest districts, they in effect would have been able to dictate policy on state education spending.
The foundation formula provides money to help districts reach three arbitrary statewide per-pupil spending levels in 1991-92 - $6,835 for kindergarten through grade 5; $7,519 for grades 6 to 8 and $9,091 for grades 9 to 12.
Florio aides say those levels will provide all children with quality education. A district's share of foundation aid depends on its property wealth and per-capita income. For 1991-92, 428 districts will divide up $3.2 billion, with the poorest districts getting the biggest share.
The state's 150 richest districts will get no foundation aid. They include Princeton, Tenafly, Millburn, West Orange, Wayne, Livingston, Hackensack and Englewood.
Because the foundation aid package includes money to help meet the state's new requirement that all local districts pay their teachers' pension and Social Security costs and retiree health benefits, those 150 districts will have to pay all those expenses from local taxes. The estimated annual increase of pension and other costs is about 11 percent.
Suburban superintendents and teachers fear that those costs - worsened by both the law's budget cap and four years of declining state aid through 1996 - will lead to cuts in staff and programs and reduce premiere districts to average ones over time.

HEADLINE: A Corrupt Alliance in New York Clenches the Construction Trade

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Authorities say Thursday's indictments of 12 men accused of rigging painting contracts spotlights a wider problem in the city's construction industry: the secret pacts between the Mafia, union officials and corrupt contractors.
Law-enforcement officials and other experts who have studied the city's construction problems believe that some contractors have long viewed the Mafia as a stabilizing force that will insure profits in a hard-pressed industry.
The painting indictments obtained by the Manhattan District Attorney's office charged that all major public and private contracts in the city had been rigged for the last 12 years. Those accused of participating in the conspiracy are eight top officials of the painters' union, two suspected leaders of the Lucchese crime family and two contractors. 
 
Inflated Costs
Prosecutors say the corrupt painting contracts inflated public and private costs by untold millions of dollars. The indictments came only a month after a Federal indictment asserted Mafia leaders had fixed bids on $142 million in window contracts at the city's Housing Authority.
In addition to painting contractors and window manufacturers, prosecutors say that the carpentry, dry wall and concrete trades have long been under the thumb of New York's five organized-crime families. Contractors in each of these trades, the authorities say, formed secret and profitable monopolies known as ''clubs,'' with the Mafia's blessings.
The ''clubs,'' with the connivance of bribed union officials, squeezed out legitimate competitors. In a report in 1987, the state's Organized Crime Task Force found that many contractors in the city actually welcomed the Mafia.
''Syndicates can assure contractors that they will only have to pay off once for a specified result, that the amount to be paid will be reasonable and that the services paid for will be delivered,'' the report said.
As an example of the underworld's influence, the report noted that the Mafia secretly obtained for contractors lower wage scales and resolved union jurisdictional disputes that might have led to work stoppages. In this role, the report emphasized, racketeers by criminal means serve as de facto labor consultants.
Frank M. Schoenfeld, a former official in the city's painters' union, the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades District Council 9, said he tried unsuccessfully to get contractors from outside the city to seek work here.
''The legitimate contractors can't compete with the guys in the club,'' said Mr. Schoenfeld. ''And on top of that they certainly don't want to get messed up,'' he added, referring to physical violence.
Several contractors who agreed to be interviewed on the condition they would not be identified acknowledged paying bribes to union executives, as well as organized-crime figures. The payoffs prevented wildcat walkouts that would have delayed projects, increased costs and jeopardized profits, the contractors explained.
Many contractors are strapped for cash because they get full payment from private developers or the city only after a public or private project is completed.
Contracts for municipal construction and renovation and maintenance work are normally awarded to qualified low bidders. City agencies can reject a low bid if it is too high. Officials, however, contend that it is difficult to measure reasonable construction costs.
 
Corruption Is Ingrained
''Even if vigilant city officials were to detect patterns of corruption there is little they can do about it,'' said Edward A. McDonald, the former head of the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force in Brooklyn. ''Collusive bidding is so ingrained in the economic life of the city that it would be meaningless to disqualify one or two bidders suspected of bid-rigging.''
In 1986 the administration of former Mayor Edward I. Koch tried to reduce the mob's influence over concrete supplies in Manhattan. The city guaranteed million-dollar municipal contracts to any responsible company that would build a plant on rent-free city land on the West Side of Manhattan.
But there were almost no takers. The reason: many out-of-town companies said they were intimidated by the reputation of the city's construction industry for corruption, violence and Mafia influence.
Law-enforcement officials say that organized crime penetrated the construction industry mainly through its domination of pivotal labor unions. Most construction workers in the city have no steady employer, no seniority rights and they are usually assigned to jobs through union hiring halls. Union officials, especially business agents, are critical in determining who works and who gets the highest-paid jobs.
''If you are a corrupt union official, or in cahoots with the mob, you make sure your cronies keep electing you,'' said Herman Benson, secretary of the Association for Union Democracy, a group that monitors union elections and civil rights. ''There are virtually no grievance procedures for anyone in the construction trades who fights the Mafia.''
Until the early 1980's, the Federal Labor Department's New York Office of Labor Racketeering was the only agency that routinely watched for underworld influence and corruption in the construction field. Labor racketeering generally had a low priority for Federal and state law-enforcement agencies. Sporadic convictions of low-level Mafia figures or union leaders had little effect on corruption.
But in recent years the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the state's Organized Crime Task Force and the Manhattan District Attorney's office have begun long-range campaigns to clean up the city's industry.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 44.55 Points, To 2,857.18

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks tumbled late yesterday as program traders moved in heavily toward the end of the day selling stocks along a broad front.
By the close, the Dow Jones industrial average had plunged 44.55 points, to 2,857.18.
Despite three days of advancing prices after Monday's 53.71-point drop, yesterday's loss brought the cumulative decline for the week to 78.71 points.
Just one week ago the bellwether blue-chip average stood at 2,935.89 -its highest point in history. 
 
Reason for Move Uncertain
With many Wall Street traders leaving early on a hot summer day, analysts were hard pressed to find a solid reason why program traders moved in so heavily when they did.
But David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist for Jesup & Lamont Inc. of New York, said, ''Half the traders in the S.&P. pits in Chicago left early, and there was no one around to counteract the sell programs.''
One trader remarked, ''Someone important had to have been shot for the market to drop that much.''
Traders have apparently been nervous all week, particularly after Monday's sharp decline. In expectation of further declines, speculators have been selling short, that is, selling stock they do not yet own in the hope of buying it later for less money.
For most of the day the Dow moved narrowly, staying close to the opening level of 2,901.73, climbing just before 3 P.M. to around 2,921, its highest point of the session. From that point it dropped sharply.
 
Effects of Two Sell Programs
Birinyi Associates cited two sell programs, where traders used computers to sell stocks and buy S.&P. 500 index futures. One program began at 3:24 P.M., lasted for 16 minutes and clipped 39 points off the Dow. The other, starting at 3:46, lasted seven minutes and lopped off 15 more points. Buy programs and normal trading activities helped offset the strong decline.
Laszlo Birinyi, head of the research firm, said, ''On a late Friday in the summertime, there's not going to be many buyers around to stem the tide.''
Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said that while durable goods orders rose 3.9 percent in May, or much more than had been expected, and personal income rose three-tenths of 1 percent, or somewhat less than expected, neither created any market excitement.
''There's a little apprehension out there,'' he said.
He said that the big financial institutions had been buying stock in the last two weeks to ''dress up'' their portfolios and that this ''has been supporting the market.''
But, he asked, ''What happens when the second quarter ends and the window dressing stops?''
Moreover, he said, earnings reports on the second quarter will begin coming out soon and that ''uncertainty'' over both the end of the window dressing and what earnings will look like would keep the market ''trendless and directionless'' until some hard news comes along.
Mr. Johnson argued that that news is still two weeks away, when the Government announces employment data for June.
In Cleveland, Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Prescott, Ball & Turben, said that after Monday's decline, ''the rally that followed was not big enough to convince people it was a rally.'' He noted that stocks advanced most of the day yesterday but that ''the advance lacked volume as well as breadth.''
Mr. Bostian of Jesup & Lamont argued that buy programs and end-of-the-quarter window dressing had supported the market but that the buying ''burned itself out.'' Volume, still only moderately strong, rose to 172.6 million shares, from 138.6 million the day before. But 893 stocks fell and only 607 advanced.
While the Dow industrials slumped 44.55 points, the broader S.&P. 500 index fell 5.04, to 355.43, or the equivalent of a 40.57-point drop in the Dow, confirming that the selloff was fairly widespread.
The Nasdaq composite fell 1.94, to 459.33, and the Amex market value index slid 0.93, to 359.29.
Among market favorites caught in the selloff, I.B.M. fell 2 7/8, to 116 1/4, in heavy trading. Compaq Computer slid 3 3/4, to 120 1/4, also in heavy trading. Digital Equipment, another big computer company, fell 2 1/2, to 83, again in heavy trading.
Walt Disney fell 3 3/4, to 127 3/4, on substantially more than a half-million shares.
 
Campbell Soup Off 2 3/8
Campbell Soup, supposedly a takeover target of Philip Morris, fell 2 3/8, to 57 1/4, on 483,000 shares after Philip Morris agreed to buy most of Jacobs Suchard A.G. of Switzerland for $3.8 billion. European analysts have speculated, however, that Philip Morris may still be in the market for other big companies.
After Moody's said it was considering downgrading their bonds because of the weakening outlook for military business, Litton Industries fell 3 5/8, to 71 1/2; McDonnell Douglas fell 1 1/4, to 34 1/2, after hitting a low at 34; Raytheon fell 2, to 62 1/2, and Lockheed fell 3/8, to 34 7/8.
Boeing, which rose 4 5/8 last week to 60 1/8, fell 1 5/8 in heavy trading, to 57 3/8.
Loctite, a maker of sealants and adhesives, rose 2, to 60 1/4, in strong trading but declined a New York Stock Exchange request to say why. First Brands, maker of Glad bags and Prestone and STP automotive products, rose 4 3/4, to 28 3/8, on 1.9 million shares after it put itself on the block.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Up Last Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods jumped 3.9 percent in May, the Government reported today. Analysts said it was further evidence that the economy's sluggish manufacturing sector might be bouncing back.
''There have been some signs of a manufacturing rebound,'' said Paul Getman, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. 
The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods - items like automobiles and appliances expected to last at least three years - totaled a seasonally adjusted $128.2 billion after falling 4.2 percent in April.
 
Record Plunge in January
Orders have risen in three of the last four months after plunging a record 10.5 percent in January.
''Taken in conjunction with the stronger 6.7 percent gain in March, there are signs that industrial activity may be gradually emerging from its slump,'' said Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers.
Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, noted that much of the recent manufacturing weakness had been in the automobile industry. ''With the auto sector moving back to more normal, the manufacturing tone in terms of orders, unfilled orders and industrial production is starting to look a little better,'' he said. ''It could be an element of hope that has not been present for over a year.''
 
Rise in Autos and Planes
Most of the May increase was in transportation equipment, up 9.9 percent, to $35.3 billion. Nearly two-thirds of this rise was concentrated in automobiles; most of the remainder was in aircraft. Transportation orders have been volatile during much of the year, with, for instance, a 13.5 percent drop in April and a 24.1 percent gain in March.
Excluding transportation, orders were up 1.8 percent in May.
But while analysts saw some reason for optimism in the overall report, the closely watched nonmilitary capital goods sector, often a barometer of business investment plans, fell 1.4 percent, to $36.1 billion. It was the fourth decline this year after peaking in December at $44.4 billion.
Military equipment orders, another volatile category, jumped 19 percent, to $9.9 billion, after a 3.4 percent rise in April. Excluding the military sector, orders rose 2.8 percent.
Shipments of durable goods, which have increased in three of the last four months, were up 3.5 percent in May, to $126.1 billion. Unfilled orders edged up by four-tenths of 1 percent, to $500.3 billion, nearly half of which was in aircraft.
Both non-electrical machinery and primary metal orders were up in May. Non-electrical machinery posted a 3.2 percent gain, to $22.2 billion. Primary metals were up 2.2 percent, to $11.8 billion, most of which was in steel. Electrical machinery orders inched down two-tenths of 1 percent, to $20.4 billion.

HEADLINE: May Spending Unchanged; Income Shows a Small Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Personal spending was flat in May, the Government said today in a report pointing to growing caution among consumers who have been a major source of strength for the economy during seven years of growth.
''The consumer clearly has pulled back in a dramatic fashion,'' said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.
The Commerce Department also said personal income rose by only three-tenths of 1 percent in May for a second straight month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.7 trillion. 
 
Rate of $3.66 Trillion
The department said consumer spending remained unchanged at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.66 trillion after seven straight months of gains, including five-tenths of 1 percent in April and three-tenths in March. But even the April and March rises were weaker than first thought. They were revised downward from the six-tenths of 1 percent and five-tenths increases reported last month.
Consumer spending is considered a barometer of economic health since it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Analysts have cited a poor job market and weak wage increases for the flagging consumer confidence.
Indeed, the income gains of only three-tenths of 1 percent in both April and May followed three consecutive monthly rises of eight-tenths and were the lowest since a two-tenths increase last September.
 
No Match for Inflation
The income gains have not even matched the inflation rate, said Sandra Shaber, an economist at the Futures Group, a Washington management consulting firm.
Today's report was the latest indicating a slowdown in consumer spending, which has been a driving force for much of the current economic expansion that is now in its eighth year.
The Commerce Department reported last week that retail sales fell in May, their third consecutive monthly decline. It was the first time retail sales fell for three straight months since the summer of 1981, during the last recession. Retail sales represent about half of overall consumer spending. And the department on Thursday revised downward its previous estimate of consumer spending in the first quarter.
Nevertheless, Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley said the slow pace of consumer spending was not likely to tip the economy into a recession because ''there are other things out there still giving the economy a boost.'' He cited a second report today showing that orders for durable goods - ''big ticket'' items expected to last at least three years - jumped by 3.9 percent in May.
 
Savings Figure Improved
The difference between incomes and spending in May helped improve the savings rate of Americans. The rate - savings as a percent of disposable income - rose to 6.2 percent following a 6 percent rate in April and a 6.3 percent rate in March. March's was the highest in five years.
A higher savings rate means less dependence on foreign capital as more funds are available domestically for business investment.
The report said the income of Americans after taxes increased by two-tenths of 1 percent, the same rate as in April. The key component of the income category - wages and salaries - rose by $10.3 billion after a $16.4 billion gain in April.
On the spending side, purchases of durable goods fell by $12.6 billion after an $8.5 billion gain in April. Durable goods purchases had fallen the previous two months.
Purchases of nondurable goods were down $500 million in May, their third consecutive decline. Spending on services slowed to $13.1 billion after a $14.7 billion gain in April and a $19.6 billion rise in March.

HEADLINE: One Holdout Said to Snag Trump Deal

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
A major German bank is now the biggest obstacle between Donald J. Trump and a $65 million loan package to rescue his empire, bankers said yesterday.
Bankers negotiating a plan to help keep Mr. Trump out of bankruptcy said several Japanese banks that had refused to approve the loan proposal had changed their position, but Dresdner Bank A.G., which holds a $15 million share of a loan secured by the Trump Tower, was refusing.
Mr. Trump, who has been largely absent from public view since news spread of his financial troubles, issued a statement yesterday expressing confidence that the banks would reach a final agreement.
 
Deal Called 'Very Close'
''The banks we have been working with are very close to coming together in support of a restructuring plan,'' he said. 
The package, which will include lending the developer $65 million and deferring interest and principal payments on about $850 million of his nearly $2 billion of bank debt, has the tentative approval of Mitsubishi Trust and Banking, Sumitomo Bank and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank.
Earlier in the week, those three, along with Dresdner, had refused to approve the new loan arrangement because it required that another lien be put on the Trump Tower, the developer's Fifth Avenue skyscraper.
Bankers in the talks said Dresdner Bank was still refusing to approve the package and wanted the large American banks to buy out its position. Bankers and lawyers in the talks said that none of the banks would agree to buying out Dresdner and that they would allow the deal to collapse rather than buy out any other bank. Representatives from the Trump Organization will be meeting with Dresdner executives today to try to persuade the bank to change its stance.
Dresdner ''refuses to budge,'' one banker said. ''And unless the Dresdner Bank agrees, this German institution will bring down Donald Trump.''
 
Part of a Syndicate
Dresdner is part of a syndicate that now holds the $75 million loan that the Chase Manhattan Bank originally made to Mr. Trump against the Trump Tower. Each of four foreign banks in the syndicate holds just under $15 million of the loan, with Chase holding slightly more. The plan for the new loan requires that all the banks with loans secured by Mr. Trump's assets approve the plan. Most of the other loan syndicates, including one led by Citibank and another led by Chase, have generally agreed to go along with the plan.
Mr. Trump failed to pay bankers and bondholders about $73 million that was due last Friday. If he does not pay the holders of bonds from the Trump's Castle casino about $43 million by midnight Tuesday, he will have defaulted on the bonds and will probably lose control of that casino. Such a default would threaten all of Mr. Trump's Atlantic City casino licenses and could ultimately force him to seek the protection of the bankruptcy court.
Two holders of bonds tied to Mr. Trump's Atlantic City casinos filed a class action suit yesterday in a Federal court in New Jersey charging that Mr. Trump had misled them.
 
Talk of Who Would Benefit
In his statement yesterday, Mr. Trump thanked the banks for their work and also noted that the restructuring of his real estate and gambling empire would benefit his employees and those who do business with him.
''A final agreement would benefit all of us, but perhaps most important are the 25,000 employees and thousands of family firms and other suppliers - spanning the hotel, construction, development and travel industries - that are dependent upon the Trump Organization,'' he said.
Mr. Trump said he was confident that the banks that had not yet approved the package would do so. He said he wanted to do not only what was in his own interest but also what was best for the economy of the region.

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Issues Rise a Bit

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were slightly higher yesterday despite several seemingly negative currents swirling about the credit markets.
One factor that was ignored was the Government's report of an unexpectedly sharp 3.9 percent jump in May durable goods orders. In another report, the Commerce Department said that consumer spending was unchanged last month and there was a small rise of only three-tenths of 1 percent in personal income.
The two reports seemed to cancel each other out, said Elizabeth Reiners, a bond market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The durable goods report showed a strong industrial sector, but that was offset by the weaker-than-expected personal consumption data, she added. 
 
Flood of Debt Shrugged Off
The domestic fixed-income market also shrugged off the flood of new Treasury debt coming to market next week, when nearly $48 billion of bills and notes are scheduled for auction.
What did interest bond market participants was a further decline in prices of Canadian Treasury debt because of the constitutional crisis that has engulfed the largest trading partner of the United States over Quebec's latest bid for greater autonomy. Dealers said Canadian long-term Treasury bonds lost a further half-point, or $5 for each $1,000 of face value, while shorter issues were down a quarter point.
But the widely held 8.5 percent Hydro-Quebec bonds of 2029 were steady at 9.25 percent bid, to yield 9.39 percent in American funds. Dealers said investors on both sides of the border thought the likelihood of power shortages in the Northeast United States was more certain than the chance of a Canadian breakup.
In the United States, ''there are several reasons why our Treasury market seems to lack direction,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. ''One obvious reason is the ever-increasing supply of Treasury paper coming to market, partly as the fallout from the savings and loan disaster.''
He noted that the $11.25 billion of two-year notes scheduled for auction on Tuesday had been increased by $450 million; the $8.25 billion of four-year notes to be sold the next day was raised by $250 million, and the record $10.25 billion of one-year bills to be sold Thursday was also increased by $250 million.
''A large portion of the increases will go for the bailout,'' he said. ''So will a sizable portion of the $50 to $55 billion of debt that we expect the Treasury will sell in the third quarter.''
After being virtually unchanged for most of the day, a modest late rally created small gains. The Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered late in the session at 102 31/32, up 4/32 on the day. The long bond's yield dipped to 8.47 percent from 8.48 percent the day before, but was still above the 8.42 of a week ago.
 
Long Notes Show Rise
The Treasury's long notes, the 8 7/8's of 2000, rose 3/32, to 102 16/32, to yield 8.49 percent. Meanwhile, the two-year notes that the Treasury plans to auction on Tuesday traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.34 percent, compared with 8.36 percent the day before. The four-year notes yielded 8.43 percent, against 8.46 percent the day before.
At the shorter end of the Treasury market, the discount rate on 90-day bills eased a basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, to 7.76 percent; the six-month bills dipped two basis points, at 7.63 percent, and the outstanding one-year bills lost two basis points, at 7.55 percent.
There were signs that the banking system had adequate reserves as the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans eased to 8 3/16 percent. This compared with the 8.25 percent level that the Fed has apparently set as its target since last December.
