HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
A Leg Up for Ailing Pets

 BODY:
Pets who are old, ailing or injured don't have to be confined to the floor. Even if they find it difficult to jump to their favorite high spot, they can now make it there with the aid of PawsWay, a ramp designed for cats and small dogs with limited mobility. 
The idea came from Mary Coeli Meyer of Acworth, Ga., who built a ramp for her mother's 18-year-old arthritic cat last year.
''She gets lost if she can't get to where she wants,'' Ms. Meyer said. With the ramp, ''she could get where she wanted instead of howling for help.''
Dr. Pam Webb, a veterinarian at Bells Ferry Veterinary Hospital in Acworth, who helped Ms. Meyer modify the design, said old pets, or those who have recently had surgery, need to rest on soft surfaces and may feel they are being punished if they must stay on the floor. PawsWay can help them get on a chair or sofa. PawsWay is a 7 1/4-inch-wide wooden ramp with a gradual incline and a carpeted surface. It can be adjusted to six lengths, from 4 1/2 inches to 19 inches.
''It isn't much different from using a wooden plank,'' Dr. Webb said. ''It's just a piece of furniture and a little more attractive.''
At Ms. Meyer's request, the ramps are being built by unemployed veterans through a program run by the Veterans Administration. It has been on the market for about six weeks and has mostly been advertised in pet industry journals and at pet shows.
PawsWay can be ordered through Pet Care With Love Inc., P.O. Box 764, Department MPR, Glenview, Ill. 60025; telephone 404-928-2700. A pine model costs $49.95, and one in oak costs $64.95. Add $8 for shipping and handling.

LENGTH: 1707 words

HEADLINE: The Elbowing Is Becoming Fierce For Space on the Radio Spectrum

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The pizza-delivery business, the cellular telephone industry and futuristic high-definition television have something unfortunate in common. All covet the same bands on the already crowded spectrum of broadcast frequencies.
The conflict is one of many instances in which technologies that rely on radio and microwave signals are competing for a finite amount of space that is almost full. New technologies are pitted against existing ones, and the commercial sector against the military. In the middle are the White House, Congress and the Federal Communications Commission.
The many companies that use the broadcast frequencies, without charge, to sell goods and services have total revenues estimated at $100 billion a year. That number could grow faster if the Government gives up some of its frequencies, allowing the introduction of new products, said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who has introduced legislation to that end. 
''Opening more spectrum will contribute to economic progress in the United States,'' he said.
Mr. Markey and some other legislators say the Government - in particular, the military - should give up some frequencies, arguing that because of reduced international tensions the military needs less space on the broadcast spectrum.
On Friday the Department of Defense said it strongly opposed Mr. Markey's bill, which, it said in a statement, ''would adversely affect U.S. national security.'' The statement continued, ''This concern received little attention in the current drafting of the bill.'' A spokeswoman added that the Pentagon used its frequencies heavily and efficiently.
How to allocate frequencies is a public policy issue comparable to how to make the best use of public land, an issue as old as the nation. In 1785, for instance, Congress reserved one section of each township in the Northwest Territory for the use of public schools. In the 19th century, the Federal Government decided to allocate public land in Western states to encourage companies to build railroads.
''The railroads would have developed very differently and probably much slower without those land rights,'' said Eli M. Noam, a Columbia University economist.
 
Decades of Debates
The broadcast spectrum is public property, and the Federal Communications Commission is charged with regulating its use in the public interest. Debates over the spectrum are not new; in 1925, Commerce Secretary Herbert C. Hoover announced that the broadcast spectrum was full and that no more radio licenses would be issued. For decades, debates have flared as inventors of new products sought access to allocated frequencies.
Until each logjam is broken, the American people do not have access to a product or service that some company is eager to provide. Motorola Inc., for instance, a few years ago developed a wireless short-range computer modem, a device that would allow computers to transmit data directly to other computers, bypassing telephone lines. But the device could not be sold until recently because no frequency was allocated for it.
The decisions about how to re-allocate broadcast frequencies could also affect a number of services that are a staple of life, like AM radio and UHF television.
 
Effect on Competitiveness
The decisions will also affect the international competitiveness of the American telecommunications industry for decades to come, because the first country to introduce a product typically sets technical and manufacturing standards that other countries follow.
''If we're going to continue to be a leader in telecommunications, we're going to have to move fast on this one,'' said Sherrie P. Marshall, one of the five commissioners of the Federal Communications Commission.
Some current conflicts include these:
* The microwave frequencies that energy companies use to relay safety information from remote pipeline-monitoring instruments are coveted by proponents of at least three new types of tiny cellular telephones, as well as by backers of high-definition television, which will provide movie-quality picture and sound.
* Frequencies being used for UHF, or ultrahigh frequency, television channels 21 through 69 are also wanted by supporters of high-definition television. The cellular telephone industry wants these same frequencies, as do those parties that rely on two-way radio -pizza-delivery companies, railroads and police forces, for example. Owners of television stations that currently use the frequencies generally favor reassigning them to high-definition television, in which they hope to have an interest themselves. The existing UHF stations would then be converted to high-definition technology.
* Digital radio broadcasts, which allow sound quality rivaling that of compact disks, need frequencies now used by the Government and by private companies to transmit data from rocket launchings and tests of experimental aircraft. Companies that want to use satellite-based systems to provide navigational assistance and telephone communications for trains, trucks, boats and planes have a few of these frequencies and want more.
If nothing is done to reallocate frequencies, the introduction of such products and services will be delayed. But Congress has historically been reluctant to tackle the problems because powerful interest groups control many frequencies and because the issues are technically complex.
Two events in Washington this month reflected the growing concerns among public officials and regulators.
On Tuesday, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce unanimously approved a bill that would compel the Government to hand over to the private sector within 10 years a large chunk of the frequencies it controls. A vote by the full House is expected next month, while the Senate Communications Subcommittee is considering similar action. Inquiry by F.C.C. On June 14, the F.C.C. voted unanimously to begin a broad public inquiry into whether frequencies should be set aside for several new technologies that could allow wallet-sized cellular telephones to be used almost anywhere.
Representative Markey, who is chairman of the House subcommittee and a co-sponsor with John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, of the bill approved on Tuesday, said the legislation represents a peace dividend as Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union seem less of a threat.
The Dingell-Markey bill would force the Government to give up usable frequencies totaling 200 megahertz.
The Bush Administration has refused to support the bill, although it has not actively opposed it.
Political debates over frequency allocations have moved slowly in part because of their technical complexity.
The electromagnetic spectrum is an immense range of energy waves at varying frequencies, including everything from radio waves and microwaves to visible light and X-rays. In broadcasting, the information to be conveyed is converted to an electrical signal that is transformed into radio waves or higher-frequency microwaves of a particular frequency, or channel. These waves are then broadcast to antennas of receivers, which convert them back into electrical signals that re-create the information.
 
Frequencies Allocated in Europe
A home or car radio receives music and voices on frequencies low on the spectrum. Television and cellular telephones use higher frequencies. Communications satellites and the private microwave links of long-distance telephone companies and other corporations use an even higher part of the spectrum.
Now, with virtually all usable frequencies actually being used, the debate is fiercer.
Wallet-size portable telephones that can make and in some cases receive calls are in production and in limited use in Britain, but cannot be used in the United States except in small test areas, for lack of frequencies. West Germany, Italy, Spain, Portugal, France, Holland, Belgium and Finland have allocated frequencies for the telephones, and their national telephone companies are negotiating or have signed contracts to buy the needed equipment, said Timothy P. Lowry, the director of mobile systems at GPT Ltd., Britain's leading producer of telecommunications equipment.
 
Handicap Seen for U.S. Industry
''For American industry, not allocating frequencies is a handicap, because they don't have a home market in which to build up sales,'' he said.
One reason for the frequency shortage in the United States has been that frequencies have long been handed out without charge in a highly subjective process involving numerous lawyers, lobbyists and elected officials. Once allocated, frequencies can be bought and sold by the license holders, and some critics of the system have said this provides the initial recipients with a windfall. But the traded frequencies may be used only for their original purpose, even if it no longer seems so pressing. The F.C.C. can issue waivers but seldom does so.
As a result, one band of frequencies may receive very heavy use while another band of slightly higher or lower frequencies may be lightly used. Recent trades of allocated frequencies have highlighted this discrepancy.
 
Disparity in Values
For example, a recent deal in New York valued a band of cellular telephone frequencies 25 megahertz wide at $4 billion, or $160 million a megahertz. But a band of adjacent radio frequencies 1.5 megahertz wide in New York recently sold for about $12 million, or $8 million a megahertz, because the F.C.C. had allocated those frequencies for use by long-range car radios like those used in taxis.
New technologies make it possible to squeeze more information onto existing channels. But because industries with large allocations of lightly used frequencies, like pipeline companies, pay nothing for frequencies, they have little incentive to invest in alternative technology.
Regulators say industries like pipeline operators that use frequencies for communications between fixed points are prime targets to lose some frequencies. ''If you're using frequencies for point-to-point communications, fiber optics and copper wire is usually more efficient,'' said Janice Obuchowski, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2454 words

HEADLINE: Hazards At the Keyboard: A special report:
Automation: Pain Replaces the Old Drudgery

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
For nine years, Paula Tydryszewski has operated a video display terminal in New Jersey's tax collection office. She types numbers and names from tax returns at woodpecker speeds into a keyboard that is tied to a big computer in the center of the room.
Ms. Tydryszewski and the 111 other full-time data entry clerks do white-collar work with blue-collar rhythms and discipline. They are tethered to their tasks by machines that let them do vastly more work than they could have done 15 or 20 years ago with paper and ledgers and typewriters.
Like Ms. Tydryszewski, an increasing number of workers around the country say they are suffering from ailments caused by the repetitive motion of their jobs. These potentially disabling ailments include cysts, inflammation of tendons, nerve damage that can lead to a loss of feeling in the fingers, and arm or shoulder pain. 
Occupational health specialists, labor unions and the Federal Government say tens of millions of workers, like the keyboard operators here, are at risk of these cumulative-trauma or repetitive-motion disorders. The Bureau of Labor Statistics said the disorders accounted for 48 percent of the 240,900 workplace illnesses in private business in 1988, up from 18 percent of 126,100 illnesses in 1981. The problem showed up first in factories and is now spreading through the growing office sector of the economy.
 
Shift in Values a Factor
Experts attribute some growth in injuries reported to more awareness of a relationship between the ailments and work. Another factor is a shift in values: in the late 20th century, safeguarding the environment and protecting one's health are probably cherished as much as keeping the economy going and keeping one's job.
Experts say the actual numbers of injuries are proliferating because people are being pressed to work hard - in private industry to keep up with foreign competition, in government to hold down spending.
Automation has done away with heavy lifting by humans and replaced it with light lifting at rat-a-tat-tat speeds.
''We're really asking people to do more,'' said Don Chaffin, director of the University of Michigan's Center for Ergonomics, which studies ways to adapt working conditions to suit workers. ''That has a cost.''
Vern Putz-Anderson, who leads a group of professors at the university who are studying the disorders, said, ''More than half the nation's workers now have jobs with the potential for cumulative-trauma disorders.''
Among the jobs are those in the automobile and textile industries, and in meatpacking, where carcasses are turned into steaks and chops by a sort of assembly line in reverse.
With better workplace and equipment design, and with more breaks for relaxing, occupational health specialists say most problems can be avoided. But many employers have been slow to acknowledge a link between work and the disorders. And some workers, including Ms. Tydryszewski, are reluctant to report injuries, out of fear that employers will let them go or shift them to lower-paying jobs.
Nor can workers' problems be easily linked to cruel bosses. ''New Jersey is fighting a budget deficit, and putting tax receipts into the bank promptly means the state can collect that much more interest before it pays its bills,'' said Barbara Jo Crea, assistant chief of the New Jersey Division of Taxation. ''The mission of this branch is to deposit the money.''
 
One Woman's Story
Scars on Arms Tell of Pain
Ms. Tydryszewski's problems are showing up in her work. Her union, Local 1033 of the Communications Workers of America, points to two two-year-old incisions on her left wrist, one across the base to remove a ganglionic cyst, a formation of syrupy fluid on sheaths surrounding the tendons; the other incision running lengthwise, from the palm about two inches up the arm, to relieve a more serious condition, carpal tunnel syndrome, a disabling tendon and nerve irritation.
The cyst, a grape-sized lump, appeared first. ''I kept pushing it back inside for two years,'' said Ms. Tydryszewski, who is 36 years old. ''One morning it wouldn't stay down, so I went to the doctor. I had surgery and did exercises. Then I dropped a milk bottle. I had no feeling in three fingers. So I had surgery for that.''
Now at the end of each day, Ms. Tydryszewski said, muscles near the back of her neck tighten into a knot, and her right arm has begun to hurt. But she said she would not complain; she is afraid of losing her $18,000-a-year job.
In early May, her supervisor sent her a memorandum. ''My records indicate that you received a written warning for excessive errors on Nov. 8, 1989,'' it said in part. ''As of today, you have not made any improvement in this area. On April 26, 1990, as documented by computer compiled statistics, you entered 189 documents with 264 errors.''
Management repeatedly advises Ms. Tydryszewski to take more time, but taking more time means falling below its requirement that she make 8,000 keystrokes an hour. Working faster, on the other hand, could mean more visits with the surgeon.
 
Workplace Changes
Computers Spread; So Do Problems
In the past, most reported cumulative trauma disorders arose in heavier work, especially in meat and poultry-packing plants and in automobile assembly. The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has won agreement from several leading meatpackers to correct conditions that contribute to the disorders, and in February it cited a 2,000-employee General Motors parts plant in Trenton for 40 cases of workers who needed surgery to correct repetitive-motion injuries.
But the disorders are now showing up widely in computer work. Supermarket checkout clerks appear to be getting them as a result of the twisting motions they make in sweeping shoppers' purchases over the little windows through which laser beams record the product and the price. And they are proliferating among millions of office workers, who also have other concerns stemming from the use of computers, including exposure to radiation.
Sixty-one percent of 645 Associated Press news employees who participated in a recent Newspaper Guild survey said they had neck and back pains, said the union's research director, David J. Eisen. And a study by the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health and the University of Michigan said 38 percent of the reporters and editors at the Long Island-based newspaper Newsday had similar complaints arising mostly from the speed and the time that reporters spend using their terminals.
The Los Angeles Times surveyed 1,200 news employees and found more than 17 percent, mostly reporters, complaining of symptoms of various types of disorders. ''Two or three have needed surgery, and six or seven have been diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome,'' said Michael G. Manfro, the newspaper's safety and environmental affairs manager. He said the company now provides better working equipment that requires less strain to operate, along with special glasses.
 
OSHA's View
Laws May Take Years to Enact
Gerald F. Scannell, the head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, said that in view of the rising injuries, the agency would soon issue voluntary guidelines for meatpacking companies to use in preventing the disorders. Later, perhaps in August, it plans to issue guidelines for all other industries, he said. The guidelines, he said, could be followed by regulations that would have the force of law, but that could take years. Until then, OSHA can go after employers over repetitive-motion injuries by charging them for unsafe working environments.
Mr. Scannell said he also supported a proposal of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, to triple, to $30,000, the amount OSHA can fine employers for each worker found to be working in violation of health and safety laws, but he said he opposed the Senator's proposal that OSHA raise the limit unilaterally every five years to keep pace with inflation.
Roger L. Stephens, OSHA's top specialist in the science of adapting the things people use to avoid pain or injury, said workers had always done awkward repetitive tasks, but infrequently enough or slowly enough that their tissues and tendons restored themselves. ''Today,'' he said, ''we see a lot of production demands.''
 
The Injuries
Modern Ailments For Modern Jobs
Repetitive-motion ailments, like writer's cramp and tennis elbow, have plagued people for ages, but their connection to the workplace is fairly new. Among the most common are ganglionic cysts; tendinitis, an inflammation of the tendons; tenosynovitis, another form of tendon-sheath inflammation; peritendinitis, an inflammation of the area around the tendons; bursitis, an inflammation of a sac of fluid over bones that allow movement of the tendons, and carpal tunnel syndrome.
Carpal tunnel syndrome seems to arouse the most concern because of the involvement of the vital median nerve. The nerve runs down the arm and through a tunnel at the wrist, about an inch in diameter, into the hand, where it services most of the palm, the base of the thumb and the other fingers except the last. Ten tendons, enveloped in sheaths and running parallel with the nerve, protect the nerve and control the fingers. A ligament forms a belt across the tendons and binds the wrist bones, adding more protection.
Doctors say frequent and awkward maneuvers of the hand and wrist irritate the tendons over months and years. This can cause the tendons to inflame, and to squeeze and rub the median nerve, ultimately damaging it.
Proper posture can help prevent carpal tunnel syndrome. This means sitting in an upright ''piano'' position at the keyboard. Ideally, one's arms are parallel to the floor and there is some support for the wrists.
Symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome are numb and tingling fingers, usually at night, and loss of feeling. Early on, it can be treated with rest, a job change, wrist splints that avert unnatural movements, and cortisone.
As symptoms worsen, the last - and usually effective - resort is cutting the ligament at the base of the wrist. As Dr. Putz-Anderson wrote in a book, ''Cumulative Trauma Disorders,'' after recovery ''it is important that the worker is not returned to the same job or task that precipitated'' a disorder.
Even so, some of the victims of the disorders who work for the State of New Jersey return to their old jobs after they are cured.
 
At the Keyboard
The Worker's Body Does the Adjusting
Trenton's tax collection office, similar to other data entry centers in the state Government, uses two large rooms, one for smokers and one for non-smokers. The clerks sit at tables, each about a yard wide, with white formica tops. Chairs can be adjusted, but only for height and to rock. Some people bring in pillows.
On the tables in the data processing offices are 16-year-old terminals, about half the size of conventional desk-top computers. Neither the keyboards nor the screens can be tilted, turned, raised or lowered. Because they cannot adjust the equipment, the clerks adjust their bodies.
During the peak of the tax season, from February until June, the office hires about 200 temporary clerks at $7.53 an hour. In the most intensive six weeks, the temporary clerks get an incentive: 10 cents an hour more for every 500 keystrokes an hour above 8,000.
In a tacit acknowledgement of a connection between the injuries and computer work, the New Jersey Department of Health has issued guidelines for the safer use of video display terminals. Among other things, they urge installation of more adjustable chairs, work tables and computers.
Ms. Crea said she and the Division of Taxation supported such changes. But in view of budget problems, she said, new equipment ''is not in the cards.''
Some state clerks like the work. Robin Sabol, 32 years old, who works in a Labor Department data-entry office, said that her required keystroke rate was 10,000 an hour but that her actual rate was 18,000 to 21,000. ''I like to push myself,'' she said. ''Ten thousand is boring and monotonous.'' As for aches and pains, she said: ''Sometimes it gets to you. But if you like the job, you're going to do your best.''
But complaint and discomfort seem more the norm. In a survey of 118 clerks at the tax office completed two weeks ago by Local 1033, 81 percent said they had had hand or wrist pain, 47 percent experienced numbness or tingling in their fingers, and 82 percent had had arm or shoulder pain. In addition, 15 percent said a doctor had found them to have tendinitis, 8 percent said they had cysts on the hands or wrists and 7 percent - eight workers - had carpal tunnel syndrome.
Terri Croushore, who is 35 and sits near Ms. Tydryszewski, has not had maladies as acute as her colleague's in her four years on the job. But Ms. Croushore, who does 14,000 keystrokes an hour when the work is heavy, says she is beginning to get a burning sensation in her elbows, a tingling in her wrists and numbing in her fingers. She doesn't complain. ''They would just tell me to slow down,'' she said.
 
The Claims Ahead
Flood Predicted For the Future
New Jersey officials say they accommodate injury cases when employees can bring persuasive evidence from doctors that an injury is job-related. The worker receives full pay and benefits without losing any of the 10-day-per-year sick leave. Ms. Tydryszewski, who was out for six months in 1988, said she had never heard of the policy, but even if she had she might have had a tough time proving her case.
Ms. Crea said she had had only two requests for sick-leave benefits related to cumulative trauma disorders, one involving carpal tunnel syndrome and the other tendinitis. The requests were denied, she said, because they were deemed ''pre-existing conditions.''
New Jersey officials, like many employers, say they have to be tough about granting benefits to people who allege work-related disorders, partly because of budgetary constraints, partly because the ailments are often hard to trace to any single cause.
For those reasons, and others like fear of demotion, disability claims for treatment of the disorders are low. Stover H. Snook, ergonomics director at the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company in Boston, said repetitive-motion injuries accounted for 1 percent of his company's claims and 1.5 percent of the cost of the claims.
''But it's a major health problem,'' he said. ''In the past, workers would tolerate it just so they could get work. Now they're less tolerant of pain and discomfort. Any employer that has large numbers of employees doing these tasks has got to worry about the floodgates.''

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
The Danes Prize American Jazz. Why Don't the Americans?

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:
A month ago, the gifted American tenor saxophonist and composer David Murray won a $30,000 prize. And along with the money, he won the chance to perform concerts in France and Denmark and spend a week rehearsing with a Danish group - Pierre Dorge's New Jungle Orchestra - and other Danish musicians for the performances. He also won the financial backing to release an album.
The prize package, put together by the Danish Jazz Center and called the Jazzpar, was instituted, according to a press release, ''with the firm intention of promoting greater recognition of jazz in society'' and with the ambitious hope of having an effect similar to that of the Nobel Prize. In its scope, it surpasses anything available to jazz musicians in the United States. 
Yet, in only its second year (the first winner was also American, the pianist Muhal Richard Abrams), the prize remains virtually unknown both here and in Europe. The Jazzpar committee includes critics from East Germany, France, the United States and Denmark. The guidelines for winning are vague, but the award is meant to go to someone who can benefit from the recognition, and is in a fertile part of his or her career. It is the sort of thing that makes the jazz community here envious and deeply resentful and lets it succumb to the common argument that Europeans take care of American art better than Americans do.
Jazz does get institutional support in this country, but not much. The Thelonius Monk Center for Jazz Studies in Washington has recently begun awarding a $10,000 piano prize annually and plans to start a Louis Armstrong Prize for trumpeters. The National Endowment for the Arts distributes several Jazz Masters Awards a year worth $20,000 each. And though the Endowment spends roughly one-eighth of its yearly $16 million music budget on jazz, jazz in the United States is still mostly dependent on the marketplace for its daily bread.
This is good in that it makes artists accountable to a public, but the marketplace rarely gives the sort of cultural encouragement implied by the Jazzpar, and it virtually guarantees that expensive large-scale works won't be produced. There isn't a chance Mr. Murray could work with Mr. Dorge's orchestra in the United States (and forget about the rehearsal time provided by the Jazzpar); though one of America's finest musicians, Mr. Murray can barely find work for any group larger than a quartet.
What the Jazzpar does is remind the jazz community, blunted in its cultural and political aspirations by years of neglect (no jazz composer or instrumentalist has ever been awarded a Pulitzer Prize for music, for instance), that jazz in the United States can be treated as an equal to European classical music. Though jazz sells roughly as many records as classical music does, there is nothing in the jazz world that can remotely compare to the larger prizes and the support systems devoted to classical music.
A quick look at the classical award system in this country shows the ex-tent to which the jazz community has lagged behind in this sort of financing and cultural affirmation. Take the Van Cliburn, the Naumburg and the Grawemeyer awards, three of the more famous classical prizes given in America.
The Van Cliburn awards a young pianist $15,000, along with two years worth of engagements, estimated to be the equivalent of $200,000. The competition is covered by roughly 80 news organizations, and it is the type of cultural event that has documentaries made about it. For instrumentalists, the Naumburg Foundation awards $5,000 and underwrites two Alice Tully Hall appearances, a record and residencies and orchestral appearances across the country. And the heavyweight of the classical-music prizes is the H. Charles Grawemeyer Award for composition, which enriches the recipient by $150,000.
More important, the awards generate interest outside the classical world and often make careers. They're magnets for attention, and they allow younger musicians to break into the competitive classical circuit. They create news stories and visibility for classical music in a world that would mostly prefer to listen to pop. The awards regularly encourage the pursuit of a form of expression that is often marginal, both sociallyand economically.
The similarities between the Jazzpar and these awards raise an obvious question. Why aren't there more organizations analogous to the Van Cliburn, Naumburg and Grawemeyer Foundations to offer support for jazz?
The Jazzpar should remind the jazz community and the philanthropic world that this sort of substantial award is possible. Jazz is healthier and more vital than at any time during the last 30 years. This itself implies a type of activism: many gifted individuals have decided not to become pop musicians or lawyers, doctors or businesspeople and instead are pursuing a path as difficult and usually less financially rewarding.
The determination that allowed jazz musicians to choose the tough path - becoming an artist in a country that doesn't pay much attention - should now be channeled into a new jazz activism. Why leave it to Denmark to bestow prizes on American musicians? It's time to question why so little mainstream music financing goes to jazz, and why the Pulitzer committee has never awarded a prize to a jazz composer. It's time for the jazz community to demand equal billing.

HEADLINE: Kubelik in Prague - and in the Catalogue

BYLINE: By RICHARD FREED; Richard Freed is a contributing editor of Stereo Review magazine.

 BODY:
After an absence of 42 years, Rafael Kubelik returned to Czechoslovakia several weeks ago to conduct the CzechPhilharmonic Orchestra in the two performances of Bedrich Smetana's symphonic cycle ''Ma Vlast'' (''My Country'') that opened this year's Prague Spring Festival.
That grand patriotic cycle of six related tone poems (among which No. 2 is the famous ''Moldau''), the traditional opening work for the ''Prague Spring,'' is music whose character makes it uniquely suitable for occasions of national jubilation or rededication. It fell to Mr. Kubelik to preside over two such events 45 years apart.
When Prague was liberated at the end of World War II, the first concert given there was a performance of ''Ma Vlast'' he conducted in Wenceslas Square, with all the city's orchestras combined. The square itself became a symbol to the world last fall, and Mr. Kubelik's appearance this year seemed to set the seal on all that had happened in his homeland since then. It also served to call attention to some of his marvelous recordings that have recently been reissued on compact disks. 
Mr. Kubelik, who will be 76 years old on Friday and now is a Swiss citizen, left his homeland in Czechoslovakia at the time of the Communist takeover in 1948 and vowed not to return until that situation changed; by the time it did change last year, he had given up conducting.
Four years ago he was compelled to retire because of exhaustion and acute arthritis. Several months ago, however, he accepted an invitation from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, whose music director he was from 1950 to 1953, to conduct one brief work next season in a concert celebrating that orchestra's centenary, and he began a regimen of exercises to prepare himself. Mr. Kubelik's wife, the Australian soprano Elsie Morison, made her first visit to Czechoslovakia when he returned. Two weeks after his own concerts, his old friend and countryman Rudolf Firkusny, a resident of New York for near 50 years, performed as soloist in the Second Piano Concerto of Bohuslav Martinu, a work the pianist introduced in 1935. Mr. Firkusny's last performance in Prague had been in 1946, when he and Mr. Kubelik collaborated in the Dvorak Piano Concerto in the first ''Prague Spring'' festival.
Mr. Kubelik conducted ''Ma Vlast'' in several countries after his departure from Czechoslovakia, and recorded it four times, with orchestras in Chicago, Vienna, Boston and Munich. Entirely by coincidence, the last two of those recordings were reissued on compact disk at about the time he was heading back to Prague, as were his similarly authoritative ones of another big Czechoslovak celebratory work, Janacek's Glagolitic Mass, and all the symphonies of Gustav Mahler. There are about a dozen recordings of the complete ''Ma Vlast'' on CD. Mr. Kubelik's 1971 version with the Boston Symphony Orchestra has been transferred to disk in Deutsche Grammophon's midprice Galleria series (429 183-2), and Orfeo's live recording of his 1984 concert performance with the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, formerly on two CD's, has been reissued on a single full-price disk (C 115841).
It is the Boston performance that is the finest of the four this conductor has recorded, and surely the most inspiriting account of ''Ma Vlast'' on CD. Although the Orfeo is a digital recording, made with an orchestra that had been Mr. Kubelik's own for nearly two decades, it is not a match for what he achieved in Boston, and the sound quality itself is less well defined and has less impact than DG's splendid analog recording, which is noticeably more impressive than it was on LP.
On another CD in the same DG Galleria release Mr. Kubelik conducts the Bavarian Radio Orchestra in two works by Janacek, the magnificent Glagolitic Mass and the rhapsody for orchestra after Gogol's ''Taras Bulba'' (429 182-2).
The Mass, whose title alludes to the Slavonic text (or, more specifically, the alphabet in which it was written), is itself of a certain national or patriotic significance, having been produced in 1928, Janacek's last year, for the festivities marking the 10th anniversary of the Czechoslovak republic. The music itself, though, is neither narrowly patriotic nor religious in any ordinary sense; it is representative of the ''pan-Slavonic'' outlook and pantheistic character that inform so many of this composer's finest works.
There have been other fine recordings of the Glagolitic Mass - the recent digital one conducted by Sir Charles Mackerras, the stunning older one under Karel Ancerl, both on Supraphon - but Mr. Kubelik's, taped in 1964, exudes a passion and urgency that keep it fully competitive. None of his vocal soloists - Evelyn Lear, soprano; Hilde Rossel-Majdan, alto; Ernst Haefliger, tenor; Franz Crass, bass - is Czechoslovak, but all are splendid.
''Taras Bulba'' is a fairly graphic response to key episodes in Gogol's novel. This is another work Mr. Kubelik recorded more than once, and one for which his special sympathy is surpassingly evident in this performance, vividly recorded in 1970. The sound quality belies its age in both works on this disk, and the leaflet includes full text and translation for the Mass.
Between 1967 and 1971 Mr. Kubelik recorded the nine Mahler symphonies and the Adagio from No. 10, but not ''Das Lied von der Erde,'' with the Bavarian Radio Orchestra for DG. They have been reissued, with generally fine sonic results, as a set of 10 budget-priced CD's in which each of the symphonies fits on a single disk except No. 3, whose finale shares a disk with the Adagio from No. 10 (429 042-2).
As this layout may suggest, some of the tempos are brisker than those favored by many conductors today, but everything in this set rings with conviction. (Bruno Walter's Mahler was faster than today's norm, too, as interpretations closest to the source often tend to be; Mr. Kubelik heard Mahler conducted by some of the composer's direct disciples when he was a young man in Prague.) The First Symphony here receives an especially poetic reading, and the vital, unceremonialized sweep in the Second gives that work a bracing quality that wears well, while the climax of the great Adagio of No. 9 is brought off with unparalleled power and clarity.
Elsie Morison is the ingratiating soloist in No. 4. Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau is one of the soloists in No. 8, and one misses his performance of the ''Lieder eines fahrenden Gesellen'' that came with No. 5 on LP.
There would have been room for that song cycle on the disk with No. 1, to which it is related, and DG has in fact issued these two performances together on a separate CD in its ''Musikfest'' budget series (429 157-2). For those who prefer to acquire the symphonies singly, this economical disk is a strong contender, regardless of price.
In addition to all these welcome reissues, a generously filled new Orfeo CD of Haydn and Mozart symphonies, recorded digitally in Mr. Kubelik's concerts with the Bavarian Radio Orchestra between 1981 and 1985, has made its appearance. Haydn's masterly Symphony No. 99 in E flat receives a stylish, utterly winning performance, as do two Mozart symphonies: the dramatically charged No. 25 (the ''Little G minor,'' K. 183) and yet another work Mr. Kubelik had recorded more than once before, No. 38 in D major - the ''Prague'' Symphony (Orfeo C 206 891).

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Are There Really Any Billionaires?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
In an age when millionaire no longer sounds very rich, billionaire still has a certain ring to it. Last week, on Manhattan's East Side, two very different men, each of whom became the best-known ''billionaire'' of an era, could reflect on shifting fortunes.
At Sotheby's auction house, Nelson Bunker Hunt, the one-time silver king, watched as part of his and brother William Herbert's collections of antique vases and coins were auctioned off. With more than 26,000 coins to be sold, the sales will take a year. 
The sales brought better prices than expected, but that won't do the Hunts much good. The proceeds largely go to pay off creditors as part of a bankruptcy settlement.
Less than two miles away, at Trump Tower, representatives of Donald Trump were trying to persuade the banks to put up money to keep the Trump empire intact and to leave him in control of it. The deadline is Tuesday.
Bunker Hunt, a man of the 70's, believed that inflation was a sure thing, and that prices of oil and precious metals would never stop rising. His buying helped push silver past $50 an ounce, but left him in a hole when the market collapsed.
Mr. Trump, a man of the 80's, paid top dollar for prime New York real estate and plunged into Atlantic City casinos. He believed, in the words of Shad Rowe, a Dallas investor, that real estate was an ''asset-appreciation game, not a cash-flow game.'' Texas real estate investors learned what was wrong with that idea a few years ago; New Yorkers are only now getting the message.
With some justification, the Hunts and Mr. Trump can complain that everything was going well until the rules changed. For Bunker Hunt, it was the rules at the Comex, which, after he bought, made it practically impossible for others to speculate on silver. For Mr. Trump, it was a stunning attitude on the part of bankers, who belatedly embraced conservative credit standards.
In the 90's, it appears one new rule is that takeover activity is no longer likely to provide support for the market, a fact that was emphasized last week by the departure of Coniston Partners from the raiding scene. That leaves the market more vulnerable to other factors, which helped to explain why a blip up in interest rates on Monday, and a late sell-off Friday that began in the Chicago futures pits, sent the Dow Jones industrial average into tailspins. It ended the week down 78.71 points, to 2,857.18.
Mr. Trump's friends say he remains rich, that his assets are worth vastly more than he owes on them. Just now, however, it appears that there are no buyers available at those prices. With time, there may be, but then again there may not. The Hunt brothers managed to buy time for prices of their favored assets to recover, but they never did. Silver now trades for less than one-tenth of its peak quote.
How, Bunker Hunt was asked, does it feel to be an ex-billionaire? ''I think about 99 percent of the people who are referred to as billionaires aren't. I know I wasn't,'' he said. ''Even Donald Trump might say the same thing.''

HEADLINE: Business Diary: June 17-22

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Profiting From the Bailout
 
How to profit from the savings and loan bailout: First, default on a real estate project. Then, go back into business under a new name. Finally, turn around and buy the property from the Government at a fraction of its initial cost. Such are the shenanigans already afflicting Federal sales of property seized from failed savings and loans. There's more: consultants and former savings executives drawing six-figure payments to manage failed institutions; country-club expenses billed to the Government; a deposit on the sale of one building made with a suitcase of cash. Should the Government screen buyers, managers and brokers to make sure none were involved in the savings and loan collapse? Do that in Texas, some say, and almost nobody would be left to broker or buy. But with a single state accounting for more than half the 35,908 properties (book value $14.9 billion) up for sale, the bailout is likely to result in a flood of funds from the rest of the nation into Texas. 
 
Pointing Fingers in Washington
 
It was tough enough for Democrats and Republicans to observe a tacit nonaggression pact when the savings and loan bailout amounted to some piddling tens of billions. But now that it is a certified, half-trillion-dollar disaster, politicians from the President on down are hunting for someone - someone else - to blame. Democrats accuse the Administration of causing a second savings and loan crisis by bungling the bailout that Congress approved last year. ''The minute the bill was signed, there was an abdication of responsibility,'' Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, said at a recent hearing. Marlin Fitzwater, speaking for the President, responded sharply last week. He cited the roles several Democratic senators and House members played in the mess, and said, ''There are a lot of battles that can be fought on this turf, and we're ready.''
 
Accusations Against Neil Bush
 
Mr. Fitzwater's attack on the Democrats took place the same day it was revealed that Federal regulators had considered banning the President's son, Neil, from the banking business. A draft document released by the House Banking Committee said Mr. Bush had violated rules on conflicts of interest three times as a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. For lack of evidence, the Office of Thrift Supervision has instead has sought only to prohibit Mr. Bush from violating the rules again. Mr. Bush has said he did nothing wrong.
 
Bargains, but for Whom?
 
Last week brought a sobering example of the losses the Government can expect for real estate taken from failed savings institutions. The Gibraltar Savings Association invested $330 milion in the Stonebridge Ranch, a dazzling spread of golf courses, man-made ponds and million-dollar homes north of Dallas. Richard C. Strauss, son of the former Democratic Party chairman, Robert S. Strauss, was the project's manager. The Government agreed on Thursday to sell it for $61 million to Yukio Kitano, a Japanese industrialist.
 
Credit Crunch Is Relative
 
Alan Greenspan isn't keeping Fed-guessers guessing. On Thursday, the Federal Reserve Board chairman said on Capitol Hill that the economy will keep chugging along without risk of recession. And, implicitly, without easier money from the Fed. And what about those complaints of a credit crunch? Credit seems tight only when compared with the lax standards that bankers and regulators have allowed, he said.
 
No Free Ride for LTV
 
The Supreme Court ruled last week that the Government can limit its Aid to Corporations with Dependent Pensioners. Only the truly needy companies will qualify, not those in search of a handout. In the case at issue, the LTV Corporation filed for bankruptcy four years ago and turned its responsibilities over to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which paid reduced benefits. Then LTV agreed in talks with the United Steelworkers of America to make up much of the difference between the Federal payouts and its former pension plan. The agency saw that its safety net was becoming more of a trampoline. It ordered LTV to resume paying for its pension plan without Government support, and the case went to court. The ruling will keep corporations from dumping more of their pension costs on the agency, which is already in financial trouble
 
Economy Winds Down
 
The latest gross national product economy is gasping but growing. A 1.9 percent annual growth rate for the first quarter, after a 1.1 percent rise in the fourth quarter last year, continued the weakest pace of expansion since 1986. The first-quarter number was revised last week from an earlier estimate of 1.3 percent, but economists paid more attention to a lowered figure for consumption. ''It points to slower growth ahead,'' said Joseph Carson, senior economist at Chemical Bank.
 
Stocks Stumble
 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 78.71 points last week to 2,857.18. Traders blamed familiar culprits: computerized trading programs, a weakening bond market and fears of lower corporate profits.
 
COMPANIES
 
The Patent Wars
 
Between Japan and America, the patent battles can be as punishing as the trade wars. A Federal District Court judge banned Motorola Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. from selling some chips last week; a higher court soon issued a stay. Analysts say Motorola faces the greater threat. The patent squabble pits Motorola's popular 68030 chip, used in Apple Macintosh and Sun Microsystems computers, against a Hitachi chip not yet sold in this country. ''If both chips had to stop shipping, Motorola would be hurt more,'' said John M. Geraghty, an analyst at First Boston. He added that Motorola is accused of far fewer patent violations than Hitachi. The broader issue might be the balance of power in patents, he said, with Japanese companies finding it much easier to enforce patent rights in the United States than American companies do in Japan. Hitachi led all companies in American patents last year, with 1,053.
 
Ben's Advice for Mr. Trump
 
Donald J. Trump went to the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, where he presumably studied the art of leverage. He might have done better to study the teachings of the university's father, Benjamin Franklin. ''He who goes a-borrowing goes a-sorrowing,'' Franklin said. If Mr. Trump can claim that his methods rescued Central Park's Wollman Rink, Franklin even made the colonial postal system profitable. Mr. Trump has insisted he is no gambler: ''I've never gambled in my life. To me, a gambler is someone who plays slot machines. I prefer to own slot machines.'' But Franklin would have kept him from exaggerating his casinos' expected performance. ''Ah, think what you do when you run in debt; you give to another power over your liberty,'' Franklin said. ''The second vice is lying, the first is running in debt. 'Tis hard for an empty bag to stand upright.'' Even outside of work, Mr. Trump has failed to follow some of Franklin's best-known advice: ''In all your amours, you should prefer old women to young ones.''
 
In Brief
 
E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company plans to build four plants to produce refrigerants that, unlike chlorofluorocarbons, would not deplete the atmosphere's ozone layer.
 
*
 
The House Judiciary Committee voted last week to repeal most of the insurance industry's exemptions from antitrust law, the first time such a measure has gone so far. It is still more likely to become a ''cash cow'' - provoking insurance companies to raise their campaign contributions - than a law.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Bustin' the Charts
 
Rapper turned recording mogul? M. C. Hammer said last week that he was starting his own label, Bustin' Records. Mr. Hammer's first venture in the industry came three years ago, when he was an assistant to Charles Finley, owner of the Oakland Athletics baseball team. He borrowed enough from a couple players to press his own record, then sold thousands from his basement and the back of his car. A contract with Capital Records followed. Now Mr. Hammer's second album, ''Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em,'' has the top spot on Billboard's chart, and his own label has plans to release albums by 10 new groups.
 
'Junk' Casualty
 
The Coniston Partners will be among Wall Street's most feared corporate raiders no more. They plan to return the proceeds from their main, $700 million investment fund to backers. With the stock market high and the ''junk bond'' market low, Coniston has all but run out of financing and promising deals. The firm was founded on the familiar 1980's premise that forcing companies to cough up huge payoffs for noisy, impatient investors would somehow improve corporate performance. That notion at least did wonders for Coniston's performance, with 40 percent annual returns common until the firm lagged the stock market last year. The partners plan to keep their stakes in TW Services Inc. and the UAL Corporation, which after repeated raids and restructuring has gone from being the nation's largest airline to No. 2.
 
An Even Bigger Philip Morris
 
The Philip Morris Companies agreed on Friday to buy most of the operations of Jacobs Suchard A.G., the Swiss coffee and chocolate company, for $3.8 billion. The deal will vastly expand Philip Morris's presence in Europe, where its Kraft General Foods subsidiary already has revenues of more than $3 billion. Suchard's products include the familiar triangular Toblerone chocolate bars. Suchard will further Philip Morris's diversification away from tobacco.
 
A First Bout of Unemployment
 
East German unemployment is already surging. The official rate rose from 100,000 to 130,000 in the first two weeks of June. East German leaders have said they expect at least 20 percent of their nation's businesses to shut down after the two German economies become one on July 2. Economists say that more than 2 million of East Germany's 9 million workers will lose their jobs over the next year. Under its Communist rulers, the country had no unemployment - but plenty of inefficient factories spewing out second-rate goods.
 
The Real Taj
 
The ''Trumped-up Taj,'' one Indian newspaper called it. Indian publications just can't see how a wealthy American could transform a classic Mogul memorial into a mish-mash of onion domes, minarets and zillion-watt neon signs. ''It demonstrates that Hollywood does not have a monopoly on bad taste,'' said The Saturday Statesman. The original Taj was built in the 17th century by Shah Jehan as a tomb for his beloved consort, Mumtaz Mahal. Unlike Donald J. Trump, The Sunday Observer said, Shah Jehan needed no bank loans. Mr. Trump, meanwhile, continued negotiating with his bankers.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Where to Gain From the Dollar's Loss

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
While the dollar has been relatively tame this year, it has still raised the returns of some Americans who invested away from Wall Street.
And if forecasters who think the dollar will decline later this year are right, this could be a good time to invest in stock markets abroad - in Britain, West Germany and Japan - that look as though they have a chance to rally in the second half of the year. A weaker dollar later this year would give investors more for their money when stronger pounds, yen, marks or other foreign currencies are turned back into dollars.
In the first half of 1990, this exchange-rate gain - because of a weakening dollar - has accounted for most or all of the profits from several European stock markets and has mitigated the losses in others. 
A 9.5 percent rise in the Swiss franc against the dollar accounted for most of the 11.9 percent gain in dollar terms from the Swiss stock market through last week, according to the Financial Times World Indicies. The market is up only 2.2 percent this year. This is the first time in two years that Americans investing in Switzerland have received foreign-exchange gains. In 1988, a 10 percent gain in the market was turned into a 7 percent loss because of a rise in the dollar. Last year, a much smaller rise in the dollar chipped a 23.7 percent gain in the stock market down to 21.4 percent. The investor in Britain also has been helped this year by the recent weakening of the dollar against the pound. Through last week, the London market was down 2 percent for the year. But with a 7.5 percent gain against the dollar, the dollar investor has more than a 5 percent gain. In Spain, a 4 percent fall in the market is cut to 1 percent when the stronger peseta is turned into dollars.
In the case of Japan, the reverse has occurred. A stronger dollar has made the sharp losses in Tokyo even more painful because the yen now buys fewer dollars. The Tokyo market, measured by the Financial Times index, fell 21 percent through last week, but the foreign-exchange factor increased this loss to 26.5 percent in dollars.
Unfortunately, forecasters are divided on what direction the dollar will take the rest of this year. But it looks as though the variables favor a weaker dollar, although there is no expectation of a collapse.
Those who feel the United States economy is slowing while West Germany's and Japan's continue to grow expect the dollar to fall some against marks, yen and other currencies. With moderating growth in Japan and low inflation, and with stronger growth in West Germany, these economies are more attractive than a slowing United States with inflation stubbornly holding around 5 percent.
If the Federal Reserve Board decides in the next few months to lower interest rates because the economy is growing too slowly, the dollar's decline could quicken. Analysts already expect the West German Bundesbank to raise interest rates later this year to curb any inflationary spurt from the economic union of the two Germanys. This would make the mark more attractive to investors.
The dollar, which now commands 1.6745 marks, could drop to 1.50. Now worth 154.85 yen, it could fall into the 140's by some estimates. The pound, although it is at $1.7335 and its high for the year, could move even higher if the euphoria over a British move to join the European Monetary System continues.
This view of a weakening dollar gives investors a fairly attractive opportunity. Some analysts now expect the Tokyo stock market, as measured by the Nikkei 225 Index, to rally to between 35,000 and 40,000 by the end of the year, a remarkable rebound from the 30 percent decline in the first months of this year. At 40,000, the Nikkei would be at an all-time high.
The market in Germany, which has fallen about 10 percent since reaching a record high at the end of March, does have the potential to recoup or even move higher if the jitters about monetary union subside after the two German economies are unified in July. This major European market has offered the smallest boost from foreign-exchange rates so far this year.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Soliciting the Foreign Perspective

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
A couple of weeks ago, Tenneco Inc.'s directors flew to Europe. First they held their regular board meeting. Then they held a meeting of an entirely different sort: They brainstormed about economics, about markets, about products, about all kinds of things with the chief executive of Switzerland's F. Hoffman-La Roche & Company, the chairman of West Germany's Ruhrgas AG, and a half-dozen other distinguished European businessmen who sit on Tenneco's European Advisory Council.
''It was time for the board to get a global perspective on evolving events in Europe from people who know what's going on,'' said Thomas J. Slocum, Tenneco's executive director of corporate communications. 
More and more American companies are turning to councils of foreign dignitaries to insure that directors and corporate executives alike are not taking a parochial view of other cultures and economies. At least 300 companies list such councils in annual reports. Experts say that probably four times that many have them, and that, with Eastern Europe in turmoil and with a united European Community scheduled for 1992, more are being formed each day.
''What better way to figure out what is going to happen in Europe than to bat ideas around with people who are there?'' asked Robert K. Mueller, author of ''The Director's and Officer's Guide to Advisory Boards.''
Executives are no more willing to divulge what their international advisors tell them than they are to repeat directors' conversations, so examples of the councils' worth are hard to come by. But they definitely bring to the table perspectives that directors, staff expatriates or foreign nationals on payroll cannot - or will not - provide.
''There is no question that our advisory council has helped us develop a strong commercial presence in Europe,'' said Donald R. Beall, chief executive of Rockwell International, who last month flew to Europe to meet with such eminent advisors as Umberto Agnelli, Fiat's vice chairman; Jacques Mayoux, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs Europe, and Emile van Lennep, Minister of State of the Netherlands, before taking a swing through Eastern Europe.
Mr. Beall won't repeat the advice these men gave him. But he clearly likes advisory councils: He is considering one in Asia.
If he sets that one up, he will join a growing club of executives who believe that if one council is good, more must be better.
The General Motors Corporation is finding its European Advisory Council ''especially helpful as we prepare for the 90's,'' said Jack F. Smith Jr., executive vice president of international operations, and the company has set up another council in Australia.
The International Business Machines Corporation's business regions in Europe, Asia and Latin America each has its own local ''world trade'' board, including such notables as Umberto Nordio, the retired chairman of Alitalia in Europe; David K. P. Li, chief executive of the Bank of East Asia in Hong Kong, and Gustavo J. Vollmer, chairman of Banco Mercantil in Caracas.
''Our business unit heads call on their boards to help develop strategic plans,'' said J. Mac Jeffery, an I.B.M. spokesman.
Advisory councils have many advantages over boards of directors. Among them:
* They are not decision-making bodies, so their members need not worry about liability exposure, and are less likely to temper their comments out of fear.
* They do not have to review budgets, worry about succesion planning or handle other fiduciary duties, so they can devote full time to the sort of macro-international issues that can have enormous impact on a company's future as a global competitor, but that rarely make it onto board meeting agendas.
* They rarely meet more than a couple of times a year, and they generally meet overseas. This means that they can attract high-level people who want the exposure to American companies and culture - and, of course, the honorariums they get on a council - but would be loath to make the time and travel commitment that serving on a regular board can entail.
* These high-level people often provide companies with invaluable contacts when they are looking for joint-venture partners or for better distribution networks.
''The councils' role is clearly complimentary to that of management and directors,'' said William C. Turner, a former United States Ambassador to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, who has helped about a dozen companies create advisory councils. ''In that sense, they begin where the board leaves off.''
 
DISBANDING THE COUNCILS
Not all advisory councils are permanent bodies. Sometimes, a company forms them as a stopgap measure - until it has enough international expertise in house, say, or until it gets a joint venture off the ground.
There are other reasons why companies might abandon councils:
* More international executives join the regular board. That's why Hercules Inc. disbanded its advisory council two years ago.
* An acquisition or merger makes the council redundant. Berol Inc.'s council was dissolved when the company was acquired by Sweden's Nobel Industries.
* A change in corporate strategy. Campbell Soup Inc. formed an advisory council in 1982 to help its international division spot possible acquisitions in Europe. Last month, Campbell did away with the group. ''Since we are no longer looking for acquisitions, it had no purpose,'' said a Campbell spokesman.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
STAID MUNIS LEARN THE P-BOP

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
For the most part, municipal bond investors are an ultraconservative breed. They look not for appreciation but for income, and managers of muni bond funds crank it out, quietly but steadily, year in and year out. Innovation rarely rears its head.
But right now, a burst of creative energy has gripped the $200 billion municipal bond fund business. One fund has adopted a new trading strategy that has fund managers throughout this staid industry taking notes, however discreetly. 
The strategy - dubbed P-BOP for Put Bond Option Program - lets managers of municipal bond funds leverage their portfolio and fatten investors' monthly checks. Designed to take advantage of a rising market, it allows managers to sell discounted bonds in a package with put options and make a profit by investing in more bonds.
Clearly, this is a bold experiment for this section of the market, and some would say there's no room for such risk-taking in a widows-and-orphans sector. But if it succeeds, it could transform the way muni bond funds manage their money.
The technique was developed by E. Eugene Mahon, senior vice president with Greenwich Partners Inc., a Connecticut-based institutional municipal bond boutique, in a joint venture with Prudential-Bache. Mr. Mahon said he has scheduled meetings with several funds that asked for more information after seeing a prospectus outlining the strategy.
But the strategy has never been tested in mutual funds. It was used by insurance companies to lift profits from bond investments in the mid-1980's and is being used, on and off, for the same reason by money-center banks like Citibank and Chemical. Some say it doesn't quite gell with the raison d'etre of municipal bond funds - income through safety, safety and more safety.
Clearly, any strategy that forces fund managers to bet on interest rates is more volatile than a strategy that simply seeks out value in the market. At the very least, it could confuse conservative investors who shy away from risk in any form.
''It's inconsistent with what investors in a plain vanilla muni fund expect,'' said one industry expert who asked not to be identified because of his firm's policy against commenting on competitors' products.
That's balderdash, says the president of the fund acting as the industry's guinea pig. ''It's not nearly as risky as one might think,'' said Vincent J. Malanga, president of the $250 million New York Muni Fund. ''The whole concept of safety is still preserved because only a small portion of the fund's portfolio is involved and if the market goes against he grain, we can take offsetting steps.''
True to muni bond form, the fund is first testing the waters. It will commit only 5 percent of its assets ''until we can filter out any potential problems,'' Mr. Malanga said. It began using the strategy on June 13 and it is too early to assess its success, he said.
But there are potential drawbacks. Mr. Malanga said that if the market moves up, any appreciation in bonds that are sold is capped, so the fund gives up some potential for capital gains. And funds that rely on this strategy double their market risk. If the market heads down, fund managers would have to be quick on their feet, hedging at the first sign of any slump.
Here's how the strategy works. The fund sells some of itsdiscounted bondsin a package with a ''put'' option. Put options give a buyer the right, but not obligation, to resell bonds at a set price for a set period of time.
Individuals or institutional investors who buy the package collect interest on the bond while they hold it. But they hedge their risk because the put gives them the right to resell the bond to the fund at the price they paid.
So if interest rates rise, pushing down bond prices, investors would sell the bond back to the fund for what they paid. If rates fall and bond prices rise, they would keep the bond and sell it in the open market for a profit.
From the fund's point of view, it has sold discounted bonds for more than market value by including the put option. The proceeds from the sale is invested at the then-prevailing interest rate, which is more than it would get on the discounted bond that it sold. Thus the fund earns more tax-free interest than would have been possible otherwise.
Let's say a fund wants to invest $80 million. It can buy bonds selling at par and yielding 8 percent, or $6.4 million in one year. Or it can buy discounted bonds with a 6 percent coupon rate, also yielding 8 percent. Because those bonds are discounted, $80 million would buy about $103 million of discounted bonds.
Now the fund sells the discounted bonds for par and agrees to repurchase them at the same price in one year if that's what the buyer wants. The buyer collects his 6 percent interest and at the end of the year either gets his money back from the fund or sells the bond for a profit in the open market.
Let's say the fund sold the bonds at par, receiving $103 million, and bought them back for the same amount a year later. It invested the $103 million at 8 percent, ending up with $1.84 million more than it would have got from just holding the bonds.
 
A CLEAR PATH OF UNCERTAINTY
Clearly, the stock market has been in a raging bull phase since mid-January. The Lipper Growth Fund Index - a benchmark for funds similar to Standard & Poor's 500-stock index - has been logging in at record-breaking levels.
But since the middle of 1989, the more than 40 stock funds measured by the index have behaved very erratically.
The steady upward line that would support a sustained trend is missing. And that means there is doubt in the marketplace about just where the market is going.
Market experts say the reasons why the market has been heading up - at least most of the time - include institutional buying, bargain hunting and Federal Reserve policies on interest rates.
But clearly, full investor confidence is one critical factor that is missing.
They warn that growth spurts don't make a bull market. And as a result, staying somewhat skeptical could be the wisest investment strategy right now.
